reviewText: I initially set out searching amazon specifically for Bluetooth sport headphones with a mic for use jogging with my Blackberry curve 8900. My first impression was that there did not seem to be the best selection of models to choose from, I had it in my mind what I wanted but had never used any similar products. I had previously used a set of wired sport headphones and the wire was an absolute pain while jogging! Competing models seemed to be more expensive than these, ranging up around $75 and the reviews weren't all that satisfying.When I saw these Motorola S305, the form was exactly what I had in mind and the price ($33 shipped) seemed fantastic to me. I liked the fact that there were so many positive reviews as well. I purchased them from Amazon and received them with in 2-3 days with free super saver shipping; I live in Washington state...Durability: I had a little concern ordering these based on a review that stated the build quality was a bit weak; I don't find that to be the case at all; these appear to be very well designed and built.  I had also read that some other brands had issues with sweat and rain which made some concern; I am not "heavy sweater" but I defiantly do a fair share of perspiring when exercising and I have also worn these in the rain, they have not missed a beat.Battery Life: I charged these up which I think took about 2-3 hours for the first full charge. I used these for almost a week at 30-40 minutes per use on a single charge, I'd estimate that I got about 4 hours of continuous music play which I think is amazing considering the battery must be tiny because these are so light weight. They started beeping when the battery went low and I was just about to run so I put them on the charger for about 10 minutes which was enough juice to keep them going for the next 40 minutes without beeping at me (very pleased!). They seem to be smart in that they shut off if no connection is present, I like that feature.Sound quality: My main use for these is listening to music while exercising. I am a huge music enthusiast but I am not super picky about sound coloration and such. I specifically wanted an over-ear phone, not an in-ear bud, so that I could still hear my surrounding environment. Sure in-ear buds have impressive bass response but I also have found that the cords tend to pick up and transmit a lot of noise which is very annoying to me. I would imagine that a set of Bose would out-perform these but honestly, as I mentioned I am very in to music and these sound great. I don't crank them too high so I'm not sure if they would distort but for normal listening, I couldn't be happier.Bluetooth connectivity: As mentioned, I use these with my blackberry curve 8900; they were very simple to do the initial set up and the pair/ un-pair without issue every time.Control Features: When previously using my wired headphones connected to my blackberry which I had in an arm band, it was very difficult to control the music player. For example, when a song comes on that I don't like it really messes up my running rhythm and I want to fast forward but it was difficult with the blackberry in the armband. The controls on the headphones were one of the main features that attracted me and they are VERY EASY TO OPERATE; I couldn't be happier. The buttons are spaced out enough to easily control the function you intended and there is a nice audible feedback beep when you adjust the volume (different for up/down).Phone: I mainly wanted these for wireless music while jogging but the ability to answer the phone was a bonus as well. The control button on the headphone is very easy to use and supports voice dialing or last number redial. Operation is fantastic and the microphone seems to work well. I tested by speaking softly and a little less clearly than normal and the other party had no issue hearing me at all. On the other hand, the received voice signal from the other party oddly enough is not very clear; it is defiantly usable but I am surprised in the low quality of the signal.Comfort: For about the first 3 days of use, I felt a little pressure on the back of my right ear where the rigid band rests, I would say it was slightly discomforting but I dealt with it. By about the 4 time using these, my ear had gotten used to it and the discomfort had gone away. These are very light and now that the initial discomfort has gone away I almost can't even tell these are on my head.Potential concern: I haven't checked availability but I would assume at some point the foam pads will need to be replaced and I'm not sure if they are replaceable. I'm not going to discount these headphones yet based in this as I haven't checked in to it but it is a consideration.Packaging: This is the only item that I give a huge FAIL. These were in the most user un-friendly packaging I've seen in a long time. The display plastic packaging was molded close to the item and the seam seal around the edge was very strong making for a work-out just getting them out of the packaging... Come on Motorola, get with the game on this one.Summary: I am so excited about these headphones, they meet my needs and expectations at a great price. I was so pleased that I just purchased another pair for my wife.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging

reviewText: So I got these along with the Sennheiser MM100's and Motorola S9-Hd's from a store going out of business (I'll be reviewing both at a later date). My test-bed was an iPhone 3Gs.The first pair I tried was the S9-HD's. These sounded pretty good and the fit was nice.The second pair I tried were the Senns and wow. These were pretty impressive. I thought there was no way a pair of bluetooth 'phones could compete with wireds, but alas, I was wrong. While not acoustically perfect (slightly anemic bass), these sound amazing.This brings me to the S305's. These look nicer than the Senns, but that's where the overtaking positives end. The sound is quite flat with a slight tinnyness to it, and has very little bass. The bass gets a little better if you press the phones against your ear, but who wants to do that? I tried every single eq setting and none made a difference. That being said, the iPhone is noted for having a relatively flat response, but the Senns offer decent bass response. Heck, even the S9-HDs have a relatively good low end. So there's no reason this particular set doesn't. And I'm not talking bass-head low end. I'm talking enough to provide a balance fill. The second issue I take with these, is they aren't particularly comfortable and make my ears sore after just a few minutes of use.Don't get me wrong, these aren't terrible. But not something to rave about either. There are better headsets for the price. (i.e. if you don't mind in-ear, the Moto S9-HD's are a good bet).

reviewText: I liked everything about this headset.  Until I wore them to the gym and worked up a sweat.  Everything was fine until I finished my workout and tried to turn them off.  Nothing happened - held down the power button and they just kept blinking.  I let them run out of power (and dry out) and charged them again.  They worked fine for 30 minutes.  Once I worked up a sweat, they started cutting in and out and finally just made a buzzing noise and wouldn't turn off.  I let them dry out again and they worked fine for two days.  Then I went back to the gym and sure enough, once I worked up a sweat they started cutting in and out and then started buzzing.  I got so fed up that I stomped on them and threw the remains into the nearest trash can.  I wish I had sent them back for a refund, but I lost my temper.In any case, they were excellent until they stopped working properly.

reviewText: I bought this headphones in January 2012. It worked well for couple if month but then started bad times when my return window is closed. Automatically disconnected from the phone without a reason. Worked well with Skype sometimes. I need to connect the headphone then start the skype app in my iPhone and log-in. (you need to follow this order). Then it'll work for the first call I make. If I want to hang up and make another Skype call, then I have to disconnect the headset, log off from Skype and follow the above steps again. Finally, + volume controller stopped working. So I couldn't use it anymore. Too bad!

reviewText: I received these as a gift, from my Amazon wish list. I also own a set of theMotorola MOTOROKR S9 Bluetooth Stereo Headphones. I wanted these to replace the in-ear bud of the S9's which was terribly uncomfortable after listening for a couple of hours. Sound quality far exceeds the S9's but is no where near myUltimate Ears SuperFi 5 Pro Noise Isolating Earphones (Black). They both serve separate purposes though, the SuperFi's of course have excellent noise reduction capabilities, 26dB!The S305 headphones do also tend to get uncomfortable along the ridge in the over the ear support bar. It feels literally like they are cutting into your ear after a couple hours of use.The phone functions are on par with the S9's. Sound is excellent, and the microphone is decent. A bit "tinny" on the receiving end from what I've been told.The S305's pair easily with my Blackberry Storm, and also have the same micro USB charger which is where the industry is currently headed so that was a nice bonus!

reviewText: This BT headset does exactly what I wanted. It readily connects to any of my BT devices and the phone quality is good. Not as good as my Plantronics headset,but certaintly good enough for the times I am listening to music. The music sound quality is excellent. If you are expecting the quality of a $500 Sennheiseer, you have to be dreaming. But for general istening and where I am not expecting to hear Synphony Hall quality, they are great. And given the low quality of music that people listen to, the headset should be more than adequate. They are not real comfortable for listening beyond about two hours, but I don't listen to music more than that at one time.If they give out in a few months I will post another review, but for now they are 5 stars.

reviewText: I decided to buy this headset, because it has over 1000 reviews, mostly positive. However, these are my points of assessment:Comfort: I don't know what most people consider to be "comfortable", but this set does not fit for me. It feels awkward, with its ark at the rear of my head, and it does not hug my ears snugly enough. When I lean back against my high sofa seat or pillows, the beam behind my head gets in the way and pushes the set off my ears, since it is not precisely snug around the rear of my head.I also wear reading glasses, and the bow of the set gets into a room crisis/conflict with the branches of my glasses right behind and above my ears. There is room for one of those, but not for the both.I wanted to use it for two things: as my speaker system for the laptop and at the same time, to use as the blue-tooth for my iPhone-4. The sound quality for music and sound files played from my laptop is poor, compared to the Plantronics DSP 400 I have been using until now. For my iPhone, I tried to pair it 3 times. I turned it off, then on again, to be discovered. It signaled that it was paired for phone calls, but upon testing it by calling my husband's iPhone-4, I never got to hear anything in the headset. I had to turn to the phone's speaker system instead. Maybe it needs that separate adapter that they also mention (although they claim it works with the iPhone "guaranteed".For all these poor performance reasons, it goes back into the box and returned for a refund.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I last owned a pair of Bluetooth A2DP headphones a few years ago -- they were a high-end Sony unit. The sound was never quite perfect on them, but cutting the cord made it worthwhile. I purchased these on a lark, as they are quite inexpensive (compared to what I paid for the Sony's), and I wanted that convenience again. I was surprised at the quality of the sound; I really can't tell the difference between these and wired headphones. They work great with both my Windows Mobile phone and my Ubuntu 9.10 workstation. The AVCHD controls work perfectly, which is great - no more fumbling around to flip to the next song or pause, just press the button on the headphones. Glad I made the purchase!
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I own all sorts of headphones and ear buds.  My best are Etymotic ER-4 microPro ear buds, fabulous, and Grado SR80s, good.  For work I have been using Koss's Porta-Pro folding headphone and can easily recommend them for the cost.  I consider the PortaPro the best headphones for under $50.  I am most certainly NOT an audiophile as any true audiophile would scoff at the cans I use.  However, I do not like so-so audio quality either.The Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headphones were bought hoping I could use them to listen to music from various sources I have at the office.  And they fill that bill.  I also wanted a decent set of cans.  Nothing great, just good enough to keep me un-annoyed.  And they seem to do that although getting them to work cleanly with Amarok on my Fedora 16 desktop took some fiddling.  They now work and sound as good with my Linux box as with any other box or OS.The S305s work with my Droid Bionic (Android 2.3.4), my Samsung RF511 (Windows7), my Dell 6410(WindowsXP.Pro), and my Dell desktop (Fedora16).  It syncs and holds sync well with all of them.  The cans are a little dull and bassy sounding.  Not horribly so, well OK horribly so when compared to my ER-4's; but otherwise OK compared to my Koss Porta-Pros.  Their quality, however, is not as good as the Porta-Pros.  For that sort of quality in Bluetooth headphones I suspect one will have to spend $100 or more.Sounds like I might not like them.  That's the wrong idea.  They are OK for the price.  I have walked 60+ feet away from my desk in a cubicle office environment with a high concentration of electronics and they still work.  They connect to Asus BT21 Bluetooth dongles or my Bionic.  60 feet isn't shabby at all.They are generally comfortable.  If you wear glasses with thick ear pieces and don't have a fat-head (like I do) you will get along with the S305s.  Fortunately I have thin ear pieces with my glasses and can adjust the phones to be comfortable enough.My only wish is that I had experience with other Bluetooth headphones so I could judge these better.  I don't think you'll hate these headphones; but, I think you'll want to move up as soon as you can afford to.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: For under $35, I was very impressed. This headset easily connects to my iPhone and my computer for wireless music and telephone calls. I was hesitant to buy a headset that didn't have a separate extended microphone piece but nobody has ever even asked me if I'm on a headset or not because they can hear me just fine. Having the ability to turn the speakers up so loud during phone calls is priceless, too. I mostly bought these so that I could talk hands free in the car and have a stereo headphone set for other times. This accomplishes both beautifully and people can hear me just fine.Also, I have an older 2G iPhone. By default the, headset works fine with this phone as a phone only, not as a stereo headset. I was able to download the A2DP app (Google it) and could then listen to my music from my older iPhone. It works beautifully. If you find yourself needing to do this, keep in mind two things: 1) The iPhone must be jailbroken to get this app. If you have a 3G or later, you don't need it - these will work perfectly with no modifications. 2) You have to start your music on the phone then press the play button on the headset in order for it to recognize it as a music player.The battery life is great on these headphones - it seems to last as long as I want. I did run out of battery once but it was one of the first times using it when the battery hadn't ever been fully charged.My only dislike on this is that after a while the headset can get uncomfortable and it's not a perfect combination with sunglasses because it uses the top of your ears to hold the weight, as do the sunglasses. Not a big deal and certainly no deal breaker.All in all, I really enjoy this headphone/headset combo.Buy them. You'll be happy you did.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I was looking for the the most convenient earphones to use while watching videocasts on my Macbook while doing housechores.  I have several sets of earphones but they are either bulky or requires to hook up a power adapter and audio cables.My current favorite before this purchase is an IR line of sight Sony.  It uses one "AA" battery which lasts for a very long time.  Another bonus is that the transmitter that you plug to the audio source also works as battery charger.  I also have a 900 Mhz Senheiser.  A lot of reviewers seem to like this but I found it too heavy and bulky.  The interference is too much for me that I hardly use it anymore.Anyway, I mentioned an IR, a 900 Mhz, but this time it is a bluetooth headphone.  They all work in differently.  The bluetooth will only work if you have a bluetooth device.  For my purpose, this is excellent as you don't have any power adapter and audio cables to attach.  The 30-35 ft in the spec is accurate.  I did wander beyond 50 ft but the connection starts to fail at that point.  And when I turned across the corner, the music signal finally stopped.It has the power button, forward, volume control (- and +) located on the right ear.I also tried it on my iPhone and it works fine.  The music will stop when you get a call and just a push of a button to accept.  After hanging-up, your music continues where you left off.It also works great with my iPhone while exercising on the elliptical machine.  Now I don't have to strap my player and worry about hacking the earphone cord with a wayward motion of my arms.Cons:- I really like to have an option of a replaceable battery.  If this goes dead in the middle of whatever I am listening to, there is no choice but to plug it via USB and wait a few hours before I can use it again.  A  triple "A" battery would be nice.- It is hard to tell if it is on because the LED light  is hardly visible.  But I think is what you want if you want to use it as a phone accessory instead of just a music and podcast listening device..There is another Motorola Bluetooth set of earphones that is even smaller yet a bit more expensive, the S9-HD.

reviewText: Overall the Motorola S305 is a very good B/T Stereo Headset. I have had it for almost a year now. It paired very easily with Windows Mobile and Android Phones (Samsung, Motorola, HTC); as well as my B/T equipped laptop (HP).Wearibility-wise, although it caused the some annoying discomfort in back of my right ear, it rested well over the ears. Perhaps a softer (rubberized?) padding around the plastic band would have helped.The audio/call control buttons are placed intuitively. I found the B/T range to be excellent. A very nice feature is that with my phone set to mute, I could receive the various audible notifications (email, text message, incoming phone call) on the headset.The sound quality is very good although not as good as in high-frequency range an "in-ear" set might provide but this IMHO is a trade-off (as most in-ear sets don't have very good low-frequency reproduction). The volume range is excellent which compensated very well for the muted highs.I have worn this headset while working-out and had no issues. Over time, as sweat accumulated on the foam covers it lost its softness. I finally figured out that removing and replacing the foam pieces after cleaning them was a cinch.I highly recommend this B/T Stereo Headset from Motorola.

reviewText: These are simply the best bluetooth headphones I have ever had.Build Quality: Motorola has spent some years mastering these bluetooth stereo headphones and this set is proof in that development process. The headset is much lighter than they appear and can easily fit a wide array of heads. The comparitive in-the-ear model made by Motorola can be quite uncomfortable for those with a large head. I wear a 7-3/4 hat size and this pair is perfect.Sound Quality: This is a mixed review for sound. The sound quality is quite good and has excellent range. I most often use these headphones for watching movies and TV shows on my tablet and laptop and in these instances, I would rate them a 9/10. For music, they are closer to a 7.5 as they are not perfect in this area.Call Quality: Considering these are made by Motorola, it should not come as a surprise that these headphones have excellent call quality.Battery life: These headphones seem to last forever on a single charge. I have not directly measured the number of hours, but I use them frequently and seem to charge them once or twice a week max.Overall: This is actually my second pair of these headphones and I didn't really realize how much I used them until my pair was lost. I like to pair them with my tablet or laptop and then fire up a movie or catch up on some TV shows while working around the house. Being able to plant my tablet on the table and freely move about without cables is what makes these so special. You can also do the same connected to your phone.I simply love these headphones and with this price, it is an empeccable buy.

reviewText: I bought this brand new for about $30. At this price it is a bargain. The sound quality is amazing. Treble is crisp and clear and bass is alright. It also has a built in mic. You can use this for skype, games, music, etc. This mic is decent in terms of audio fidelity. The battery life is amazing. It lasts me hours 3 to 4 hours of gaming which is what I use it mostly for. I'd like to also note that you can charge this head set while using it. So if you don't have a pair of wired headphones, you can just connect the Motorola via Bluetooth and charge it at the same time. Charging to full battery is pretty fast. The led will be orange when it is being charged. It will switch to green when it is fully charged.The headphones are great for workout and fits comfortably on my head. However, prolong use of this headset will hurt your hears. I would say after 2 hours of use, you should take it off before your ears get sore.

reviewText: I purchased the Motorola S305 mainly for my iPod Touch. I disliked wired systems because I found the tangling of the wires annoying. The freedom of Bluetooth makes my iPod more enjoyable to use with my music and other apps. I also purchased a Bluetooth dongle (Medialink - USB Bluetooth Adapter) for my netbook with the intention of using the headset.Each transmitting Bluetooth device needs to be paired correctly with the headset. Pairing was straightforward with both my iPod Touch and my netbook. Once paired, the headset worked well with both devices.Note that the Motorola S305 is a headset (as opposed to just headphones) as it includes a microphone. It works very well with Google Voice, Voice Memo, and Skype on my iPod. The sound is excellent and the microphone produces very clear sound.I've never used a behind-the-neck headset before and only had over-the-head headsets. It took a while getting used to but once I did, I found them just fine. They are not adjustable for size but they me fit well and the pressure on the ears is not too great. I find however, that after about a half-hour, I need to take them off.They have built-in ear cushions and I'm not sure how they will wear over time. They also seem a bit fragile and I'm not sure how they will hold up. The manufacturer says that if the frames become bent they can be straightened out by carefully bending them. A feature that would have been nice is if they folded flat so that they could be stored in my netbook case.All in all I found it to be a very good headset.

reviewText: I used these for about a month of running, during which I ran about 50 miles.  The sweat and light mist from that month (never did I run in the rain) caused these to go out.  Don't buy these with the expectation they are even somewhat rugged.  I don't know what else somebody would use them for if not exercising...
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I love how lightweight these are, and how easily they paired with my phone.  I use them several times a week at the gym, and also at my office (it gets loud in CubeLand).  Battery life is great - even when that I use them at the gym and then almost a full day at the office, I can usually get away with a day and a half (or so) between charges!  Recharge is quick too, usually I can go from completely dead to completely recharged in about an hour.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I'll address the reason this is only 4 stars right now- sound quality on phone calls. Sound quality to the headsets is fantastic- I love to hear conversations with both ears. However, Call quality to the caller, not so good; I've heard from many people that I cannot be understood on the call. Obviously, this is a microphone or software deficiency and something that Motorola should address.To the positive- everything else on these headphones works, as it should. Ilove that they pair easily, sound quality is great, and it's easy to switch from one device to another. I've tried a couple other headsets and come back to these.The predecessors to the 305's were the HT820- much larger, and I used them for 3 years before upgrading. I bought my original 305's from an e-tailer and the audio on one side went out within a month of purchase. I contacted Motorola who replaced them (with my return shipment) promptly. Since then,it's bliss.I charge 2x per day, about 15 minutes a piece (not charging after about 6 hours of use leads to a dead battery on my commute home- I literally wear these about 11 hours a day, 5 days a week).As long as you're buying new, you'll have these headphones for a good, long time.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I bought these primarily to listen to music on my iPhone while cycling. While the sound quality doesn't compare to myGrado iGrado Headphones, for bluetooth headphones at this price, it's good enough for casual listening and has exceeded my expectations.  The range is pretty poor and I've had a few instances of brief stuttering with my iPhone 4 in my jeans pocket (in its case); however, those intermittent issues are an acceptable trade-off for wireless convenience when working around the house or yard.  With the latest version of the iOS, all the playback controls  (play\pause, skip fwd & rev) on the headphones work. Call quality is very good and people have no idea I'm on a headset.Overall, these are fantastic for cycling as there are no wires to get in the way, at a reasonable volume the headphones allow in enough outside noise to hear traffic, and, with the phone in a jersey pocket or bike mount, the phones are close enough not to have any issues with range. On the bike, you will get a bit of wind noise. The neck band sits comfortably below a helmet so they are comfortable on long rides. For cycling these headphones are a great in combination withRAM Mounting Systems RAP-274-1-AP6U EZ ON/OFF Handlebar Mount for Apple iPhone 3G & 3GS. Battery life is good - my iPhone seems to run down faster when using bluetooth and GPS; good for at least 3-4 hours just listening to music.Pros- sound quality better than expected (decent, not great)- good call quality for phone- completely compatible with iPhone 4 and latest iOS- reasonably comfortableCons:- build quality- not particularly loud- very limited range (10' open air, 3' in a pocket)Ratings (1-5):Sound quality music: 3Sound quality calls: 4Build quality: 3ease of use: 5comfort: 4Value: 5
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: They easily connect to devices (have them connected to my macbook, ipad and galaxy note phone)I give them an 8 out of 10 on the sound scale (could use a little more bass). But they still sound better than any earbuds i've owned.Extremly durable - I've had them over a year, toss them in my gym bag, ran marathons with them, and do yard work with them...these things have taken a beating & still work as good as day 1.They fully charge within 45min...and that charge will last a good solid 6hrs of playback time. I maybe charge them twice a week maybe.can make phone calls with them, can control your music through your phone with them. Very convienent for runners.The one con in my opinion is they feel a little on the cheap side. But that only took like 2 or so weeks for me to get used to.overall - this is a solid purchase.

reviewText: I'm impressed with the sound quality of this Bluetooth headset, mostly because it's Bluetooth. I haven't had great experiences regarding sound quality on Bluetooth devices. This one is different. The sound embodies crisp highs and full lows. Some headsets are mid-range only, but I'm happy to report these rein in the full scope of sound.They seem to have one small drawback: the volume. It's too low. At their loudest, they're just below where I usually listen to music. Not good for lawn mowing or anyplace where there is ambient noise. I hear conversations from the patio next door when I have them on at full blast. One weird little quirk about that: I like them for bike riding. With my Bose ear buds, they're very loud and I can't hear car traffic, but with the Motorola S305 on, I can hear the music pretty well while also detecting oncoming cars.Battery life is good, functionality is good, sound quality is good less the volume issue. It's very lightweight and flexible. Easy to use and quick to charge. I don't have any real issues with this unit except the volume. I would still recommend them for use with theApple iPod touch 32 GB (4th Generation) NEWEST MODEL.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I purchased the Motorola S305 in January 2013.  In November 2014 the battery no longer holds any charge.  I don't think I ever got "6 hours" of use out of it.  The most was a little over two hours.  In the past 3 months the unit was running one hour at most, and steadily declined.  It got down to 15 minutes, now no more.  Less than two years.Phone call quality is fair to poor.  Indoors in a quiet place call quality is good.  Fair means that people on the other end of the line might mention about the call quality and background noise.  Poor means people say they can't  understand the call.I'm not a great judge of sound quality, my hearing is not good, I do wear behind the ear hearing aids at times.  One thing I like is that this headset does fit with the hearing aids on or off.  And I also wear glasses.  The unit fits with or without any combination of glasses, hearing aids.  Music, speech and other audio sound very good with or without the hearing aids -- the unit sounds much better that sound from the various Thinkpad and Mac laptops I use.  After an hour+ with the hearing aids, glasses however my ear tips do feel a pinch.The headphones fit my big 7 5/8+ size head.  I have worn them for intense workouts in the gym and during active yard work on hot days.  A lot of sweat doesn't seem to bother them.I have had no problem syncing these with my Android phones, and with my Panasonic Bluetooth DECT 6.0+ home wireless phone base station.  I also have used these iPod Nano 6, with a bluetooth adaptor.  The Nano  was only able to drive the micro adaptor for a little over a hour though.  Functionality with the nano and the adaptor was good, pause, fwd/rev, all controllable via the headphone buttons.  Syncing with my Macbook Pro was tricky and  in the end not really reliably functional mainly due the Mac's poor Bluetooth handling of units like this headset with a mix of both Stereo-playback  and phone-headset bluetooth protocols.I like the buttons all on the right ear piece.  It took a few days of use to get the button positions down, but now I find they come easily, naturally.I have just ordered a different manufacturer's model as a replacement.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: So the purchase I'm reviewing is actually my second set. I bought my first set just about a year ago and they crapped out after about 6 months of use. I wanted to write a really angry review about it but in reality, these were like $30 and for that $30, they did a hell of a job.I mostly wear these for my pedestrian/bus/train commute to work. The audio quality is great for both calls and audio. It's definitely much better than many $20 price range headsets/earbuds but it's probably not audiophile quality either. I don't know because I'm not that hardcore into sound quality. I'm told the mic picks up quite a bit of background noise but none so bad that I can't complete my calls. I'm not sure if my phone or the headset is to blame, but you see lots of Bluetooth interference on busy streets resulting in skipping. Certainly nothing so bad I can't deal with it though.Micro USB ports and easy pairing also make this a plus. They're great for my purposes but I think my last ones crapped out due to sweat from walking during my commute so I definitely wouldn't recommend for workouts. Otherwise, these are almost certainly worth the $30.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: After reading all the good reviews on Amazon, I finally decided to buy this headphone because I have an iTouch (with the latest 3.1.2 firmware) and I wanted a wireless headphone for the freedom that it offers. I got it in a day after ordering using Amazon's prime shipping. Charged the headphone completely (until the green light came) and also paired easily with my iPod and also my laptop. But very soon into my hearing experience, I started getting pauses between listening to my iTouch. The audio lagged so many times even after a full charge that I was so disgusted and I am returning back this product. Also the ear fit is very uncomfortable and I doubt if anyone can wear this product for 30 mins or more. All in all, a very poor product that has disappointed me.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I wanted a pair of Bluetooth headphones for wearing while working around the house, on the car, in the yard, etc. I wanted to be able to pair with my phone for music and calls as well as with my computer for music and video. I settled on the S305s based on the price and other reviews. Here are my impressions so far:Pros:-Easily connects with my Galaxy Nexus and 2010 MacBook Pro and can have both connected simultaneously.-Decent sound quality (Mac owners search for Terminal command to improve bitrate.)-Reasonably small and light.-Micro USB charger.-Battery life is decent, I get between 7-8 hours on a charge.-Range seems decent but there are a lot of other variables (other device, wireless interference, walls, etc.)-I wear glasses and these do not interfere.-Works pretty well while running or cycling, not sure about sweat resistance though-Calls sound ok through the headphones, but callers reported that I sound better than usual when using the built-in mic.-Price seems reasonable for the performance.Neutral:-Volume controls don't seem all that easy to press, the other buttons are however-If you experience lag when watching video on your computer, consider using a program like VLC Player so you can control the audio delay to properly sync things up again. Not the headphones fault, but worth mentioning.Cons:-Neck loop is large for my head and just hangs in the back. This makes leaning your head against anything awkward. That's just the way some universal fit things are I suppose.-There is some "sound bleed". So if you're in a quiet environment such as a library you might disturb your neighbors with moderate to high volume.-Not really that comfortable in my opinionOverall these do the important things right and I am pleased with the performance (especially for the price). I'd recommend these to anyone who needs a decent of Bluetooth headphones without breaking the bank.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I'm using it with a Samsung Galaxy S3. The gain of the microphone when connecting earbuds, either those supplied with the phones or others, is very weak and people were constantly complaining that they had a hard time hearing me, so I was hoping a bluetooth device would work better.I've been using this one for about a month and so far I'm loving it...Pros:* Very comfortable to wear, even with sunglasses (thin temples) and a bike helmet.* Sound quality is very good. I really enjoy listening to music on the go* Holds a good charge* Charger is standard 5V thin USB, so you can use your Android phone outlet or USB adapter to charge it from either an electrical outlet or a computer (supplied adapter is outlet only)* microphone quality is pretty good, as long as I'm in fairly quiet surroundings, people report hearing me well* I can drive or ride a bike with them as the external sounds are not completely blocked* No wires! earbuds cables which constantly got tangled used to drive me crazy. No more!* Low price - great value for the moneyCons:* No charge level indicator - I need to guess. Even three leds for >80%, <20% would have been great* Takes some practice to get them connected to my phone. Bluetooth connectivity has always been a black art. The best way for me is to turn off bluetooth on the phone, and then turn it back on as I turn on the device.* Sometimes cuts in and out. I assume this is due to interferences. It rarely gets to a point where it is a real nuisance, but it does happen. For example, walking down the Chicago loop (downtown), it was cutting in and out so much that it was unusable, but in general works fine* Takes some time to get used to the controlsAgain, overall a great buy. If I'd lose it, I would buy it again without thinking twice.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: It's rare to find a product that meets your expectations; no more, no less. There are no bells and whistles. This is a bluetooth stereo headset, plain and simple. The music quality is amazing, it's SUPER easy to use, and all the buttons are in the right places. They are so intuitive that you actually don't even need to read the manual to know what each button does, it just feels natural. It's comfortable, I wear mine on average about 2 hrs a day and I often forget they are even on my head. I like wearing this to listen to podcasts and music while riding my bicycle. Often, someone will call my cell while I'm riding. I don't have to stop or get my phone out of my bag, I can just git the button and this headset will automatically stop my music and connect me with the call. Even more amazing, I can be riding at 15 mph and I can hear the caller perfectly, and she/he does not notice any windy noises. As soon as they hang up, I don't have to hit any buttons, the headset automatically start my music where it left off. I can also control my music with the headset (pause, next song, previous song, volume, etc...). The battery life is amazing. I've never had it die on me, so I'm actually not sure how long it lasts. I've used it for 2 hr long phone calls, and use it to listen to music on long runs/bike rides/while doing the dishes. I charge it about once to twice a week. It takes like 15 mins to charge too. I highly recommend this, especially if you want to use it while riding your bicycle!
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: These Bluetooth earphones are a good value for the price.  I use them with my Blackberry Storm2, primarily at the gym and in my home office.Pros:* Pair easily and reliably with my device.* Good sound quality.  They are not the same as a Bose over-the-ear wired headset - but they do cost 1/6 the price.* Construction seems fine.  I carry them around in my gym bag and in my car.* Battery life is fine.. Somewhere between 4-6 hours of use and recharges quickly.* Very lightweight.Cons:* Occasional skips, especially when the device is far away (more than about 15 feet) or in my pocket.* Design is a bit bulky, which is typical for over-the-ear styles.* Buttons are on the small side and somewhat hard to distinguish from each other.  However, I have seen much less usable button styles on other headsets.* Comfortable to wear for about 90 minutes, then the headband tends to become uncomfortable around my ears.For $35, I would purchase these again... or until someone produces a Bluetooth headset with a slimmer profile or equal or better sound quality.

reviewText: I work in a cubicle environment which can get noisy, so I often listen to music.  I was constantly forgetting I had my earbuds in and would move to the other side of my desk which would yank them out.  I also would get caught in the cord as I worked.  My husband bought me the Motorola S305 headset for my birthday and I love them!  I can move around my desk freely now.  In fact, I can go quite some distance from my desk and the sound quality is as good as when I'm sitting right next to my iPhone.  The earpieces slip over the top of the ears which I thought would be uncomfortable, but I wear them for hours with no problems.  Most of my co-workers don't even know I have them on since my hair covers them completely. My only complaint is I can't seem to find a carrying case for them.  I take the train to work and have them in my tote bag when they aren't in use.  They don't seem to be of the sturdiest constructions, so I am concerned they might get damaged without a protective case.

reviewText: These little headphones do sound very good for inexpensive phones, good strong bass and clear treble. Being free of connecting wires seems wonderful, I must admit. The fit is very comfortable for me also. I was dissapointed that with my new 3rd generation iPod Touch 64 Gb, the phones will not advance to the next song or go back to the previous song with the push controls as they are supposed to do. I later found that the issue here is that Apple does not support the S305's particular Bluetooth profile (AVRCP). Neither will my iPod recognize the phones built in microphone for voice recording as a result of this same issue. The phones themselves are great, but for anyone expecting to use them with their iPods, this is definitely a problem to consider.

reviewText: Ok first of all, if you have a crappy, tinny sound being produced from these head phones, Step #1- get a different blue tooth adapter or update the drivers.  My phone (HTC G2) and the blue tooth adapter I boughtIOGEAR USB 2.1 Bluetooth Micro Adapter GBU421work AWESOME.  However the blue tooth adapter that's incorporated into my work laptop (IBM Thinkpad T410) absolutely sucks in terms of the sound quality I receive.The reviews that say these feel cheap - no cheaper than the $10 wired headphones.  Which lets face it, if you're spending this sort of money on a wireless set, yup, they're going to feel cheap.Range, microphone quality, fit, all very acceptable.  The set is slightly tight around my ears but I'm uncertain if its because I never wear an over the ears headset or if its the headphones.  I wear a 7.75" hat to give you an idea for sizing.100% recommend these.

reviewText: I bought this headset for use with my iPad 2 for when I want to watch a movie or play Angry Birds and don't want to disturb anyone.  I thought that I would use them when I wanted to hear music or a soundtrack to a movie when I am at home, but I never do that for a few reasons which I will cover soon.  Here is what I like about this headset:*  It syncs with my iPad 2 pretty easily and I can walk to the other side of the house and it still works.*  They are really lightweight.*  The sound is pretty decent for a lightweight, Bluetooth headset, (even the bass is acceptable.)*  The price is pretty reasonable.Here are some of the things that I am not to crazy about:*  I really don't like the way that it fits.  It is difficult to keep in the right place over my ear and I don't like the way the headband has to go behind my head.*  When I am listening to music, a movie, or even the spoken word a person sitting next to me (like on an airplane) can hear what I am hearing enough to tell what is being said.  I have to really turn it down low to keep that from happening.*  Recharging it is kind of a pain.  I really have to look close to be sure that it is charging.That being said, I seldom use these except for when I am traveling mostly because of the way it fits.

reviewText: I really like these headphones. I am about to buy my fourth pair in two years. They have decent sound quality, plenty sufficient for my primary use of listening to audiobooks and podcasts, and talking on the phone. Since I am not an audiophile, they are okay for music but I prefer to use good headphones for "real" music. They have very good call quality. They are my go-to bluetooth headphones for most activities and very handy to be able to listen to music and be able to take or make calls.The downside is that the average life of them is six months before they start flaking out and they won't turn on any more. Usually before this happens the light won't go out on them even when they are turned off and they burn through the battery quickly. Yes, I am well aware of the battery reset process, which usually stops working after three or four months.But I can't be too hard on them since I wear them for exercise and outdoor activities and I sweat a lot, so the foam cushions get soaking wet. This is probably why they don't last too long for me since this likely affects the inner electronics and/or battery which is why they have such a short life for me. And it used to make me mad that they gave up the ghost so quickly. But, once the price dropped to around $30, I started considering them disposable and a 6 month lifespan was acceptable. I certainly would not pay more than $30 for them, though.These headphones also meet two other absolute requirements I have - they sit on top of the ears and don't completely cover it up, or stick in my ear like earbuds, which would lead to even more sweating - plus I get ear infections when using either one of these. And they charge with any micro-usb cable so can be used with any of the dozen chargers I have lying around at home or work. I really ought to give them five stars for just these features alone since there are very few other headphones that meet these two criteria, but with the short life span of them, I really can't.Edit, 6 months later: Here I am looking for another pair since the ones I have are about to go. But I won't buy them this time since the price has risen to $40, granted that's the price including shipping since I have Prime. But they don't last long enough to justify that cost. So I am off to buy the Inland equivalent of these, the ProHT, since they _are_ $30 at my local Microcenter. The buttons are not as convenient and it charges with a mini instead of the preferable micro usb, but I can't bring myself to spend $40 on disposable headphones.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: CONS: These headphones HURT to wear. The reason being is there is no padding whatsoever on the part that actually rests on your ears. The best way I can describe it (which you cannot see in the picture) is imagine a long rectangular piece of plastic, now fold that in half so you now have a long u-shaped piece of plastic. Now form that piece into the curve shape you see in the picture. Now strap this around your ears with the weight of both sides (granted they are pretty lightweight) supported solely by the tops of your ears. Keep in mind, you have a two plastic edges sitting on top of each ear. After about 15 minutes of running I have to take them off. No amount of re-positioning helps. A better design would have made the headband part a solid cylinder so there are no edges, or placing a small section of padding on the part that actually rests on the ears.PROS: For the money, they sound like you would expect. I have no complaints in that department. For my 2nd Gen IPOD touch, the volume works, play/pause, but the track forward/reverse buttons do not work.All in all, I wish I would have gotten something else :(

reviewText: I was skeptical about Bluetooth headphones, and have stayed away from even trying them mostly because of the price. But the Motorola S305's cost half what other Bluetooth headphones have in the past so I decided to give them a try. Mostly I've been very impressed with these, though I do have a few problems.First, the sound quality is very good - on par with a decent set of wired headphones of similar price. I haven't found there to be any static, though occasionally (and inexplicably) the sound will cut out for a half second, which can be annoying. It doesn't happen that often though. The range on these is remarkably good - I bought these specifically for jogging, so the range would only ever have to be about 2 feet, but I've also used them at my desk and I really appreciate the freedom to get up and walk around up to 20 feet away with several walls between my phone and me. When the headphones do get out of range, they just disconnect, and then reconnect when they're in range again. The volume is also very good, and although they do not cover the ears completely, the volume can be turned up to the point where it covers most outside noise. If I were choosing headphones just for work or travel, I might choose something with greater noise isolation, but since I chose these for general use and especially exercise (where size and weight are the main consideration) these work nicely. The headphones are quite comfortable, more so than other behind-the-head earphones I've tried. Wearing them for a couple hours at a time did not cause any numbness or pain. They are also pretty secure, and jogging with them hasn't been a problem. I appreciate the fact that these charge with a micro-USB cable, which means that I can charge with my PC and a standard cable when I'm on the road. Sadly, the included charge is a hard-wired micro-usb type, unlike the ones that take a powerplug and provide standard USB-out, so if you don't want to bring the power charger with you you'll have to buy a micro-USB cable.My biggest problem with the headphones so far is the buttons. There are a total of 7 buttons; one for power (with indicator LEDs) and volume up and down all located on the rim of the headphones, and then a D-pad layout for call, play/pause, >> and << on the outside of the right earphone. The buttons located on the rim are loose and feel cheap. Worst of all, they rattle when jogging. That clickety-clack is quite loud when it is right next to my ear, and it is distracting. The other buttons all work fine, though as other reviewers have noted the >> and << buttons don't work with the iPhone/iPod Touch because of Apple's software. I've also found that I have to be a little careful in handling the headphones because it is easy to accidentally press the "call" button, which automatically triggers a call to the last person you called, and that can be somewhat embarrassing.My final annoyance is with the auto-power-off feature, which does not seem to actually work. The manual states that if the headphones are unused for 5 minutes, they will power down, but they obviously just go in to "sleep" mode and will automatically wake if there's an incoming call. This can be frustrating since the headphones might be 20 feet away in another room but when someone calls, the headphones will take over the call and I've found myself on many occasions talking into my phone while the person on the other end is talking through the headphones. This is, I'm sure, an issue that my phone is just as likely to be the cause of, but it's worth noting because it does happen a lot. Just make sure to turn the headphones off when not in use and it won't be a problem.Reading that last bit of my review one might get the idea that I'm not happy with these headphones, but that's not true; I think they're good for the price, and I would certainly recommend them to anyone who is looking for an inexpensive pair of wireless headphones for office or exercise. But those looking for the best at any price are likely to find more expensive headphones better.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I got this headset because I was tired of using a clunky wired headset that sat on top of my head and I wanted to experiment with wireless headphones.PURPOSE: I want to listen to streaming music on my computer while not disturbing others if I am in my small apartment, a coffee shop, an airport, or anywhere else.PROS:-- An acceptable sound range (nothing amazing like high-end headsets)-- Wireless-- Light to wear-- Don't blare music where others who are nearby can hear it-- Has a microphoneCONS:-- Pairing was not super easy on a computer. Kept dropping and starting up again.-- Distance range is laughable. The signal started to fade when I walked into my apartment's kitchen and completely stopped when I went into the bathroom.  Again, I am in a very small apartment. Most times, I only need it sitting at the computer but it'd be nice to have tunes playing if I walk away for a minute.-- The music skips a little with short distances (5-10 feet away).  I have a high speed internet connection so that's not the issue.  This means reception can be spotty on the balcony which is literally right next to my computer area.-- The buttons don't work with Windows Media Player or an internet browser playing Pandora (or any other music site).  These downsides aren't obvious after reading the product description because it focuses on cell phone or iPod/iPhone.  Maybe there is a way to rig it up but it would be great if these features were seamless for users (the buttons serve no purpose to me while on my computer).I am not blown away by the headset but being wireless and having a cheap price (1/2 a Logitech headset I was considering and much less than the Beats) allows me to look past the complaints.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I bought these for a plane ride about 18 months ago and used them without issue with a couple of iphones (4), an older ipad, an fairly new ipod, an imac, etc. Having no issues with them (turned them on, used all the buttons, worked OK) on the Apple stuff, I didn't think much about them for a while... Even put them aside for about a year... (Hey, I moved, changed jobs, etc.) Eventually, I came back across them and wanted to use them with a Gateway T-1628, Vista Sp2 laptop. I'd used them before on an XP machine, and they were, "OK," so I thought, "next." But, Oh, baby - what a mess! Had to add a bluetooth adapter to the laptop... Fine. Until I tried several... No way to link up with these headphones to use them as I'd been using them with the Apple stuff! Turns out Microsoft took more and more features out of their bluetooth "stack" until the S305s were limited to Skype-like stuff. Weird! Figured out I could buy some software from [...] (from $20-30), or, I could just give up on this particular idea. Yay for Appple and its support of commonsense. The headphones themselves were OK with my imac and phone. Very pleasant, actually, to just fire them up and go about my business. Sound quality, at this price, was excellent. Range was the advertised 30 feet or so - even through the walls of the house. Early buyers apparently wanted to use these to exercise. No. These things would soak up water like a sponge and they have several obvious holes in them. But, for around the house stuff - light work - these have been fine. If they worked with the PC stuff without additional grief, I'd give these a "5" at this price. But, they don't... Or, won't without too much (my opinion) effort. Kudos for the batteries, by the way. After leaving them sitting around for so long, I just charged them up again and they've been fine... I've yet to run the battery down since I've started using them again. They just keep working.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: I've been eyeing this headset for a while. Someone splurged and got them for me for Christmas. Overall, I am very pleased with the gift.Connection: Easy to connect to iPhone - my primary device. And the range is suitable. I've run all over my first floor without an issue - clear all around. I don't see myself needing much more than that.Comfort: Putting your head on a pillow or leaning back on the couch? You may want to choose another headset as you may bump the neck wrap on these and push the headset around. Wearing a hat that goes past your ears (beanie)? This can be difficult (You can put the beanie over the headset in some cases). Glasses can be a pain too, depending on what style you have. However, if you are sitting up, walking around, no hat, wearing a baseball cap, etc., then these work great and are very comfortable. Where they wrap over the ears takes some time to get used to, but that's about it. I run with these, and they stay where they are supposed to and feel great, start to finish. Lightweight and cozy. And no wires!Sound: Pleasantly surprised. Excellent quality for a bluetooth headset. Music and calls come in crisp, clear, and perfect for my needs. The mic works great as well. I have had no complaints from those I've been speaking with regarding call quality, so I'm happy.Quality: The plastic wrap has a little give to it, but I don't want to put it to the test. This is the only part of the headset I have long term concerns about.Wishful thinking: I wish these came with an adapter that was compatible with the latest iPod Nano. I'll be hunting for an adapter soon. I also wish there were controls on both ears. Maybe play on one ear and pause on the other. With gloves on, it's difficult to track down the proper button on the single ear panel. Lastly, I wish they came with a case or folded neatly to put away. I don't want to stuff them in my bag, so around the neck is about the only storage I have - unless I purchase a third party case.

reviewText: As other reviewers have written, these headphones will not hold up to sweat/liquid exposure. But then again, they aren't intended to. The purpose of the headphones is to have wireless access to your music/phone while doing leisurely activities, which they achieve almost flawlessly. They aren't meant to last through rigorous exercise routines. So if you are looking for a product fulfilling that purpose, then move on, they're not for you. The sound quality is surprisingly really good; the music comes through clear and crisp. On that topic, however, they could use improvement on interference and range, as you will notice gaps in playback if you stray too far away from your device (a microwave *as expected* causes the signal to stop working entirely). The construction does feel a bit fragile, but If handled with the care a high tech pair of headphones deserves then you'll be fine. They are extremely lightweight and feel natural when worn. The controls are conveniently placed and work great. I don't recommend buying these if you're going to primarily use them for phone calls because the caller on the other end will notice a slight distancing of your voice (I imagine due to the placement of the microphone). All in all, I'd recommend these to the casual music listener who enjoys having their hands free while listening to music from high quality, comfortable headphones.
title: Motorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset w/ Microphone (Black) - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Headsets', 'Bluetooth Headsets'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Audio & Video Accessories']]

reviewText: This little speaker set is way overpriced, but they do work quite well. I purchased the set over a year ago and am now surprised that it works with my MacBook Air, as well as my iPhone and iPad. While the sound quality is not that great, it certainly brings a significant sound boost to portable devices. The sound can get pretty loud. Just keep holding down the plus button until you hear the sound go up.  On the first couple of tries, the Bluetooth connections may not seem to work, but they do. Great portable speakers that you can throw in your bag, but the price should be like $50 at most.Update: the speaker does not support wired sound connection, only Bluethooth.
title: Motorola EQ5 Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Bluetooth Speakers'], ['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Speakerphones'], ['Electronics', 'Car & Vehicle Electronics', 'Vehicle Electronics Accessories', 'Audio & Video Accessories', 'Bluetooth Car Kits']]

reviewText: This has about the same footprint as my iPhone.  It's about a fraction of it's weight.  Build quality is excellent.  The speaker contains a rechargeable battery and there is a clear indication of when it needs to be charged and when the charging has been completed.  More on the charger and that "clear indication" in a bit.Pairing with my iPhone was immediate right out of the box.  I turned on the speaker, went to the bluetooth discover screen on my phone, it picked up the unpaired device, I entered the super-secret code number (0000), and it was done.Sound quality is good (for this type of speaker).  The sound is clear, there is very little (but at least some) bass, and it doesn't sound tinny.  I bought it for playing background music on the deck and it's certainly clear enough and there's definitely enough volume for that.The description implied and it should be clearly stated that in addition to working as a speaker this also works as a speaker phone and can also pass voice commands to the phone.  In fact it works just like the Motorola S9 headset except that forward and reverse don't seem to work with my iPhone4 (and it's much more difficult to wear as a headset).Now for the stupid decisions:There's a very bright and annoying light that insists on flashing when music is playing. According to the (well written) manual it means there's either a call or music on standby.  Near as I can tell there isn't.The AC charger is universal (at one end); it accepts 100-240V at 50/Hz.  It's the other end that I have issues with.  For some reason Motorola chose to use a micro-USB connector which is far from universal.  Even though it supplies 5VDC just like any other USB power supply if you lose theirs then you're out of luck.  (OK, I realize that this speaker was designed to accompany the Motorola E8 phone and that device used the same micro-USB connector.  Frankly, if I was reviewing that phone I would have the same complaint.)The less than universal foolishness doesn't end with the AC supply.  Since the connector is less than standard you need to get a special cable if you want to, say, not bother with a special charger and use your laptop to charge the speakers.  Guess what isn't included...Minor annoyances aside, this speaker is a good value.  You can share music from your mobile device at good volume and reasonable fidelity while keeping said mobile device on your person.  I haven't tried the wired connection and frankly if I was looking for that kind of speaker I'm sure there are plenty available that would cost less while providing the same sound quality.BTW, I feel that honest, effective reviews can take the place of first-hand experiences that are lacking in online shopping. I've always appreciated the help I've received from other reviewers and work hard to return the favor as best as I can.  I hope you found this review helpful and if there was anything you thought was lacking or unclear leave a comment and I'll do what I can to fix it.
title: Motorola EQ5 Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Bluetooth Speakers'], ['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Speakerphones'], ['Electronics', 'Car & Vehicle Electronics', 'Vehicle Electronics Accessories', 'Audio & Video Accessories', 'Bluetooth Car Kits']]

reviewText: I got this to use on the porch, and going to other places like friends and family. I run it with bb curve, the  next/previous track and pause/play work, the fast forward and rewind function does not. the volume buttons work.  the call funtion works as well.  I was going to get the EQ 7, but the thought of removing and reinserting batteries, discouraged me. This phone has the built in battery, which you plug in and charge.  On this note, the charger light next to the plug/port shows green if 70 percent charged or orange if less than 70 percent when you plug it in. My suggestion is if orange when being recharged, recharge for 2 hours. If green when being recharged, recharge for 1 hour.  When you plug in the charger cord, about 4-6 seconds the light will come on orange or green.  6 hours of playback time is what I am getting.  Pretty basic and gets the job done, at least for me.  I am not a talkin on the phone person, so my call experience with this product is minimal, but, the little time I did use it so far, it worked fine.
title: Motorola EQ5 Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Bluetooth Speakers'], ['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Speakerphones'], ['Electronics', 'Car & Vehicle Electronics', 'Vehicle Electronics Accessories', 'Audio & Video Accessories', 'Bluetooth Car Kits']]

reviewText: For a low-priced, wireless, rechargeable speaker, this mini Motorola speaker synchs up perfectly with just about any bluetooth-transmitting item.  The system is well thought out and is fully outfitted--with AC adapter, Motorola case, and mine even came with a Motorola cinch sack. Also, since Bluetooth can be temperamental, or erratic (especially with other Bluetooth-connected electronics devices in the near vicinity), a convenient audio cable is provided for a surefire connection between player and the Motorola speaker.The speaker is loud enough and should amplify the human voice sufficiently for efficient, unforced conversation.  But anyone who claims this speaker excells at musical reproduction simply has no use for bass frequencies, which for the most part are inaudible on the EQ5.  The Motorola EQ7, on the other hand, covers the entire frequency range, its four JBL speakers constructing a soundstage and providing a sense of life-like presence and vivid realism simply unequaled by any other bluetooth speaker.  Since the beginning of the year the EQ5 qppears to have more than doubled in price, making several other bluetooth speakers a better value--at least for anyone seeking full-frequencied music reproduction.  Logitech, Creative, and Spracht all make bluettoth speakers capable of rich, full-bodied, hi-fidelity music reproduction, though the Motorola EQ7 emerged a clear-cut winner in my side by side comparisons.  It's the first time I've heard a walkman-sized speaker practically equal the thunder of a "home theater" system.  If you think you could handle not a facsimile but Oscar Peterson's piano, Ray Brown's bass, and Bobby Durham's drum kit--or Joey DeFrancesco's Hammond B3--transplanted into your listening space, the EQ7 is the real "sleeper" among all portable personal speakers.
title: Motorola EQ5 Portable Wireless Bluetooth Speaker

reviewText: GREAT ITEM!I purchased a Droid X that came with one of these factory-issue Motorola chargers. I really liked it so when I went looking for a charger to power my other comparable micro-USB accessories I couldn't help but be drawn to it.I've read reviews that stated that the product is "generic" or doesn't charge correctly (which, as an avid vehicle cusomizer, I have generally determined through testing that its usually a charging system problem rather than the charger...or it's simply being plugged into a device that does not meet or exceeds the tech specs!)I anxiously awaited receipt of the charger and was pleased when I pulled it out of the packaging to find it in a Motorola retail packaging. I will also add that it is BETTER than the one that originally came with my phone! Much more even blue light output and exactly the same performance!This is NOT an imitation! This is the real deal and, generally, looks better than the one you get with your phone when you buy it!Many have said the blue light is "too bright" or "distracting"....well, it all depends on where your accessory plug is and how dark the dash lighting is in your vehicle. I have a 07 Mustang with the color-changing dash lights...they are currently set to blue and I barely notice the blue from the charger. NOW, if you're driving an 84 Buick Century with dim, green dash lights it might just be a bit distracting...but if you're that easily distracted don't buy a charger with LED lighting!

reviewText: Well, I have tried many car chargers before this one & after getting this one, I have learned off brand charger just don't cut it. reviewText: Unlike a myriad of other vehicle chargers I've tried this one not only is able to keep up your phone when you navigate with it- that means having bluetooth on, the gps on, the screen on- likely on bright and maybe you're streaming music along with the map's data. I get a good few percentage points gain, even in this high draw condition, every 10 minutes or so.Best of all, the charger does it for more than a month or so.  This thing has lasted a couple of years without the connector or the power connector falling apart- huzzah! The bits and pieces feel as though they are actually assembled rather than just placed in close proximity to one another like so many pieces of junk other vendors sell.The only downfall or fault I've found is the rather bright, blue LED lighting which fills the "M" that serves as a gripping point for the power connector.  The good news it's easy to remove from the connector the bad news is you'll likely need to carefully aim this light if you want to see at night inside your car.  It's really that bright; not sure why so many vendors feel it necessary to light everything... I mean I could understand a small led or marker in the USB connector- I mean that is always falling into the gap between the console and the seat or disappearing into some unknown area on the floor so that we are left trying to trace our way from the cigarette lighter down the cord to the usb connector- am I right? The need for a light at the power connector though, I just don't get- it's always in the same place and it's way to bright.  Fortunately, a bit of electrical tape or some modelling paint can get rid of the annoyance.If you have a big phone battery or like to actually use your navigation on your phone, this charger is for you.
title: Motorola Rapid Vehicle Power Adapter for Motorola Droid A855

reviewText: I bought this charger as a cheap extra to keep at the office rather than having to remember to bring my original DROID charger back and forth every day. For the price it's a good buy, but it does have its good and bad aspects:Good- The head of the charger (that plugs into the outlet) is the same size as the charger that comes with the DROID. I don't know what comes with the other Android phones, but it matches the size of the DROID's charger. If you keep your charger plugged in behind a nightstand or something then you won't have to worry about adjusting it if you're replacing with this one.- The cord is about six feet long, which makes it about twice as long as the cord that comes with the phone. This makes it ideal for plugging into an outlet at the floor behind your desk, since you shouldn't have to worry about the cord not being long enough.Bad- The cord is not a USB cable. It is attached to the head of the charger, so you can only use this for charging your phone, not for plugging it into your computer. This may not be an issue for you, but it is important to point out.- The cord is not thick like the original charger cord. This is a thin cord with a partition down the center, similar to many standard power cords. If you aren't abusing it you should be fine, but take note that this doesn't have the thick, round cord that the original charger did.- My charger is slow. I know some people said their phones charged faster, but it took me 2.5 - 3 hours to charge my phone from 0 the other night. With the original charger it would take about half that time for me. This doesn't matter for me since I'll be using it at my desk at work and won't need quick charges, but depending on your needs this may be a big problem and may not be.Overall the two biggest points to keep in mind for this charger are that its cord is about twice the length of the one on the charger that comes with the DROID and that it does not have USB capabilities. If you don't need it to plug into your computer, I suggest you go ahead and get it. It's very inexpensive and the longer cord makes it much more accommodating than the original charger.

reviewText: The dock is great for the Droid, I use it in my car actually.  I know there's a Droid car mount, but I drive a lot and I wanted something to mount it in without the need to plug it in every time I got in my Jeep, and vice versa when I got out.  So I use this mount and it works great.There are a few things I'd like changed with it though:-no contact list icon on the "dock home screen", so if you want to make a phone call, you have to either pull it out of the dock station, or you have to press the "exit dock screen" button, then hit your contacts button.-no wallpaper support-no color selection support (only two colors; night and day modes, which is dark red or light blue)-when a call comes in, it still asks you to slide the bar to the right to answer it, which is annoying to do while docked-also when a call comes in, if you answer the call and the phone's still docked, you'd assume it would use a bluetooth headset if attached, or automatically activate speakerphone but it doesn't - you have to slide the button across to answer then press the "speaker" button once the call connects-also when a call comes in (and with some other phone features), the display still shows in vertical mode even though its docked horizontally-this may be a smaller thing, but, since I use it in my Jeep, I don't like that the weather doesn't update once you've moved your location - I think it just updates to your location once it initially docks, but not continuously as it updates, which is weird because it constantly updates the weather forecast, but not the location? weird.-fixed angle (you can't lean the Droid closer or further away, it sits at the preset angle you see in the pics)There's probably a few more small ones, but I can't remember right now.As I said though, even after these nitpicks of mine, I still love being able to dock my Droid so it charges without having to plug it in.  Even if you don't like it, its the only Droid dock that I know of.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I love this, this Dock worked great, had it next to my bed, as an alarm clock, it was great when my son wanted to watch a video, or see the sideshow of pictures, I would recommend it
