title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I ordered the Motorola Droid Multimedia Station on the Droid's release day because I thought it was a cool idea.  I didn't see it in person until it was delivered to my door and the geek in me loves it!PROS:- Nice build quality- Non-skid base- Turns your Droid into an alarm clock and weather station- Sync your data via USB cable- Just plain cool lookingCONS:- Will not work with cases- Somewhat expensiveThe box includes 4 items, the actual dock, a micro USB cable, an AC adapter, and a user guide.  The dock itself is very well made and is quite hefty in weight.  You won't be accidentally knocking this dock around from your desk especially since it also has a non-skid base.  The dock has a micro USB port that you plug the cable into and then you plug the other end into the AC adapter.  This of course, powers and charges your Droid, which is perfect for your nightstand.  If you want to sync your Droid, just plug the micro USB cable into your PC.  This will charge your Droid too, but at a much slower rate and only when your PC is powered on.When you dock the Droid in, the orientation changes automatically to landscape.  You select what city you want your weather widget to display and boing, you have your multimedia station.  The dock has magnets located in specific areas to activate this mode, which I just found can be activated by using an app called "Dockrunner."  It is available for download in the Marketplace.It's a little pricey for what it does but it is cool nonetheless.  An audio out or built-in stereo speakers would've been cool but no biggie!
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I tend to charge my Droid every evening so this dock sitting on my night stand makes this pretty convenient. The dock works well and is attractive. In reality though, all it does is provide power to the Droid along with a vertical tilt. Cool and all but the price seems a bit steep for what is really just a cool, convenient charger.Overall I'm happy with the device but they really should have included a longer cord. I have a power source directly below my nightstand where the dock is located. It's just an average sized night stand yet and could not be closer to the power source. However, the dock has to sit a bit sideways on my night stand because at the "correct" angle, the cord won't reach. It's that short. Think about it... 3 feet. How high is your night stand? You can replace with just a longer usb cable and their AC to USB adapter that comes with it, but for that price you really shouldn't have to. Currently I consider it to be the absolute minimum length to work in optimum conditions. I'd have to guess for most people, the cord length won't work at all.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: This is the perfect accessory for power hungry Droid.  The multimedia station is a charger which turns your phone into an alarm clock and weather display. It uses magnets to determine when/if the phone is docked and automatically switches to "Multimedia Mode".  Kind of expensive, but worth it.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I originally bought the dock for the first generation Droid and I loved it, it turns your phone into a desk clock or a picture frame while charging your phone, I have mine plugged in to my computer, so every time I charge it, I have access to my files and pictures to transfer back and forth from one place to the other.Works on Droid 2!So I just upgraded to the Droid 2, and although the Droid 2 is a little longer than it's older brother, it still manages to fit in perfectly on the Multimedia Dock. The menu and features are nearly identical from the first Droid when connected to the dock.Note: I tried both, the Droid 2 and Droid 2 Global (My wife has the Global version)I highly recommend this product for both the Original Droid and the Droid 2.Note: I also tried the Car Dock for the original Droid on the Droid 2, and it does NOT work since it graba the phone from the sides and the Droid 2 is a little longer than the original.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: If you have a desire to use your Motorola Droid as a bedside alarm clock, then yes, this dock is definitely for you. Because that is pretty much all it does (except it also charges the onboard battery).The dock triggers the phone to enter "dock mode", but the dock mode can be triggered by a free program from the AppMarket called DockRunner (Droid), no dock needed.And really, the dock mode, as shown in the picture, turns your phone into a bedside alarm clock. You can set alarm, trigger "night mode" (softer contrast), and even get a preview of the weather, among a few other minor passive functions. You *could* make it also play music in the background (yes, the built-in MUSIC app has a jukebox mode), so I guess it's more of a clock-radio with alarm.If I really want a clock radio with alarm, I would buy one in my local Walgreens (or whatever) for $10, not pay $20-$30 for a fancy piece of shaped plastic with a charger tip.As many others have pointed out, the dock is designed for an UNPROTECTED NAKED PHONE. It is not compatible with cases. If you have a case slipped on, you cannot put it in the dock.While, technically if you don't want the BOTTOM half protected, then you can remove *THAT* and put the phone in the dock with the keyboard exposed, but that rather defeats the aesthetics of the dock. Doesn't it?There is ONE good thing about the dock though... The AC adapter you get with it can be used WITHOUT the dock. Yes, you can plug that tip straight to the phone, skipping the dock altogether. Since a spare AC adapter cost the same as the dock on the Verizon website, you may as well get the dock.If you already have alarm clocks and such, then this accessory is superfluous, except it looks cool. But then, looking cool is not always a good reason to spend money.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I just received my Dock and have to say I really like it.  Usually I just lay my phone down at night to charge. The DROID goes into clock mode where it shows the time temp etc.. there is a certain amount of customization you can do too as far as news weather sports etc.Considering you get another charger plus the dock it is a really good deal.

I just use a front protective cover.If you have any questions please post.  I'll be happy to answer as quick as I can.

reviewText: I got my DROID back in November of 2009, shortly after they were first released, and I was instantly satisfied with it.  Unfortunately, what I would come to find out is that although there was no shortage of the phones themselves, or the car GPS mount (which I also ended up buying), there was a distinct shortage of the multimedia docks.There were workarounds, of course: you could go and buy a cheap knockoff of the mount, designed to merely hold the DROID in such a way as to allow you to snake your power cable through a slot, and have a magnet hit the DROID in just the right way so as to bring up the clock interface.It just wouldn't have been the same, I thought to myself.And in the end, I now know with complete certainty that I was right in that mindset.The dock is very simple in construction: it's a weighted base with rubber feet to maintain traction on most surfaces, with a brushed aluminum surface.  The phone sits very securely on the power receptacle in the provided groove, and there's no wobble if you go to interact with the screen while docked.That being said, I guess I could see where some people would have grief with it: it IS very limited in what it'll allow to fit in the dock.  That is, it's only gonna seat your phone, and nothing else.  If you have one of those Bodyglove-type cases, you're gonna have to remove it before you can dock.In the end, I can't see that as being a problem as I've never used a case for the DROID.  The screen is, as far as I can tell, quite oleophobic (meaning you give it a quick wipe with a cloth, your shirt, etc., and it comes clean) and is very resistant to scratches, and the rest of the phone is just as resilient it seems.  In the five months I've owned my phone, it has yet to take any damage.But yes, the dock is an incredible (and well worth it, in my opinion) purchase to accompany your DROID.  It gives you immediate and intuitive access to the clock app (which you can access without it, of course), and charges your phone, while at the same time allowing you a way to steady the phone for interaction as you lounge in bed.My only complaint would be that although you can dim the screen of the DROID, it doesn't dim/turn off the menu strip of buttons along the bottom edge of the phone.  But then, that's a DROID issue, not a dock issue.Well worth the cost, I'd highly recommend this product to all DROID owners.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: For the money, you might expect a bit more than a weighted base (with magnet!) and a power adapter.  I know I did.  You can use software to go into the same mode as the dock for free, so YMMV.I appreciate the design.  It's heavy enough to not get knocked around too easily on my desk, and my wife keeps hers in the kitchen.  It would work equally well as an alarm clock/night stand device.  We got these with our 2 droids since it was a nice refined way to charge them and still get plenty of functionality (weather/time/music) at a visible angle.Pros:1. Well weighted with rubberized bottom keeps it from bouncing around easily2. Designed nicely - Looks sharp.  The Droid's audio is surprising clear in speaker mode for playing music (especially for such a small speaker), but a Bluetooth or corded headset (or speaker setup) would work here.3. Nice angle for keeping an eye on the clock.  I'm hoping Google improves the interface... the weather section is a bit small and doesn't give much info.  A real-time radar with more info would be best and perhaps a smaller alarm clock with more configuration/personalization options for color, stock ticker, etc. would be great.  But this doesn't affect my review of the dock.4. Fits perfectly and makes it easy to remember where you left your phone.  :-)Cons:1. I thought that the cable for USB/DC Converter was a bit short.  It's the same as the one that came with the Droid.  Nothing that can't be amended, but for $30 they couldn't throw in another meter?2. It boils down to being a weighted/angled slot with charger/usb cable for $30.  It probably amounts to $2 in materials if that.  It would be expensive at $15.3. It really doesn't deliver much.  You can get everything but the pre-positioned angle without the doc, and the doc software needs improvement (not a slam on the dock itself, just pointing it out).  Unless you're really using it as an alarm clock, It's difficult to see the point now that I have it.  If you're watching movies on it as a sort of TV replacement, then maybe... yeah.4. No cases allowed (it won't fit with them on).In the end, it is well built and designed nicely.  I think it should offer more for the money (maybe built in speakers?) but it is what it is, an overpriced accessory, and for what it's worth, usually overpriced accessories are built like junk, so this gets a 4.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: Excellent quality product with a good slant view angle.  Top quality materials and well built for a fraction of what they sell for in Verizon stores.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: This is a well-designed docking station. There's a little ramp that helps guide the phone into place. The micro-USB is sized smaller than usual to allow for smooth docking**. When it's in the dock the screen display turns into a clock/weather-station. You can change from color-scheme from day-time to night-time with a single touch. The weather is shown full-time in the lower left corner and updates frequently to stay current. The base is solid and heavy and has tacky feet so it's not likely to slide off your night-stand or desk.The incline is steeper than it looks in the photo, but I think that was deliberate. When it's sitting on my desk, the phone is squared to my perspective. You can still manipulate controls when it's in the dock. None of the controls are blocked by the station. So you can watch movies or Youtube while it's in the stand. You can even slide the screen up and do a little texting but that's not very ergonomic (carpal tunnel!!). Sliding the screen up also give it a slightly higher perch, which makes it slightly more comfortable when watching videos. Otherwise, you're looking down just enough for your neck to get sore. 2 hours into an intense movie, straining your eyes on the tiny but very crisp screen, you're going strain your neck.So the station is well-designed, but it does NOT fit a phone with a protective case. If you have a case on your Droid and you don't want to take it off every time you use the docking station, you'll have to buy Seidio's cradle.**Jacks are normally sized large for a tight fit so it won't fall off by accident. You'll notice you have to tug a bit to get the jack free. The phone is held in place by gravity and therefore doesn't need a snug fit. When you slide this into place, you don't feel any resistance at all. That's comforting for me since I know those jacks expand with repeated use and don't stay in place after a few months.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: It's a decent dock and does what is advertised, but don't expect anything fancy beyond that.  For an Android phone, it should do more.  Android phones are getting well known for going way beyond what current smartphones can do, and a dock that could live up to that standard should have been thought through.  The buttons on the phone don't lend well to alarm clock functions because of their size and location.  Placing these functions on the dock would have been impressive and much more useful.  Also, I find it strange that they wouldn't run audio through the dock.  Apple has been doing that since first version.  Instead, you have an audio jack sticking out the side of the phone, which is ugly and takes up more space.The base station is precisely this: an option to display your phone more upright (on its side), a magnet to auto-start the alarm clock mode, and a battery charger.  If that's all that you're looking for, you'll love it.  Docking stations for non-Apple phones is somewhat of a new idea, so this is a fair first.  But it could have been designed with more intelligent features in mind.  For a phone touted to be so smart, the docking station lacks.Pros:1. Weighted base2. Polished, looks nice3. Does the job4. Comes with USB charger and data cable5. Has magnet to automatically start "alarm clock" mode when docked6. Solid, well built7. Non-skid padsCons:1. Does not include audio jack in the base2. Does not include any function buttons (alarm snooze, volume)3. Cannot dock a phone with any shielding or plating on it (InvisibleShield works though)4. Data cable is consistently too short.  Needs at least one more foot to be really useful.
title: Motorola Droid Multimedia Dock (Retail Packaging) - compatible with the first Droid A855

reviewText: I can't add anything good that hasn't already been said. I ordered this dock before I noticed in the description that it wasn't compatible with Droid 2 or Droid x. categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: I've been a victim of 3rd party accessories. I'm rather leery of window mounts in general, but since this is an OEM Motorola product built just for the Droid, there really was no way I could go wrong. The price of $30 was a little hard to swallow at the Verizon store, but once I got it mounted (it comes with a regular suction mount, as well as a stick mount for putting it on your dashboard) in my window I found just why you go and buy original accessories. Since it's built for the Droid, my Droid of course fits perfect. I was rather happy to find that it's very easy to get the phone in and out, without the risk of scratching at the casing, and it's also easy to plug in the headphone jack as well as the power charger, not to mention use the buttons on the device. I leave the mount in my window, and slip the phone in place when I need to use it for Navigation, which sends it in to Car Dock mode, providing an easy menu for operating the phone when it's docked, providing easy access to your contacts, Google Navigation, and voice command. I was also rather happy that it's very easy to adjust the face position of the phone, but it stays in place, a big bonus to anyone who's had to deal with touchy mounts that either just fall over or won't move unless you adjust the dial. Even though it's a little pricey, I'd still recommend anyone with a Droid just get this dock off the bat.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: Using a phone for GPS, MP3 player, Satellite radio etc is just super. This mount makes it so nice. The mount itself sticks well to the windshield. I was skeptical because of previous bad experiences with suction cup glass mount systems for other items but this one works as described. It holds the postition you place it in well. No vibration I can see.If I have a complaint, it's really just nit picking at this price. That complaint being the way the phone snaps into the mount uses a tab that can't last forever. After sitting in the sun for a year or two I expect that tab to snap off rendering the mount useless. But for $20, who the heck cares?
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: The Motorola Droid (A855) window mount is fairly basic -- it's well made, but not as well made as some of Motorola's older window mounts.A Droid will automatically go into "automobile" mode when inserted into the holder, and the horizontal (landscape) orientation is perfect for GPS (a little clunky for phone -- but you shouldn't be trying to use the keypad while driving anyway).The keyboard won't open when in the mount -- again, you shouldn't be using the keyboard when driving... but it'd actually be nice not to have to take the phone entirely out of it to enter an address when you're parked.If you have a Droid 2 the Motorola window mount for that is so much better designed... and there's no reason why this one didn't mate power rather than forcing your to insert the power cord separately.The price isn't bad; but you might not actually get that much more bang for the buck buying Motorola over one of the generic ones... though most of those hold the phone vertically (so weigh how much you will use GPS vs phone).You won't go wrong buying this product -- but it just isn't what it should be.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: I purchased this for my droid, since i use it as my primary gps.  Dock mounts fairly well.  It comes with a cloth to clean the mount.  The texture on my car wasn't exactally smooth, but it seems to be holding well.  It came up a few days after I put it on.  I did allow for a 24 hour "set" period.  Hopefully once the weather heats up in the south it won't come  loose.  Very solid product, 3m stick.  I did get it 33% off at Verizon official store - so only paid 20 bucks for it.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)

reviewText: Got this shortly after getting my Droid when I realized that Google Navigation (available on phones running Android 2.1) could really replace my Garmin GPS. It's actually better than my Garmin because it can tap into the internet. Anyway, the OEM mount work great. You put your Droid in it and it's ready to go, ready for input. So far, the suction cup seems to work very well. Unlike my Garmin, the suction cup doesn't randomly lose suction. And, the travel charger that comes with this is perfect too. You will need it if you are doing longer trips as the GPS really sucks back the battery on the Droid. Anyway, solid construction, works as advertised. Love it!

reviewText: This is a custom holder for droid and I really like it.  I've had the squeeze type holders and you never know if its secure and they tend to vibrate loose. reviewText: I ordered this and it arrived in a few days. I opened the package and it came with a few parts to put together, I was dash mounting this so I used all the parts. I cleaned off the dash with the supplied alcohol pad and stuck the sticky base on and it went right on fast. I then mounted the holder and I had a few problems getting it to stick correctly, but when I did get it it went right on. I snapped the actual phone holder onto the base and stuck the droid in. It went right in and immediately went into car mode. The face was sliding and dipping all over the place until I realized I had to tighten it all with the knobs and when I did the thing was perfect.Some people are saying they got one without the car charger but mine did come with the rapid car charger but I don't think I would ever use it. I have a USB splitter I use in my lighter than I can plug pretty much anything into that has a USB connection and the splitter has 2 slots. I would call and say it didn't come with a charger if you need it and I am sure you can get one.Overall I highly recommend this mount, I am not disappointed.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)

reviewText: This is by far the best car mount I've ever used. The suction cup is vastly superior to any other GPS handheld I've used in the past. It does not come off at all, over rough bumps or uneven pavement. My Garmin GPS suction cup falls off all the time from the windshield. This is a great buy if you have a Motorola Droid. I've used mine on numerous road trips and it pays off. Also get the OEM Motorola Droid charger, it illuminates a blue light inside the clear "M" logo that just looks awesome. I use the two in conjunction and they work great.Definitely a great buy.I recommend this, the charger (mentioned above), and the OEM Motorola charging dock........ I have all 3 and would definitely buy again.

reviewText: I have mixed feelings about this Motola mount. The actual mount itself is great. It can be attached to either your windshield or dashboard (I choose the latter), it can be adjusted very easily, it is literally a snap to put in or remove the phone with the easy release button on top, it can be oriented horizontal or vertical for the phone, and the phone automatically enters car mode when it connects and exits car mode upon disconnecting. Again, the mount itself is great.However, I have two major problems with the product as a whole. After only a couple months I noticed that one day I was driving and the mount just fell forward onto my dashboard and off the bottom adhesive. I put it back up but this is still a frequent problem and I typically have to reach up and push the mount down onto the adhesive as I start to see it lifting up slightly. I assume this is a heat problem, as it doesn't seem to be an issue when it's cloudy or at night; just when it's sunny and hot. So that is one problem. The other is that it is just impractical in the first place to mount on the windshield or dash if you live somewhere with a sun that comes out and actually plan on using the phone for navigation or anything that requires the screen to be on. The Droid heats up fairly quickly when its screen is on and the CPU is actively working (such as for navigation). If it is a sunny day, all the plastic in the mount absorbs the heat and transfers it right into the phone, increasing the heat by a lot. I have a battery meter app, and I have literally seen my phone sit in excess of 130 degrees on my dashboard on a hot day while I'm driving. Not only is this excessive heat bad, but it makes it impractical to use for navigation for a long period because the phone will not charge at that temperature, *even when plugged in* (try it and see). It will discharge and your battery will drop fairly quickly, putting you at risk for having a dead phone if you're not keeping an eye on its battery meter.The bottom line is that the mount itself works great. I think it is perfect the way it is. However, I hesitate to recommend it if you live in a sunny area because mounting your phone in plain sun exposure will cause it to heat up very quickly and by default cause the battery to discharge whether plugged in or not. If you live somewhere where the sun is hidden more than out, then you're in luck...but in a sunny area you may think twice before getting this kind of mount. An A/C vent mount may be better for keeping the phone cool and working efficiently, if you can find a good one.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: This product is exactly what I expected of it.  Much to my surprise, It even came with a car charger!  The mount holds the phone great, turns it to car-ready mode, and works exactly as expected...when there isn't a case being used.As a disclaimer, I will say that before purchasing this mount, *I KNEW* that it wouldn't work with ANY TYPE of case on the Droid.However, there-in lies my gripe with this product.  It's not so much what the product doesn't do that it's supposed to...it's more what it SHOULD do that it wasn't designed to.  It is beyond my comprehension as to why Motorola would create such a great mount without even bothering to make it either (A) modify to accompany some sort of a case, or (B) offer 2 versions of the mount, one of those being for someone with some sort of a protective case.  Even if it would only accompany a Motorola-brand case, it would have been nice to at least have the option.  Why would Motorola offer cases for the Droid, but then step on its own feet and require any type of case be taken off to use it?  For many people who are starting to use the Droid to stream/play music in their cars, the phone is mounted almost every time they get in the car.  Many cases can be quite the pain to remove, as most aren't meant to be removed regularly.  While this mount is very convenient to both mount and remove, it still lacks compatibility with...well, pretty much anything but the plain droid.I gave this mount 4 stars for the reason that it did succeed wonderfully in doing everything it was advertised to, but that it's requirements of a bare-back setup on a $400+ phone seems foolish, especially with so much of the push from both the manufacturer and the cell phone provider to use some sort of a protective case.  If both were serious about pushing you to use a case, one would think that they would have at least designed a mount to accompany it.
title: Motorola DROID 1st Generation Vehicle Dock with Rapid Car Charger (Retail Packaging)
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts']]

reviewText: If you have a phone cover, the dock will not fit the phone. (I have the Siedio Innocase. It's the thinnest cover I could find.) My solution is to not use the back cover. The front cover gives edge protection on 3 sides and the face of the phone. It's not perfect but it works for me.Clean you windshield prior to the first application. This will help the suction cup maintain it's grip long term. If you must remove the mount keep it clean. Grime, grease and dirt will effect the long term suction power of the unit. I learned this the hard way with my GPS suction mounts.I use the car mount all the time. I would repurchase it if wears out or I manage to loose or destroy it. It is sturdy enough to hold the phone securely and is easy enough to position where I want it. It would be nice if a model was available with a power dock.

reviewText: First off, real simple - the battery you get here (or I got here) is an exact replacement for the one that came in my Droid.  We all know that droids eat batteries for breakfast and dinner so having a spare is a good thing.I keep this battery in my car in case the one on the phone dies - and I keep it in the SPN5564NEW OEM Motorola Droid Cliq Battery Charger SPN5564charger so that it is always topped off.  NOTE HERE: Ordering the SPN5564 does not include a wall wart charger nor does it include the fullsize USB to mini-usb cable to power it.  I guess Motorola expects by now you have a few of those cables hanging around.  Get a cig lighter to USB adapter and a USB to mini usb cable if you plan to keep a hot battery in the car.  Power used by the charger is next to 0 once the battery is full so it won't drain your car battery.With that set of parts I feel alot more confident that going on the road with my droid I'll always have a full day's battery on hand.

reviewText: I bought this battery direct from Amazon.  I do not trust the 3rd party sellers; none of whom appear to be authorized Motorola resellers.  Counterfeit cell phone batteries are widely available for cheap prices, but who knows what quality you are getting.  Cell phones have been known to catch fire or explode and manufacturers usually blame counterfeit batteries.  The battery that I received from Amazon appears identical to the battery that came with my Motorola Droid phone, including the hologram labeling that is printed on the bottom of the battery.My Droid can last a whole day on one charge if I use only the phone features.  If I use the internet or media or GPS features heavily, then the battery can last less than 8 hours.  Fortunately, the Droid does allow you to easily pop in a spare battery.

reviewerName: Marvin Segal "Wild bear country in Northwest ...
reviewText: I got one of these batteries from OEM Planet via the amazon.com marketplace. It acts and looks exactly like the one that came packaged with my phone, and it works great. The price was terrific, too. Later, I bought four more from another seller on amazon.com marketplace. I will omit their name to avoid possible problems with them. They claimed to be selling actual "made-by-Motorola" batteries. But, with no notice to me, they shipped an off-brand that I had never heard of. I was able to get a refund without hassle through Amazon.com, because this was a "Fulfilled by Amazon" purchase. To be clear: Amazon was not the seller; they only handled the fulfillment of the order for the actual vendor. I subsequently purchased a battery from BTO, Inc. on amazon.com marketplace. But first, I emailed them and specifically asked if they would assure me that the battery was a true Motorola battery. They promptly responded that it was, and when the battery arrived, it was indeed a real Motorola. At a great price. So, there are substantial bargains out there on this battery, and they are worth seeking out. But, BUYER BEWARE - be sure of what you will receive, and be sure of the return policy of the specific vendor that you choose.
title: Motorola  DROID and DROID II 1300mah Standard Battery

reviewText: I had already ordered fake and genuine Motorola BP6X batteries from 3rd party sellers at $5 and less.  They both were either very old or did not hold charges beyond 4 hours, or both.  I considered ordering from Amazon at full price instead, and after being unable to give me a manufacture date on the item they would send me, I decided to order anyways.  Manufactured date is an issue since these batteries start losing their capacity from the day they're made.  Lo and behold, I get a battery from September 2009 that holds a full charge for about 5 hours.  This is after doing a power cycle, and charging to full.  Order at your own risk.  Kudos for Amazon for giving a refund.

reviewText: Update:  If you were thinking about the Seidio Innocell 2600 mAh Extended Battery for Motorola Droid, my advice would be "don't do it."  The OEM battery is a much better power supply.  It actually lasts longer than a few months, which is more than I can say for the Innocell battery I purchased.Review:I enjoy my Droid phone and with my usage, I go through batteries quickly. You can conserve power by turning off options you are not using (Bluetooth, 3G, Screen Brightness, GPS, Wi-Fi, Checking Email) but sometimes I forget or don't want to cut my features. I got a spare Original Equipment Manufacturer battery and an extended life battery at the same time.  This is an OEM battery worked properly from the start, unlike the extended life battery which needed to be "trained" in the phone.  I could not tell the difference in run time between this battery and the one that came with my phone from Verizon.The GoodThe battery fits in my Motorola car dock, which I use all the time.  It also fits in my desktop charging dock which I like to use. The Extended life battery does not fit the Motarola car dock or the desktop charging dock  The OEM battery does not add bulk to the phone.The BadThe OEM battery does not last as long with the features most people use turned on.  It is a pain to have to manage phone usage to keep the battery alive.  I am a heavy user of "Advanced Task Killer" which I usually access by holding down the Home key.ConclusionI am happy with the purchase.  I chose my battery according to what my use will be. When I have been out all day with my first battery and I'm going out at night it's nice to be able to snap in a charged battery. (without taking the time to charge my battery)  If I'm going to be in my car I use the OEM battery.  If I am out and about I use the extended battery.  It is nice to have options.  I still bring my OEM spare battery when I don't want to take the chance of having a dead phone.Unlike our I-Phone friends we have the ability to pop in a new battery. ;-)
title: Motorola  DROID and DROID II 1300mah Standard Battery

reviewText: This is just like the OEM battery in the original MOTO phone.  It works and last just as long.  The battery for the Droid 2 last for about 1.5 days with nornal use.  Good to have an extra battery.  Would buy again.

reviewText: These batteries described as OEM are not all the same. It is a bit of a gamble buying these batteries but fortunately it doesn't involve much money. The first time I purchased inexpensive Droid batteries from Amazon I received two batteries (from UnitedIntegral according to Amazon's order history page). Each worked for about three hours after my older, original battery lasted at least twice that. They clearly were not real OEM batteries (or were defective), but at the price I didn't mind too much. For the price it was still of value to have spares on me in case my main battery died while traveling, even if I did have to change the battery twice on some days.Obviously having extra batteries with a full charge is much better, and I tried again more recently from another seller (listed as OEM Planet in the order history page). This time both batteries are lasting longer than the original battery in the phone (presumably being true OEM batteries with my original battery now having a reduced life due to age). The original battery typically had to be recharged in late afternoon. The last two batteries I received typically last into the evening, allowing me to wait until I'm home to recharge.I'm not certain if the listings as to where each battery came from is accurate as when I click on the first order listed as from UnitedIntegral I get to a page for OEM Planet. When I clicked on the more recent order which lists as OEM Planet on the history page, I wind up at a page saying yet a third company, Accessory One.When I tried to write a review of the second set I wound up on the same page as the review I wrote of the first set despite receiving them from different sellers and a considerable difference between the two. It appears Amazon is lumping all the Droid battery reviews together regardless of seller, but from my experience these are not the same product from each seller. This probably also explains the differences in reviews here.
title: MOTOROLA OEM BP6X BATTERY FOR DROID A855 A955 PRO A957 CLIQ XT MB200 MB501 QTY 1

reviewText: Was VERY happy with it for the first 4 months of owning it, and couldn't imagine a better phone. I could do my emails, read texts, and play music at the same time. I could GO ON THE WEB and stay in a phone convo at the same time. Just was amazing and the phone didn't limit what I did.The first issue I encountered was the battery. It barely lasted 8 hours, and that's with background syncing and all that stuff backlight all that turned down. You'd be lucky to get 1 hour at best if all that was on. I got the extended battery, and when it helped, it somehow made my screen go nuts. No joke, put the old one in and the device screen works and never an issue. The extended battery, it scrolls, clicks n things, and the landscape mode didn't work. Motorola tech support recommended a full reset, so I had to set up everything once more.The next issue I had was the music player integration. I can BLUETOOTH myself MP3 songs that AUTOMATICALLY are stored to the 8GB factory included SD card (finally), but they do not have any sort of identification. It says the track name- but with the track number, they are only in numeric order for example 01-"Only Time" The album names for everything that is Bluetoothed over is Bluetooth. It doesn't drag over the album name, and the artist simply reads unknown. I tried the USB with the same result, so i guess it's not all the bluetooth.And while the ANDROID 2.1.1 Android operating system is a joy to use, you cannot save APPS to your SD card. This leads to small lagginess, such as Angry Birds, takes literally 2 minutes to fling the next bird. As far as I was told, processor speed has nothing do with this, and as this was a premium phone, I'd think it had a good processor in it.Overall:It wows, but it could be better. Do I recommend it, yes, somewhat, if it can have it's issues fixed. I guess if you don't mind the SD issue it'd be a perfect phone, but unfortunately I decided it was something I didn't want to use and upgraded.
title: Motorola Droid A855 CDMA (Black) QWERTY Android Touch-Screen Smart Phone

reviewText: The Good: Excellent design, lots of power, superb features from Google, amazing cameraThe Bad: App store is still young, processes running in the background kills battery life, keyboard is a bit cumbersomeGoogle as been known for revolutionizing the internet and now they are with their Android phones. The Motorola DROID (A855) is the newest and most advanced phone on the market right now, and this bad boy does an awful lot. A lot of people are going to compare this phone to the iPhone, but the DROID trumps the iPhone in features, and freedom. I will discuss, first, the tech specs and compare them to the iPhone head-to-head so you can see how powerful the DROID truly is.Techno BabbleThe DROID has a 550 MHz processor, and to be specific the Arm Cortex A8 processor that is also present in the iPhone 3GS by Samsung. The 3GS is clocked only 50 MHz higher and can be overclocked to 800 MHz. To compare that the original Xbox has a 733 MHz processor. So can the DROID be overclocked to this as well? Most likely. With a monster processor the DROID can multitask and has one of the first actual mobile OS (besides Windows Mobile 7). This also means maintaining processes running in the background to gain battery life, uninstalling apps (not just deleting them), and a lot more, but we'll get to that later. The iPhone however can not multitask due to the OS running on it, and the processor is only used in games.When it comes to graphics the DROID still hasn't been pushed to its limits. There are very few 3D games on the Android market, but as of right now the iPhone stomps the DROID in the graphics department. The DROID has a 200 MHZz PowerVR SGX 530 GPU. The iPhone has the same, but due to the slightly better CPU is can currently outperform the DROID. The iPhone has been on the market for quite some time, so there are bigger better games available. The DROID should start getting the same quality soon. They both have 256MB of RAM, so under the hood they are pretty much the same.The DROID has a slightly bigger screen sizing in at 3.7' and the iPhone at 3.5'. Does 2 millimeters matter? Yes it does. There is a good 2 millimeters on the top of the iPhone that could be screen, but for some unknown reason it's not. The DROID has a higher resolution of 854480 and 265 ppi (pixels per inch). The 3GS has a 320480 resolution with only 163 ppi so the DROID has double the resolution of the iPhone. That is great for people wanting to watch high-res movies on their device.Both devices have the same input such as the 3 axis accelerometer (tilt sensor), digital compass, Multi-touch display, proximity and ambient light sensors etc. The DROID is a bit heavier than the 3GS, but only by 1.2 oz. The DROID wipes the floor with the 3GS' camera. The DROID camera is 5MP compared to the 3GS 3MP. The DROID has dual LED flash, and geotagging and it can even run higher than 30 FPS. The 3GS has all this except the dual LED flash and this is a huge plus.When it comes to storage the DROID wins with its external memory option. You can insert up to a 32GB micro-SD card, but you're stuck with the 3GS' internal memory and have to pay a huge price for more. The DROID even comes with a 16GB micro- card when you buy the phone. So when it comes to comparing junk under the hood they both have the same hardware, but the DROID has the extra tidbits that push it over the edge.GUI: Graphical User InterfaceThe DROID has an excellent GUI and the whole marketplace is run by the community. There are programs such as PandaHome, OpenHome, GDEHome etc that allow you to change "themes" for a small price or for free. These also change icons, clock widgets etc. The DROID has a great interface that is more like a computer that gives you a desktop, then a slide up menu where all your apps are stored. You can drag and drop as you see fit. The iPhone, however, is plagued with the mundane Apple OS that only show apps in a grid format with a black background. Sure you can change your "wallpaper" but this is only when the phone comes out of sleep mode so it's rarely seen. This makes every iPhone look the same so the DROID wins in customization by a long shot. There are four touch buttons located at the bottom of the screen which are your back button, menu, home, and search. You will use these buttons a lot so Motorola and Google were smart to put these here.Apps: Who's Better?It all comes down to the apps. Who has more right? Well the iTunes marketplace has hundreds of thousands of apps that the DROID doesn't have so the iPhone wins there. However, the Android market is ever-growing, and thanks to the user run community a lot of great apps are showing up that the iPhone can't run. These include a lot of customization apps and loads more. Apps are easier to run on the DROID since there is no iTunes type program. The app store is run off the phone, downloaded from the phone as well. If you don't want an app anymore you go to your settings and uninstall it. Google also allows you to refund anything you buy within 24 hours and Apple does not support this. While iTunes may have more stuff, Android has better customer service and a better community and setup. There are really no "hardcore" games for the DROID like there is for the iPhone, but it's getting there. You do not want to get a DROID for a gaming system just yet for sure; stick with your iPod/phone.Features: Welcome to Google TownThe DROID has a lot of little things going on in it. You can do everything a touch screen phone can do, but it also has a slide out QWERTY keyboard. The buttons were a little flat and the top row is hard to get at if you have big fingers, but it works well. If you tilt the phone sideways you can type with a landscape keyboard or use Google text-to-speech. I found this feature extremely useful when typing long messages or writing reviews for apps. Since this is a Google phone you get all their awesome apps such as Google Earth (yes it's in 3D and you can see every detail), and Google maps. Switch to your "car app" and press navigation. Speak your selection (i.e. Phoenix, Arizona) and Google will give you directions for a car, bus, or walking (God forbid you walk that far!). Press get navigate and the phone will speak you the directions. It doesn't update in real-time, but it does update as you drive down each block.Google Sky is a fun app that lets you point your phone in the sky and it will show you, in real-time, where each constellation and planet is. You get plenty of excellent Google apps such as Gmail, YouTube (yeah Google owns YouTube), and Google Goggles which allows you to take pictures of products or objects and the phone will scan it and search it for you. There's even a Google search bar on the desktop with a text-to-speech button next to it. Brilliant. There are plenty of other apps such as the Amazon store, eBay, Bank of America, MLIA, FML, and even ShopSaavy. This app allows you to scan a barcode and it will tell you where you can find it cheaper online or locally. Of course you have all your social networking apps like Twitter, Facebook, and MySpace which run great.When it comes to things like ringtones, pictures, and videos, so the DROID delivers. You can store any MP3, or picture and set them as wallpapers, notifications, or just ringtones. Mount your SD card via USB and just create the folders. No having to sync with a program on the PC. Total freedom is what Google gives you and this is what I love.Problems: It's Not PerfectThere are some issues with the DROID, but not many and they are minor. The biggest one is the running processes in the background that can kill your battery even in sleep mode. You have to get the Advanced App Killer app and every so often check everything you don't want running and kill the apps. Another problem I ran into was that since most of the apps are user made they can be glitchy and screw up your phone so watch out and read reviews before downloading anything. You could say that the major issue is the app store. There is a lot of apps, but some of it is junk. There aren't any excellent games available, and the app store doesn't have any sort feature except Top Paid, Top Free, and Just In.For a $550 phone (if you pay for it without  a plan) the DROID delivers and trumps the iPhone in every direction except the apps. The DROID is a very advanced phone, and is for people who love using their phones constantly and make it a part of their every day life. With a sleek design, excellent features, sturdy hardware, and monster processing power the DROID should be the #1 phone in 2010.Update: 10/15/2011Now after I have had this phone for 18 months I don't like it as much. The phone started having issues with serious lag, slowdown, and just hardly responds anymore. The touch screen lost sensitivity after about a year, plus the hardware is ancient compared to what is out now. Due to that all the apps are now optimized for higher end phones so the Droid is left in the dust.Overall the phone just doesn't really work anymore internally. It won't come out of sleep mode some times, won't answer calls, turns off randomly, and the internet is just impossible to surf due to the now weak processor. Hardware wise it has stood the test of time with many drops, slides, fumbles, and kicks. Not a single crack or anything, but thankfully this phone is now discontinued. If you have the original Droid you are probably finding the same problems even after a factory reset. The phone was great 22 months ago, but now I just absolutely hate this thing. If I were to amend my score I would give it a 4/10 now, but of course that's unfair and should be remembered for how great it was at the time of release. Did I also mention that the appraisal price for the phone is about $20 now-a-days?

reviewText: Description -> Item Model Number: SN5580/SNN5580AReceived a SNN5893AThis battery WILL NOT work correctly with the Droid X or X2. It will fit, it will charge, but your battery meter will not register the battery correctly and you will be looking at a red blinking low battery light all day long. If you have a Droid X or X2, and you get the SNN5893A which is for the Atrix return it ASAP. Again, the BH6X with the SNN5893A batteries will not work correctly in your Droid X or Droid X2.[...]
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 Extended Battery BH6X

reviewText: The storage difference from the BH5X is almost negligible. Battery (purchased from CELLULAR NATION) seems OEM. It fit my Droid X with the original battery cover and the cover was only the slightest bit harder to get on.I would say if your current battery needs replaced go for it but if you are hoping for more battery life don't waste your time.
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 Extended Battery BH6X

reviewText: this battery ore than tripled my battery life... best upgrade for the money... glad to have a phone that I can upgrade
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 Extended Battery BH6X

reviewText: There's a couple types of the Motorola BH6X battery, there's the model (SNN5880A) and the other one is (SNN5893A). My Motorola Atrix 4G came with the SNN5893A model. I also have another spare battery with that same model number and that works great too. I read some reviews and things online about this SNN5880A and people said it worked in there's Atrix, so I gave it a try. The first battery I received did not work, I was kind of nervous, but I also tried it in my friend's Droid X and it did work in that either. So I contacted the seller and they sent me a replacement very quickly. The new (SNN5893A) they sent has been working great. I've been using it for a couple days now and I couldn't be happier. It's great having a couple spare batteries. I'm going on a vacation in a couple weeks and I was worried I wouldn't have many opportunities to charge my phone. Now I'll be able to just swap my battery out if they get low.I charge my spare batteries inBattery Charger for Motorola Droid X (Mb810)and they work great together. I love having a phone that I can just swap out the batteries when needed.
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 Extended Battery BH6X

reviewText: You will not receive the battery advertised here. It says on the product description that it is a SNN5880, which would work fine with the Droid X and X2, but the battery received is a SNN5893A. This battery is for the Atrix, and will not work properly with a Droid X or X2. It will likely just behave strangely.I tried the battery on my Droid X expecting to get better battery life, unaware of the fact that it was the wrong battery. The battery fits, charges, and appears to work, but didn't last as long as I expected. It behaves strangely though. Using "Battery Monitor Widget," it reports negative percentages, and the android system seems to just guess at what the actual capacity is. The battery still charged (but only took around 10 minutes for a full charge, which makes no sense), and could run my phone, but you are not going to be using anywhere near the actual potential of the battery.So don't buy this for a Droid X or X2. Or, contact the seller and ensure you get a SNN5880, or SNN5880A.
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 Extended Battery BH6X

reviewText: While it would fit in my DroidX, it would not charge nor allow the phone to boot.  I had hoped to get a battery with a bit more life than the original, instead I got nothing.

reviewText: I love my Droid X, and find it to be better than my original Droid in almost every fashion. Unfortunately, the desk dock accessory is one of the things that was superior on the D1.Things I like about this product: Performs more or less as it should. The charger cord is permanently affixed to this dock, and is a lot longer than the charger cord they give you with the phone and with the dock I had for my D1. The phone knows when it's docked and will launch the dock screen for you-- and if you have other apps installed that have dock integration (like an alarm clock, for instance), it will give you the option to launch those instead.Things I don't like about this dock: The phone sits in there so snugly it can be difficult to seat and difficult to take out. This is the result of the HDMI port-- both the power port and the HDMI port lock into the phone from this dock, and seating the phone on both, perfectly and simultaneously, takes a bit of maneuvering. Taking it out is worse, you have to pull up on the phone at exactly the right angle to get it dislodged. Since I undock it immediately when I wake up in the morning and am still a bit groggy, this is a pain in the rear.Overall it's better than leaving it on the bedside table laying down, it's not perfect either. The D1 dock was better.
title: Motorola HD Dock for DROID X and Droid X2 - Motorola Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Cell Phone Docks'], ['Electronics', 'Computers & Accessories', 'Computer Components']]

It is very convenient,  and immediately goes into time and temperature mode. It is very handy to always have it close to the bed, totally charged  and easily accessible. reviewText: I have been using this product for about a month now. Construction quality and materials are top notch. The dock does what it says it will do, and does it well. However docking the phone smoothly is difficult. The phone may become momentarily confused if you bump the connectors while docking. Also, sometimes the lit buttons on the phone stay lit for some reason, instead of going dark after a few seconds. I wish there was a way to delay the recognition that it is being docked for maybe 5 seconds. I use Go Launcher with the screen orientation locked to portrait. That arrangement does not work well with the dock--if you touch the connectors briefly while trying to dock the phone, the Go Launcher home screen will become frazzled (wallpaper off size, some icons appear scrambled, some areas of the screen look strange) and stay that way AFTER undocking. The only solution is to enable orientation switching.I use this on my nightstand and often find myself docking in the dark, compounding the problem. I still like my dock, just a little less than I thought I would because it is more difficult to connect to my phone than I had expected.

reviewText: I was looking for something to spruce up my alarm clock and this did the trick for $25. I think it retailed for almost double that at some point, but I cannot see why. Perhaps I'm not looking correctly, but the functionality is very limited with the multimedia dock. It looks ok, but there are only a limited number of widgets one can use which is almost pointless of even having a separate screen for a dock.This thing works well...maybe too well. You'll have to play with it a little until you get the feel for how it fits into the dock because it's very precise. However, even if the phone isn't placed all the way (it seems even if the charging port comes in contact with the mini USB) the multimedia's dock (built in MotoBlur screen) tried to pop up. If you try to adjust to get the phone placed, the screen will disappear and dart back and forth between your normal home screen and the dock's default one.No room for a case either so if you're dedicated to leaving a case on your phone go ahead and skip over this accessory.This item is solid in design, it' subtle and definitely provides some functionality but leaves me wanting more. I gave it 4 stars because it did what I wanted to. And it was a steal.

reviewText: The Droid X OEM car dock is a good product, and includes the Motorola charger as well. Here's my opinion.Pros1. Nice mounting method. The rubber suction cup is tensioned using a lever to get better vacuum. It seems to be a growing trend and certainly a welcome one. Also included is an aluminum ring with 2-faced mounting foam if you want to mount the unit off your windshield.2. Motorola charger included!  If fits, and works quite well - at least for me.3. While I don't use the "Auto" menu often, it does display in a darker color - good for night driving.4. Great for navigation and phone reception. It's not really a feature of the dock - but since most people will have this on their windshield - you'll get better reception for GPS and phone. I travel a lot and this makes a big difference for me.Cons1. Size - The case seems big and could block some of your view. I placed mine in the left corner of my windshield where my inspection sticker blocks the view anyway. It also lets me get close to the phone if I need to hit the screen to answer a call.2. Charger might not be for everyone. The Motorola charger looks really nice. It has a glass ring that glows blue with the Motorola logo. It's nice to look at but might be too bright when driving at night. It also might not fit well with some automotive plug locations. Check out the photos and see for yourself.3. The dock removes from the mounting bracket by simply sliding it up and out. It might be a bonus if you want to hold the phone in the mount, but it makes removing the phone from the dock itself with one hand difficult (you need one hand to hold the dock in the mount, and one hand to pull out the phone).  Not a biggie for me but I'm just trying to be honest.In a nutshell, I am quite happy with this product.
title: Motorola Vehicle Dock for DROID X & Droid X2 with Rapid Car Charger - Motorola Retail Packaging

reviewText: Had issue with seller who was selling OEM (which it was) but it was a return with the OEM seal broken which was not disclosed in sale. Watch that. Also, took advise of other reviewers and made sure this version had the car charger cord with it. It is not a long cord so don't plan on plugging it in anyplace but the front dash. The AUX cable that came with it is also short...and since my AUX jack is behind the center console island, it did me no good.Connection to a window is extremely secure and you can press and use the phone in the dock if you ensure the base is resting on the dash. The plastic disc with adhesive that is supposed to be an optional mount surface was useless. Waited the 24 hours to let the adhesive 'cure' and it popped off the dash just in trying to connect the mount. Worthless option. Plan on keeping it suctioned to the window.Feb 2012 addition......Less than a year later, the car charger section stopped working. Despite being stationary during 10 months of use, the cord started shorting out at the base where it plugs into the mount. Now have to buy another car plug. Quality leaves a great deal to be desired.Revised the star rating down to 2.

reviewText: If not for the fact that the mount doesn't include a power cord I would have given this product a 5-star rating. It's very solidly built and holds the Droid X very securely and I've only used the suction cup mount on the windshield.The magnet that automatically allows the phone to know that it's being placed in a mounting bracket is a very nice feature also. It automatically starts the CarDock program on the phone (either the one that came with the phone or others that you can download from the Market).Motorola paid close attention to detail to get the Droid X to do exactly what you would expect it to do while in CarDock mode: it automatically pauses the music player when receiving a call, all calls go into Speaker mode automatically, you can have your most frequently called numbers at your fingertips, etc. If you use Google Navigation (which I have given up my dedicated Garmin GPS for) then a car mount is a must buy because of the battery drain it puts on the phone.The car mount makes all this possible. The mount does have a spot to receive the microUSB power cable so you don't have to fiddle with the power cord each time you put the phone in or out of the mount. And it also includes a cable that plugs your phone into your car's sound system (standard headphone adapter) if your car's stereo has that feature. Just be sure to buy the car charger. I bought this one and have been very happy with it. Motorola P513 Vehicle Power Adapter MicroUSB Rapid Rate Charger

reviewText: First off this thing is enormous and takes up a sizable chunk of windshield. With the phone installed it automatically goes to the cardock app, which is customizable. I used the phone in this dock for navigation a few times and it would often crash and reboot the phone, making you have to re-enter everything. Also my weather app (mycast) would constantly crash while driving because it couldn't keep up with my location. I would recommend against using this for navigation, but it works great for music and phone, plus you can set up one of the widgets for the camcorder and have your own dash cam.

reviewText: The car mount came in the original Motorola packaging, but was clearly opened by The OEM Store. They were even bold enough to place a label over where they opened packaging that said it was opened to "inspect" the contents.  What they really did was take out the Motorola rapid rate charger and replace it with a (very) cheap imitation.  I'm sure they're selling that on here separately as well.  The imitation charger cable does not fit very well, and is barely long enough to reach from the power outlet to the mount on the window.*Update*  In addition to my qualms with the seller, this product was just poorly designed by motorola.  When mounted to the windshield, the arm is just unnecessarily long and because of it, the device vibrates terribly when idling - causing an audible and annoying sound to come through the mic to the person on the end of the call.  Within a few weeks of using, the mechanism that locked the phone holder into the rest of the unit wore out and it no longer locked in place, creating a very insecure fit.  I finally replaced my DX with an SIII and bought the samsung infuse car mount.  That mount is MUCH better quality.  Shorter arm means little to no vibration, and the suction is much stronger/secure since the lever arm doesn't extend so far from the fulcrum.

reviewText: This mount is essential if you plan to use the GPS capabilities of your Droid X.  Since many vehicle dashboards, including mine, have a textured surface, Motorola supplies a self-adhesive disk that will accommodate the car mount even on textured surfaces, but my best results came from sticking the suction cup directly to my windshield.  Such an arrangement places the phone's screen at an ideal distance for me to see it clearly without having to take my eyes off of the road.  It also makes it easy for me to switch the mount to another car if necessary, while leaving no evidence of the previous installation.  Dropping the phone into the mount causes the phone to display a different screen, appropriate for vehicle use, that can be customized.  If the phone rings, while in the mount, I just touch the "Answer" button to use the phone hands-free.The rapid charger cable plugs into the back of the car mount and the phone connects with a plug mounted in the cradle.  Since this mount gives a glove-like fit to the phone, it won't accommodate the phone if it's in a protective case or has a thicker, high-capacity battery installed.  However, since the plugged-in car mount supplies power to the phone while it's guiding you to your destination and the car mount provides solid protection for the phone as well, neither of those other two accessories would be necessary until you remove your phone from the mount.After using my car dock for more than a year, I bought a second one for my motor home.  It attached conveniently to the driver's side window and sits within easy reach and view on the dashboard.  Owning a second dock saves me the hassle of moving the one from my car.  When I upgraded my old Droid X to a Droid Razr Maxx HD I discovered that I could remove the insert from this vehicle dock, then grind the lower left interior side of the tray to expand its width about 1/8" and this dock will accommodate my new phone.
title: Motorola Vehicle Dock for DROID X & Droid X2 with Rapid Car Charger - Motorola Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts'], ['Electronics', 'Computers & Accessories', 'Computer Components']]

reviewText: I bought this because I wanted a car dock that was specific to the Droid X. If you already have a car charger with the micro usb connection, the car dock has the connection in the back so that you can now insert the charging usb connection into the USB connection on the dock. When you slide the DX into the dock, it will automatically start charging. I like that feature.The fit of the DX into the dock is excellent IMO. You slide the phone down into the cradle and on top there is a latch that closes down on the top of the phone to keep it snugly in place. When you are ready to pull out the phone, you just push the latch up and pull out the phone. Very easy.The arm is perfect for my car. It is very short and very functional as far as being able to situate it the way you want it in your car. If you have a large car or the area where you plan to mount the dock is going to be more than 4 or so inches from where you plan to use your phone, this setup may be too short for you. Also, I like that the arm is short, which minimizes arm vibrations and shaking. I had a different set up a few months ago with a longer arm mount and it would allow the phone to shake too much when driving.The package came with a mounting disc, as well as an aux cable. The cable is a rubbery flexible cord. Much better than your standard plastic insulated aux cables. The dock also has a fitter in the back that allows you to always have the aux cable securely connected to the dock so you don't lose track of it whenever you plug/unplug the aux cable from your device. Nice touch.Although I do like this mounting dock, I do think it's a bit pricey. But when it comes to have an exact fit for the Droid X, I was willing to pay the extra $.I always keep my dock suctioned to the disc, never taking it out. It has been up for about 2.5 months and has never fell down or off the disc.All in all, I would definitely recommend this dock to Droid X owners. A bit pricey, but I think it's worth it.
title: Motorola Vehicle Dock for DROID X & Droid X2 with Rapid Car Charger - Motorola Retail Packaging

reviewText: I ordered this for my Droid X to mount in my car.  I enjoy using the GPS feature for directions and finding out where the heck I am sometimes.It is very easy to attach onto your windshield or dash.  Included in the box is a mounting disc that sticks to the dash.  Or if you prefer to attach it to the windshield, there is a suction mechanism that provides a very solid attachment easily.Once you attach the Droid onto the unit, the application kicks in and gives you options for what you want to view (map, apps, clock, etc).Also included is a car charger that hooks up to the mounting device, so you can leave it hooked up even when the phone isn't there.  Just remember to unplug it from the lighter when you're not driving.A great product that delivers on all its promises.

reviewText: The mount is custom made for the droid x, so it fits like a dream. Mounts easily on the wind shield and they have a sticker if you want to mount on your dash(didnt try this). The mount looks a bit chunky but is very functional. When mounted you can even operate the phone i.e. use the touch screen with out fear of the phone moving under your fingers. It holds the phone quite firmly which is nice. It is easy to adjust to any alignment or angle. Works as expected.The only complaint I had - I have to remove my phone's case before fitting it in the mount. This is the silicone type case that I got from the store and not a very bulky one. They have a kind of mechanism to make room for a case, but it does not work. I just peel my case off. Not a big deal.All in all, good buy.

reviewText: I love my Droid X phone and the docking stations I have for my desk and nightstand, so I just needed to round the experience out with the car dock. All told, this is a GREAT product!  Well build, it's very sturdy and lower profile than I thought it would be in my relatively small windshield.  The arm extends further than it looks and the angle of the phone is adjustable, making it really easy to see.  I love that it is permanently connected to power when in the dock. No more forgetting to plug it in while in the car, which happens to me often.  The big buttons on the customizable program that starts up when the phone is docked are perfect for everything I need while in the car. It does come with an adaptor to connect the headphone jack of the phone to the stereo, which it doesn't mention on the box, but it didn't do me any good because my stereo doesn't have a jack.  I, however, use an FM transmitter for my music and that works quite well for me.The only reason I didn't give the dock a 5 star review is that I'm disappointed that what is seen when music is playing isn't customizable.  Instead of showing me the name of the song and the artist, it shows the name of the song and the name of the album...which is unimportant to me.  I wish I had the option to change what is shown on the screen. Seems like it would be a no-brainer to me.  Other than that, though, I completely love this item!  Highly recommended!
title: Motorola Vehicle Dock for DROID X & Droid X2 with Rapid Car Charger - Motorola Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is the perfect vehicle dock for the Droid X family. Mine's the X2. For those complaining about the "vibration" as the vehicle moves, it's not possible to engineer this type of mounting any more solidly that Motorola has done. Get over it.And the clamping mechanism for holding the Droid to the base is rock solid and does not interfere with the screen at all. I don't use a case with mine so can't comment on those who do but the mount seems to be designed to be used with the bare Droid.I don't think that I'll be using the docking software functionality much, but found that I can get to the main home screen by hitting the "Return" button. Other than that, the only other time that the dock software gets in the way is that it comes up whenever the "Home" button is hit. Just hitting the "Return" button then brings up the main home screen.Motorola could have designed more movement into the support, especially in the first rotating joint up from the base. This would have provided more flexibility in positioning but, for me, is not a major point.

reviewText: After seeing how well a similar mount for my Droid X worked, my wife wanted me to order one for her Droid 2. Since many vehicle dashboards, including hers, have a textured surface, Motorola supplies a self-adhesive disk that will accommodate the car mount even on textured surfaces, but our best results came from sticking the suction cup directly to her car's windshield. Such an arrangement places the phone's screen at an ideal distance for my wife to see it clearly without having to take her eyes off of the road. It also makes it easy for us to switch the mount to another car if necessary, while leaving no evidence of the previous installation. Dropping the phone into the mount causes the phone to display a different screen, appropriate for vehicle use, that can be customized. If the phone rings, while in the mount, just touch the "Answer" button to use the phone hands-free.The rapid charger cable plugs into the back of the car mount and the phone connects with a plug mounted inside the cradle. Since this mount gives a glove-like fit to the phone, it won't work if the phone is in a protective case or has a thicker, high-capacity battery installed. However, since the plugged-in car mount supplies power to the phone while it's guiding you to your destination and the car mount provides solid protection for the phone as well, neither of those other two accessories will be necessary until you remove your phone from the mount.Overall my wife has been pleased with this purchase, which works for her as well as my similar Droid X car mount works for me.  She has also been delighted with her Droid 2 phone.
title: Motorola Car Mount and Rapid Car Charger for Motorola DROID 2/DROID 2 Global - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Car Accessories', 'Car Cradles & Mounts', 'Car Mounts'], ['Electronics', 'Computers & Accessories', 'Computer Components']]

reviewText: Bought this docking station for my wife's Droid 2. While the phone sits securely in the dock, one very disappointing design problem is the difficulty of placing the phone in the dock. It is difficult properly line up the micro USB charging connector to the phone charging slot - have to have good lighting in order to do so, which at night means possibly waking up your S.O. There is no LED indicator that the phone is charging, so sometimes can't tell whether it is or not (I had to install a clock app which alleviated this problem by changing the interface of the screen). My own phone is a Samsung Epic which also has a charging dock, much better designed for the phone to easily slide in or out without having to hold the dock down and has an indicator LED.
title: Motorola Multimedia Station for Motorola DROID 2 and DROID 2 Global

reviewText: I love this product! It is convenient, fits my Droid 2 Global with a case once the insert is removed. Fits snugly just as it should. Looks great and works perfectly. Charges as well & quick as the original cord. Does NOT fit with a Body Glove case as it is too bulky. The change to a horizontal display is great with the ability to dim or brighten it. I bought this as a second one and wish I had bought the first one through you as it was MUCH more expensive in the kit I got at Verizon. I have it plugged into a power strip so I can just push the switch off in the morning rather than unplug. Works out well. My son would be happier with it if it could properly be plugged into external speakers as a coordinated set or cradle into a speaker dock. Since his case is too fat to fit in it, I'm the one who uses it now. This might change when he gets a different case.  Still VERY happy with it. Only things I can see that could make it better is that it could hook up to speakers - and perhaps it could have two inserts to accommmodate bigger cases???  Tiz excellent product and functions very well for what it is intended. Colors would be nice to make the girls happier.
title: Motorola Multimedia Station for Motorola DROID 2 and DROID 2 Global

reviewText: If you absolutely need a heavy base, angled display, and extra power cord, then by all means shop around for price and pick this up.  Otherwise, call this a hugely-missed opportunity by Motorola to add something special to the dock: speakers, a powered USB hub, integrated Bluetooth or mini router, toothpick and tweezers... I could go on, of course, but you get the picture.  I think speakers, followed by a powered USB hub, would have been terrific for this.Also note: you can power/ connect the dock to your PC via a microUSB cable as well, assuming you'd want the dock to synchronize with your PC.  That's decent, but again, not worth a premium.--#
title: Motorola Multimedia Station for Motorola DROID 2 and DROID 2 Global

reviewText: I have a protective "case" on my Motorolla Droid 2, so I removed the inner plate from this dock as instructed for phones that have a case.  The phone goes into "clock" display when I put it in the dock, but it takes some playing with to make it charge.  WhenI get it to start charging, I have to  be careful not to disturb it because the connection is so sensitive.This dock works and charges just fine if I take the case off the phone.  Maybe my case is just shaped a little too irregular.  Despite this issue, the dock is inexpensive enough to feel like I got my money's worth.  Plus, the charging cable can be disconnected from it and used as an extra charger.

reviewText: It's probably not 'the cheapest of them all' but given that at the time I'm writing is you can get it at Amazon with free shipping, it's pretty much 'out there'.Just to be clear: unlike the XOOM's power port, the HDMI is NOT proprietary. XOOM has a standard HDMI Type D port meaning that any Type D (micro) HDMI wire will do. I don't have a Droid but I assume it's the same there.If you search Amazon for 'HDMI Micro' you should find quite a few alternatives to choose from. One thing that I would NOT do is buy an overpriced (but in no way better) standard wire from a phone company store.

reviewText: This HDMI cable worked like a charm on my Bionic. I used it to watch Netflix and NFL Mobile on my home TV. NOTE: the Bionic just had a software update this week (12/16) to fix some of the freezing when connecting to HDMI. Before the fix, I did have some freezing with the cable in. But a quick restart fixed it.If you can't get the HDMI to play - keep trying. Sometimes you will get an error with some programs but if you simply try again or powercycle then try again it will work. If you still can't get it to work, search the app store for Droid X HDMI and go with one of those programs to help your phone.It is a real Motorola cable, not cheaply made and the price can't be beat.
