reviewText: If you own a Droid Razr and do not want to upgrade to the Razr Maxx with the larger capacity battery, then this little external charger is the way to go. On average usage, m Razr lasts about 10 to 12 hours on a  single charge so by the end of the night, if I am out and away from a wall socket, this little beauty comes in real handy to keep me up and running until I can plug my Razr into an electrical socket. Just to be clear, this device doesn't really add significant charge to the battery but does keep it from draining to 0% for at least a half an hour to an hour (depending on how much you are using the phone while you have this device plugged into it). There is a larger capacity charger that is also manufactured by Motorola (and looks identical to this unit) that will charge your battery quite well even while you're using the phone but it is almost twice the price of this unit. So for a very reasonable cost, this model suits me just fine!!
title: Motorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power Pack - Black - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Travel Chargers'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Batteries, Chargers & Accessories', 'Power Strips']]

reviewText: First things first...I would not recommend this if you plan on charging iPad's, iPhone 4's, or even some iPod Touches.  Second - I would HIGHLY recommend this battery pack in your backpack if you have multiple gadgets that need charging on the go.I personally used this a few times with my Blackberry Bold 9700 and Motorola Atrix which are both Micro-USB.  I have also used the spare USB port to charge a Jabra headset.  While this is not going to get you charged back up to 100% (depending on how low you are) - it will get you enough juice to last until you get to a good ole AC power source.The device has led's - bright white led's - on the front so you can press the button to the left and find out how much battery life is remaining.  It takes a good 4-6 hours to get a full charge from empty...and considerably less if you have 2-3 led's of charge remaining.NO complaints thus far - but I do wish it worked better with Apple devices - Apple is just notorious for not allowing aftermarket accessories to work properly and they have proven that again this time.So, in conclusion - buy one if you walk around with headsets, Blackberries, Android handsets, etc...whatever device that is native to usb charging should work just fine.
title: Motorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power Pack - Black - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Travel Chargers'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Batteries, Chargers & Accessories', 'Power Strips']]

reviewText: Motorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power PackLike many of us, I have found myself increasingly dependent on my phone.  I get positively paranoid if I forget my phone on my desk.  My palms get sweaty when I find my self evaluating the time left on my phone battery.  I feel the remaining time in excruciating detail as I wait for my life to go black!  Reading his over, I am increasingly despondent on how fixated I have become on cellular reception.  It isn't just to chit chat, Oh No!, nothing as simple as chit chat.I want to find the best price on gasoline with GasBuddy.  I want to check on Roethlisberger's condition.  Arrghh! I want to check the stock market or ball game score and I can't do any with a DEAD battery.There is hope and it isn't expensive.  This is the perfect item when you find yourself charger-less.  Those of you who have never, ever left your charger someplace you wish you hadn't may cast the first stone. Otherwise, button up and be aware there is a simple solution.  This little fellow is smaller and thinner than my DroidX and will recharge it while I am using it.  It seems to have double the strength of the battery on the Droid.  For $27.69 at Amazon, you can slip this in your briefcase, jean's pocket or duct tape it to the back of your phone and have TWICE as long to stay connected.  Motorola P793Universal and portable, the P793 is a power pack that can simultaneously charge multiple devices, including mobile devices like the iPhone, Bluetooth headsets, and MP3 players. With 1420 mAh capacity, the P793 can provide up to an additional five hours of talk time.It has a single micro USB connector that will fit many items besides your phone and a standard USB if you have your charging cable.  It charged to full charge in less than two hours.  This would make a great stocking stuffer.
title: Motorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power Pack - Black - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Travel Chargers'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Batteries, Chargers & Accessories', 'Power Strips']]

reviewText: If you have an iPhone, you might be aware as to how poor the battery life is.You would have charged it 100% and then it will go down to about 10% by the end of the day.If it were a blackberry, you can change the batteries which is not possible with iPhones.  But if you carry this Motorola device, you can use this to charge your iPhone and use it for another 4-6 hours.
title: Motorola Universal Dual-Charging Portable Power Pack - Black - Retail Packaging
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories', 'Chargers', 'Travel Chargers'], ['Electronics', 'Accessories & Supplies', 'Batteries, Chargers & Accessories', 'Power Strips']]

reviewText: I absolutely LOVE this thing! I bought this because although I love my new car, it doesn't have bluetooth capability built-in. After reading all the good reviews, I decided to give this a chance and I'm so glad I did. The sound quality is ridiculously good! I don't know how these speakers work so well, but they do. I tried calling my boyfriend while he was in the car and I was whispering very low and he still not only heard me, but couldn't even tell I was whispering because the speaker is so powerful. It's very easy to use and it even tells you how to pair your device. It works well with my phone's voice commands, says who's calling or sending a text and allows you to accept, reject or callback. I love the auto on/off thing as well since I can never remember to turn it off when I leave the car. The MotoSpeak app is okay, but you really have to get used to it. You have to speak to it a certain way or else it doesn't quite understand you. But that's not really the device's fault, it's just something the app developers have to work on some more. It still reads incoming text messages very well and I like that the app starts and stops on its own when your phone is paired to the device. I'm very happy with this and would definitely recommend it!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought this primarily for the FM transmittal function and speakerphone.Pro's:1.  Compact design2.  Pairs perfectly with my Motorola Razr Maxx3.  Automatically connects when I enter the car4.  Automatically disconnects when I leave the car5.  Voice calls over the speakerphone are excellent6.  Voice calls transmit over the car's stereo speakers when in the FM mode and music automatically stops7.  Driving directions are broadcast through the FM transmitter to the car's stereo speakers8.  Setup was simple and took only seconds9.  Long battery life10.  Recharges quickly when neededCon's1.  FM transmittal is only so-so2.  Static is evident regardless of station in the FM transmittal mode (This is not an issue with my car's stereo system - I checked.  It does the same thing in my truck.)3.  Must download MotoSpeak to your phone to use the hands free featuresConclusion:Not recommended for FM transmittal, but awesome for hands-free calling and texting except for having to download Motospeak to my phone, which has a tendency to keep running after my phone is diconnected from the Roadster.  I would recommend this product to a friend and hope Motorola enhances the FM transmittal strength of this device to eliminate the static I and others are experiencing.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I'd previously purchased the motorola T505, which worked great. One of the features I liked about the Roadster is the standby feature, so when u get into your car, it automatically picks up the Bluetooth, and stays on. The only thing about that, its not consistent. I use with my iPhone 4, so maybe it's not well supported by.Overall I'll give it a 4 star.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I drive a Ford Expedition using a Blackberry 9810 Torch phone. My Expedition is a little older and doesn't have built-in Bluetooth. I usually use an earpiece, but I'm always forgetting to put it in. My wife always gives me a hard time about using my cell and driving, so I decided to give this a try. So far, it works really well. Speaker sound is nice and clear, easy to pair with my phone and the battery lasts a long time. I haven't tried using it over my car stereo yet. Has a nice feature that when you're receiving a call, it tells you the number that's calling or the name that associated with it in your phones address book. And to answer the phone, you can simply say "answer" and the call picks up. All in all, very happy with the purchase.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I love the text feature. It allows you to hear the text you have received and also allows you to speak your text response. Also, incoming calls are heard with crystal clarity and allows you to speak while it cancels out the background road noise for maximum audibility. It is easy to install and use and really defines the words "hands free".
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I purchased this device from Staples as a Christmas present for my wife.  On x-mass day, we un-boxed the product and gave it a good charge.  After a few hours, we went to test it out.  The phone (Samsung Epic 4g Touch) paired perfectly.  However, the FM transmitter functionality was completely non-working.  I called the support number, and the support representative dutifully ran down her checklist ... nothing worked.  I was told to bring it back to the store for exchange.A few days later, I exchanged the device, and the replacement unit appeared to work fine.  Call quality was good, and the FM functionality worked well for routing call and music audio to the car stereo.  The auto-search feature for finding empty stations isn't very good.  Very often I'd tune to the directed station, and find my signal being stepped on by an existing broadcast.  After a bit of fiddling, you'll eventually find a clear channel.  When that happens audio quality is pretty good.  My wife used the device for the better part of the week, and for the most-part it worked just fine.  ...but then it started acting up.  It would be slow to "wake up" and pair every now and then.  And then today ... it just wouldn't wake up despite having a full charge.  Even flipping the power switch on-and-off had no effect.  It had worked perfectly just a few hours before ... and then nothing.So ... I called customer support Sunday, Jan 6 sometime after 6:30PM EST.  The representative had me try a few trouble-shooting steps, but then agreed that I had (yet another) defective unit and we started putting together an RMA.  He took some very basic information from me, and then put me on hold.  After about 5-minutes on hold, he comes back and tells me they're "having trouble with their systems" and asked if he could "call back in 5 minutes."  I made sure he had my phone number correct, hung up and went about my business.  At about 7:10pm EST, I realized I had never received my call-back, so I called in myself ... only to be greeted by a recording stating that they were now closed for the night.  I guess Mr. Indian Accent didn't want to deal with my RMA so close to quitting time, so he just blew me off.  I'm sitting here steaming as I write this ... hopefully they'll take care of me tomorrow.PROS: (when the device works)- Pairs quickly and easily- Call quality and noise cancellation is good.- FM functionality routs sounds to the car speakers via the radio.CONS:- Apparently terrible quality control - Two consecutive faulty units- Frequency finder isn't really good at finding empty frequencies for the FM tuner- Customer Service reps are lazy, which wouldn't be a problem except for the fact that they ship poor quality products.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've been using the Motorola Roadster Bluetooth for almost a year now, and in my experience it's a pretty nifty tool. Setup didn't take long at all and I haven't experienced any issues with it malfunctioning. My only real problem is that sometimes the people I'm talking to report that I sound very muffled, but this is the exception rather than the norm. Many conditions and variables could affect this, and factoring in convenience and safety I still appreciate what the Roadster has to offer. If it means you and the other drivers around you are a little safer out on the road, slight occasional issues with sound quality can be tolerated.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Out of the box, it looks great, sounds awesome and should be what I need.  I will review again down the road, but I am very happy with this purchase.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Motorola Roadster proved to be pretty much as advertised: easy to link with my Droid 2, direct access to the contact list, strong speakerphone capabilities, clear communications even with background noise, even capable of sending simple text replies via voice commands. (MotoSpeak must be downloaded for this feature, but that is readily available via the Droid Marketplace) Overall, I am pleased with the unit itself.What I am not pleased with is the documentation that came with it. According to the printed material, the Roadster should respond to incoming calls with the name of the caller, provided that the caller is in your contact list. That does not happen; instead, it announces the phone number, not the name, just as other reviewers had noted.Additionally, nothing in the printed instructions talks about recognized commands or options, yet there is a specific list of commands that the Roadster recognizes. I accidentally discovered these one afternoon when I turned the Roadster on while my Droid 2 was lying on the desk face up. Suddenly a list of commands and options that I did not know existed appeared on the display screen of my phone. Since then, I have taken the step to remove my Droid 2 from my belt and place it with the screen facing me while in the car; in this way, I can see both who is calling and what commands are available.Would I recommend it to friends? Yes, but with the cautions about the shortcomings of the printed instructions and what steps worked for me. By the way, Motorola support for this problem proved to be no support at all! While they appeared to be  helpful initially, once I discovered that the documentation -- not the Roadster -- was at fault, Motorola support techs suddenly stopped all communications with me. I guess that Motorola does not appreciate when a customer discovers a flaw in its armor.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I love it, I hate it... here's why:Love it:Automatically paired with my phoneAutomatically shuts off to save battery life when not pairedAutomatically connects and disconnects as I get in and out of my vehicle during the dayMicro-usb chargerHate it:Buttons don't light up in the darkI don't like fumbling around trying to answer and adjust volumeSound quality is not as good as my Jabra bluetooth speakerphoneIf it's on sale and you NEED one of these, it will probably meet your needsIf you want to spend a little more, go for theJabra CRUISER2 Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone, it works better and has better sound quality. The Jabra DID NOT auto pair like the Motorola though and often needs to be reconnected after leaving and re-entering the vehicle.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I tested the product with an iPhone 4 and it setup and paired easily.  I really can't figure out what the problem some reviewers had is.  It works fine for me.  The unit is attractive and very easy to use.  The unit has a few functions that are geared toward Motorola phones that I was not able to test.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I tested this with an HTC EVO.  Overall it performed as intended.  People could always hear me and I could hear them so the FM transmitter seemed to work fine.  Battery life seemed to be sufficient but obviously that depends on how much you use it and I didn't test specifically for how long it lasted but it seemed fine.  The only quibble I would have is I don't like the tactile sensation of the buttons and construction felt a little cheap.  But all thing aside that is not a big deal.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Oh this is a wonderful little gadget.  Very easy to set up and use.  In reality, I turned it on and it voice prompted me to get that phone paired or it wouldn't quit yammering.  I did as told and now I've got a great little in car hands free system that can podcast too.  My current cell phone is a mytouch 4g.  There have been no weird issues.Oh yeah, the other wonderful thing is that the Motorola Roadster came with an in car charger that has a micro USB connector.  So, the charger also works for my phone.  Sweet.This is my first blue tooth speaker.  I like it much better than the ear bud things I've used.  Yes, people can sometimes tell I'm not talking directly into the phone.As for playing stuff from the myTouch, through the roadster, and out the car's audio system - it works fone for me so far.  I usually listen to books on tape (mp3) or language lessons, so the audio quality isn't a huge factor.  That and the car audio system ain't all that anyways.Anyways, this little gadget has really been a quality of life improvement.  I'm very very pleased.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: * The sound quality is scratchy and the volume rather low* The FM transmission quality is poor. At first I thought it was a good feature, but I don't use it due to the quality.* There seems to be an issue with the bluetooth connection. I use TomTom GPS on my iPhone. The spoken directions come via the motorola speaker instead of the iPhone, which I normally wouldn't mind. However, the first second or so of all directions are cut off. It's rather annoying.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The speakerphone looks nice, and it paired very easy with my phone. It turns on when I open the car door.My main issue with it is the charger. The speakerphone is designed to be attached to your visor, so to charge it, the thick ugly coiled cable has to go down from it to the plug. It definitely takes more than few minutes to charge, and I just cannot drive around with the coiled cable dangling in front of my face. I do not trust the device to leave it charging when the car is sitting in the garage. So, the speakerphone ended up sitting in between the front seats in my car, and, of course,  you cannot really expect to calls to be clear when the thing is so far away from you. The sound is reasonably clear when I pick it up and talk into it, but this is no way to use a hands-free device.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I was looking into installing an FM modulator or an Parrot hands-free kit in my 2006 Volvo S60.  This was a much cheaper/easier option, and I thought I would have replaced it by now, but it works so well that I haven't been in a rush to replace it.I drive an hour each day.  I use it primarily for streaming Pandora and having conference calls over my car's stereo.  The battery usually lasts about two weeks.  Finding the perfect station takes a couple days.  The unit likes to piggyback on weaker stations and doesn't seem to work as well on open frequencies.  The musical quality of the A2DP is excellent.  Much better than other previous experiences with other FM modulators and transmitters.  Most of the time, the sound quality is excellent, but hen the station that it is piggybacking on gets too strong or weak, you get some noise that reminds you are using an FM device.Mic is good, but not great.  People can't hear me as well as they do on my jawbone, but I don't get too many complaints.  It is real hard to switch between the roadster and the jawbone.  Just turning off the roadster and turning on the jawbone does not do it.Device looks great and built-in on the visor.  Buttons are easy to use without looking at them.  Connects quickly to my android phone, though startup and shutdown sounds and voice are slightly annoying.At some point, I am going to get a Grom Audio device to replace this device, but again, it costs 3-4x as much and has to be installed.  Roadster was a great buy!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've owned many in-car Blue-tooth Speaker-Phone systems and I have to say that I'm very impressed with this Motorola Roadster Blue-tooth system.  It was very well designed and works well with my iPhone 4G. In fact, I find it very difficult to find something bad to say about it.  The only minor complaint I have is that when it syncs/pairs with my iPhone, it tells me the battery level of my iPhone instead of the battery level of the unit itself. I'm usually aware of what the battery level of my phone is, so it's redundant... and I'd much rather know what the battery level of the speaker-phone is.  This is a very minor issue and I am impressed that it DOES display the battery level of the speaker-phone on my iphone screen when it is synced/paired. Other than that, this thing is great and I still give it 5-Stars.Here are some of the reasons why I thought this speaker-system deserves 5 Stars:-Easy to use-Charges through standard USB to mini-USB cable.-Syncs very easily and consistently... and speaks to you to let you know it's synced. Voice is easy to understand.-It seems to sense when you are in your car and syncs accordingly even though the Blue-tooth range is much greater.-Two options to listen to phone calls/music (through the on-board speaker or a radio channel of your choice through car speakers)-unit is small, the buttons are backlit, and the clip stays clipped to the sunshade very well... it's sturdy.-Long battery life and long standby time. I've had the unit sitting in my car for about two weeks and haven't needed to charge it again yet.-Voice quality is good over speaker-phone speakers.-Comes with Car charger & Cable... plus, frustration free packaging.Conclusion:If you're looking for a great hands-free blue-tooth in-car speaker-phone that does the job and you're willing to spend a little more for the quality, this is the one for you. I rarely give 5-Stars for products, but I couldn't resist giving this one 5 Stars. It's is surprisingly well designed.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This was really a great idea. Everyone who has a cell phone needs a hands free option. I really dislike headsets because they never fit my ear just right. I saw this and thought this would be a great way to be safe and have a conversation.The speaker phone was pretty easy to set up and the pairing was fairly easy the first time. I have a HTC Hero and that's what I paired with the speaker phone. The only problem is that after the first time, whenever it connects to my phone, my phone comes up saying that it's connecting and a strange password gets put in and then disconnects itself. I had to manually connect every single time a few times to get connected to this.Also, it says that it can sense when the phone is near by and turn on automatically. While this would be great if it really worked, most of the time, I had to turn off this thing and turn it back on for it to sense that the phone is there. In fact, I did this even after full charge and it was still doing this.The sound of this was actually surprisingly good. It was loud and pretty clear and I had no problems hearing the other person on the other line. However, it seems to not pick me up well or I have to put the phone right up to my mouth because my caller said that I sound far away and can barely hear me. I still haven't figured out this part.While I loved the idea of this, it seems to fall in terms of what it promises. The connection issues and the fact that the other caller could not hear me too well makes me not really use this any more. Just need to tweak this a little bit and this would be great.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Can't fall off your ear!  Clip is strong.  FM transmitter seems to work well too.  I also LOVE that I can push my music or an audio book through it and that it will pause automatically when a phone call comes in (although that may be a phone setting too).  No complaints on either end with call clarity or volume.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I live in a state that mandated only "hands-free" calling while driving at the beginning of 2011. Although I've been regularly using aPlantronics Voyager 510 Bluetooth headset/mikefor two years, other household members have been slower to adopt the hands-free habit. This was due to both inconsistent pairing of the Plantronics with our phones, and perhaps vanity over the nerdiness of the over-the-ear headset/mike.The Roadster solved both those issues. Since we've had it, we've upgraded our cell phones. The Roadster recognized and quickly paired with our older two LG phones and, after upgrading, with the two new HTC EVO phones without issue. Incoming call quality through its integrated speaker is perfectly acceptable, as is the quality of our outgoing speech.I also exercised the functionality of the FM transmitter, to route call audio through the car's radio. We live in a area where the FM bands are relatively crowded with signals from multiple large cities, and this seemed to sometimes confuse the Roadster, just as it sometimes confuses the car radio too!Unless you have a smart phone and are interested in streaming music services (such as Pandora or Rhapsody), I don't consider this a serious drawback. We use this unit to stay legal (and arguably, safer) than non hands-free calling would make us while driving. It delivers on those accounts...
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Lots of reviews both good and bad (mostly good).  I've had the Motorola bluetooth speakers before and traditionally they've been very reliable.  This one is no exception.PROS:  Easy to setup / pair with my phone.  Volume is GREAT!  I can play music using this as the speaker, or press the "FM" buttom and it will transmit to my car stereo.  BATTERY LIFE IS UNREAL!  We must've gone at least 2-3 weeks before the battery was low.  And everytime you get in the car, it automatically powers-on and gives you a voice prompt on the battery level.CONS:  Really haven't identified any problems with this.Would certainly recommend this!  Peace!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Worked great for the first month and 8 days (we bought two, btw) . We received them on the 12th of February and one died on the 20th of March. OF COURSE, the deadline for returning it for replacement expired on the 15th of March. OK, possibly we got a lemon. That notwithstanding, we are still out the money. A bad experience and a negative for both Motorola and Amazon as far as I am concerned. We are hoping the second one proves to be more reliable...but, I may be here again with a negative update. If you buy this, be very aware of the deadline for returns here on Amazon. I really think 90 days, NOT one month ought to be the policy for electronics...for good customer relations, that is.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Call quality was decent according to callers on the other end of the line. Each person I spoke with said they could tell I was on speakerphone, and there was obvious background noise that was tolerable. I was frequently asked to repeat myself several times during every conversations, though. And, as much as I was asked to repeat myself, I think I had more difficulty hearing people on my end. The speaker on the Roadster was not the best for phone calls as voices sounded muffled. Audio quality was better when I used FM to transmit through my car speakers, but there was some interference now and then which resulted in me changing the station a few times.I listened to some youtube videos, a bit of an audiobook, and I played a few songs from Pandora - it all sounded fine through the Roadster itself and even better through FM. There wasn't much bass on the Roadster, though, and audio was a little tinny but still comfortable to listen to through its tiny speaker.The buttons felt a little soft and mushy. It was frequently hard to tell if I'd actually pressed one hard enough to prompt a response. The icons on the buttons are raised for better distinction so you don't have to take your eyes off the road to know what you are pressing so that is helpful.One of the selling points of this speakerphone for me was being able to use the Motospeak app, which actually works with other non-Motorola bluetooth speakerphones as well. Well, I found that using Motospeak was mostly useless. It only understood me about half the time I spoke messages, and I discovered that I actually find it more annoying than helpful having text messages announced when they arrive. It's rather frustrating when you're trying to talk to another passenger in the car or place an order at a drive-thru and the automated voice interrupts with her big text announcement. I gave it a shot, but that app is not something I'm interested in anymore. I'll just check my texts at red lights or when I'm not driving.Can't say anything about battery life as I didn't keep the Roadster long enough to need to charge it again. I returned it for something that functions with better clarity on calls and hardly any interference on FM aka theMotorola T505 Bluetooth Portable In-Car Speakerphone, which I highly recommend. It's still a 4-star product after 650+ reviews, and it's cheaper and just plain works. Motorola still has quite a good thing going with the T505. Try it...this Roadster may be a newer model, but newer doesn't always mean better.Please click yes if you think this review was helpful, and I hope it was. Good luck with your purchase!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've had several bluetooths and a few wanna be bluetooths, but this Motorola is by far the best. Its sturdy and not cheap-o plastic crap. It is very intelligent and easy to program and operate. It goes off by itself conserving precious battery power. The only thing I would have liked better is if there was an AC plug sold with it. The DC only is not the best way to charge it as the drive has to be long enough to fully charge it  Overall its a much better devics than all Ive ever owned and would recommend it.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is a great devise for anyone who wants to make hands free calls and pump pandora through the speakers of your vehicle.  Not sure why the bad reviews.Pairing:  As soon as you turn this on it give verbal instructions to pair with your phone and help to do it.  Took only a few seconds to do without any manual imput.FM:  The trick here is to start at the channel it suggests.  If that channel is too close to an active channel you can manually change the frequency on the unit to a better channel and match it to your radio.  Some low hiss between songs if the volume is up but not noticeable during music play.  I was not expecting hd quality music direct from CD, just wanted to listen to my tunes without obvious noise.  If you are a real high Def kinda person your car is likely equipped with a USB, hdmi or aux jack input already so FM is not likely to be a problem.True hands free conversation: Option of verbal "answer" or "ignor" for incoming calls.  1 button push for outgoing calls.  Even Captin Kirk had to press his communicator once in a while.Motospeak Ap was free so there is no monthly fee for upgraded text to speech like Jabra.  Have not tried the google voice yet with this set.I got this for under $50.  I now have hands free driving and get to listen to my favorite 80's rock (back when there used to be real music). I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 just because the Jabra freeway looks a little more updated and the voice interaction (instruction) is updated.  I think that products firmware is also upgradeable compared to the motorola, so in that respect the technology for Motorola is about 2 year old.  But for me $50 was better than the newest models out for $130.  Drive save and enjoy the ride!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Sound both ways is great.  The automatic sensing of movement in the vehicle and the phone in range makes connection a breeze.  Also like the voice recognition of incoming calls with announcement of who is calling.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I own the newer Motorola Roadster and the slightly older Motorola T505.  So it made sense to do a head-to-head comparison to see which unit is better.Design: Both units are compact.  The Roadster's layout is somewhat more appealing to my eye.  The Roadster's controls are labeled and easy to find.  They are also illuminated.  The T505's controls are not as well labeled or illuminated, but it is easy to use nonetheless.The T505 has a reversible mounting clip, so it can work with cars like my Audi, which have sun visors that swing from front-to-rear rather than the usual rear-to-front.  Roadster's mounting clip is not reversible, so I must mount it backwards in order to use it.  Once the unit is mounted backwards, throw those easy-to-read labels and icons out the window.  The T505 is made from plastic.  So is the Roadster, but it also is partially covered by a nylon or poly cloth material that could prove to be less durable.  While the Roadster features a more updated look, the lack of a reversible mounting clip gives a slight advantage to the T505, as the Roadster is hard to use when mounted backward.Pairing.  Both bluetooth units pair very easily, but the advantage goes to the Roadster, which announces that it is ready to pair and then does so quickly.  Things couldn't be much easier then that.  But the T505 is also easy to pair, just not quite as easy as Roadster.  Also, the Roadster turns itself on when you enter the car, which is nice.  The T505 must be turned on manually.I paired both units with a newer Palm Pixi Plus and a slightly older Palm Treo 755p.  While Roadster initially paired with this somewhat older 755p, after a couple of days it would no longer pair.  I tried everything I could think of and got to pair eventually, but it later developed the same problem, dropping pairing and then refusing to pair.  The T-505 paired and remained connected without issues.  While the Roadster pairs easier than the T505, I had no issues with the T505 and I had several problems with Roadster's pairing.  Advantage: T505.Streaming Music:  Both units can stream MP3s from your cell phone through your car stereo.  When advancing from one track to the next, Roadster required me to hold down the advance button for much longer than I'd like to, creating a distraction while driving.  A single touch on that key pauses the music but it must be held down for awhile to advance the track.  I had to hold the button down to the point where it was annoying.  Also, the advance takes longer than I'd like and is accompanied by a very loud beep and then a clicking sound.  Also, with Roadster, I cannot revert to the previously played track.  With the T505, I simply click on the right side button to advance and the left side button to go back.  Changes from track to track only require a short touch, the change is immediate and it is not accompanied by the obnoxious beep tone or clicking noise.  Advantage T505.Speakerphone: The Roadster's built in speakerphone is louder and clearer than the T505's.  If you are using the speakerphone and not streaming to FM stereo, the advantage goes to the Roadster.Output to FM stereo: Both units have similar output strength to FM.  It could be better but both units are much better than a Jabra unit that I tested earlier.  I'd consider the output to FM on both units to be on the better side of acceptable.  Roadster can select a specific FM frequency that you'd like for the unit to broadcast on each time.  The T505 cannot do this.  T505 will automatically scan for a frequency and you can select a preferred frequency, but it will generally select whatever it likes.  I'd probably call this a draw, although I do prefer Roadster's frequency-selecting ability.Call quality: I spoke with my mother on the Roadster first and then with the T505.  I was driving a convertible with the top up.  The car is not noisy but is slightly more so than a hardtop vehicle.  The Roadster's microphone was so sensitive that it was picking up much of the background noise and forcing the duplex to me even when I wasn't speaking.  That meant that I couldn't hear much of what mom said because Roadster picked up the road noise and shut off mom's conversation.  The T505 didn't have this problem.  Big advantage T505.Incoming calls: When an incoming call arrives, both units announce the caller's name and number, if available.  Roadster allows you to say "answer" or "ignore".  With the T505, you simply tap the telephone icon to answer.  Slight advantage Roadster.Texting: It's my understanding that Roadster can read back texts and allow you to reply to them.  I did not test this function, but assuming it works properly, it seems like that would be an attractive feature for someone who texts a lot.  Advantage Roadster.The Winner: Of the two units, I prefer the T505.  It's less fussy than Roadster.  While Roadster's pairing failed several times, the T505 was always rock solid.  Music streaming track advances were much quicker and smoother on the T505.  The microphone was way too sensitive on Roadster, although this might not be a problem for those with a very quiet car.Both are decent units, but I'm using the T505 daily while Roadster sits in its box.  Roadster isn't bad, but I can't give it more than 3 stars based on my experiences.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought this for my husband.  He is not very computer savy, but seemed to handle it ok. It went out on him, but our granddaughter fixed it for him. As far as I know it has worked fine every since.  He also uses this on an oler phone but still with blue tooth capabilities.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Got this for a friend and while she is very happy with it I think the device could be a lot better. The FM beamer in particular sucks very much as the sound is full of static (especially on her car where the antenna is on the roof in the back). Also the A2DP sometimes mixes up and music beams via HFP in mono :-/ Restart required.The speakerphone is okay, loud and crisp for calls, but in no way suitable for music playback.Microphone is hit or miss without particular way to tell. Sometimes people at the other end hear you very well sometimes it sucks big time for them. I wouldn't carry out any important conversations via this device.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: law required hands free cell phone usage in car but didnt want to wear clumsy thing over my ear so came across this when searching amazon. well ive used it for a week now and I LOVE IT. sound is loud and clear. no need to do anything just put on visor and it goes on automatically when you get in car. also tells you battery life, so you can plug it in.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Roadster is a lightweight unit roughly the size of a cellphone but molded to fit properly on an automobile sun visor. It comes with a car recharger and small instructional booklet. I unpacked mine and turned it on. It immediately "spoke" through the built-in speaker, indicating that its battery level was low and that it needed to be connected via Bluetooth to my cellphone. I have an iPhone 4; I turned that on and selected the Settings app so that I could set up the Bluetooth connection. Following the instructions I'd just heard on the Roadster, I accomplished that within a few seconds. The Roadster then indicated that it was connected to my iPhone, using my iPhone's personal name through the speaker.The next day, I put the Roadster in my car, plugging it into the lighter socket to recharge the battery. A blue LED on the lighter plug indicates that power is being received and the unit announces that it is being charged. A little while later, I received a phone call. The ring tone that I'd normally hear on my phone came through on the Roadster's speaker and I was quickly able to answer the call. While driving on the highway with some interior noise in the car, the unit had excellent clarity and my caller indicated that he had no trouble understanding the conversation.While I can send the Roadster's speaker output to the FM radio band instead, I rarely have the radio on and so have not used that function.I left the car at the airport, leaving the Roadster turned on and unplugging the lighter plug, and taking my iPhone with me. Four days later, returning to the car, as I opened the door I heard the Roadster announce that it had detected my iPhone and was setting up the Bluetooth connection. This required no action on my part. Battery level was announced as being high, so clearly the unit had turned off appropriately during my and my phone's absence. I initiated a call this time and the input/output was automatically directed to the Roadster's mic/speaker setup without any additional action on my part.As you've read in other reviews, the Roadster has other capabilities, such as streaming music, voice response to certain commands, and so forth. I haven't utilized these capabilities yet, but the strength of this product is in the straightforward and easy setup, the clarity of the speaker and microphone, and the ease and speed with which it links to the Bluetooth connection of my phone each time I return to the car. I've observed no errors or problems in this regard over the first 10 days of use and am looking forward to a long relationship between my phone and the Roadster.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Connection to my Blackberry (Torch) is clear and does not drop... unlike the built in Bluetooth in my previous car. People understand me, and do not have reverb or static creep into a call either...For such a small amount of money, this is a great way to get Bluetooth speaker connectivity in a car. Simple to use, many additional features if you want to use them... works well.Highly recommend... eBay has it about $10 cheaper.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: So far so good. Works well with my iphone. Speaking works well, charge holds for decent amount of time. Should have purchased a 2nd one for my truck. I love it.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Pros:- Very loud - almost painfully loud at times. Most phones go into compression while this speakerphone will play, for example, an alert at real volume (which is usually full volume). This makes it possible to actually use this phone while driving down the highway.- Good noise cancellation - people I've talked to say they can understand me just fine.- Amazing battery life - I used this for two weeks straight in the car without recharging. I was using it to listen to podcasts, so it was actually active for ~2 hours a day. In the age of nightly recharges this is amazing.Cons:- FM Transmitter is a little weak - might be my car (Camry), but while operating in FM transmitter mode, it is not noise free.- Auto Sleep - I was hoping to use this unit as a speakerphone in conference rooms, but unfortunately, if not moved around (natural vibration of the car etc), the unit will sleep after a certain amount of time. This seems like an odd quirk to go into sleep mode during a call, but it's happened several times. Along these same lines, the unit is much more sensitive in one axis than the other (read facing the phone button). This is great for road noise cancellation, but it does make less useful as a speakerphone on a table.Conclusion:Overall a very effective unit for what it's intended for. Loud audio, noise cancellation and long battery life make it a winner for anyone who wants to add bluetooth to their car.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This was a great product. Bought three of them for me and my kids. I used mine for a year in the old truck and I loved the fact that it would even speak out the text messages for me while I was driving and I could just talk back to it and it would translate into a text message. Makes driving much safer. I just bought a new truck with built-in blue-tooth telephone capability so I gave mine to a friend so he could safely talk and drive. One of my kids uses the blue-tooth feature to play the music from his iPhone and he loves it.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: If I rely on the auto-off feature leaving the car, it stays connected with the car in the driveway and me in the house. If I shut if off manually I have to reboot the pairing. I am going to return it.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Used this unit for a few weeks and finally halfway on a trip to California before it quit. The last words out of it was that it was fully charged and then it died while I was driving in a hands free state. Would not recommend this unit for anything.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I use this for listening to podcasts on my commute, and the phone call functionality as well.It pairs reliably and never drops the audio like some Bluetooth devices can. The volume is ample, and the FM transmitter feature works well too.One of the best features of this speakerphone is the way it powers on and off. There's a hard (slider-style) on and off switch but when it has been on for a while with no activity, it shuts itself off. The great thing is that it senses when you enter the car (usually when you shut the door or begin moving) and powers on. This means that the batter can last for over two weeks with heavy use, and you never have to worry about forgetting it on, or manually turning it on when you get in the car.The Motorola app that is suggested is buggy, and works just OK. It's not required to use the device.You can answer calls by speaking. When a call comes in, it will announce who is calling and ask you if you want to 'answer' or 'ignore'. This voice recognition works very well, and has never failed me. It also has a button to initiate your phone's voice command dialer, and another button to answer or hang up.For listening to podcasts, there is a play/pause toggle that will skip to the next track if held down. This is brilliant for running errands and jumping in and out of the car as you never have to reach into your pocket/purse for the device. Just play/pause from the speakerphone itself.If a podcast is playing, and a call comes in the audio is paused. When the other party hangs up, the device resumes your music/podcast.The current price at the time of this review makes this an even better value. I paid about $70 for mine, roughly two years ago.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I love it so far (a few weeks in).  It senses motion when I get in the car and turns on automatically.  If I'm on a call already it transfers to the device quickly.  Sound quality is great through the speaker.  Controls are simple and easy to find, even in the dark.  Battery lasts a long time, and the included charger is also the same as the one for my S3 so I still only need one charger in the car.I guess the one knock I have is the FM Transmitter function.  You have to turn the volume up pretty high to hear, and then you hear the static.  That may be my phone or my stereo though.  I'll just stick to the speaker.All-in-all I love it and don't know how I got along without it now.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Trying to avoid a bluetooth in the ear thing...this sounded like the best deal.  Maybe I'm getting what I paid for, and generally motorolla items are fine.  But the problem with this one was the voice recognition was very weak.  My phone and google voice worked fine, but not through the device.  Have received my refund so feel satisfied, though still would like to have a reliable bluetooth device.  This is not the one.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Lots of issues.  This device does not charge long and almost has a mind of its own.  It rarely works and was an absolute waste of money.  Less than a year later and now I need a new one!!!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: No more to say. This is a great product. It plays all the songs from my phone and sounds crisp & clear!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Needless to say this one comes in packed full of features. You can sync two phones at once which is a plus for me. There is an app you can load into your phone to brings out its full flavor of device. with the app, it will learn your contacts and state when they are calling. Otherwise, it will just call out the phone number calling. I haven't used the device for playing music on it though it does have buttons for it. People sound pretty clear on it during calls, though some words sound a bit high pitched regardless of who is calling.I give this a 4 star due to its battery. If left ON at all times. It will disconnect and reconnect to your phone on its own. the only problem is that the battery will only last about 2 weeks or so. My last Motorola used to last 3 months. That other one wasn't as capable as this one. I plan to turn it OFF/ON to see how much longer the battery will last in that manner.The profile is think which is nice as it doesn't stick out at much as my old one did. I am able to hit the button wearing medium sized winter gloves with no issue, so the buttons are sensitive enough for me to use the voice commands or answer a call. As a added bonus, it also comes with a car charger. Its the same type that many Android phones use to charge. So it has multiple uses for it, which is great
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: this turned out to not be the answer to my older cars lack of bluetooth that I thought it would be.  First off, on a good day, call quality is just not that great - other people can't hear me very well when I use this and it is kinda static-y.  On a bad day, people hear nothing when I call - zip, zilch, nada.  I do like the built in fm transmitter, but unfortunately music quality isn't that great using it.  At this price, I really can't recommend this motorola roadster and feel like it should have much better clarity and quality than it does.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewerName: Nathan Andersen "Gadget lover and author of S...
reviewText: Before getting this I did quite a bit of searching on the web, and couldn't find anything that explains exactly how well this speakerphone works with iPhones.  Several other reviews outline its main features, and a few mention that they use it with their iPhones but don't discuss the limitations of that mode, so what follows is intended just for those who hope to use it with an iPhone.  (I've got the iPhone 3G, but I can't see any reason it would work differently with the iPhone 3GS or 4).It's clearly designed for droid phones, and on those phones you can download the MotoSpeak app and have it read texts out loud - and even allows you to compose texts hands free.  Still, the basic and most essential functions appear to work with any Bluetooth enabled phone, and certainly with my iPhone 3G.It hooks easily to the sun visor of the car, and the charger plugs into the cigarette lighter.  It links easily with the iPhone, once you go into the settings and enable Bluetooth.  After it's linked, the Roadster recognizes your phone, and turns itself on automatically, apparently triggered by the sound of an opening or closing car door.  Once on, it speaks out loud that it recognizes your phone, and even says the name of the phone it's linked to.  It also tells you whether it's fully charged or not.If you receive a call, it tells you there's an incoming call and if your phone recognizes the caller it tells you who's calling.  You can then say either "Answer" or "Ignore" and it will either pick up the call or drop it.  You hear the call either through a speaker built in to the Roadster or you can set it up so it transmits directly to your car stereo through an unused FM frequency.  The onboard microphone picks up your voice - all you have to do is speak at an ordinary level and it works fine.  My wife reported that it sounds just like it does when I'm calling her directly through the iPhone.Pressing the call icon on the Roadster will redial your most recent call.  Another feature built in to it is that you're supposed to be able to click on the dial tone button and speak a phone number - but when I press that button the Roadster tells me that the feature is unsupported by my phone.  It strikes me a bit odd that the Roadster can control my iPhone enough to dial the most recent call, but not to dial a different number, but that's the way it is.You can also play music from your phone through the Roadster - it sounds awful if you try to do it through the speaker on the Roadster, but when you've got it on the FM transmitting mode, and assuming you've got it set on a clear station the music sounds pretty decent, about as good as you'd get it from a decent but not perfect signal on a regular FM station. In my case I hook the iPhone directly to my stereo with a USB cable, so I wouldn't ever bother with this.So what this is really useful for on my iPhone is answering calls hands free - and in my case that's the main thing I wanted it for so it works pretty well for me.  If you want to make phone calls a lot while driving, or want to receive and send text with voice commands, you'll need a different kind of phone, with Android 2.2 or higher.  Having said that, those features would make this an excellent device for owners of Android phones; the more basic features still make it quite useful for iPhone users like me.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I purchased this device for my wife.  She drives a convertible Beetle and she is hard to hear.  She uses a Droid X.This device does come in slightly better than the Droid X.  I was hoping it would be much clearer but it isn't.If I were able to test it first and experience the results I would not have purchased it. My car has a built in speaker phone and it far surpasses this device.  I was thinking since her voice is closer to the device it would be clearer but I was wrong.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: From a setup standpoint, this device is very simple to set up. Just turn it on, it will tell you its in pair mode, and then tell your phone to scan for bluetooth devices, pair it, and done.  The built in speaker is clear and loud enough to overcome road noise with the window(driver side) partially rolled down.  To go to fm mode, just press the fm button and use the volume buttons to scan for an open frequency.  Quality across the radio in a large city has some static, as there are not very many open frequencies, but this is try of all OEM fm transmitters, they aren't allowed to transmit with a lot of power so there is often bleed-over from another frequency.  However I was able to play and hear my music from my EVO with no problems.The system has some voice response capabilty, allowing you to answer calls and such by voice command.  Battery life is high.My only complaint is, that at least in my Honda, the devices buttons are hard to find, they are not easily in your eyeline.  I found myself needing to turn on a cabin light just to find the on button.  Even once on the illuminated buttons sit very flat when attached to the sun visor, so you can't find them immediatly while driving.  This is the only part I would try to improve on.Overall though I am very happy with this device and use it in place of a bluetooth earpiece when drive, with the added benefit of getting the play media off my EVO.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: gave it a 4 because I didnt love it. cool, neat, easy to use, as long as its really quiet, no wind, no music, nobody else talking. dialed the wrong number a few times and found my seld yelling at it as it asked me if i wanted to call don while im trying to reach mom. i even tried speaking slowly but it doesnt like that either. still, answers, ignores calls hands free like a champ, no tickets to date, knock on wood.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is quite an awesome unit for smartphone gps and voice use, speakerphone and anything your smartphone bellows.There is a glitch that Motorola tech support does not know how to resolve (or the tech I spoke with). Motorola replaced the unit thankfully but the same problem returned.In time the unit will disconnect indicated by a loud ping within a minute of reconnecting this to the smartphone. To fix this one has to turn off the Roadster, unpair it from the SP, remove the battery for a moment. Then pair the unit after installing the battery of course. It may do it again in a few weeks but mine hasn't 'pinged' disconnect in a month now. Now others know how to fix this and it should be 5 stars for them too.12/25/13.. So now I have a new HTC DNA with no removable battery but it doesn't disconnect on it's own like my Rezound did. This Roadster is awesome. Incoming phone calls as I lie in sleep it asks "call from.... say answer or ignore" IGNORE and it hangs up and only my lips moved haha...answer and still only your lips move as you converse via speaker, f a n t a s t i c!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I tried 2 different brand new Roadsters, both from Amazon.  They performed great until I tried to use the FM radio feature which was virtually worthless on both units.  I could barely hear the unit over the FM radio and yes, I even tried a different car and my home FM radio.  The problem is definitely in the Roadster.  If I touched the wire visor clip while broadcasting FM and aimed the visor downward so it was parallel with my radio antenna the performace would improve somewhat.  This tells me that there is an antenna and/or FM power problem with this unit.The reason I purchased the Roadster was because I sold my older Motorola T505 to an employee who needed one right away.  I decided to upgrade since I now have an Android smartphone and this unit supposedly has text to speech and speech to text capability. By the way the text to speech was minimally useful and the speech to text wouldn't work on my phone.After trying a Jabra Cruiser as well, which also failed miserably in the FM department I decided to go back to the T505 which arrived today.  As usual it is flawless in the FM department and sounds great just on its internal speaker.  I love that unit and will stick with that.If you don't care about the FM then the Roadster is a nice sounding very attractive unit.  It is a bit louder than the T505.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I just got this thing so my review is very tentative, so far I am very pleased as people can hear me very well and I can hear them. Infact I am using a Evo 4G and I actually have to lower the speaker volume cause its so loud, so thats a plus. Another reason I lowered the volume was that at high it does tend to give out unwanted vibration and its annoying. The text to speech is so far a hit and miss, its 50% right and about 50% wrong but I think it has to do more with the app from Android than the product itself so Moto has to update that app and from what I can see many people feel the same way as lately the ratings have crashed. That said I am very pleased with the Moto so far and now have to see if with updates and fine tunning the BT gets not so much better but more relaible. My second concern is life span as I have ready some reviews that within a few months the thing dies so hope those were just bad batches. Other features I love is the auto off/on feature that way I won't be the one doing that because I would forget most of the time and bettery life would go out the window. This thing also has media play so you can listen to Pandora or other stuff through it as well as the radio feature to listen through your car speakers. I have not tried those nor do I plan to as I just wanted a BT that works I have all those other features built into my stereo already. Last but not least another great feature I love about this BT unit is voice recognition as when a call or text comes in all I have to do is say answer or read and its cool. To end I would have given this thing a 5 star but issues with the text to speech and speech to text (which is one of the reasons I bought it) I had to lower until they fix or make more reliable.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Motorola Roadster (TZ700) Portable Car Speaker is a good quality bluetooth speakerphone. It is easy to pair up and operate.  The button are back lighted and big enough, and the sound quality is good (both speaker and the mic due to dual-microphone noise cancellation technology). The auto-off feature is convenient and battery last a long time. The sound is loud enough even in a noisy car (or window open).Make sure your phone/device is compatible before buying this speakerphone.Pros:1. Good speaker sound quality (mic quality is also good)2. Very easy to operate (easy to pair up, and buttons are back lighted with LED)3. Pair up with multiple devices (not at the same time however)4. Auto-off (and auto-on) and safe battery life (good battery life)5. Solid build and compact6. FM frequency can be customized (vs just a few pre-set frequency)7. Read message pretty good (the text to speech function)Cons:1. Power LED is small and on the side (hard to see)2. On FM transmitter mode, the volume button become radio frequency tuning, and no way to change volume from the speakerphone3. FM transmitting quality is just average (but this is true for most FM transmitter)4. When the sound is set to quite high, the sound isn't very good (they should set the max volume lower).Sidarta Tanu
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Okay, it works great now!!!This is a great unit. I take back everything negative I may have said. The sound quality is great and it is easy to set-up and use. It was touchy at first, but once it's paired it'll stay paired: my problem was with "naming it" in my phone's bluetooth device name space. You can write anything there and it'll say whatever you type, such as, "Connected to MJ007" or whatever you care to name it. Buy it!!!----------------------After using this for 2 months... ca-ca! Pure poop! Here's the pain: every time the battery goes low (this is the 2nd time) and it get recharged, IT LOSES ALL THE PAIRING INFORMATION, and one has to re-pair it again, but it's not easy because it DOES NOT WANT TO PAIR AGAIN!! I am not a techno-idiot, but this thing will make you feel like an idiot because it does not follow basic configuration standards. Stay away. And the problem arose after my 30-day warrenty expired. If I can I'm returning this.---------------------------My 4-year old Jabra SP700 would not pair with my latest phone, so I had to seek another speakerphone for my car, and bumped into this one here on The Zon. From its feel to its function this unit is fine. I say perhaps too good because it pairs with my phone from a long distance, say 200 ft. I left my phone in the house once and went to move the car and while in the car, in the street, it connected to my phone 25-yards away in the house! This is stuff from spy novels. The speakerphone has great clarity and all of the voice activated functions work like a charm. I don't have blue tooth radio but if I did this unit can act as a remote FM speaker too. The Motorola insignia on the face shines like a light at night, so in order to camophlage the remote clipped onto my visor, I took a black marker and blackened all of the shiny areas: out of sight, out of mind. After a month's worth of use I highly recommended this unit for hands-free talking. Sensible driving!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: If you have an older car without bluetooh connection and still want to enjoy hand free phone calling, this device is perfect.It works as advertised. It pairs witha phone quickly and easily. The voice promts make it easy to figure out what is going on (incoming call / connection status, etc)It's cheap. It's easy to use. And you can have hands free calling in any car quickly. Plus it's portable so you can move it between different cars if the need arises. Or you can use it as a speaker phoen if for some reason you needed to hav ea conference call on your cell phone. It's a great way to give a nice loud connection to your phone.The FM transmitter part works, but it's a little cumbersome. And it doesn't do teh greatest job of picking a 'clear' frequency that you can bradcast on. So its' not the best option for pushing the sound to your car speakers. But the speaker in the unit is plenty loud enough on its own.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I live in Southern Cali and you have to be hands-free when talking on the phone. The tickets can be upwards of $500!!! This is a great way to talk hands-free and stay safe. I have two sons in there early 20's and this was a gift for them. They have used them for over a month now and my husband has the same device! Great buy and much cheaper than a ticket!!
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Moto Roadster worked great with my Samsung Omnia and my iPhone 4S and a friends Blackberry. It reliably connects and the audio is clear and consistent over the internal speaker.Since I have not used android devices I don't know about the Moto app for memos and dictation. I also did not use the FM to radio option as the internal speaker was loud and clear.The pairing was simple and reliable. Getting into the car the phone is detected and the Bluetooth connects right away with a friendly audio confirmation.Battery life has been all I can want. I've never come close to 20h of talk time. Standby is quite long. the in car charger brings the charge back up quickly.The only drawback here in New England is the winter. If it's below freezing the Roadster will not reliably come on. When it warms up, there are no problems. Since three months of the years is likely to see sub-freezing temps I knock off 2 stars. Except for cold weather non performance it would be a great solution for me.I hope this helps someone.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is the second Motorola Roadster i have tried and they have both failed. each time the device would cut off, refuse to switch back on or charge. If i left it off for a few hours it would switch back on and work again. I have used an older Motorola for about 5 years without a hint of trouble, not this time! Time to try a different brand!FYI i am using an iphone 5s
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I opened the package and noticed that I had to go to the apstore and download Motospeak.  Just my luck it isn't available for an IPhone.  So I put it in my truck, plugged it in, turned my phone on and....it works great.  I can call, I can text all hands free.  Wonderful news since it is now illegal to use a cell phone while driving in Illinois.  I have an IPhone 5 and love this product.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: works brilliant! voice quality is amazing.. and i love the fact that it powers on automatically as soon as the door is closed.. truly hands-free as you can answer a call by simply saying answer! compact, stylish and reasonable price as well

reviewText: Pros: Easy to pair, long battery life, turns on automatically and off when you leave car. Speaker is excellent, FM transmitterCons: Lasts for a year or so, Mic is just ok especially on highways

reviewText: MY CUZ USE IT FOR TRUCK DRIVING
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: You might already know that the Motorola Roadster is a bluetooth hands-free device for your cell phone. A product like this is not so new to us.  However, I would like like to emphasize that the specialty of the Roadster compared to other bluetooth speakerphones.  I love the Roadster for its special features.If you want to use the Roadster as a traditional bluetooth speakerphone, the Roadster is a pretty good one.  My wife has never used an in-car speakerphone like this, and she loves the clarity of the sound and the convenience of the Roadster.  I have more than several bluetooth headsets now (probably 5 or 6), and my wife never used any of them, due to the poor sound quality and the hassle she had to go through to use the headsets.  The Roadster was installed on the visor in her car and did the work it was designed to do without bothering my wife, so she had no reason to hate it.  Once my wife closes the car door to drive out, the little shock made by the door wakes the Roadster up and automatically pairs itself to her cell phone.  When there is a call, the Roadster says the name of the caller if the name is in the address book or reads a phone number if there is no entry in the address book of the paired phone.  And by saying "Answer" or "Ignore", the call is connected or not.  The voice recognition worked pretty well.  What a convenient feature for my wife who does not like to operate electronic devices in the car.What I liked most about the Roadster is that it transmits all the sounds from your phone to the FM radio in your car.  I have a smart phone (Samsung Galaxy S) and frequently listen to internet radio.  And I do not have any auxilary audio inputs in my Prius. The Roadster serves as a great bluetooth-to-FM transmitter.  I would not say the quality of the sound is top-notch, however, the clarity was pretty good.  I have been using a FM transmitter from Monster Cable that got great reviews here on Amazon, however, I prefer the Roadster for its signal strength.The added benefit of the Roadster is that everything is voice-guided.  Even if you have never paired a cell phone with a bluetooth device before, you can follow the voice directions which are very clear and loud.  You should be warned that sometimes the passengers are surprised by the greeting sound of the Roadster when you get in your car with them.  Once you get in the car, the Roadster wakes up and tells you the connection status and the battery level and this might surprise your guests.Selecting FM frequency for the sound transmission is easy and straightforward.  You can change the FM frequency by increments of 0.2MHz manually or the Roadster can automatically find the best frequency for you if you push a scan/seek button.  And the voice tells you which frequency was set for the Roadster and the radio.  The battery life is pretty decent. I charge it only once a week.  If you attach the Roaster on a visor like me, then you should take the Roadster out for a charge, since the length of the included car charger is too short.The one thing that I am still not sure is the battery status that is told by the Roadster.  I thought that it was the battery level of the Roadster, however, it might be the battery level of your phone.  I tested several times and am still not sure which one is right. Sometimes the Roadster says the battery level is low right after a full charge and my cell phone's battery level happened to be low.  That's why I suspect that the Roadster was telling me the battery level of my phone connected to it.Overall, the Roadster is a great motion-sensing bluetooth-to-FM transmitter, and I absolutely love it.  I might buy one more for my other car pretty soon.
title: Motorola Roadster Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The saying "you get what you pay for" holds true most of the time.  Rather than buying an expensive battery for $25+ at a retail store, I bought 2 (for my wife and I) for much less than what I would pay for even one.  They worked flawlessly for the first 3-4 months, and now they can barely last a day with light use.  The stock batteries lasted about 10 months before the same occurred.  From my experience, this is generally true for most of the batteries out there.  These came brand new from what I could tell.  I examined the connectors and they did not have the polished look to them, which is what you get when you plug in batteries into the phone because the connections rub against each other when the battery is slid in.  These might have been just laying somewhere for 1-2 years, which is not that great, but they worked.  The shelf life on these things is around 2 years if you don't use them.Anyways, would I recommend it?  Yes, but don't expect miracles for that price.  They'll work great for the first several months, but after that you might as well buy new ones.
title: Motorola OEM Droid X/MB810 BH5X Battery

reviewText: The description claims this is the exact same brand and model battery as was included with my Droid X (model BH5X). I can confirm the product I received appears to be just that. The manufacture date was marked as 8 months prior to when I received it, so still "fresh". The battery life is almost identical to the original, which is what I expected. I've been switching between the original and this for 4 months and both have been functioning identically.In case someone is interested, there is also an official BH6X extended life battery available for the Droid X. The original is 1500mAh versus the ~1900mAh extended, and you need to a special back cover that might give trouble with my car mount and any aftermarket protective sleeves. Seidio makes one with a whopping 2600 mAh and an even larger cover. But they were both definite no-gos for me when I saw the reviews were less than stellar, and the price was much higher than the dirt-cheap $5 (including shipping) I got this one for.

reviewText: I received a BP7X as an upgrade due to some bad warranty replacement attempts by retails stores; it does provide about 30% more run-time, which effectively gets you an additional half-hour of active GPS navigation, or two hours of 3G browsing.  The replacement door is snug and doesn't really change the shape all that much.  It's subtle.  Trying to get the door off, though, is a nightmare.  It's really machined with a tight tolerance, and there is no good way to slide it off.  The curved profile means your fingers slip off, and you have to be careful that you don't apply too much pressure to the phone as you attempt to force it off.  I'm all for good fits but this is ridiculous.-C
title: Motorola Droid 2 Extended 1800mah Lithium Ion Battery-Snn5875 Bp7x Factory One Year Warranty

reviewText: I usually come on amazon to get discount prices, this battery is nearly the same price as just going into the verizon store. another issue is that it does not come with the door that is required to fit over your droid 2 battery holder. the default cover for the droid 2 will not fit after placing this inside, you will need an extended cover for around 10 more dollars. happy to get this because the droid 2 already drains the battery so quickly. with the new larger battery and cover, it is barely a difference in width, perhaps 1.5milimeters. will show pics.
