reviewText: This is a great Bluetooth headset.it works well with music and video sound.and can link up to 2 phones at the same time.it will give you voice notification of battery level and the devices it is pairing with when you turn it on.the call quality is very good.you can listen to music for 5 hours straight before you need to charge it.as far as just using it on standby for phone conversations.it lasts even longer like 2 days or so and longer if just left on for stand by.I use it for listening to music at work and lasts the entire time.and when charging it.it only takes about 30 to 45 min.to charge from dead battery. Even less if you are just wanting to charge it from medium battery.if you are using it for music or video.I suggest you only pair it with the phone you intend to use.for some odd reason when paired to 2 phones and want to listen to music there are issues with playback.haven't figured that one out.but over all it is a great Bluetooth.it also works good with voice command on your phone.it will give you. Voice instructions on how to use when you have 2 phones paired at the same time.the clarity is Aldo good.people can hear me good and I can hear them good.the range is not bad either.I think maybe 15 feet.I love it its a great accessory to my phone and you will like it to.it also calls names out of who is calling even when your phone is silent.you can answer by voice or reject the call by voice.handy for when you are driving.also has a call button on the back for answering calls if you chose so and for making voice command calls.overall you will not regret this purchaseIt
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have kind of a long history of trying headsets, kind of liking them and then, almost immediately, losing them.  In my experience, they require complex cables (complex in this case usually means a very small plug that is not useful for anything except the headset), rubber or vinyl knobs that are supposed to insert in your ear but often fall off and are lost and not-so-great sound.Let's face it, the reason for a headset is that holding a cell phone to your ear can be a dicey proposition. Cellphones are not designed to be cradled between head and shoulder and whenever I get a call on mine, I usually call back from a landline.  A headset is meant to alleviate this, but by the time I find mine, the call is generally over.The Motorola CommandOne comes (as advertised) in a premium package ("Premium Packaging!").  The box is comes in is a miracle of plastic engineering but it gets thrown away almost immediately.  Looks good on a shelf, but its designed for the purpose of selling the headset without another function.The headeset itself is small, a good sign.  I used to hate the ones that were long and that would hang out away from my head at an angle making me look like I was trying to talk to aliens.  This one fits in the ear and barely extends outward.  It picks up sound very well (almost too well, I made a call outside and ambient noise drowned my voice out for the person I was speaking to).  It also can be quite loud.  The button on the side is easily found and works immediately. I paired it with my Droid phone in about 10 seconds and it has worked nearly perfectly since.As far as cables go, Motorola has engineered this one to accept the same cable that powers my Droid and my Kindle.  In short, the cable is common, not complex and slots easily into the headset.  A little light next to the plug (on the body of the headset) tell you charging status.  While I have not tested the dictation command function, which I have not interest in using, I believe that this item is a really good one.All in all, a great headset.  The only reason I took one star off is that for all the premium packing, the headset did not come with a box or a bag that you could keep and use to store the headset in a bag while you are on the go.  Right now, its loosely floating around in the pocket of my carry bag...not a longevity scheme for something that is relatively small.  I'd have rather paid for less of a package and more of a functional way to stow the headset.If you are looking for a headset, this is a good one and not expensive.  Other than the carrying concern, I am happy with the purchase and will use the item often.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I purchased this phone for the capability to receive GPS instructions and musicI have been totally pleased with the performance and the ease which it will connect (and inform you when it disconnects).  My other Blue tooth devices would not atomatically reconnect.I give it only 4 stars since it went dead and would not charge after two months and I have had my replacement only a week.  I will see how well this one performs.HOWEVER.  Service by motorola was OUSTANDING.  I was on the road, called their toll free number. I explained I only had the device two months but, I did not have the warrantee or the invoice ... The lady said "no problem, we will help" .. reviewText: I've been through a lot of Bluetooth earpieces.  They all either had a short battery life, poor reception, lousy microphone, or some other aspect that wasn't a negotiable for me.  This one has had it all.  Wish I would've found it sooner.  The app that goes along with it is nice too.

reviewText: Motorola regains its shining spot on top of the phone/ accessories market.The motorola CommandOne not only matches the Jawbone and Plantronics top of the line bluetooth headsets, it passes them.  Motorola dominated the market for years as bluetooth headsets struggled to fill their promise of clear easy wireless phone call use.  If you didn't know which model to get then you were always safe with Motorola.Recently, Jawbone came to market with innovative style, comfort and signature noise canceling technology.  For the last few years, the cadillacs of the bluetooth market according to most blog reviews was either made by Plantronic (longtime phone accessory manufacturer) or Jawbone.  Not anymore.I have been using the Jawbone ERA with an Iphone 4.  But after a week of evaluation with the CommandOne, the Jawbone is officially kicked to the curb.The CommandOne Features:CrystalTalk(tm) technology cancels everyday noiseListen and dictate text messages with MotoSpeak(tm) application*Stealth mode microphone cancels wind up to 40mphVoice controls to manage calls by saying "answer" or "ignore"Compared to Jawbone... the noise cancellation on the CommandOne is equal to or better than Jawbone.  For the Jawbone to work, it must be positioned correctly touching your face so it knows what to filter.  The CommandOne accomplishes the same task without the physical contact.  If you are wearing your headset all day or for a long time the Jawbone moves around and loses noise cancellation.  The CommandOne can rest in whatever comfortable position you want and works fantastic.  In several environments, the car, living room with TV on and walking outside I consistently got better feedback from the person at the other end of the conversation.  There was no doubt the people I was speaking to loved the CommandOne and consistently said it was better than the jawbone.On the issue of comfort, there are many ear rubber fitting pieces that come with the CommandOne.  They also include an over the ear loop, if you prefer that position.  But the headset fits comfortably without it.  This headset is so light weight, you will forget you are wearing it. This is an incredible feature.The rest of the features of the CommandOne that really come in handy are the hard buttons on the device.  Aside from volume and start and stop call buttons, there is a mute button and most importantly an On Off Switch.  This saves battery life on both the headset and the phone, when you aren't using it.  This has been my biggest "pet peeve" especially if you want to easily switch to a car system.I was unable to test the text to speech because the programs for that are only on Android and Blackberry devices.  But, with the Iphone it seamlessly connects and disconnects when you need it.Finally, all the top of the line headsets are putting massive speakers into their systems.  This is so you can listen to music or audiobooks or streaming youtube.  The speaker also makes it easier if you need a loud volume headset.  For me, i have listened to music, but just in one ear, its not as satisfying.  However, I find for audiobooks it works really well.This headset is at the top of the price scale, but its added features are worth the extra money.  You will not want a new one in 6 months.  Bluetooth headsets have finally fulfilled the promise of easy wireless accessories.  It couldn't be easier or more simple to use, and it does its job very, very well.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have always had great luck with Motorola headsets and this is no exception to my statement. Great sound quality, only draw back is a way to cancel out back ground noise like on my Motorola Finiti headset. All in all this is a great buy.

reviewerName: Raquel S. "Avid Amazon Fan and Kindle User"
reviewText: My husband works as an over-the-road truck driver. We communicate a lot over our cell phones and rely heavily on our bluetooth headsets. Problem is, the cheaper headsets, while OK if you're in a quiet background, are notorious for picking up irritating background noise. The voice quality is not that great either as it gets muddled into the background noise.Enter Motorola's CommandOne Bluetooth Headset. WOW! I had the opportunity to use this first. I found it much more comfortable to wear and easier to use. I enjoy how the device tells when the status of the bluetooth. I also like how it respond to my voice commands to pick up the phone when it's ringing. It easily connected and worked smoothly with my Samsung Flight A797. I really enjoyed this headset while I had it.Eventually, I gave the Motorola Bluetooth Headset to my husband. I figured this would be the true test on the sound and voice quality of this device. He uses it with his iPhone 4. WOW AGAIN! This bluetooth made a huge difference in the quality of our communication! Way less background noise and more of my husband's voice. It works so well that there are times I ask if he's still there. HUGE difference from the cheap headset he had the last time. (I hated that thing!)However, these are the problems my husband has encountered. The Motorola seems to take longer to connect/reconnect to his iPhone 4. (I did not have this problem with my Samsung, so I'm wondering if the issue is with the iPhone itself.) The rubber piece that covers the charging port falls off. (My husband, despite being a truck driver, is not rough with his stuff and neither is he heavy-handed. This is why I knocked of a star on this otherwise 5-star device.) Other than that, he's been very pleased with his headset. He enjoys his conversations more with way less stress and frustration.The Motorola CommandOne is truly a worthwhile headset consider. It truly does a better job of blocking out background noise while letting in the user's voice. Yes, there are other good features on this headset, but the quality of the voice alone makes this device a winner.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I suppose I should cut the CommandOne some slack since I just noticed per Moto's website after the fact that the iPhone isn't even listed as a "compatible device."  Since this is an iPhone-specific review however (iPhone 4 in particular), here are some things I've found lacking with the unit.  Aside from the fact it belches out the word "Droid" every time it connects, it's larger and doesn't sound as good as mySamsung HM3700 Stereo Bluetooth Wireless Headset(which btw would not get very high marks either given the amount of connection issues I've had with it).  The CommandOne has similar connection issues as the bluetooth connection is dropped periodically (something that rarely if ever happened with my lost and dearly missed Moto 790).  As far as the sound quality, I'm not trying to make this read like an audiophile review of a bluetooth headset but it's loud and trebly and not a device I'd prefer to listen to for an extended conversation.  Conversely, the Samsung 3700 sounded terrific (when it would stay connected).  Battery life seems to be alright and the voice commands are great.  All in all, a solid 3 stars (defined as "OK")...maybe 3.75 (just shy of "I like it") given what I paid for the bulk package unit.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewerName: Richard C. Drew "Anaal Nathra/Uthe vas Bethod...
reviewText: I have a Droid X, and like most smart phones out there, you can use voice commands with the phone. Say "call home"  to call home, or "call office", etc. Well, you can use the CommandOne to send voice commands to the phone - press the call button, and you'll hear your phone's prompt to speak a voice command. Say "call home" (assuming you programmed that into your phone" and the phone will dial.) The phone stays in my pocket or on my belt  - I just tap the call button and speak a command.  Of course you can just say "call" followed by the phone number. The point is, you don't have to touch your phone. That's a feature of your phone, and the CommandOne fully supports it.Sure, you may get some strange looks walking around spurting commands, but it's just so techy. 20 years ago you would have undergone psychiatric evaluation - now it's normal.For incoming calls the CommandOne will speak the caller ID of the incoming call.  You say either "answer" or "ignore" - Ignore will send the call to voicemail.The charger uses the standard mini-USB cable - the same one the Droid uses (and many other newer phones) so you can use the same charger cable (USB from your laptop, for example) - just plug it in and go.  An A/C charger is included - so you can use it with the CommandOne or your cell phone! Nice additional benefit.When you first turn on the CommandOne  you hear a battery status - the CommandOne  actually tells you how full the battery is (there's also a colored status LED.)  Not paired, or cell phone Bluetooth not on? The CommandOne will give you instructions. After you pair, make sure the phone's Bluetooth is on before the CommandOne  is turned on - then you won't hear the instructions- You'll hear "xxx connected". For example, I hear "Droidx connected" - yes, it tries to pronounce Droidx.It's also a wireless headset for listening to music. Pretty much all smart phones support Bluetooth music - the phone will use the CommandOne  as a mono headset.  Not the best quality, but not bad. The music will pause when a call comes in or when you tap the call button, then resume when you're done.Texting: You need to download the free App for your phone (Droid or BlackBerry.) After you install this, the phone will read text messages to you and allow you to reply, automatically converting your verbal reply to a text message.I did have the phone lock up on me a couple of times over a few days - just power-cycling the headset fixed this. This only happened with using the voice commands - my Droid also locks with voice commands without the CommandOne  connected, so I'm prone to blame the Droid, not the CommandOne.Comfort - There are four additional ear adapters included, and you really should try a few different ones.  After finding the best fit I was able to wear the CommandOne  all day with no discomfort.  It's much smaller and lighter than my Jabra - and can be worn with glasses (unlike my Jabra.)Another cool feature - you can pair two different phones.Range - I left the phone in my gym bag and walked over 20 feet away - never lost the connection.Yes it's a bit pricey, but it is very lightweight and feature packed. Well worth the price!
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The manual (if I remember correctly) said had 5 hrs. talk time. Mine is MUCH shorter about 1 (one) hour or slightly more. Other than that pretty good set and I've had MANY in a noisy environment.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have an iPhone. I am not particularly interested in the feature that allows you to receive and send text messages via this bluetooth - and it's a good thing because you don't have that capability with an iPhone.  If that's important to you, you're going to need specific Android or Blackberry phones. Since part if the attraction of this headset is that texting capability and certain voice controls, you really need to make sure in advance this will work with your phone.So why the 5 stars? Because what I care about is the comfort and reliability of the bluetooth. I swear I've gone though at least 10 bluetooth devices in the last few years, and they all hurt after a short period of time. Not so with this one. It's simply the most comfortable bluetooth I've had yet, and I forget I even have it on. And I should add an additional plus is that you really don't notice it on your ear the way you do most headsets - it just doesn't stick out. Because I can use it for hours without any discomfort, because it was so easy to set up and use, and because it comes in loud and clear (even in my car or in a department store), I highly recommend it.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: After receiving this item and charging it up, I paired it to my Android. The very first time I used it I discovered that it had a very tinny sound quality.  I was not pleased and returned to Amazon.  Of course Amazon was great about the return and I purchased the Plantronics Voyager Pro HD. I gave the Plantronics a great review and am still using it.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: What I liked specifically in this headset is that it's designed to be used with an Android phone to do voice texting.Like all voice recognition software, that's a bit hit or miss. It does great on audio versions of texts that are received but homophones and some words come out a little off in the sending texts.I'm using it with Android 2.1Pros-Comfortable- it comes with 5 gels to fit it perfectly. I really hate having things in my ears, but this isn't too objectionable. If you don't mind having things in your ears, it shouldn't bother you at all.  The headset is very light, and the hook is smooth and comfortable even with glasses.Stylishly subtle- If I have to be Borg, I don't want anything too obtrusive. This is a nice matte black that's slim and not at all flashy.Sound quality:Listening- Sound quality is good, and you can turn it up or down either with the phone or the headset itself. So you can adjust as needed for the call you are on.Speaking- There is virtually no pick up of the sounds and conversations around me for the person I'm talking to. Using my phone normally, you can hear more ambient sounds than you do with the headset.Voice commands- Decent set of easy to remember voice commandsCons-Sound qualitySpeaking- sometimes there is a slight hollowness for the person on the other end. It's been compared to talking on a speaker phone.Voice commands- Slight delay, it can take a moment to answer the phone.Android specific- voice texting with MotoSpeak:Outgoing- can get a little garbled. You need to speak in a non-projective clear voice. Occasionally you will wind up sending the wrong word, like where instead of wear.Incoming- It's very good, and very convenient. You can voice activate the headset when a text comes in to hear the text.Being hands free is very convenient. This is easy to set up and use and in the last couple of weeks it's gotten constant use. More than I anticipated originally.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought this to replace my broken Blueant Q2 with high hopes it would be better, or at least just as good. While this is a good BT which connects quick, is loud, and others can hear me fine...even over my work truck which is a Mack Granite dump truck, it's not good when paired the with my GS3. It announces Caller ID name from contacts which is a *must* and battery life seems to just as good or better then the Blueant but it KILLS the battery on my phone. For some reason, I guess because of A2DP, keeps my phone awake through Bluetooth Share. There is no way to disable BT share without killing the caller ID feature. My GS3 loses approx. 5-7% an hour in batt life with no use and cpu continuously runs in intervals...about 1/2 the time total when paired with the commandone. Using the Blueant, I'd lose 2% an hour. All in all, I get maybe 10 to 11 hours out of my phone with the command one while before I was getting 18-20 with moderate use using the blueant. Moto was no help in this matter and neither was thier sparce forums. Other than those gripes, this BT is perfect.Pros: light weightgood batt life (command one)Caller ID name announce/ voice commands/ voice prompts.Fast chargingSpeaker is loud and others hear me fineCons: Kills phone battery while connectedEar cushion has raised edge around it causing ear to hurt after awhileDoesn't make breakfast
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've had the Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth headset for about three weeks.  Although not needed on a daily basis, it has performed admirably when called into duty.  The out-of-box experience and initial setup was painless.  After the initial charge, I was off and running.  The unit paired immediately and simply with my Motorola Droid phone (running Android 2.2).  The headset is light and comfortable enough to wear for extended periods.  Voice commands seem to work well.  I found the sound quality to be excellent, both in terms of listening and speaking.  Prior to getting the CommandOne, I have mostly been using my Droid in "hands free" mode by using the speakerphone.  Although safe while driving, I was forced to speak loudly so that the person I was talking to was able to hear me.  Now, with the CommandOne, I can speak in a normal tone of voice without being drowned out by background noise.  The people that I talk to while in the car have commented on the improvement.I downloaded the MotoSpeak app to my phone to allow text-to-voice and voice-to-text capability.  For the most part, this has worked as advertised.  The incoming text messages announce the name of the sender.  Messages have been read accurately.  I have used the "call the sender" function without any problems.  The return voice-to-text messages have not been as flawless as the incoming messages - sometimes the message is misinterpreted.  That said, it is still a nice feature and will probably get better with practice.All in all, the Motorola CommandOne headset has exceeded my expectations.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought this headset after breaking 2 other headsets and hoping it would work with my HTC One X because not many do.  After reading another review and finding out that you MUST disconnect the headset from the charger before pairing (many thanks to the reviewer who included that tidbit in their review because I was going to return it thinking it was not compatible - OK, it was 3am when I was playing with it), it paired easily and flawlessly.  I tried out the Motospeak 2.0, set up was simple and user friendly and the device paired flawlessly.  Motospeak not only recorded every word I said correctly but repeated the entire text word for word and then asked me if I wanted to send it.  I didn't even have to repeat what I said 5 times like my other headsets, no aggravation and I didn't want to bounce the bluetooth off the wall, it got it right the first time.  The product itself seems to be quality constructed as compared to the other 2 bluetooths I owned and broke due to being cheaply made.  I agree with another reviewer that the call button is a little awkward but the excellent sound quality, command usage, Motospeak software and other benefits easily outweigh that very minor design flaw.  The volume level is crystal clear and perfect.  I'm loving the hands-free driving mode and saying my commands and not having to look at and push buttons on my phone.  I wear the headset around the house all day to answer my phone and texts.  This works perfectly with my HTC One X and I highly, highly, highly recommend it.
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: after one week the thing stop working my wife like it at first but later the Bluetooth stop working would not charge up are turn on are off waste of money Motorola who in the hell made this for you this is not like you to put this s*** out wheres my money back
title: Motorola CommandOne Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I just switched from using a Jabra to this Motorola CommandOne BlueTooth headset.Quality of the sound is cystal clear compared to the Jabra.  Other than it paired with my iPhone easily, was able to listen to Music (but it is Mono not stereo).If you have an Android phone you will be able to make better use of it because of the apps.

reviewText: this is the second one of these i ordered on here. the first one cost me 5 bucks more than this one and it was DOA. the folding prongs were broken right from the start and it would not charge my Xoom at all. the prongs were hard to open and had to force them closed, never seen anything like that with other travel chargerssent it back and ordered this one. when i got it, the prongs folded up great, did not feel broken or no need to force them closed like on the first one i got. now after a month of having it and hardly ever closing the prongs but leaving it plugged in, the prongs wont close and i am not going to force them closed. it still works, just can't close the prongs to use it as a travel charger like it was intendedbottom line, even though this is branded Motorola, it still has its flaws, not that everything Moto makes is perfect :)not sure if both of mine were from a bad batch or not, just beware

reviewText: These earphones worked ok at the begining but they doesn't fit well in my head. After few minutes they are unconfortable and cannot resist for long time. They failed after two weeks of the waranty expiration, the battery no longer charge even using them once per week during 11 months.

reviewText: I really love these for running, outside and on a treadmill. They stay put and work seamlessly via bluetooth and don't need to be charged all that often. Unfortunately, I find that I wish the volume were higher or could go higher - in a row of treadmills which are really loud, I sometimes wish I could turn it up when I am watching videos. After a while, it makes my ears start to hurt from the pressure, but that it is to be expected as they stay pretty snugly on when running.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I really like these and the fact that I can do away with dongling cables when I run.  However, the fit was much tighter than I expected and my head is not overly large--just average.  That said, they bend easily and maybe part of the snug fit is what lets them stay in place so well when I'm on the move.  However, when I pull them on I always have a tinge of concern that I'm gonna pull to far and hear a crack or snap.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Works great sounds great. Haven't killed the battery yet between a charge (avg. 2 hrs). Used, so far, exclusively while gardening, sweat everywhere, but headset keeps on plugging along. I have had no drops except for my phone losing the wifi as I move around my house, which has nothing to do with this headset. Bass response is good enough, but didn't expect body thumping bas from headphones like this. The most important factor next to sound quality was water resistance, and this product delivers. Pairing was relatively easy. As others have complained, wearing glasses might put some pressure on your ears, but wasn't a deal breaker for me. My only complaint is that the retail box was in Spanish (although instruction manual was English) kinda put me off for a second, but I got over it. My only concern is that the built in Lion battery is not replaceable, so unfortunately, these headphones are destined for trash one day in the future, even if you were to protect these with the utmost care, however, it seems that electronics are moving faster toward functional obsolescence. I've owned a few Motorola products and this one delivers just like the rest. 4 out of 5 stars for non replaceable battery.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have been using the Motorola S9-HD's for a couple years but they crapped out on me after 20 months. (my original headset stopped playing one channel at 11 months and I got a replacement under warranty.  The replacement did the same thing after 9 months.)  I liked the 9's.  They were comfortable.  I could wear them for hours.  They were not audiophile quality but they sounded pretty good.So, I needed a new headset.  I ordered the S10-HD and was very disappointed.  The audio quality wasn't near as good as my experience with the S9.  The S10 has little to no low frequency.  Low frequency was pretty good on the 9's.Comfort... NOT!  These were terrible.  I could never forget I had them on.  They hurt.  Way to tight.  I had to take them off after a half hour.Because of the discomfort I used them very little and at 2 weeks all buttons stopped working.  Wouldn't even power up.  So I sent them back for a refund.  If they were comfortable, I would have ordered a replacement.  But, I can't see spending that much money to be miserable.Anyway, I'm going back to the S9-HD.  Even if they only last a year, at least I can enjoy my media with better audio and no pain.Don't Buy the S10.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Very well pleased. Use at work. Very high quality!
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Would rate this a five star but the power cord to recharge is for Europe definitely will not work in the USA.  Otherwise headset is great. Perfect sound and noise cancellation.  No echoing or static.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I used these headphones for a couple of months.  Always on the treadmill while walking and running.  I have small ears and even with the smallest ear buds that they included in the package, they hurt my ears if I wore them for longer than 15-20 minutes, they just feel heavy and cumbersome.  The volume was pretty low, even at the highest setting.I didn't have any issues with sweat getting into them.  And, the battery life seemed to be pretty good. I never let the battery drain all the way, I charged it every week (about 4 hours of use). Connection to my iPhone music source was really good, it never cut out and I could go 20-40 feet away and still have signal, which I thought was great.These are good starter headphones, especially for the price range, but if you have little ears, they may hurt.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I tried the Jaybird Freedom 3 earbuds, the Plantronics Back Beat GO 2, and the Motorola S10. Ultimately, I kept the Plantronics. Although the sound quality was decent, I found the Motorola S10 the worst fit of the 3 I tried. The rigid band was very tight on my head. I may have a somewhat larger than average head (7.5 hat size), but it's not that big. The arms on both sides of my head really felt like they were squeezing my head. The ear pieces were also tight around my ears. The ear plugs were very large and none of the sizes fit well in my ears. They are labeled as earbuds, but the whole assembly is too big to fit into my ear canals.But, the worst problem of all is I could not wear these with glasses while running. The combination of the earpiece and my glasses was very uncomfortable and very tight. I have to take off my glasses and clean them during longer runs and I could not put them back on while wearing the headset. I had to pause my run, take off the headset, put my glasses on, then put the headset back on. When combined with being very uncomfortable, these just weren't worth keeping and I sent them back after just two runs.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I like my bluetooth headphones. Using the Hands-free option to talk on my cell phone is great. The Hands-free option to talk on my phone while walking and traffic passing by is TERRIBLE. You must be in a quiet place to hear your caller clearly and not send noise through the line to your caller. The volume levels are good for music. The bluetooth signal is strong and continuous. The fit of the headphones isn't comfortable. The design of the headset isn't fitting for women. It isn't comfortable or convenient to wear glasses and use the headphones. I will be searching for a more comfortable set of headphones in the future.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: These are great headphones, but they take a little getting use to (my first pair of Bluetooth headphones). They are comfortable, light, seem to last well on a charge, and have no wires!
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: They seem to be robust and well built. They charge OK, nothing lighting quick but do seem to last a while. Volume is OK and adjustable. They seem to work with-in a 20 foot or so range no problem. I wear a 7 1/2 hat (meaning a bit bigger head) and I am comfortable wearing these for 25-30 minutes. and don't really notice them. After that they do start to irritate just above the ear where the pressure is placed to keep them on. It is a harder plastic that they are built from, hence the aforementioned robustness, but that means not a lot flex and pretty good pressure. They are not going to slip off once on, which is good. I saw another reviewer mentioned he flipped his over and that solved the problem. I tried that but found them a bit irritating as they were in the jawline for me and made it so I couldn't turn my head with out being constricted. For me they are keepers, but only because I only run for 25-30 minutes at a time. If I were consistently going longer I don't think I could keep them on.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: what will a good and my phone sounds great but the earbuds hurts your ears after a while

I had the s9 which was my regular workout headphones and running headphones for three years.  they had better bass, better sound and it took two years of heavy summer in dc sweat to break them.  these suckers broke after just two or three jugs and workouts.

reviewText: Highly recommend this.  All functionality works great and they stay put when running.  Motorola makes quality product.  I've used others and they don't work nearly as well.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Had for about 20 months, and the right ear shorted out...little to no sound now.  However, the sound was never great to begin with and bass almost non-existant unless you pushed the buds into your ears and held them there.  The buds are all gigantic, even the smallest ones, so finding a good fit is impossible (would fit snuggly in nostrils though.)  After about 13 months, 2 rubber strips placed just above the ear buds on the side facing the temples, began to slip off exposing wires, etc.  I called the Motorola for a fix and they said they won't cover it, even though it's an obvious design flaw.  I glued it, but it appears the damage was done as sound quality suffered after that.  Battery life was good, but the buttons were very finicky.  You have to press hard and some times several times to get the volume up or down, or to skip, and that was an issue from day one.  The volume never got that loud, ANY outside noise would make it diffcult to hear.  Partly due to volume itself and partly due to poor fitting earbuds.  In comparison to standard apple headphones, the volume and sound quality were HORRIBLE...but avoiding wires while running or at the gym was worse the sacrafice of sound.I would NOT recommend this to anyone.  Motorola's consumer products in general aren't nearly as good as Sony or LG.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I am one of those people who do not like earbuds. They are just not that comfortable and fall out of my ears. Consequently I am just as likely to wear a pair ofRCA HP5043 Ampz On-Ear Headphones - Gray/Blackaround the house when no else wants to hear audiobooks that I mainly listen while in the car. This looks stupid however particularly outside home, say at the grocery store.Bluetooth headphones solve part of the problem, You still look slightly dorky, but the effect is not as pronounced. They are slightly less comfortable than wired headphones which means they are decidedly more comfortable than earbuds.The sound quality is excellent, an attribute one seeks in all portable audio. For those concerned with comfort and dorkiness these are a great option.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: as a head phone its very nice but not as a Bluetooth because the other person hear a lots background noise, shipment on time and price is good thanks.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I ordered this headphone to replace a similar model from a different company that had quit working after less than a year.  The battery would no longer hold a charge.The Motorola feels like it's much better made, and not as fragile as the one from the other company (iKross).  It slips over my ears easily (over the earpieces of my glasses), and fits comfortably.  It rides well, and does not slip out of my ears.  It has better sound as well.  The control buttons are much superior.  Instead of having three buttons that have multiple functions controlled by the number of times you click, the S10 has seven buttons - three on each earpiece (easily located) and one on the underside of the part that goes around the back of your head which you push to activate your bluetooth connection, also easily located.  The buttons on the left side control your volume (top and bottom), the middle accepts a phone call.  On the right, the upper and lower buttons take you to the next or previous track, while the middle one puts your music on pause.Since I primarily use this while I'm riding my bicycle, it seems to be the perfect headphone for me.  I can listen to my music, but still hear enough to be aware of a car sneaking up on me, I can quickly and easily change tunes or volume with just one easily located button click, or answer a call.  It's well sealed, so sweat should not affect it.  Only time will tell about the durability of the battery, but if it lasts two years I'll be satisfied and would purchase a replacement.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have had these for about six months and here are my observations:* Paired easily with my iPod touch.* Lightweight but awkward to initially fit right. Tended to be tight and uncomfortable until they were broken in. Unfortunately, by the time they were comfortable, the red grips on the inside of the arms started to fall out and leave adhesive everywhere. This happened despite never having used them in a workout or outdoor environment.* Audio is typical Bluetooth audio.* Worked ok as a hands free headset for voice/VoIP calls.* Controls were unintuitive and difficult to master.* Battery lasted 4-5 hours of continuous use.Bottom Line: I would NOT recommend these unless they were $20 or less and you were looking for a disposable wireless headset experience. There are currently way better options available at this price point. I suggest you explore them.UPDATE: Motorola provided a warranty exchange of my headphones. The customer support representative seemed to be aware of this issue and handled my exchange without incident. The replacement item appears to be new and not refurbished. Hopefully, they will last a little longer than my original set.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: At first, they were pretty good, but it you wear them too long, they hurt your ears. Also, within a few months, they started to fall apart. Things peeled and glue wore off. Parts just started to disappear. Not worth the $50 that I once spent on them...
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have been searching Amazon for a headset I could  use while riding my bike, so of course, I wanted something that would stay put, comfortable and sound good. And I found this piece, which honestly speaking, is not bad, but it does have some flaws and sound issues.The headset comes in the retail box with three pairs of ear plugs; one installed, two on the side. A charger and a small instructions booklet.Charging the unit is easy, simply flip the rubber cover at the back of the heaset, plug the usb cable, the light on the headset will remain red until it is fully charged, turning blue.Pairing the headset is very easy. Turn the bluetooh on your device (Galaxy 3 in my case), do a scan and voila, you're done. I didn't need to enter the standard "0000" code, the phone allowed it to connect right away.The headset has all the buttons needed to control your music and phone calls, on the left side you have the volume and phone buttons, on the right, you have the play/pause and tracks buttons.Comfort:I wore these puppies for about 7 hour on and off. Comfort wise, it's a hit and miss, and it all depends on how you place the headset, but I did notice that if you have average to above average size ears, this headset can be a bit painful to wear. Again, this can be avoided to a certain degree with how you wear them. The instructions say to firs put the headset on an upward position with the back of it in fron of your face, then slide it over your head towards the back of your neck and let them sit on your ear. Problem is, if your ears are not under the loop, they will get pinched. Also, if you have a big head, they might press against your head.I'll say this, they stay put, but you have to make sure you have the right size plugs on them, so they sit on your ear canals and not in them, more on that later.Sound:Just ok. They lack bass, but have the right amount of mids and highs. The biggest let down for me was the lack of volume, but I'm not sure if this was due to the phone or the headset, but probably a combination of both, point is, I felt the headset could use more punch and higher levels, I need this for long bike rides, I mountain bike, so I don't have to worry about traffic and such. There are just a couple of equilizer settings that are supported by bluetooth technology, at least on my end. For example, I couldn't get the extra bass setting to engage, it kept telling me that it wasn't compatible with bluetooth. I was able to get Rock, Pop, Normal, pretty much every other settings beside extra bass and treb. Sound quality also depends, at least for me, on how the ear plugs fit; I was under the impression that the deeper they're in, the better the sound, well, I learned my lesson, it turns out that for somebody with average size ear canals, the pre-installed plugs are perfect and will transfer sound much better; they sit at the entrance of the ear canals, covering them, but not going in all the way. With the pre-installed plugs, the sound was much richer and solid. When I had smaller size plugs, the sound was extremely flat and lacked definition. With high quality files, the sound is much better, but not enough to give this headset a higher rank. Low quality files or older tunes, do not sound great, they're decent.Controls:A bit on the stiff side ; they require some getting used to. They can't simply be pressed, you must place between your thumb and index, then press down, or you'll be pressing against  your ear, which can be painful and distracting.Phone Calls:Very clear. As you receive a call, you will hear a very subttle gingle on the headset, so you will hear this, plus your phone's own ring, unless of course, your phone is on vibrate.Range:Very impressed. I was able to walk around the house with no signal drops. Of course, as I turned corners into rooms that were in a more intricate part of the house, I noticed a drop. But as far as actual range, these things are amazing. Needless to say, while I had the phone and headset close together (pocket, biking pack, etc), the signal is extremely good/strong.Sunglasses:Not so great. I have a few pairs of oakleys, I have the Juliets, 5 Square and Half Jacket...With both the half jacket and 5's it was a mess, they kept popping outward in front of my face, they both have plastic frames. With the Juliets, which have a metal frame, it was much better in regards to them staying put, but not so comfortable overall. In conclusion, you may have some problems with glasses and will depend on their shape.In conclusion:I ended up giving the headset to my wife, who is a small girl and loves to listen to music while walking our dog and when she's doing things around the house. I give this set a 3 star ranking, because they do work and credit's due where it's due. I will however, keep on looking for the right set for my needs. Something comofortable that also sounds great, which sadly, the S10-HD does not provide.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I own theMotorola S305 Bluetooth Stereo Headset, which I have been using happily for a year or so, but I wanted a second, in-ear pair of Bluetooth headphones for several reasons.  So I have nothing against Motorola products. Indeed, Motorola has always been my go-to brand for Bluetooth -- in addition to the S305, I've bought theMotorola DC800 Bluetooth Stereo Gateway, aMotorola H700 Bluetooth Headset, and aMotorola HS850 Bluetooth Headset.Let me also add that, unlike some reviewers who discovered as much late, I knew how these headphones were supposed to fit from the get-go -- looped over the ear.Yet even when worn properly, these headphones still cause an incredible degree of discomfort. The band is stiff and heavy, which it presumably needs to be inasmuch as it contains the electronics (unlike the S305s, whose electronics are contained in the on-ear portion). Given this relative inflexibility, it binds the mastoid bones just behind the ear. This is a indeed an unpleasant and uncomfortable sensation. If you like the sensation of having your head in a vice, these are the headphones for you.In addition, none of the four provided earpieces provided me with a decent fit, let alone a comfortable one. I know in-ear earbuds, how they should fit, and how they affect the sound. Earbuds should slide easily into one's ear, but should not be too loose (unless you like tinny sound) or too tight (unless you like discomfort). The ideal fit provides both a nice, comfortable seal and a decent sound with good low frequency response. These earpieces provided neither. Three are uncomfortable, and one is too loose.To add insult to injury, the sound is decidedly subpar, certainly compared to the S305 (which, in my book, are simply adequate). No matter which earpieces one uses -- even ones with a tight (albeit uncomfortable) seal that presumably should aid with low frequency response, there is very little bottom. If I were to guess, I would say that the frequency response drops off a good 12 dB below 120 Hz, irrespective of earpiece. I have other, wired earbuds that have come with my various devices, and I've never had a problem choosing buds (either as shipped or from the extras provided) that both fit and improved the low-end.I have yet a couple of other quibbles, neither of which I would call minor. The power button is essentially a 1/8th inch rubber-embossed screw head on the bottom of the band and requires a significant amount of pressure, and provides little feedback. All of the other control buttons (pause/play, ffwd, rev, call/answer) are on the ends of the band just above the earbuds, and are similarly small, rubber-embossed press switches, so unless you place a finger behind the bottom of the band, you end up pushing the earbud deeper into the ear. Ow.In sum, this headset is an extreme disappointment in design and performance. Even if you could somehow adjust to the fit and discomfort, you are left with the inferior sound. Look elsewhere if you want in-ear buds -- and let me know if you recommend something else, because I am currently looking. (UPDATE: I have since purchased theLG Tone HBS-700 headset-- it is amazingly comfortable, cleverly designed, and -- with the right earbud size -- has more than decent sound.) If you don't care about in-ear/on-ear, you'll find that the S305s, despite the on-ear miniature hockey puck look, are much more comfortable and provide much better sound.I have been an Amazon customer since 1997 (1995 if you count CDNow, which Amazon took over). I have bought many different electronic and audio devices from Amazon, and I've never had to return any of them.As they say, there's a first time for everything.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Initially I loved these headphones.  They fit great, were lightweight & just what I was looking for.  Sound quality was okay, not great, but did the job.  However, after 5 months of light usage, they simply stopped turning on.  No power, no matter how much I charged them, etc.Avoid these & look for better quality.  Motorola is no longer top notch in bluetooth creation.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: ... and it's the first set of BlueTooth headphones to work correctly with my 2011 17" MacBook Pro. I have bought and triedSony Ericsson Hi-Fi Bluetooth Stereo Headset with FM RadioandLG Tone - HBS-700 Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange. Both those lose connection while I'm working out on myNordicTrack Sequoia Skier (Ski Machine). Even more importantly, both those are extremely difficult to make the connection in the first place. In fact, I actually got so frustrated with the HBS-700s I smashed 'em with a mallet!My MBP is about 30-feet away in the living room, while I'm working out in the bedroom, both on the 2nd floor. I took the S10-HD out of the package, charged them fully (per manual), set the MBP to connect via BlueTooth, turned on the S10-HD holding down the power button until the blue light became steady, and they connected. I am able to walk all over the house, including on the 1st floor!!!! No breaking-up of connection, works perfectly! They are a bit tight, but they do not fall off. I wore them for 1.5-hours yesterday during my workout and not problems.I bought the S10-HD refurbished from woot.com for thirteen bucks!!!! Wish I'd bought fifty of 'em.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Solid design, amazingly good bluetooth range/signal, generic micro usb charging port, and best battery life for a stereo usb headset w/mic.I did eventually switch to the Jaybird Freedom because its more pocket and helmet friendly but sadly I had to sacrifice 50% of the battery life and the amazing bluetooth antenna in this thing.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: update from below, after a year: not as moisture resistant as needed to endure a good sweaty workout or lawnmowing session.  The controls stop working once the sweating starts.  On the bright side, they recover once they dry out and havent TOTALLY fritzed out like the last model did.  They are still working.Droped a star...for the bluetooth headsets I've had, average.*********************************June 30 2011Had the set for a couple of days.  Was prepared to return immediately if the reviews were correct, but I'm not disappointed (horribly) yet.Pro:  Sound is GOOD.  Perhaps not quite as good as the S9 models, wont replace your BOSE QC's, but DEFINITELY GOOD enough for mobile, running/workout headphones.  I don't get the "tinny" reviews; perhaps those folks are using low bit-rate music...and these are the first headphones that were good enough to pick it up?Construction certainly FEELS more solid.  I haven't tested the "water/sweat resistance" yet...will get to that...in due course.The Blue-tooth reception seems stronger with these.  The 9's had issues with a laptop sitting at arms length...not these.Cons:The controls are hard to push, and they are located RIGHT OVER THE EAR so when you push on them, you are jamming the earbuds deeper in the ears.  Motorola should re-locate these controls to the down-loop right BEHIND the ear...so it pushes on the knobby part of the back of your head...would be MUCH nicer there.These are a little bulkier than the S9's.  They still wear well, but are shaped different on the back, stand out a little more, and seem a little heaver.  But, again, still WEAR WELL...just as good as, or more snugly even then the S9's.Pairing with multiple devices, at least a computer and an iPhone doesn't go smoothly.  Pairing with the computer is "FUN" to figure out (make sure you go into blu-tooth devices and check the "headphones" box) and the will work fine, but will select an iPhone over the computer if it has information for both.  Had to turn the blu-tooth off on the phone to get the computer to pick it up.They went with the new "slim" USB power jack.  Why?  This probably annoys me the most.  How many different chargers do we need???Anyway, as my stars indicate:  they've got the basics down.  If they don't FRITZ out when I sweat on them...I'm a happy camper!  Fix my cons...and you'll get the fifth star (Motorola).
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: These are the first pair I have owned. I love them though, they are light weight and the sound is great

reviewText: I do like these bluetooth headsets better than the other two pair that I've owned, but they're not without some problems.  The good thing is that these stay connected to my phone the whole time.  Some of the others would lose their connection when I paused my music for very long.  However, they don't have as much bass as some of the corded headphones that I've used, and with the way that they're designed, the sweat does run down my hair onto the arms and into my ears.  I have to take them out and wipe the sweat off.  Still, I'd recommend these because they have served me well for many months now.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought this headset knowing that I would mainly use it during work outs. At first I was not sure out the fit or form factor as I have seen much more slim and light weight head phones, but after using them for a month I am generally very happy with these headphones. When I first put them on I was worried that they were putting too much pressure on the sides of my head, but I think that akward feeling goes away quickly because I was not used to it. Also I am sure they stretch out a little bit. The fit and feel may scare some people away, but I have been using them for over a month both on a treadmill and also doing a lot of weight lifting and these headphones have yet to fall off or feel uncomfortable. Most of the time I forget they are even there, only sometimes needing to adjust the back of the headphones, which sometimes does fall a little low on your neck. I think the thing I like most about these headphones are the number of controls on the device. I really like having a pause/play button on the headphones, that way I can pause my workout if I need a water break or to change my weights around. It has a total of 6 buttons, 3 on each ear. It does take some learning to know which is where, and it took me a few days to learn how much pressure to push on the buttons, because it seems as if the water resistance method of sealing the buttons makes them harder to press than other headsets. Also, I like that I can press down the call button on the left ear side and it activates my voice dialers on my phone (Google Now on my Android phone). So overall I was very suprised by how much I like these headphones. The controls are great, they are water resistant so I dont worry about sweat ruining them, the distance for the bluetooth as I can walk across the gym and they are still streaming audio, and they do a good job of staying on my head even when I am running or doing heavy cardio. The only bad thing about them is probably the oversized rear of the headset where the battery is stored. If they could slim that down a bit they would be perfect. I also seemed to get a solid 5-6 hours of streaming time on the battery.BONUS TIP: These work very well in my garage when I am doing wood working with loud tools. I simply put these on, stream my audio, and then put on some over the ear protective headphones and I can hear my music perfectly while still protecting my ears from damage of loud power tools.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've owned my S10-HD headphones for about 10 weeks.  I bought them specifically for running, and from my perspective they are great for that.  I've probably run about 80 miles with them, in addition to using them to listen to music at other times.  I really like not having a corded headset while running.  Earbuds tend to fall out after I get a good sweat going and I don't like the cord bouncing around.  So these are ideal for this purpose.  It will only pair with one device at a time (iPad, iPhone, etc.), which is a tad annoying, but I don't know if that's part of the Bluetooth specification or something that Motorola did.  You can perform a factory reset in about a minute, so it's not a huge deal.Regarding issues with sweat, I've probably run about 12 hours with the headphones and in that time and I have had zero issues with sweat causing them to malfunction, and let me be clear, I run in a region with 70-95% humidity, so there is plenty of sweat.  I cannot account for the problems that others have had, but it hasn't been an issue for me.  The one issue I have had with sweat focuses on the earbuds.  The headset comes installed with the largest set.  When I ran with those after about 20 minutes the sweat and the bouncing of my body would produce a popping sound in my ear from the earbuds.  I changed to the next smaller size and the problem disappeared.Another complaint I've read about is the fit.  I wouldn't say I have a small head or a big head.  Mine is more oval than round.  The headphones fit me fine, but if my head were a cm wider, I'm not sure they would still fit well.  Unfortunately they are not adjustable.  If they don't fit return them.Finally, a word about the sound quality.  I think it's very satisfactory considering it's wireless earbud technology.  I'm not an audiophile, but I am an information technology professional, and one piece of advice that I give to my customers is wired is always going to be better than wireless in terms of overall performance.  You go with wireless (whatever) for convenience at the cost of some quality.  If you're looking for concert-hall quality sound or have a very fine ear, these are probably not what your looking for.  As I said before, I think they are very decent, but if accoustical quality is your thing then get a pair of Bose or Sennheiser wired headphones.Overall, for what I purchased them for, which is running, I am very satisfied.  I wish I could pair them with both my iPad, iPhone, and laptop simultaneously, but I can live with resetting.  The fit could be a bit looser, but again, it's not a show stopper for me.I hope you enjoy yours.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I love these things. They are a very tight fit but work great and the battery life is amazing. I'm a 6"2 250lb guy so I'm pretty big and these fit, tight, but they do fit. I never leave home without them
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Reset is the volume + button pressed at the same time as the On/Off Button - then the light will be blue...then pair with phone and or computer..this headset is great - I  can walk around the house and the both yards and cut the grass etc... with my phone indoors and me outside...Ride my bike with phone in my pocket.. works great, actually gonna pick up another to keep.now one thing - I have an app on my phone that prevents me from dialing by accident, this is a problem when I use voice commands, but can disable the app and it will work fine...i have big ears but when I put them on I just drag the flesh through the opening and they fit fine.when I golf I listen to some great tunes and can still have a conversation with my friends..anyway, learn the reset thing, I was perplexed until I read that and all is good now..
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: There are many people on here who defend this headset. They claim  that people who buy this product expect too much from it, especially if you are comparing it to a wired headset. True, you are dealing with a wireless headset. They claim that folks shouldnt try it for just one day and send it back because they haven't really had the time to use it. People say the sound quality is better than iPod earbuds...Look yall, I gave this two stars...one for amazon and their great service and one for the interesting design of the headset. For those who purchased these headphones as your first ever Bluetooth headphone purchase (not talking about Bluetooth headsets that just go in your ear and are mainly for communication) like myself, I think majority of you will come to find out that these suck. For my head, which is big but not too large, the fit was absolutely horrid. I even put in the smallest eargel in the attempt a decent fit seeing as my ears are small as well. The sound was trash. I didn't expect beats quality, but I expect some sort of HD sound. No bass, no range, just garbage. The volume was kinda trash too. I wouldnt recommend these at all.Maybe I'm mad because I paid $60 for them, and maybe I am over reacting because they are in fact, a wireless headset, so I shouldnt expect at least a vmoda type experience. All I know is I'm sticking to wired headphones. Cables don't really bother me anyway .
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought the S9 a few years ago and they were perfect in terms of comfort and performance and then they died after about a year from the usual sweat problems. They could still be used if they were dried out for a few days but being only able to use them every few days wasn't a solution. I went wired for about 18 months and then found the S10s.They arrived last week and I've used them a few times while working out though not for running. They feel heavier and tighter than the S9s. I have to work the top of my ears carefully under the top loop part of the S10 so that I don't feel pinched. The feeling that I get is that the back part is heavier than on the S9 and the added pressure amplifies the feeling back there. One other downside is that the buttons are harder to press. On the S9, the buttons were bigger and easier to find and press. On the S10, they are small are require more pressure to press.It is possible that it loosens up over time so I will give it a chance.I also get the feeling that the newer unit is much, much better at keeping sweat out. The seals seem to be better and some of the negatives in UI that I wrote about may have been due to compromises to improve durability.The S9s are still for sale and I'm tempted to buy another pair of those and alternate between the two - I'm hoping that the S9 would last longer if it were left to completely dry out after each use. I will write an update on the S10 in a few months. The earlier versions of these were terrible WRT durability but they work reasonably well if you're willing to replace them from time to time. The S10 could be a lot better at this - time will tell.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Well, I'm so sorry, but I had to return these.I was aware that there were fitting issues with this headphones. But I never ever expected them to actually hurt. I read the reviews and the positive ones said that if you get the right fit, this headphones work wonders. I tried everything to make them fit, I tried every earbud combination, I googled for the instructions, watched the videos, did everthing I could. Then I realized that a product that makes you work this hard to even use it is not worth the hassle.I'm sorry, but these earphones are meant for a childs head, not a 5' 8 medium built adult. The first 15 minutes were tolerable, but after that they felt like something was piercing my ears. I felt a great deal of relief as soon as I took them off. Maybe they needed time to "break them in", like new shoes? Well, after 2 weeks of everyday use, they were as painful as day one.Sound quality is OK. Not great. I've seen this particular design featured on several websites, under different brand names. Most of them were on the cheap side. Maybe this is a rebrand on those?For all intents and purposes, they are not worth the money, the are not worth the pain, the are worth NOTHING.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Edited 06/24/2012So the headset is worse and worse by day. Since my last post, the headset now skips through tracks. It makes my Iphone sound like a broken walkman CD Player when a CD skips. It also takes me a while to turn the headset on. The power button may take me a few minutes to turn on. I now give this second headset 1 start because it skips, the hardware and buttons malfunction, and it is hardly reliable. Shop around before buying this one.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Edited 06/02/2012So Since my last post, I lost full functionality of the track up key on the headset and the volume up button. These are 2 of the most important buttons for me on the headset. I called Motorola and they cover the headset for 1 year from the date of purchase by manufacturers warranty. I do have to pay for shipping in sending the headset back to them. If not They charge me for incidentals. I was disappointed I had to pay anything knowing that there headset malfunctioned.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Edited 05/23/2012 after a few Months of UseThe Headphones sound great and are more comfortable as you break them in. They have a decent battery life. I;m getting 3 to 4 days of gym time a piece. My biggest complaint why my rating went from 5 to 3 to 2 stars is that the Track Up button stopped working all of a sudden. It is either not waterproof as claimed, or there is a hardware issue as I have found with most Motorola products. Even though it has this issue, the sound quality, and sync ability to blue tooth makes this one of the only options on the market for Hands Free Gym Sweat Proof Headphones. For this reason I most likely will by another one when this one dies. It may seem like a confusing review, but Motorola produces many products with hardware defects, like my old Droid Phone, and their headphones. It still is a great product aside from its shortcomings, but needs improvement.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I previously bought these for my brother. I figured they were the latest and greatest for him. I recently bought these because my Motorola S9-HD's gave out and wouldn't turn on. These headphones are alright. I found that the S-9's had more bass and better overall sound quality. Also the s-9's were more comfortable. This one gives you different ear buds and is a little tight on the head and ears to the point where if you do not have the right tips on, it hurts your ear. I bought this model mainly for the gym. I figured it would take more sweat and so far it seems to.Pros:-Sweat Proof?-Longer Battery Life-Syncs to Iphone much quicker than S9-HD'sCons:-Sound Quality drops slightly from S9-HD's, possibly more acoustic.-Lack of Bass compared to S9-HD's.-Tight Fitting and Uncomfortable at Times. Will break in over time though, it's rubber.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have owned the Motorola Rokr S9, then the S9-HD and now these S10-HD.The S9 sounded great and worked great but eventually sweat from wearing them while running killed them so I bought the S9-HD and never used them while working out to avoid the same fate. The S9-HD also works and sound great (bass mid range & treble are all great).They were both a little snug fitting and required some tweaking to get them to fit without pinching but aside from that I loved them (still own the S9-HD).Imagine my surprise when I bought and opened the S10-HD and found that not only was it even smaller and tighter as other users are complaining of, it has been made so it is no longer possible to adjust them to relieve the pinching at the back of your head (I haven't even tried to adjust them where they pinch your ears).The sound is something that I'm STUNNED even allowed these to make it from developement to market.I can only describe the sound as something coming from a transistor AM radio. If you think I'm kidding you should pick up a pair.I'm glad my S9-HD still works.UPDATE: In order to give these headphones a fair shake I assumed there MUST be a problem since Motorola couldn't possibly risk their reputation by turning out a product that wasn't even up to par with the previous two iteration, I called Motorola who told me how to reset the headphones.While the reset seemed to improve the audio to the point where they actually sound great, the inability to adjust them to fit will definitely prevent me from wearing them.For those that want to try the reset... first delete the pairing from whatever device you paired your headphones with.Power the headphones on, Hold down the volume + button and hold down the Power button at the same time until the blue light is steady near the power button.Now pair your device with the headphones again and try it out.
title: Motorola S10-HD Bluetooth Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is a great headset, very functional and does exactly what it claims. I used to own an S9 headset and loved it, the sound quality and fit of this version is infinitely better, it is clearly the best alround bluetooth headset out there.
