reviewerName: Amazon Customer "I'm paranoiac in reverse - I...
reviewText: This little machine does exactly what the title says - it charges your battery only. For my husband, who is constantly on the road for his work, it's very easy to run a battery down completely during the first half of his work day. He bought two spares, and keeps them charged on this little gizmo, and never has a problem with dead batteries anymore. It's really awesome to have around, and makes the day that much easier, knowing that you've got the security of always having a charged cell phone.On a side note, when you put a battery on the charger, it "sings" you a little song to let you know it's charging. Its very, very quiet, and at sort of a high frequency, but it's a definite melody! Kinda neat!

I also have *not* experienced the reported Moto G "sudden death" battery issue (X % to 0% all of a sudden) when using this / after charging with this charger.

reviewText: Motorola USB Charger and CableI have a bunch of Belkin 1A USB chargers that I noticed would not charge my Kindle Fire HD! I grabbed ALL of my USB chargers and went through each one to see which of them would work on the KFHD. The Samsung 1A charger from my Galaxy S3, the Motorola 0.85A charger from my Motorola Droid 2, and a 0.85A charger from a LG phone were the only ones that worked properly. My Galaxy S3 would charge fine from any of the Belkin chargers, but I needed a travel charger that I could bring with me. As a result I ordered another of the Motorola chargers from Amazon, and this works perfectly with the KFHD. It may not be a "fast charger", but it charges it up to 100% without any drama even on the KFHD without any error messages.Overall: 5/5 stars, very very good price, works perfectly, great quality. May be only rated at 0.85A, but charges up my Kindle Fire HD 7" perfectly fine.UPDATE 29 JUL 2013:This charger works on the Go Pro Hero 3, Sony Action Cam, Kindle Touch, Kindle Fire HD 7", Samsung Galaxy S3, FujiFilm XP200, Motorola MotoActv, and BlackBerry Bold 9900 (the BB was REAL picky about chargers).UPDATE 28 AUG 2013:Using a Kill A Watt meter, I recorded 6.0 Watts with the Kindle Fire HD 7" (no error messages were observed, it charges up the KFHD just fine), 5.9W with the BlackBerry Bold 9900/9930, and 5.2W with the FujiFilm XP200 camera. This charger is not rated at a full 1.0A, but my Samsung S3 charger (which is rated at 1.0A / 5VDC for USB) consumed 7.7W of power charging the KFHD7" and 7.5W with the BlackBerry. Assuming equivalent charging voltages, there is roughly a 0.3A different in current output between this Droid2 charger (rated at 850mA) and the Samsung S3 charger (rated at 1.0A).
title: Motorola USB Wall Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging (Black)

reviewText: This charger works as described for charging devices with a Micro-USB connection, but the nice feature is the detachable cable that can be used as a USB data cable or for charging your device off a computer USB port.  I have a phone that charges from a Micro-USB connection with a charger that has a fixed cord, so it is only good for charging that device from the wall plug.  I have another phone that charges from a Mini-USB connection with a charger that has a fixed cord, so it is only good for charging that device from the wall plug.  I can charge either phone from a PC USB port with the right cable.  This charger allows me to switch cables with the wall plug so that I can charge either phone from the wall or the PC USB port, without packing two corded wall chargers and two data cables.  Good for traveling or good for a spare charger, depending on your needs.  It should work with any device that has Micro USB charging capabilities, such as a Kindle.  850mA/5.1v.

reviewText: I like this Motorola charger. I like that it is compact, charges well and has double-sided spurs to secure the connector into my phone. However, I don't like the price.My smartphone is an LG Optimus model. Last month, I returned to the local Radio Shack where I bought the phone to replace its charger (it burned out after six months). After a horrible customer service experience, I vowed never to return. So, I came home, logged into Amazon and found theOEM LG (Original) AC Wall Adapter Home Charger w USB Data Cable for Verizon LG Dare VX9700. The charger is sold by BobTronics for less than $4 with free shipping (89 percent cheaper than the after-market charger sold by Radio Shack). The new charger arrived in three days and continues to work perfectly.Now, I like thisMotorola P557 USB Wall Charger with Micro USB Data Cable, which I received for free as part of the Amazon Vine program. Compared to the other charger, the Motorola unit is more compact and, most importantly, has those double-sided spurs which help maintain a steady charge.Is the Motorola charger $25 better? No.Here is where I struggle to raise my review above the three-star level. You could purchase nearly six of the cheaper chargers for about the same cost as one Motorola charger. While I have no doubt that the Motorola charger is more durable, I can't guarantee it will last 5x-6x longer than the cheaper option.Rating: Three stars.
title: Motorola USB Wall Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging (Black)

reviewText: I bought a generic charger for a couple of dollars, and thought that was all a charger could be.  Then I got this, and was really impressed, even though I discovered that I had been wrong all along. First of all, the charger was designed by someone who actually paid attention to how people actually use it. The plug/USB connection is on the side of the device, which keeps the USB cord from being knocked out or damaged. It's profile as it sticks out from the wall is markedly less than that of the cheapie charger.It also works more quickly than my generic charger for a reason I can't determine.  At first, I thought that I was imagining it, and that all chargers work at the same pace.  So I timed charging my cell phone from dead empty to a complete charge. The Motorola charger took 40 minutes less than my generic charger, which was a good 20% quicker.That sealed the deal for me. I'll ignore any/all advertisements for chargers that aren't backed up by a trusted name, like Motorola.
title: Motorola USB Wall Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging (Black)

reviewText: Nice to have backups of these cables as an insurance policy. Those large screen androids eat up lots of battery power. One for the car, one for home, one for work, one for SHTF. They work as advertised
title: Motorola USB Wall Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging (Black)

reviewText: This travel charger has the Motorola logo on it and was specifically made for Motorola smart phones.  It appears to be identical to the charger that was bundled with my Motorola Droid X.  It's rated to work with 120/240 volts 50/60 Hz.  With adapter plugs I can use this device to charge my phone using virtually any electrical outlet in the world.  The included detachable USB cable is also handy to tether my phone to the USB port on my computer for data transfer.  This charger will also power any USB device that requires up to 850mA.  The 2.3 ounce weight for both the charger and the cable is no burden to carry.  I keep them in my computer bag and believe that if I use an authentic Motorola accessory that is made for my phone there is less risk of damage.

reviewText: This basic mobile-device charger has a small adapter, a detachable cord, and provides 850mA output power.The adapter's "block" cleanly fits on a power strip without obstructing the adjacent outlet, the cord can be swapped out for a different connector (eg, miniUSB), and 850mA is enough to properly charge most smartphones (although might be on the low side for tablets).Chargers don't always include a cable, making the microusb one included in this kit a nice touch, since I like to keep a cable in each of my travel bags, as well as in each of car/office/home/workplace.  But, the cable is on the short side for home use, barely long enough to reach from the power-strip to my nightstand.A name-brand charger that does the job: you might look for a cheaper generic model, but other than the relatively high price, Recommended.

reviewText: So, you've got a Motorola phone that needs a Micro USB charger?  Or a Kindle?  Or one of the myriad of other devices that use Micro USB nowadays?  Well, this Moto charger will take care of that. Also, since the USB cable is removable, you can use another USB cable (say mini- USB, or Apple device) and use that to charge something like a PS3 Dual Shock controller or something.  It's 850 mA output won't charge an iPad however.  I like wall chargers that have that flexibility.The current wall chargers that have been coming with Moto phones (Droid RAZR, Droid4) are much smaller, and have two USB ports, along with folding prongs, which are very compact and handy, especially when traveling, but this is a basic wall charger that can be used as a spare, or at work just fine.  Keep a couple USB cables for charging whatever you need to.  If you find the new charger, get that one instead, but this will do you just fine unless you need to charge more than one device at once.

reviewText: This works as a fair replacement compared to the more expensive ones. It will work for any product that has a micro usb port. reviewText: This Motorola dual charger gets the job done.  I previously had a Motorola auto charger that had a single micro USB output.  It worked pretty well; however, the cable wasn't detachable -- if you didn't have a micro USB input on the device you were trying to charge, you were sunk.This dual charger, which does include a USB to micro USB cable, provides much more flexibility.  Not only can my wife and I charge our phones at the same time, but we can swap out the cables and, using other cables, charge our daughter's Nintendo DS, etc.The charger will top off our phones (Samsung Galaxy SII) pretty quickly.It seats securely in the 12 volt outlet and has an LED indicator to show the electrical connection with the car is in effect.In all, it's a fine charger.  The detachable cable makes it easier to store and gives it the flexibility that many people need given the broad assortment of gadgets in our lives these days.  Because it has two outlets, it lets those of us swimming in gadgets to keep them charged.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This charger might be a little bulky for some people but it works like it should.  Nice to be able to charge 2 phones at once while traveling.

reviewText: This is a great charger. You can plug two USB cables in it. It is very compact, barely larger than a 1-cable charger. title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Always need to charge two items in the car.  This works well and charges relatively fast.  Fits nice in the socket.  No complaints.

reviewText: The dual charging function is an awesome feature, as is the fact that it's an actual brand (I've read all the horror stories about non-brand chargers).If you are only charging one device only use one cable, otherwise it will divide the available charge (your phone will charge at half the potential speed)I have a Samsung GS4. When resting the phone charges reasonably fast, low-energy apps (YouTube) will charge slowly, high-energy apps (GPS) will maintain battery life and maybe charge a little depending on how far you're driving. HOWEVER, if you're attempting to charge two devices and use GPS the phone will still die, just at a slower rate.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a good charger for the car; it has dual ports, an unobtrusive power on light, and comes with a very nice cable for micro-usb devices.Pro:Dual ports means one can charge two devices (provided one has a cable for the second device - the charger only comes with one cable).Attractive design, with sturdy construction. The "Power On" light is not overly bright, just right so as to be obvious but not blinding.A nice, strong USB cable is included, which is long enough for car use (some devices only come with a few inches of length).Con:Not really a con, but the output is rated at 750mA, which means it will not charge any of the newer high power tablets like the Ipad or my Dell Streak 7 (both require 2000mA to charge). It will run my S7, but not charge it.Summary: Nice choice if one needs the USB power for two devices. Highly recommended.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: While this car charger may be more expensive than some of the alternatives you're looking at, it's also better.  Much better.  Most USB car chargers provide around 500mA power total, which may or may not even be enough to power your GPS depending on which phone you have.  Most USB dual car chargers split the 500mA power among the two ports, leaving them with 250mA each (definitely not enough).  This unit provides you with 850mA on EACH port, for a total of 1700mA.  I don't think that you'll find a better unit in existence.  You can charge your Atrix at the same time your friend charges his iPhone.  Or any other devices that can charge over USB.  All from one 'cigarette lighter.'  I highly recommend this product to anyone looking for a car cell phone charger, especially if you may ever need to plug in two 'smartphones' both at the same time.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: I truly like the convenience of the Motorola Dual Charger. It allows you to charge two devices at once. The only drawback is that I sometimes leave it on when I'm not charging my phone. I wish the indicator light was on the side where it would be easily viewable. I like the fact that it uses the straight wires instead of the coiled. Therefore it is more likely to have a smooth direct charge. No shortage! I highly recommend this charger to everyone. Just hope you are better at remembering to unplug it than me!

reviewText: The jury is out on this charger.  The website claims 850mA out of each port but the charger has "Output: 5V 750mA" printed on it.  It does not specify whether the 750mA is the total output or the output of each port.  Since the website is not consistent with what is printed on the charger, I'm not sure you can trust the specs at all.  The input power claims to be 10-33V @ 1000mA so one would assume to draw that much power (over 10 watts), the device should be able to produce 750mA out of each port or 1.5A total (5V @ 1.5A = 7.5W) but I did not test it to determine the maximum current output.  I may do so at a later time.It did my Droid 1 and charge my HTC Rezound at the same time.  The white LED is overly bright and you may find it offensive at night, depending on where your cigarette lighter jack is located on your vehicle.I gave this 3 stars because I feel there are better dual chargers available for less and the specs were not consistent with what the website claims.  As a side note, this charger includes a micro USB sync cable.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Charger works as expected, seems to be original Motorola made. Have used it only a handful of times but charges rapidly.I would recommend this seller and product.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: See update on 4/21 for why this is a 5 star product!4/20/11: Like the other reviewer stated, the USB car chargers do not seem to charge all devices.  This was my experience with the Motorola Atrix.  I did a measured charge in the car this morning.  With data, Bluetooth, GPS, and wifi turned off on the Atrix, the test began at 7:45 AM and the phone's charge was 20%.  At 9 AM 30% and 10:30 AM 40%. This is obviously nothing like the wall charger so it makes me believe that the phone is powered plus receiving a trickle charge.  The product name is misleading in my opinion.  I plan to call Motorola to ask for their input as would really like to be able to charge the phone in the car a whole lot quicker than this.  Comments from other owners of this product would be appreciated.4/21/11: Updated the rating to 5 stars.  I neglected to mention that the test above was conducted with the phone in the Motorola Atrix car dock.  I reported the in car dock test results to Motorola and repeated the same test today, conneting the phone directly to the USB car charger without the car dock.  At  8:00 AM the phone was at 20%, 8:20 AM 40%, 9:00 AM 70% and 10:00 AM 100%.  What a contrast!!  So the issue is more than likely the Motorola Atrix car dock.  I'll be reporting this to Motorola and would expect them to address with a firmware update.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: On older cars such as mine we only get 1 car charging port in the car with no Aux ports. This is a great way to double the amount of devices you can charge. It is high quality and very durable. I highly recommend this product.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This Moto dual car charger (P617) arrived promptly & is exactly as described.  It says Motorola on it with the hologram & everything, so my guess is that it is original, not some knock-off as expressed by some others.  It is a charger with dual ports & comes with 1 detachable USB wire w/ micro plug.  I am not an electrician, but it says it puts out 850ma per port, which means it will charge most Smartphones, cell phones & Tablets quickly.  The home-charger for my Moto Droid Razr M has an output of 850ma also, so it's a good match & pretty fast.  And at around $7...instead of $20-$25...it's a good deal.  It might not work for every cell phone out there (like iphone) or fit every car lighter perfectly, but nothing will.  I recommend it!
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: The USB charger does the job.  We have charged numerous devices from mp3 players to iPhones.  The charger does not have enough power to charge a iPad but otherwise had no problems.  It is a little bulkier than most chargers but if you need to charge 2 devices at one time then it is worth the extra bulk.  So far it works well and have had no problems.  It is much better quality than the cheap chargers and similar in quality to a Belkin, etc.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: There are other car chargers that can be purchased for cheaper, but the bonus of this one is the feature that allows 2 devices to charge at the same time. Also this is an official Motorola charger that is recommended for those devices as opposed to a generic charger.Due to the fact that it does provide the option to charge 2 devices at once it is somewhat on the large size. However it is not so big that it hinders its use. It comes with a Micro USB cable along with the charger.I used it to charge my phone and my Mp3 player (cable included fit my phone, I had the USB cable that fit my Mp3 player and simply plugged them both in). They both charged quickly during the car trip I was on.Simply, this device works very well. If you are someone who has multiple devices that you would like to charge at the same time or need a Motorola specific charger then this device fills those needs perfectly.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Although this is officially a Motorola charger, and arrives with the Motorola hologram to prove it, I'm currently using one USB port to charge my iPhone 4S, and the other port to charge my Kindle Fire.Now granted, neither port is the 2.1 mA that the Kindle Fire requires, but the micro USB data cable is the correct connection, and the Motorola charger works slowly, but perfectly.  My iPhone 4S is right at home on the other USB port, charging with reasonable speed.For the family with multiple phones, this charger is the perfect solution. Most phones and small electronics have a USB-based charging cable that be added or substituted, at about two dollars each. I've got cables labeled iPhone, Kindle, LG8000.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Amazon description says this charger is rated for 850mA, but the label on the charger says 750mA. I have no way to measure that, so decide who you want to trust.Most car chargers are only 500mA. If you are using your phone's GPS navigation in your car, 500mA may not be enough to keep the battery from running down. 750mA should be adequate to charge your battery and run the GPS navigation at the same time. Two sockets is a nice bonus if you're charging two devices at the same time.The charger conveniently comes with a microUSB cable, which is standard on modern phones other than Apple. If you have an Apple device, you need to provide your own cable.Price on this charger is very expensive compared to 3rd party chargers that claim to do the same thing. Should you save your money? If your Motorola smartphone has a $600 replacement cost and you're worried about a no-name charger voiding your warranty, then I suppose this Motorola charger is worth the price. Or you could wait for it to go on sale again.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This charger works great! I bought for my mom to use in her van. She uses it all the time!
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Most cars nowadays have a 12V outlet on the dashboard and often there is another outlet inside the center console.  For charging my phone my dashboard outlet is much more convenient.  I have a Motorola 12-Volt rapid charger.  It's fast, but it will charge or power only one phone or other device at a time.  This charger requires only one 12-volt outlet, and is slightly slower, but will power or charge two USB devices up to 750mA each.  That's handy when my wife wants to charge her Motorola Droid phone while I'm using mine in my car dock for navigation.  There is a bright, white LED between the USB outlets on this charger that serves both to make it easier to find in the dark and to also show that is ready to supply power.  Both the charger and the cable weigh just 2.3 ounces, which makes them no burden to carry.  For most owners who use Motorola smart phones in their cars, I believe that this would be a useful accessory.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: i love it this charges fast looks nice and i like the fact that it can charge two not just one phone
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a nice dual USB car charger, and it does indeed work great for charging phones, iPods, and small electronic devices.It does not, however, provide sufficient amperage for charging an iPad.  Granted it is not marketed specifically aimed at iPad, but as a dual, 'universal' USB charger, I wish it provided a bit more oomph.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a well built dual USB slot charger. I didn't have any problems using it to charge two devices at the same time. It charges fairly quickly as well in addition to being compact.  Overall its a great, versatile charger.

reviewText: DISCLAIMER: Although this was given to me through Vine to review, unlike other questionable "reviewers", I actually take the time to USE the product or READ the book. So whatever score/review the product gets, it's absolutely earned. At no time is a product given a particular review or rating simply because I fear loosing Vine status. That's not how the Vine program operates.Anyhoo, onto the review:Ok. Not much to say here, but I'll give a brief synopsis. This thing is built VERY well and even came in a Motorola box. The P617, with a higher amp output definitely makes a difference in charge time. I also have the Moto SPN5400A microUSB charger and not unexpectedly, the p617 appears to charge just as fast as the SPN5400A. Compared to my "Sprint" branded charger it charged my HP Touchpad in rough half the time on a trip to North Carolina. Also, as expected, when using both USB ports simultaneously, the current capacity is split between the two and charge time is less.The well-built Motorola P617 works exactly as it should and it's excellent build quality should permit many years of charging.Recommended.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This little unit is excellent. Plugs in and provides ample power for charging my Droid. The extra USB port is a great bonus as it allows me to charge my Bluetooth headset at the same time. Great quality. Excellent product.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: It charges my phones, that is what I was looking for.  I really can't say much else.  It does not come with 2 cords.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: For those of us increasingly dependent on our mobile devices, a car charger is very handy.  If you're buying a new one, you might as well get a dual-port model for the inevitable time when your passenger's device also needs charging.  Or you get a tablet.  Or...This unit is a lot bulkier than my old single-port Sprint model, but because it protrudes further, it's easier to find in the dark, and I can see the bright LED light between the two ports; the old charger's light would be obscured by the cigarette lighter's cover-flap, in my Honda Civic EX.Many chargers seem to not include a cable, so the short microusb one included in this kit is very welcome, since I like to keep a cable in each of my travel bags, as well as in each of car/office/home/workplace.A car-charger is very valuable for today's power-hungry short-lived smartphones.  This one is a good choice, and handily includes a cable.  Recommended.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: The feature I think that is best about this charger is that I've verified it has enough current to charge an Apple iPad. A lot of these cigarette lighter adapters don't have enough wattage for tablets - being useful only for cellphones and other small devices. But on this one, both outlets are putting out enough wattage for the tablet. Of course, you can still use it for lower wattage items such as music players, etc.One negative is the big box it comes in. It just seems unnecessary to have so much packaging for something so simple.  The box is actually around the same size as the box an iPhone comes in!
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Excellent output from each port charges the phone quickly, or maintains during heavy usage such as when using the phone's GPS and still charges slowly.  Dual ports are a bonus even though it only comes with a single micro usb cable.

reviewText: This thing is lower power than a no-name $2 charger.  With navigation or other apps running, your phone will get hot, and will NOT charge.  With Motorola's other car charger, my phone charged very quickly, and didn't get nearly as hot when my phone was doing navigation or other heavy work.I've give Motorola the benefit of this doubt, but this charger is sadly disappointing.  You should go find yourself a non-name dual-port charger that actually delivers a full 1-amp output on each of the ports.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: the white like is really dem so there is no bother therereally like using it with my RAZR and GS4 both charge wellsuper helpful i recommend it to everyone

reviewText: This is really handy charger -- I'm able to take advantage of the multiple USB to "n" data cables that I have and charge a couple of devices at the same time.  Whether it's my phone & bluetooth headset or my phone and a traveling companion's phone, I'm set.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: Listen, I'm a pretty tolerant guy. I give retailers slack, I have worked at many many service jobs in my life, and I understand that things sometimes don't work out the way that was intended. There are few things that I can't forgive, but getting a different product than is literally advertised is just the lowest of the low.I went through quite an ordeal already before I ordered this one. I had another charger from Anker, but because of my iMagnet dock, I couldn't use it because the curled cord pulled the phone too much. I was frustrated, I tried to make it work, but it didn't.So, I ate the 5 dollars to ship it back (still haven't gotten to the post office to send it though), and I ordered this because of its cheaper price and better overall rating.Well, I get it, and I pop open the package, and there is this strange looking cable with an audio jack hanging off it...kind of weird, but who cares if it works right?I plug it in when I get in the car, and I immediately get the error that this cable will charge my phone slower than the standard charger. -.- Wow. That sucks. So I said ya know, hey maybe it's not so bad. It is. It charges so slow, and will lose power when I navigate and use the phone heavily. What a waste of money.Aside from the thing not being at all a "rapid charger"...I am really pissed that it ISN'T the product pictured. As many others have pointed out, the pictures look nothing like the cable, it isn't the official cable, and clearly that comes out when trying to use it. I honestly don't care if it's a little different, as long as it works the same.This doesn't.Really upset with this company, and I feel its practices jeopardize the trust that Amazon has.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: I often have multiple gadgets to plug in while I'm in the car so I purchased this charger to help with that.  No more fighting over the socket! It also came with an auxillary cable.  I'm not sure that was supposed to be included because it wasn't mentioned in the ad, but useful anyway!  Seems to charge fairly rapidly compared to other car chargers I've used.  Overall, good buy.

reviewText: I'm done buying generic chargers. They end up being bad values. This charger works for my iPhone, so I'm happy.

reviewText: This Motorola charger has been working consistently in my car for about 2 months. It works flawlessly out of the box for my Galaxy S2. title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: These days, there are a lot of car chargers on the market. Some are very cheap and cost only a few dollars. You might be tempted to get a cheaper one, since there's not much to lose even if you throw it away. But you don't want to be stuck with something that may fall apart or that won't charge your device. Cheaply made adapters don't offer solid connections, and nothing I've seen is more solid than this one.Many charges have 500ma of power. This one has 750ma (that's what's printed on my charger; the website said 850ma when I wrote this review) of output, and two ports, allowing your devices to be charged quickly.This device has a robust build. Nothing about it looks cheap. Even compared to expensive high quality adapters such asAmazonBasics Vehicle Power Cable with Mini-USB Connector for GPS and Other Mini-USB Devices, the Motorola seems a step up in robustness with very solid contacts on the sides. The AmazonBasics charger is limited to one Mini-USB connector, while the Motorola one comes with a micro-USB cable and a second connector for the compatible cable of your choice. The AmazonBasics, however, has a 1000ma output rating, and is a good choice for a single Mini-USB compatible device.Considering the two connectors, the build, and the flexibility of working with cables you may get in the future, this adapter is a good choice.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: This charger allows my wife to plug in a USB cable with a normal size mini USB end, as well as plugging in one with a micro USB end...she can charge my Bluetooth handsfree speaker or other USB device at the same time as charging my smartphone.  Since her car has two DC outlets, she can also operate her GPS all at the same time!
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewText: While the Motorola rapid charger is great, the USB cable is VERY tight. Most people don't care and think it's just fine. But the cable is so tight that it's sure to damage the port in the long term.Keep that in mind, you may have to buy a USB Cable on the side to be satisfied with this purchase.
title: Motorola P617 Rapid Dual USB Car Charger with Micro USB Data Cable - Bulk Packaging - Black

reviewerName: A. A. Glazer "world wide web wanderer"
reviewText: I got my Droid X2 as an upgrade for my Droid X which may still work had I not dropped it from 14 feet. Even with the Otter case, although it still worked, often when I hit text, my camera opened.The only difference between the DX and DX 2 are the dual core processor on the latter - and the lack of the physical camera button. Not a biggie as the camera sucks anyway. I have a DSLR for photos.The phone is great; very responsive. I found on my old one, I had a tendency to overload it with apps. Not only did it drain the battery, but too much RAM was used and it slowed the phone down.Found a new battery every year also helps. After a while, they just don't hold a charge anymore. They are not expensive here @ Amazon.All the accessories (charger, Otter case, etc) works from the original Droid.Lots of options with this phone. It has seven (7) home screens to customize. I used one for contacts THE home screen; and other for groups of apps. ...theme pages. One has maps and navigation, one voice command and personal assistants, one Weather, Facebook and text widgets and a calendar and post-it note page each. Like I said - very customizable.This is the GSM version and I use it with Kitty Wireless - a Verizon carrier in the U.S.Much better reception than my old DX as far as signal strength. Three bars in my house. I had one previously (none with ATT).People complain about [most] smartphones not holding a charge - blah, blah - just charge it every evening and you're good to go. I keep an extra battery with me, but also give it a quick late afternoon car-charge on the ride home. No phone will last 24 hours with use. None.All in all, a wonderful phone for about a 100 bucks or so. Not he latest technology but has enough bells and whistles for me and I'm a techie.No way I would shell out hundreds for an iphone when Android works like this and most apps are fee or cost a buck or two. I don't have a contract - go month to month with Kitty Wireless for $30. Pleny of talk and text time plus data if you watch it.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: I bought a used Droid X a couple months before my contract was up. I liked it so much that I upgraded to an X2 instead of pricier, 4g Droids just because I liked the X so much. Big mistake.If you love your Droid X like I do, then just keep your Droid X. The Droid X2 is a total downgrade. It is almost the exact same phone only made of cheaper materials. It is a tiny bit thinner but they are otherwise the exact same phone. All Droid X accessories fit the Droid X2.The X is more solid. The X2 just feels really generic. A piece of the battery cover on the X2 broke off inside the phone. Called Amazon Wireless and they couldn't replace it because the X and X2 are now discontinued. They kept trying to push me into taking it to Verizon. I said if I wanted to deal with Verizon, I would have upgraded through Verizon. Ended up switching to a Razr 16gb which I had to pay $80 for even though I got the X2 for free. Just a terrible experience through Amazon Wireless and if their customer support just keeps going on like this, they're not going to be in business for long. Terrible customer service.I wanted the X2 instead of the more expensive phones because it has a battery that you can take in and out and replace it any time it wears down. With the new phones, such as Droid4 and Razrs, the battery is internal and cannot be replaced without sending it in for servicing. With as much as I use my phone, I knew I needed a battery I could take in and out which is why I have never wanted an iPhone.So, don't buy this phone. Buy the cheaper but better more solid phone in the Droid X. I love it. It's my fave phone and I've had Droid2, Droid2 Global, and Droid X2 as far as smartphones go. The X has very stable software. Has yet to freeze up on me or restart.Also, I wouldn't recommend using Amazon Wireless and this is coming from a very loyal Amazon customer. It was a disaster.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: DX2 Much better than original Droid A855Rev: 11-29-2012aThe good:-- This phone/pda is much better that the original Droid (A855) that I had for two months, that older phone sux.-- The Droid X2 (DX2) is much faster, seems more refined, less buggy.  The screen is just big enough.-- Hidden treasure: FM broadcast receiver works very-very good. Uses your provided headphones (requires them to work, its the antenna), to receive FM.  This is the best FM receiver I own?  The Bandwith seems to very as signal quality varies, the result is there is much less static. And has very good fidelity.  The GUI need more attention, like push button access to the favorites, signal strength meter (RSSI) and such. Radio work wonderfully...Over all I'm more happy with this Droid X2. It would get 4-stars, if not for all the minor problems (all bad software, related, see below)...The bad:-- I had to clear all cash, 3 times, and reset to original factory setting once (erase everything and start over (this held a lot))...-- Music player skips, at least once per song, some program is interrupting or some thing??? *1-- Phone crashers for no apparent reason. Seems to be excessive CPU usage problem. Just after closing Google maps or other programs.  90% of the time this is only solved by removing the battery, nothing else fixes this problem.-- Clock is completely cell network based. If the battery is removed, the clock cant be set without turning on the cell radio, even if you have WiFi with a clock sync program running (i use airplane mode, at home, so the battery dont die overnight, as I have no cell service where I live).-- I dont like Google, any more.  It seems, I have troubles with them constantly (cant sync phone book as stated on their web site. maps crashing, Goggle application crashing (most of this was on the A855). And no one to report this too and get help (no customer support)).-- After I got the dock, "Motorola" tries to force an additional computer (drivers) update (other than the standard USB ones), if you download it, each time you connect to the computer, three folders open.  One is the Motorola drivers folder and this seems to make a browser window open and it connect to the internet, to a Verizon wirelesses backup service, a video self starts, advertising a service I dont want or need. Apparently I have to Root the phone, to remove this nag-ware from the phone, in order to make it stop. Work around (sorta): And and remove programs, and remove the offending Motorola folder. The third folder still opens, after docking, but no internet sales video starts.-- The info area at the top of the phone is supper tiny and there seems to be no setting to make it bigger.-- The signal strength bars, has just 4 bars, instead of the standard 5, and is hard to see.  Having no signal, is common where I live, and the no signal looks, like full bars.-- The info area messages comes and goes, faster than I can read (same area).-- GPS wont actually turn on, when selected (using maps), if the cellular service is turned off.  The symbol shows up, but not worke.  The work around is: Turn on cellular, then GPS, then turn cell back off, to make GPS work.  Even still some times the GPS just wont work.  THen it takes a power off-on reset. Sometimes this dose not work and you need to do the remove the battery reset, and reinstall the battery, to restart the GPS...-- Screen timeout dose not apparently apply to wake up screen and sometimes the screen goes to sleep, as I'm trying to inter the password or shut the phone off, or set it into to airplane mode.-- There is a lot of data consuming bloat-ware on the phone and rooting is the only solution is to remove. This stuff also kills memory and slows the phone as sum of it, starts and runs despite that I'm not using it. There is way too much trash, supplied by Verizon, on this phone.-- Android/ Google. I'm not liking the disclaimers, that accompanies 98% of all the applications. One example: Why dose a mapping program, need to take pictures or record sound, or can even make phone calls, without user intervention???  This is in may of the disclaimers, when you download software to the phone from the Google Play Store - Why???-- Weird battery removal process, and poorly described. A piece of plastic (red) label is used to pry up the battery. It exceptionally unprofessional - a cheap solution. I expect it will fail (tare), making imposable to remove the battery, over time. I use my phone enough, I use several batteries, and even one a separate aftermarket charger, to charge batteries out of the phone. I own 4 batteries, one of the original 1500mAh battery, the other 3 are aftermarket BH5X that is 1900mAh, I got from ebay. All are the standard thin, non-fat (dose not take a different battery door), battery.Inclusion:As you can see, I have many somewhat minor issues with the phone. I hate Apple, so what other choices are there. None.  It's much like Voting, its the choice of the least-bad solution, I guess...Cell provider:Page plus, $55 get you 2 GB data and unlimited talk and text...De:Mr. RF.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: Having owned this phone for quite a long time now (my wife has used it for 4 years now), I will say that this phone has been a very reliable phone for us. It has held up from the drops and oops and still keeps going strong. The biggest disadvantage today for this phone is that you are limited to what version of Android your carrier decides to stop at before no longer upgrading. It is well capable of handling the later versions of the android operating system but unfortunately for us, our carrier has discontinued android OS updates for the X2 at 2.3. But if you are willing to live with that then this phone is a good reliable choice. Battery life is good but like most batteries these days, they start to dwindle in lifespan after a couple years and you are stuck at either upgrading or spending a premium for Motorola's replacement battery.This phone is good for a replacement phone that you don't want to pay an outrageous price for or you don't want to renew a contract.  Having owned this and the original droid and both lasted a long time, the major difference between the two is that the X2 is a bit faster overall that the original droid, but with either one you can't go wrong with a reliable phone.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: This is my fiance's first smartphone & so far he really likes it.  The only issue he has had is that the speaker phone function works on & off.  It is a 50/50 chance on whether it works or not.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: good 3 g phone had droid x  befor fixed alot of flaws with it with x2. still freezes up every once in awhile but really good phone
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: Camera is AWESOME, video camera is even better. App download speeds are awesome, expandable memory and a card included YAYCons: When you multitask the battery is killed fast.Summary: I got this phone 2 hrs ago, but I can say, after playing around with it for about a day now in store and now, it is one of the best phones I'VE had (now that I received it)First, the camera is JUST AMAZING. I had an iPhone 4 before, and as you know it has a 5 MP camera. This has an 8. It looks much better. I really don't have any complaints on the camera.The speakers sound awesome. I downloaded some songs from windows media to the phone, and played them back while I went jogging this morning, and without headphones, and some guys lawn mower running LOL, I could still hear the music perfectly fine.I have one small issue with the battery going down, if I'm listening to Pandora and texting at the same time the battery life decreases fast. I may have to get the extended battery. Besides this, I love my phone, and love Android
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: As long as you don't need 4G, this is a great phone. The processor is very fast and the call quality is great. The camera and the music player are great and it's a great wifi device that supports 40 gigabytes (with a 32GB microSD card). I use this on a prepaid company that uses Verizon's signal and couldn't be happier with a phone.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: I like this Phone, I did my research before i made a purchase and I am satisfied. this i an average phone but a very good price. good for light everyday tasks, has an FM radio reciever built in, requires headphones as an antennae. has mobile hotspot dual core 1 ghz processor 512 mb ram and android 2.3.5 Gingerbread. the Motorola skin, MotoBlur i believe is its name is fairly simple yet full of features. this phone can be used with straight talk, for a replacement smartphone or a starter, or just to have above minimum of todays technology this phone will be your best option on verizons service. loads apps fast, sleek design and compared to todays phones, its still very useful even for an older android. you will be happy with this phone if you are familiar with android or new to the android community.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: I owned the droid series for nearly 2 years now, and I can say that they are very dependable, the built quality is extremely good. The screen size makes it very comfortable to read mails. The battery is decent. Overall I good product.
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: When i first got this phone it was amazing! best phone i have ever had.Many things that i like about this phone, that still are great: The Screen, camera and LED notification bar.----Whats not great anymore is the processor speed. Ive reset this phone back to factory conditio about 6 times in 4 months. But nothing is helping it. Wish i could do something about it, Software updates for andriod would be great but none. Like most smartphones the battery sucks. The phone freezes on average once every full hour used. So about 4x a day for me since i dont use it alot. Another major complaint ive had from others is that they cant hear me talking. Sounds real mumbly. I had such high hopes to keep for a long time, well so much for that!
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: This phone has been great. If you are looking for the best bang for you buck on an Android OS, 3G Smartphone, this is it. Although I can't say Motorola is the best hardware available in smartphones they do have value when you consider the screen size/CPU/and other stats on the phone it is the best stats you can get in the under $300 price range. I did a LOT of research before deciding on this phone. My provider is pagepluswireless which is a prepaid cell phone company and they only have a 3G capable network so I needed a phone that was 3G and not 4G. I found this to be the best price/spec/screen size phone for what I wanted. Only real drawback is the stock battery is really bad, goes dead in about 30 minutes of the screen being lit. I bought an extended battery and new battery cover for it for about $17 on Amazon here and that has worked great. Battery life is now excellent. If you are into doing custom ROM's and rooting your phone then this phone is awesome for that as well, there is a lot of aftermarket and custom support for the X2, get it while you can! :P
title: Motorola Droid X2 No Contract Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: In a nutshell, this battery will give you a full days worth of battery life, and anyone with a Droid Bionic should buy one. It will make your phone a bit fatter, but I don't mind the extra girth at all, and it makes the phone more comfortable to hold for me. Phone is still pretty light even with extended battery.I was pleased to see that the battery and case certainly look OEM. The sticker has serial numbers and marking that look exactly like my normal OEM battery. Also, the plastic extended battery back panel, looks and feels exactly like the original along with the Verizon, 4G and Google logos. As far as I can tell, this is the real deal OEM.Performance: I received the battery with about 80% charge. I charged the battery to 100%, then I downloaded and installed the "BatteryCalibration" app from the android marketplace. I followed the 4 simple steps.1) Plug your phone to the charger2) Wait till it charges to 100%3) Click "Battery Calibration"4) Unplug your phone.What this app does is wipe your battery stats. It forces the phone to recognize that you have a new and different battery with different capacity. If you don't do this, you will not get optimal battery life out of your new extended battery.After doing Calibration, I allowed the phone to die completely and then charged it again. Under first charge, my phone last just over 24hours. It's a brand new phone for me, so I have been playing with it extensively all day, using 4G mainly, some WiFi, games, pictures, a bit of Navigation, and lots of texting, emailing, browsing, etc.So 24 hours I think was really good. My other battery would die after 9 hours tops of similar use. I'm sure if you use the phone moderately throughout the day, you might even get a day and a half of battery life out of it. Most people should have no problem making it through the entire day, and then just charging it at night.
title: OEM BW8X Motorola Droid Bionic XT875 Extended Battery 2760mah and Extended door cover

reviewText: I love this battery.  Yes, it does bulk the phone up a little and make it heavier... but it actually (for me) made the phone feel more robust and sturdy.  As for battery life... this battery easily doubles the stock battery life.  The only thing I must warn everyone not to do is use a charger that is rated higher than the battery!  It will heat up the battery and destroy it.  If you use a charger that is less than 2700 mah you will get great life from this battery like I have.  (Still going strong a couple years later)

reviewText: The factory battery doesn't last very long, but this battery last an exceptionally long time. I carry it around for hours and it's still on 90%.  It's a little beefy, but I need a phone that I don't have to charge constantly, and this works exceptionally well.  Couldn't be happier.

reviewText: Difficult to adjust for an unblocked camera viewI purchased this for use with the iOnRoad app.  This lets you know if you drift out of your lane or get too close to the car in front. reviewText: I bought this at the Verizon store for literally three times the price listed here, and that was AFTER a 25% discount.That aside, I have to say that I am disappointed in the performance of the item. I commute by bus/trolley, so I need my phone handy at nearly all times to check transit schedules and maps. So, I thought this case would be great to clip onto my backpack strap, like with my original case/holster. Nope! The clip either digs into my side or scrapes against the inside of my arm, because it extends WAY past the case when the phone is in a vertical position. It's also nearly impossible to simply slip the phone out of the holster because there is a lip around all sides of the phone. I've actually missed phone calls because I spent too much time struggling with the stupid holster! And lastly, I dropped my phone while in a two-handed struggle to get it out of the holster. The top and bottom edges of the phone aren't protected by the case, so of course the phone landed in such a way that the lower front edge got shredded. The damage is only cosmetic, but still considerable. I had an Otterbox Defender originally, but they don't make a case for the extended battery. After this experience, I'm going back to my Otterbox and will just carry a power pack to charge my phone while I'm on the go.
title: Motorola OMOTBIONICSHELLHOL Droid Bionic XT875 Shell Holster Combo with Kickstand - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: i bought this at the store along with my phone and got a government discount on it.  It is one tough holster - and has many grooves on it for gripping it.  There are some nice features, and some not so nice.NICE:  The part that grips the phone works with both the extended battery and the slim battery.  SMART!It also has a push out stand that holds the phone either sideways like a picture frame or vertically like a portrait position for charging, nightstand in a motel, etc (I'd still buy the a/v nightstand setup simply for the hdmi output)Not so nice - the beltclip is not nearly as strong as the case grips the phone and I've already dropped it into my car between the open door (the threshold body part plastic) and the seat - found it there when I could not find my droid, but the missing phone app told me it was at my house somewhere.I'd give it 5 stars if the belt clip were stronger or better designed (wider).  NOTE - the clip can be rotated for landscape or portrait carry, but you must draw the phone out of the clip in a portrait orientation.All togther, this protects the screen, the back, allows photos to be taken, and makes the phone more useful when not in the dock.  It's rugged material and does not look like it would break except POSSIBLY in extreme cold (I have an environmental chamber that will go to -100 deg C and I would NOT put this thermoplastic into the chamber at that temp - I suspect permanent damage might happen and I like my case!!It's almost a 5 star product.  Of all the cases I looked at, this one has the best feel due to the fine ridge detail and the grip it maintains on the phone.  I just wish it gripped my belt as well.
title: Motorola OMOTBIONICSHELLHOL Droid Bionic XT875 Shell Holster Combo with Kickstand - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Hold the phone well. Keeps it protected. Built well, no complaints. Only down side is that it is a little bulky.
title: Motorola OMOTBIONICSHELLHOL Droid Bionic XT875 Shell Holster Combo with Kickstand - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This case accommodates the extended size Bionic battery pack, which I have.  The holster and belt clip are solid.  The phone slips in and out nicely with just the right amount of pressure needed to release the phone from the holster.  The built in kickstand is very useful in both portrait and landscape placements.Dislikes:- Access to the charging port on the holstered Bionic is obscured by the holster itself.  In order to charge the phone, one must remove the phone partially, or completely, out of the case.  A minor annoyance but an annoyance just the same.- The pins that guide the kickstand are of a plastic material and eventually failed after ~18 months of service, rendering the kickstand useless.  I'm a handy fellow but I could find no way to repair/replace the broken pin.  This is a case of bad design and a major annoyance.Four starts despite the two nits.  The holster is very good overall with the plusses outweighing the minuses.
title: Motorola OMOTBIONICSHELLHOL Droid Bionic XT875 Shell Holster Combo with Kickstand - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I received the shell/ holster, when expected.  Love the kick stand, works great.  It was more than 1/2pice cheaper than buying it directly from Verizon. Thanks
title: Motorola OMOTBIONICSHELLHOL Droid Bionic XT875 Shell Holster Combo with Kickstand - 1 Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: EDIT: I see the price has dropped from the original $40 price.  This is the belt clip I've used for the last 2-3 weeks.  I really like it.  I'm very happy they designed it to fit the extended battery.  Highly recommend buying it here at about half the price Verizon is selling it for. At this price, I give it 5 stars! END OF EDITVerizon sells this case for 10 bucks less. Amazon sells the same case but for the Droid Charge for less than one third the price. This is the case I'm buying for my new Bionic.  It provides good protection for the phone and has room for the extended battery.  It really is a great case and belt clip, but go to Verizon to buy it. reviewText: When I got the bionic, the battery usage and life was all over the place.  One day I'd get through the day with over half life left, next day it would die by lunch (with no difference in usage).  I got this to help out.  I did get longer usage with this, but the fluctuations were maddening still.  Then the bionic got an update (I think it was the 902 one that did the trick), and now the battery lasts forever!  I am a very light user, usually, and I can go 6-7 days before it gets to 20%.  (I make no phone calls most days, usually about 10 minutes of email/surfing at most... not really sure why I even have a cellphone).  For the price, you can't beat it!  Genuine Motorolla for cheap!

reviewText: This is the best bluetooth device I have owned.  It was fully charged in only 3-4 hours.  The tiny green light on one side is very bright when fully charged. It has yellow light for 80-20% charge, and red for less than 20% charged. Pairing to my iPhone was a simple one-step process confirmed by a verbal acknowledgement from the device.  It comes with four ear piece choices for on-the-ear with an ear hook, in-the-ear with an ear hook, and two sizes of in-the-ear without an ear hook.  When pairing the voice says "Connected to Phone 1 (or 2 or tablet).  With Android or other phones with "NFC technology" pairing is simply taping the headset against the phone.  Motorola claims a 300-ft range from the phone.  I've gone quite a distance but not a full 300 feet.  My biggest concern is will it work inside a "big box store?"  All the steel and concrete prevents adequate signal transmission.  I have not had an opportunity to try it in a big store, like a Costco, Lowes, etc. and will update once that trial is done.  On and off is just a flip of the little speaker. The "flipper" is a little cumbersome to open when it's being worn closed/off, and would likely be difficult for people with large fingers.  It can be worn in the open and off position, then just push the call button when receiving or placing a call. The call button on the end is easy to access and works without dislodging the earpiece.  Volume control button is on the top (worn on left ear) or bottom (worn on right ear) and works well.  However, I do tend to hit that button when holding the device to push the call button.  Maybe with some practice I can figure out how to do it without hitting the volume control.  I have a smaller than average head for an adult female so it has been quite a challenge finding ear hooks and ear pieces that don't fall off.  This in-ear piece fits perfectly!!  You can place and receive text messages verbally with "My Motospeak."  This headset can also be customized with Motospeak to choose what the "Smart Button" does (i.e. adjust equalizer settings and set noise cancellation range).  It is also possible to listen to streaming audio with this headset.  Voice answering, call rejection, and placing a call. Talk time: 6 hours; Standby Time: 12 days according to package information.  Weight is 10 grams.  Thank you Motorola!
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Being able to pair with two phones and the way it instantly connects when flipped open means I can use it with work and home phones and save the battery by keeping it turned off and flipping it open just when the phone rings.  Good quality sound.  Really don't use the software, but having texts read to me and being able to dictate texts would be handy for some.  Good sound.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Had good luck with Moto BT in the past.This one is the most expensive I have had regardless of brand.I like how you just flip the end to turn it on. It instantly paired with my HTC ONE.Unfortunately that's all I liked as the audio was very muffled on both ends. Callers had a hard time understanding me.The call/answer button is on the end and hard to push. You need to brace it with other fingers to press it. It should be on the side.For as long as BT technology has been out, you'd think that audio quality should be excellent as a given. A $20 one should sound as clear as a $150 one. You should only have to pay for features.I've tested Plantronics Marquee2, M55. Blue Ant2, and now this. This is probably the worst sounding out of the 4.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: If you don't have an Android device, then this headset might not work for you.I tried this headset with three different devices. Poor results with these.First, I paired the headset with my Motorola W766 cell phone. This is an old fashioned "dumb" phone. Pairing was dead simple. However, the two devices would disconnect and then immediately re-connect every few minutes. Eventually, the two devices would fail to reconnect. This was 100% reproducible. I phoned up Motorola tech support and their rep. stated that this headset is intended for use only with Android. She offered no further suggestions.I paired the headset with a Windows XP PC that uses the latest WIDCOMM Bluetooth software. Pairing was a bit flaky. I had to re-pair several times while testing.I also obtained flaky results pairing with my Apple iPod Touch (latest model).It is too bad, because this headset delivered the best sound quality that I have experienced so far. What I have to compare with are the Motorola H17, and two Plantronics headsets. This headset also features Motorola's "flip" design, which is excellent. Most headsets require you to hold down a button for a second or two to turn the thing on or off. With Motorola's design, you simply flip the headset open or closed, and it only takes a fraction of a second. One or two seconds does not sound like much. But if your daily routine includes unlocking your car, putting sunglasses on, putting seatbelt on, etc. then it all adds up. I really appreciate Motorola's design.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: With the plethora of BT headsets out there how can you say one is better than the other?  Range, clarity and ease of use as well as fit.  And this Motorola unit hits all of those out of the park.  Cant' say enough good things about this little gem.  Also very stylish and holds a charge for quite awhile.  Mine lasted two weeks in standby, with appx an hour of talk during that time.  Incredibly light weight fit too!

reviewText: I wanted to love this headset.  It has a lot going for it, but unfortunately, it seems as if this wasn't ever worn by anyone, just designed for looks.  I uploaded a picture comparing this headset with theJawbone ICON-Series Thinker Bluetooth Headset (Black)to illustrate my point.  The problem is that the speaker for this headset is almost flush with the part that sits on your cheek. I tried every one of the different ear hooks and gels, but none of them made the headset feel secure (like it wasn't just going to fall off if I did anything other than sit perfectly still) or gave a good seal so the sound transmitted well and blocked out environmental sounds.The problem is that there is no clearance for your tragus (Google "ear tragus" to understand which part of the ear this is) to fit between the outer edge of the speaker/ear gel and the inner edge of the body of the headset (the black part).  I wasn't expecting the same noise cancellation or sound fidelity you get with a good pair of in-ear-monitor headphones, but it felt like someone was holding the ELITE FLIP an inch away from my head in terms of sound transmission and I wouldn't dare walk around without holding this in place with my hand, completely defeating the whole hands-free concept.I have never had a headset fit this poorly, and have never even considered this particular design flaw, but now that I have had this experience, I will definitely look more closely at the product pictures for all future headsets.  Sorry Motorola, but I only kept this one long enough to pair it with my phone and listen to about 30 seconds of music before initiating my return.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Great quality, clarity and definitely durable.  It has great range and I had no problem walking around my apartment using it while leaving my phone in another room. reviewText: I'm in love with this headset! I've only had one other, the basic Sony brand for my PS3--and it sucked. It was uncomfortable, and the sound was pretty terrible. Unlike this little gem--the sound is "HD" and is better than putting my ear to my actual iPhone! The only couple of criticisms I have are that on the one sheet in the box it says you can use voice commands to have it read and record texts, but I couldn't figure out how from the instructions, but that doesn't really matter because hitting the call button twice activates Siri on my iPhone 4S. And the call button itself is a little loose, kind of rattles in it's setting which you can hear as you walk if you're not listening to anything. But I LOVE the comfy rubber in-ear attachment, and I can stream podcasts to it, no more need for annoying ear bud wires. And the battery life is great too--Motorola gets it right with mobile stuff, and I can't recommend this one enough.

title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I hoped this headset would finally replace my old PLNVOYAGER520 - Plantronics Voyager 520 Bluetooth Headset that I broke a couple of years ago.  I've since usedBlueAnt Q2 Voice-Controlled Pure Conversation Bluetooth Headset (Black, Retail Packaging), the hugePlantronics Voyager PRO+ Bluetooth Headset, and the newBose Bluetooth Headset Series 2 - Right Ear.  This one looked promising, but I just could not get it to work.Fit:  Great!  It's tiny, light, and very comfortable.  It comes with options for over-ear, in-ear, or some combination.  I used the over-ear and found it comfortable, although it has a tendency to lose position easily.  Otherwise, very comfortable and pretty secure.Call quality:  Good, but callers told me there was some static.  I also noticed callers sounded a little "distant" and tinny.Form factor:  Sleek, tiny, and with a nice folding feature to turn the unit on/off.  Buttons are intuitive and pretty easy to use, although people with bigger fingers may have some trouble.Ease of use:  Here's where this one failed.  From reading the manual, the voice commands (like "call [number]") only work for texting, although I couldn't get even that much to work to find out.  You can only use this feature if you download the enormous (beta!) app to your phone, but it force-closed on me twice and then failed to actually work the third time.  I also couldn't get the headset settings commands to work at all.  I read through the limited troubleshooting that came with the device with no results, and the Motorola support website didn't even have this device listed.If you plan to only use this by manually dialing your phone, this is a comfortable, slick headset with decent sound quality.  If you expect to use any voice commands or need troubleshooting, you should look elsewhere.  For myself, I have no need of a huge beta software file on my phone to *not* perform a basic function, but I do need voice commands.  If I need to text, I'll use Android's in-built Talk-to-Text.  And with that, I'll use the near-perfectBose Bluetooth Headset Series 2 - Right Ear.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewerName: Modern Blue Argonaut "No I do not have a shoe...
reviewText: This is one of the most comfortable, well designed, and easy to use bluetooth headsets I've ever used, and considering I've owned over two dozen, this one ranks in the top three. The only one I rank higher is the Plantronics Voyager Pro + because it just feels better on my ear.I love the flip it open to turn it on feature, and the ear loop is very no fuss and comfortable. It pairs with both of my phones at the same time just by turning it on. One of the greatest features is that this also works as a media bluetooth, allowing you to stream music from your iPad or iPhone. I have done this on many occasions when I don't want to connect a wired headset but would like to listen to some tunes. It also switches right over to phone calls should a call come in.  I was also curious what would happen if I was on a call using this bluetooth with Phone A and then Phone B rings. All I needed to do was hit the answer button and the original call went on hold while I answered the first call. I was very pleased with that and now all I have to do is let the other caller know I have a call coming in and switch over.Call clarity was very good, but not perfect. I had a friend use this for the day and found that I heard road noise when he was driving and some wind noise outside (although much better than other bluetooths).This is a really full-featured, well made bluetooth. I've always been happy with Motorola bluetooth headsets and would definitely buy this and recommend this to others.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I don't know if it is me having a weird shaped ear, or that people just deal with headsets being lose and falling out. Previous to making the switch to this headset, I had thePlantronics Discovery 975 Bluetooth Headset. I never was able to get the multipoint working in that headset.This new Motorola, hung right on my ear and produced crisp, clear sound, in a headset that sat securely on my ear. I have never found a headset that actually works well with my ears until this one. I have Tinnitus, and a bit of hearing loss in that ear. It just so happened that the ear piece was oriented for that ear, so I left it in that manner. Even with the hearing loss I have no issues hearing callers or the command prompts from the headset.I was also able to successfully pair this unit to my work Droid Incredible. So the Multipoint performs flawlessly.The unit is very small and comfortable. I'm not one of the people you see walking around all day with their "Fashion" piece in their ear, but for the short periods of time that I wear it, I find it to be minimally intrusive and quite comfortable.
