reviewText: This simple MOTOROLA ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset is a quick and simple device that sounds great.A few notes, that once you remove it, it will need to be charged as the device is not functional yet. There is an adapter that plugs into the wall and then a small USB into the device. No biggie, but for me this was annoying as I wanted to use it out of the box. But thats just me. Once its charged, the phone itself is sort of "curled" over. This is the "FLIP" part that the item refers to. Once you flip that, it serves as an 'on-off switch'. Turning it on, a female voice will trigger a welcome and then tell you how much talk time is allowed. At full charge, you have about 6 hours to talk time.I have an iPhone 4 that paired up quickly to the device and was easy to make a call from there.I gave it 4 stars for a few reasons. The first is that I really had trouble getting the phone in my ear. It could have been my own idiocy that I could not figure out how to wrap it around me ear, or that it just was not designed in the way that is obvious. I believe the former to be more true, but it was a frustration nonetheless.Second is that bluetooth has not really been a good energy saver, in my opinion. Six hour talk time is really small, not to mention it also pulls a lot of battery power off the phone. As always, my phone gets very hot when I have the bluetooth settings on. I do heavy texting, lots of internet use in additional to talking on the phone and so to have all of that pulling on battery power, it really takes a lot out of my phone and potentially reducing talk time in the process. It is useful to have a USB port set up in your car to have continual charge to counteract this issue, even if it just maintains the level its at, but ultimately, bluetooth devices need a lot of attention. Flipping the phone in "off" position should help counteract some of the time/energy issues, but if you are driving around a lot, flipping it on and off would probably be a wasted step after a while. I dont imagine someone using these devices outside of the car, so I am not sure how necessary it is. I am not sure how it affects other phones, but this has been my experience.Otherwise, once its up and running, it sounds clean and clear and the person on the other side has no problem hearing me. There is little peripheral sounds which is nice and brings the person you are talking to the forefront of your hearing.So the few things I found an issue with are not so much the device itself, which I think works very well, but more against the technology and its relationship it creates with the phone. But it certainly serves its purpose. I am relatively new to bluetooth devices, so I dont know how far they have come since they began making them, but it seems to be a nearly perfected technology, save for the issues I raised above. If you are in need of one, this would be a good choice.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I use this with a Samsung rugged phone for when driving and I have few to no complaints.I do use the ear loop as I have never been able to find an in-ear piece that fits my ear canals, but that is no problem.  I had hoped that this would work as an in-ear unit since it was so light, I thought I wouldn't have any problems, but no luck for me.The thing that always concerns me is sound quality when it comes to Bluetooth headsets.  I realize that some of the sound quality issues has to do with the phone, but most has to deal with the headset.  I have had an excellent experience with this headset.  As far as what I hear on my end, it is great.  The volume can be raised to a loud enough level that I can hear well when I am in a louder vehicle cab. I really do notice the noise cancellation technology making a difference compared to other headsets I have used.  I hear people very clearly in often noisy environments.The only drawback is that sometimes people say I am hard to hear or that I sound distant.  I have tried re-positioning things to make it better but it appears to be hit or miss.  Sometimes people can hear me clearly, other times is sound very distant.  My only complaint.Of course the unit is easy to use, flip open to turn on, flip close to turn off.  The talk button is a little flimsy to use and hard to press down, but the headset does allow for voice activation for answering calls, so that is what I use most of the time.Battery life is extremely good, I can almost go a week with using the unit while driving and not need to recharge.I can speak much to the roaming distance since I am often not much farther than 10 feet from my phone.So all in all I do recommend this unit.  I would give 5 stars but the audio quality problems on the other end of the line cost one star.If you have any questions I would be happy to answer since I use the unit daily, just leave a comment and I will try to get back to you.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: The range on this thing is amazing.  I was talking and walked into my 2nd floor apartment without realizing I left my phone in the car!  The sound started getting a little hazy when I walked from the stairs into my kitchen, and I realized my phone was in the car (past the stairs, the walls, my car).The most I've ever talked on this phone in a single conversation is 5 hours with enough juice to have other shorter conversations later.  I've left it unplugged on my counter for up to 9 days without needing a charge (reported standby time is 12 days but I've never tested that).  It is VERY easy to turn on...all you do is flip the microphone down and an automated voice will indicate how much talk time is remaining (fold in the microphone to turn off the headset). This is important to me so I can alternate between my phone and headset with greater ease.This Motorola is a very lightweight earpiece, and it's great after leaving my job in a call center where we use heavier Plantronics headsets.  I prefer the ear hook but there's a soft earpiece you can use instead.  The response to voice commands is nice too.  You can say "answer" or "ignore" with incoming calls.The best BT headset I've ever had.  I've gone through BT from Plantronics, BlueAnt, Samsung, and a cheapter Motorola model.  I've not had any problems with call quality on either end of the conversation.  Another perk is that you can stream music through the headset and still receiving incoming calls with a touch of the answer button.I can't attest to the NFC pairing since my phone doesn't have that feature, but it was easy to find/pair on my phone.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Things we loved about the Elite Flip:+ Extremely light weight - as light as an earring+ Great sound quality+ 6 hours of battery life+ Re-charges with a standard micro-USBCould be better:- The Ear hook seems a little flimsy.- Device would not pair with my phoneMostly this is an awesome device. However, I have an old-style T-Mobile Samsumg phone. It has bluetooth but could not see this device. Unsure why. My son's Exhibit (smart phone) paired with it immediately, so I used his phone to evalute the device.The sound was very clear, and is always clear if the device is within a few feet of the phone. When you pair the device with the phone, the device tells you how much battery life is left. We found it to be fairly accurate. The voice management can be turned off if you don't like it.It's very easy to use, just unfold it to turn on and fold off. The ear hook will swivel to fit the left or right ear. It's very small and attractive and I can hide it under my hair.When my son is outside and calls me using this device, I have a hard time hearing him if the wind is blowing. Otherwise, I can't tell if he's using it or not when he calls.This is a great device, very lightweight, attractive and easy to use.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I found this headset to be very comfortable after wearing for long periods.  I have very small ears, and most headsets I've owned, after 30 minutes, my ears start to hurt because the rubber insert is usually too large for my ear hole. BTW, I am 5'4.I'm not sure why some reviewers think the noise cancellation doesn't work.  In fact it is just about the best headset I've ever used. Works wonderfully while driving.In the past these smaller headset didn't work as well as the larger ones, however the larger ones looked like hearing aids!  Times have changed.  I am very happy to have a headset that works as well as it looks.Good job, Motorola!Highly recommended.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: The Motorola Elite headset looks great and has great features, but also completely died.  I'll describe the features that work well, when the device is working.  I'll then describe the problem with my unit, which is hopefully just a defective unit, with others working just fine.The Elite looks great.  It comes with attachments that allow it to fit around the ear (show in image), in the ear, or on the ear, whichever is preferable.  I preferred it around the ear.  The sound quality is excellent, both listening and speaking.  The voice recognition allows a call to be answered or ignored without touching a button on the headset.  At first, it worked perfectly right out of the box, pairing with an Evo by HTC.  Up to this point, I would completely recommend the Elite.The problem I encountered was with the headset suddenly dying, as if completely out of power.  My phone could not recognize it when searching for Bluetooth devices.  I charged it up for around ten hours, but it still would not display a full charge.  Fortunately, it was still able to pair with the phone the next morning for around ten minutes, and then died again.Mine may just be a defective unit.  If you choose the Elite, I would recommend that you spend time to go through all the features within the return period.  If it works, you're set.  If not, you still have time to return it to Amazon.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This item does it all. I can do voice text which is perfect when I am needed to respond but have my hands full!
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I have used several different ear pieces with my iPhone 4 and the Motorola Elite Flip headset has been, by far, the simplest to use. I particularly enjoy the easy start up (just a flip of the mouthpiece) and that it speaks the battery strength to you.Pros:-Ease of use-Seamless pairing with iPhone 4-Clear sound and easy volume adjustment-Noise canceling really works-Motospeak app to let you know battery strengthI admit to not having tried to use the Motospeak for texting. As far as I can tell it's only for Android phones. But if you're looking for a simple headset, this is the best one I've found.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I actually use this as much for listening to audiobooks and podcasts as talking on the phone. It is not the best for phone, but much better than Motorola HX550, which I could not use for talking on the phone since no one could ever hear me. This one is acceptable for the phone and listening to audio. I have two Plantronics headsets including the Legend with a boom mike, and people can hear me better on the phone, but both of them are horrible for listening to audio since they are way too quiet. The Motorola Elite Flip is better if you need a headset for both purposes.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: My Jabra Extreme was finally losing battery life, so I began the search for a replacement. My key features were a comfortable "in ear" ear piece, good distance so i can walk around the house, good battery life, and clarity for people on the other end. It was paired with my Motorola Droid MAXX.None of the ear pieces are comfortable.  The "over the ear" ones seem to hold the speak too far away from the ear, such that it is noticeably harder to hear.  Neither of the two sizes of the "in ear" ear pieces fit me well; the big one is too big and the little one doesn't stay in during moderate movement.  I tried using my Jabra ear piece, but its ID is just a little too large for the OD of the speaker.The usable distance is somehow worse than with the old Jabra.  Maybe 20 ft with one wall between.  Even without a wall, the distance is not impressive.  Sometimes it doesn't pair with my phone even though I have my phone in my hands.The battery life is good.  I don't think it is any better than the Jabra in its hayday, but it lasts long enough for me.Clarity seems to be good for other people, certainly no worse than the Jabra.  No one has said "holy crap you're so much clearer".  The audio quality (when listening to music) is maybe a little better, but I could take it or leave it.  Calling it HD is a stretch.If it could, I would return it, try my luck with a different brand/model.  But it is still serviceable even with the flaws.  I'm just looking forward to the day I get to replace it.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This little thing is great.  Easy on, easy off.  Fits in my pocket and is very durable.  I don't worry about it getting broken as I carry it in my pocket or computer bag.  Fits nicely in my ear and the sound quality is good.
title: Motorola ELITE FLIP Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: What can I say it's Motorola for one thing!!!and they stand behind their products. This item came packaged well and had everything it was supposed to have in it. I have had no problems with it and it works great. People can hear me well and I can hear them well. I also listen to music through this device and it sounds great. The best selling point I can say is that it retails for $130.00 but I bought it for $60.00 here on Amazon. This is by far the best bluetooth I have ever owned, I would recommend this device to all.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have tried a few others, like Jawbone ERA, and some other Motorola's, but this is definitely the best!!I always got a sore ear after a couple hours with the others, even with the most comfortable ear cushions.I can wear the Sliver all day, in either ear, and I basically forget its there. The carry case is a fantasticidea, it keeps your Sliver safe in a pocket or duffelbag, and charges it at the same time. I use my Sliver formusic(iheartradio) alot too. You can also download MYMOTOSPEAK from Google Play(Android phones)if you want to be able to listen to and dictate text messages. I tried it but I like the voice commands software that came with my DroidX2 better. I would highly recommend this bluetooth.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've been using this with my iphone 3GS and my boyfriend has also been trying it out with his iphone 4. It pairs almost immediately with both phones on it's own. Nothing to fiddle with. It also tells you directions as it's pairing in the event you have a problem and need to do it manually. It immediately also tells you how much "call time" you have, so you'll know when to charge it.First thing someone said to me when using it was "did you get a new phone? You're more clear then you've ever been!"...that alone is worth it's weight in gold! We have horrible service inside our apartment, and the Motorola Elite Sliver is great since we can leave the actual phone in the window where it gets the most bars and move about the house with no problems. The two buttons on the headset are easy to use for various tasks, and one of the buttons you can assign to do anything you like. The charger case is small and will slip in a pocket while also keeping it safe(we all know we've sat on/stepped on small gadgets!).The voice commands for dialing don't work with my iphone, but I think that's more the phone then the headset. My only real issue is that the headset hurts my ear after a little while. I have abnormally small ears, so this is a common issue for me. I have yet to find a headset that's small enough, or comfortable for an extended period of time. Though, out of all the headsets I've tried, this is the most comfortable and secure. I hate the ones that just are suppose to fit in your ear, it's great that this one hooks over your ear for added security so I don't feel like it'll come flying right out. Besides my ear size, this is an amazing headset, definitely recommended!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: You know, these little bluetooth headsets can be a thorough pain in the but*.  For the life of me I can't figure out why these Chinese can mangle up such a simple design concept.  If it's not the build quality, it's the software.  If it's not the software, it's the operational use.  If it's not operational, it's the documentation.  Or the battery.  Or weird behavior.  Or annoying "features".  There's always SOMEthing completely screwed up, left out, incompatible or just broken right out of the box.  And Motorola doesn't hold the patent for screwed up engineering of Bluetooth headsets.  Wait till you try to get a new Plantronics to work with an iPhone 5.I had lots of high hopes for this one.  Couldn't wait for it to get here.  Charged it up, but quickly found out it doesn't have a standard USB charge port.  You HAVE to put it in it's proprietary little case, then plug the case into USB.  Which means you got to carry the case around wherever you go or it'll never get charged.  Then there's the incessant beeping - and nobody - I mean nobody including Motorola tech support knows why it beeps at you every 5 secs.  Sometimes while on mute it'll beep every 5 secs.  Sometimes when it's not in "wide range mode" it'll beep every 5 secs.  Sometimes when there's more than one device nearby it'll beep.  But beep at you it will, to the point you can't even use it.  One time a fully charged unit started beeping at me about 15 mins into the call.  It showed a full charge.  A cohort has one and says he has the same problem, and went back to his Jabra.The only people that know why/when it'll beep at you are the software engineers, and they're all in China.  And unreachable behind communist walls.  And it's not documented anywhere - even internally according to tech support.  But it *IS* a feature of some sort they think.This little headset had potential - it has a surprisingly good fit.  But the button management is just stupid.  Hold the "smart" button (just above the volume buttons) and it'll go on mute.  If you don't hold it just long enough, it'll cut off the call.  The bottom button does different things at different times - but usually serves to cut off the unit mid-talk.  Miss the volume button(s) and you'll hit the smart button and again and unknowingly shut off the call.  I was hosting about 20 people on a concall and every time I'd touch the volume it it would hang up, and all 20 of us would get cut off.  One by one we'd join in again, and if I touched it it'd hang up again.  I gave up.I bet they had high hopes for this unit too - probably until some idiotic project manager related to some VP took over and ruined the idea.  For $40, I can live with it - I'll just give it to a friend.  But this unit was $150 when it first came out - the mangled implementation explains why it now cost about 20% of the original price.  They have warehouses full of these things - and nobody wants them lol
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This slim bluetooth headset is a slick little piece of technology. I'll emphasize little, because it has a low profile that hides most of the device behind the ear with a small piece that wraps around to the ear canal.The carrying case/charger is a brilliant idea and works flawlessly.A handy feature that I only discovered with use is that turning the ear piece powers the device on and off, thus engaging and severing the bluetooth connection in the process. It's a logical way to do things, but I'll admit that I wasn't expecting it and was pleased to discover it. Another nice feature is the announcement of hours of talk-time remaining whenever I pair the headset to my phone. This leaves no question about when I need to recharge.The sound quality is top notch, but the most common critique I've received from those on the other end is that it sounds like I have them on speaker phone. This makes sense given the microphone's placement behind my ear, but is a bit disappointing nonetheless. While I haven't tested the claim that the headset can work up to 300 feet away from the phone, I have tested it at closer to 60 feet with a few walls separating the phone and headset. Those on the other end say it sounds like I'm in a tunnel when I tested this, but it holds the connection quite well and I didn't notice any difference in call quality on my end.My phone is a Motorola, so the ease of setup and use may vary when connected to a different device, but given that my phone is simply a feature phone and not a smart phone (which the headset was optimized for) I've still found that it does all that was advertised. This is definitely the simplest and best bluetooth headset I've tried to date. It's a keeper.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I was sold on form and design.  I don't like the bulky boom type headsets.  However, everyone I talk to can barely hear me.  Put on my old Plantronics Voyager, and no problem.  Having had several headsets, I am under impressed with this.  It's too bad, because it is probably one of the most comfortable headsets, has good sound quality, but people complain when I call them having trouble hearing my speech.Recommendation: avoid this until mic issues are fixed.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: First of all, lets get to the good news. Amazing battery life. This set lasts almost as much as my one of many previous bluetooths even when I am listening to music. Oh, and since the unit doubles as a headset, you can listen to music stored on your phone. So, no need for that earpieces you carry around on your "other" pocket.Now, the bad news: Background noise. Now, this may be due to me owning one of the best bluetooth set in recent timesPlantronics Voyager PRO+ Bluetooth Headset, but the amount of background noise the set seems to cancel is quite low. Don't let it hold you back though, because the call clarity more than makes up for it. Just be ready to accept the fact that this is not your top tier bluetooth set.It is a very simplistic headset, and you should have no problems getting used to it. And, it works awesome with a PS3 too.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have a number of headsets and each seems to have a favorite feature. In addition to the small size ofMotorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - 89503N, what I like best about this product is the voice-texting feature. That and the clarity of the 300-foot range and high-density audio are to die for.The technology of this headset is amazing...so easy... All I have to do is plug it into my phone or my iPod, relax into a comfy chair and do my thing! There's nothing like relaxing while listening to my favorite music or texting my kids to make me happy...without worrying about static noises in the background.Wow! Highly recommended.Reviewed by Betty Dravis, March 22, 2012Author of "Star Struck: Interviews with Dirty Harry and Other Hollywood Icons"
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola Elite Sliver has been an entirely new experience for me and honestly, I find myself using using my bluetooth headset more now then ever because it's so much more convenient to use then my last one (5+ years old, came with my Razer), way more comfortable to wear, and the sound quality is superb - I can actually hear the person on the other line.For starters, the case that this headset arrives in is very slick.  It has a built in battery charger for your headset on the go and (if I understood the instructions correctly...) the case itself has some abilities to synch the headset to your phone by touch however, I don't believe my phone has the necessary technology for this to work (iPhone 3GS).  No worries though because synching this headset couldn't have been easier.  You just power it on and then seek out the bluetooth device in your phone's settings.  Slightly embarrassed to say that it took me a little while to figure out how to wear this bluetooth (you twist the ear piece so the large speaker part of the headset can slide up and behind your ear) and also how to turn it off (it turns off automatically when you twist the ear piece back into it's resting position as shown in the case).The only reason why I gave this a four star rating is because although I can hear the person on the other line crystal clear, I've been told quite a few times that my line seemed fuzzy or I seemed muffled when I've used this headset.  In fact, my boyfriend can tell without fail when I'm using my headset or not based on the sound quality of my line.  And although this may simply be an issue with my own comprehension of the instructions enclosed, I kind of feel that they were too vague.  I'm still not 100% sure what the little button on the headset does (other then make little beeping noises in my ear) and it's luck of the draw if I get the big button to do what I want it to do at the opportune time.Overall though, I love this headset.  It works and it's so comfortable!  My last headset always felt like it was on the verge of falling off or it would start to hurt my ear after wearing it for longer then 10 minutes.  This headset I could easily wear all day long and forget about it and it is super discreet with the bulk of it hidden behind your ear.  The clam shell charging case also makes it easy to just toss in your purse (or pocket) and go.  Would definitely recommend this headset to friends and family.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Very nice design overall. It pairs very easily w/iphone4S and turns on/off and connects with a twist of the earpiece (no separate switch, so that's a very nice feature). With some headsets you have to press a switch for a couple of seconds before it turns on (never quite figured that out, why do you want to press a button for that long ?).  Very comfortable and light.  Sound quality is also very good.  The charging/storage case is aesthetically pleasing.  The color scheme is neat, it's a black casing (soft to the touch) with "metallic" gray/black on the earpiece stem, so it's a really nice bit of a contrast. The only cons are: 1. Some people may think it looks like a hearing aid, 2. If something happens to the case, you're out of luck because you have to have it to charge the unit.  I think Motorola could have somehow put a charging port on the headset, although the odds of something happening to the case are slim to none).  3. The caller ID only tells you the number and it takes a while to say it, which in the meantime your phone has rung at least three times.  Motorola needs a firmware upgrade to state the name if it's available.  I use it while driving my Corolla and my wife says she can hear me just fine.Update 2/1: Still think it's a nice headset, but Motorola is misleading the user into thinking it has voice dialing. Well...it actually interacts with the phone's voice dial, so it's not built into the headset.  For it to be built-in, it would have to import the phonebook, and this thing doesn't do that. Also, don't know if it's just me, but I noticed that the LED in the charging case goes from green to red a few seconds after inserting the headset, and I've never seen the LED go yellow.  Called Motorola to ask if that's normal, but their "tech" support is not much help at all with more involved questions like that, and they say that's the only level of suppport they have.  So...my question will probably remain unanswered until I get another headset.Update 2/27: Forgot to mention..it seemed to me like this headset actually goes to "sleep" (power save) if worn but not used for a while. Several times I noticed my phone would ring, but only after the first ring did it transfer to the headset. Also, I tried pushing the button to activate Siri on my iphone (yes, it did work with Siri), but the first time I pressed the call button, nothing happened.  Had to press it again to wake it up.  Not the biggest deal, but it can make you wonder what's going on, in large part because Motorola does not mention a whole lot of operational detail in either their website or their owner's manual.  If these things are "fixed", I may buy it again.  I think this sleep mode is a big part of why the battery life seems to be so good.  Still think it's nice, but Motorola needs to inform users COMPLETELY on how this thing operates.  I downgraded my rating to 3 stars due to Motorola's lack of info...
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Ordered this it had good and bad reviews but it is easy to use was easily paired with my phone and has a nice range from the phone when around the house. and has not dropped a call yet on me so not sure where people came up with those issues I would buy again.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I work in often times warm temperatures and perspiration causes the unit to go haywire and keep disconnecting and reconnecting which is very annoying.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have bought two slivers in the last 30 days. First one just simply stopped working and now the second one is auto dialing off my phone log for no reason, I will being listen to music and it will just suddenly start dialing.. BOTH HEAD SETs have problems with play music properly, they both cut in and out all the time. Going back to return and try it one more time. Then on to another brand if it doesn't work out. To bad really it is very comy and the niose reduction is excellent! Hopefully they will get the bugs worked out.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: It's hard to get excited about a Bluetooth headset anymore. There are so many to choose from and you can only do so much to a tiny little device. Every once in a while, though, a headset will come along with a distinctive design and a feature-set that stands out from the rest. The Motorola ELITE SLIVER is such a device and my new primary headset.PROS:- Great audio quality- Good battery life (5 hours of talk time)- Charging case provides an additional 10 hours of talk time- Good noise cancellation- 300ft range for Class 1 phones (30ft for Class 2)- Stylish appearance- Comfortable fit- Android app adds additional featuresCONS:- Volume control goes in steps- Thin on accessories- PriceyPAIRINGPairing the SLIVER to an HTC Droid Incredible 2 the old-fashioned way was simple and familiar. The SLIVER also supports Multipoint (2 devices) pairing. The interesting thing about the SLIVER is that it supports pairing via Near Field Communications (NFC) too. To pair using NFC, you just take the SLIVER (in the case) and touch an NFC-enabled phone. That's it.FITAs I've stated many times over in past headset reviews, a headset's fit is one of the most important features for me. It has to be easy to put on and it has to stay on. The SLIVER comes with a selection of ear gels to optimize fit and comfort. I found it to be very comfortable to wear and is the first Bluetooth headset I've reviewed in which the bulk of the headset rests behind my ear lobe. At just 9 ounces, I barely feel the SLIVER on my ear.Initially, I needed to use both hands to put the SLIVER on. I eventually got used to slipping it on one-handed but it definitely requires more effort than my trusty Jabra EXTREME. I don't like wearing headsets unless I'm actually using them, which is why the headsets that I leave in my car are easy to put on. I keep the headsets that require a little more effort to put on for home/office use. It's also worth mentioning that the SLIVER's earpiece swivels in both directions so that it can be worn on either ear.CALL QUALITYThe call quality of the ELITE SLIVER was very good on both ends. The caller on the other end came in very clear and I had no problems with the volume. The SLIVER's noise canceling technology is referred to as CrystalTalk, which uses dual microphones. I was told by callers that they could hear me well, even when I was driving on the highway. My Toyota 4Runner doesn't have the quietest interior cabin, so a headset with good noise cancellation is a must for me.MUSICThe ELITE SLIVER supports advanced audio distribution profile (A2DP), which means that you can stream music and GPS directions from your phone to the headset. Many Bluetooth headsets support A2DP but most of them don't perform that well with music. If you spend a lot of time listening to music with your phone, you need to seriously give the SLIVER a listen, because it's the best sounding Bluetooth mono headset I've ever heard. I wouldn't throw out your hi-fi stereo headphones, but at low to medium volume levels, the SLIVER is a joy to use with music. I streamed music from Google Music, Spotify and Pandora and enjoyed the wireless freedom.BATTERY & CHARGINGThe SLIVER is rated for 5 hours of talk time on its own. When you factor in the charging case, you can get up to 15 hours of talk time and 35 days of standby! The body of the charging case is made out of matte plastic, with a glossy, semi-translucent plastic lid. There really isn't much to the case. It has a micro-USB port for charging and that's pretty much it. On the downside, only a dedicated wall charger is included in the box. For such an expensive and high-end headset, I was a little surprised that Motorola didn't include a USB cable with separate wall and car chargers. Still, because the headset uses a micro-USB port for charging, there's a good chance that you already have chargers and cables that are compatible.BUTTONSThe SLIVER has just two physical buttons. The smart(multifunction) button controls the volume, turns mute on/off, activates the Android My Motospeak app, and rejects calls. Of course, like most advanced headsets, you can use your voice to answer and reject calls. The other button on the SLIVER is the call button, which can launch your phone's voice dialing feature, redial, answer a call, and end a call. Both buttons were easy to use and responsive. My only gripe is that I prefer separate volume buttons, rather than having a single multifunction button that cycles through volume levels.MY MOTOSPEAKMy Motospeak is the Android app by Motorola that allows you to customize the SLIVER and send text messages by voice. To activate My Motospeak, you just hit the smart button, then it asks you to "say a command." You can tell the app to call or text someone at that point. Texting worked OK, but I wouldn't rely on it for lengthy messages. It's a nice option for short SMS messages though, like, "running late" or "should I pick up milk?" The app also allows you to change the headset equalizer but the default setting sounded best to me. You can also customize the noise cancellation to different environments, but I don't foresee users modifying it from the default. The app also does a decent job of reading back new text messages to you while driving. It's worth installing the app for sure, but I wouldn't get the SLIVER just for the app support. My Motospeak is available from both the Android Market and the Amazon Appstore.SUMMARYThe Motorola ELITE SLIVER is one of the most advanced Bluetooth headsets I've ever used. If that weren't enough, it's also the best sounding headset I've ever heard. Voice calls, GPS directions and music, all sounded excellent. The charging case is a great convenience for storage/protection and boosts talk time for up to 10 additional hours. The stylish SLIVER is also easy to use, comfortable, and fits well.  If you're looking for an advanced Bluetooth headset, give the Motorola ELITE SLIVER a go.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The quality control department did a poor job when they did not bother to set aside a product that would stay connected no natter what you would do to it. I returned it.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Its hard to find anything wrong with this device.  After opening the package, I immediately paired it with my iPod touch and my cellphone.The process was fast and simple.The headset design is simple and elegant.  The large, curving ear loop is very comfortable - no pricking, like I've had with other headsets.  After its been on for a few minutes I tend to forget its there!The charging unit is small, compact, tough and cool looking.  It carries a full backup charge for the headset, which gives the Elite a ten hour battery life and its small enough to fit comfortably in any pocket.I've always had difficulty using the onboard mic on my iPod to record voice memos, or to dictate text into Dragon.With the Motorola Elite Sliver, my voice memo recordings were crystal clear.When I dictated text into Dragon Speech Recognition, I was able to get perfect transcriptions of my speech.The next task was to use Skype for a phone call.  Flawless performance there too.  I made the call from the playroom in a local McDonald's restaurant, a noisy environment at the best of times.Using my cellphone in there, boosted to full volume, its usually difficult to hear, and my iPod's onboard mic couldn't deal with the ambient noise.With the Elite Sliver, my call was clear.  I asked my customer if he could hear the screaming children in the background, and he said no.  He also said the signal quality was remarkably clear and was shocked when I told him that I was using a headset.For my uses, this is one of the best headsets on the market in its price range.  I give it my best recommendation!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is my tenth blue tooth device.  All of them had problems. This Motorola Elite Sliver Bluetooth Headset is terrific. It come in a tiny case that serves as the recharging unit. After charging the unit (very fast)it was simple to pair with my Samsung Reclaim phone. Once paired, when I put it over my ear and fit the earpiece in my ear, the unit announces how many hours of talk time are available before another recharge (5 hours). I have very small ear openings and most earpieces are too big and uncomfortable. This unit is designed like a state-of-the-art hearing aid. It fits behind the ear and only a small portion of it shows leading from the unit to the ear canal. The sound is clear w/o any echo or static. It is the best bluetooth ever, and I have tried and used quite a few.

reviewText: I gave this to my dad, who is constantly on the phone when he's driving. He does complain of it not being loud enough when he's in crowded places, but it's not much of a problem since he really just uses it in the car during his commute.The design is pretty sleek and attractive, and though my dad has never really liked using Bluetooth headsets he has become accustomed to using this quite frequently in the past five months that he has had it.

reviewText: **Update 11/16/2011**I didn't put this in my first review because I thought it was my phone and not the headset... but sometimes when I play music the sound cuts in and out.  Almost like a very hard static.  With my iPhone 3Gs I thought it was because my phone was old and I had dropped it a few times.  But when I paired this headset with my iPhone 4s I (at times) heard the same thing.  The good thing is that it doesn't completely shut the app like it did with the 3Gs.  It's just a few seconds of hard static and then it goes back to the music.  It HAS NOT done this with phone calls.  I don't know if this is an iPhone pairing thing or what but I find it hard to believe that two phone could be experiencing the exact same problem************************Ahhhhh... the wonder of technology.  When I first opened the package I was thinking, "how in the world can this device pick up my freaking voice"?  One part goes in my ear and the other part wraps BEHIND my ear.  How in the... ?  Well, once I got over trying to figure it out and started using it I was very, very, very happy.  Just for reference I use an iPhone 3Gs and an iPad 2.  I think I read somewhere this is best used for Android phones.  I only found one instance where having an Android phone with this device is "better", but I'll get to that in a minute:Charging: charging items are usually a boring and little thought of aspect to electronic devices.  Not so with this one (at least with me).  Not only does this wireless headset hold a good charge, but even if you were to run it down all you would have to do is put it in its case.  The CASE is the charger!  How cool is that?  The case itself is very small and can easily fit in a purse or even your front pocket.  When you do (finally) run out of power all you do is place the headset in the case and plug the case in the wall.  The specs say that we have up to 15 hours of talk time with the case.  I have yet to get anywhere close to that, but I love the fact that I can just grab the case and go and not have to worry about lugging around yet another cord.  The bad news is that if you lose the case, you lost the ability to charge your headset.Pairing: very easy.  When you put on the headset you get prompts from the lady in the sky on how to pair it.  I didn't need to use the pass code to pair it for either of my devices but she does give you one should you need it.  I did pair it with my iPad 2 but since I don't think you're supposed to(?) it recognized it as  "phone 1".  To once you turn it off or put it back in its case linking up is automatic as long as your device has the setting to "on".  The lady in the sky also let you know once you are connected or become disconnected.Call clarity: VERY good.  I walk my kids to and from school every day.  It's about a 50 minute round trip and I am able to hear my callers even on the busy stretch of road. In the house or in the Jeep it's even better because I don't have that outside noise to worry about.  You can use the buttons on the headset to adjust volume, end calls, and start calls (if you have voice activation on your mobile device).  This device is also a good fit because it wraps around your ear like a glove.  I never had to adjust while I was out walking.Music:  Since this is a wireless headset you are able to listen to music as well.  BONUS!  This is my first Bluetooth headset and I felt like I hit pay dirt when I found this out.  Sometimes it's the small things and not having to fight with cords as I'm getting the kids ready or trying to find some misplaced item in my Jeep is one of them.Battery power: no complaints whatsoever.  I will admit that I'm not a phone hog but I do listen to music a lot and I've never gotten close to running out of power, especially since I use the charged case.The Android connection: I wanted to use the `My MotoSpeak' but that is only for Android phones.  With the app you can hear text and reply to texts.  I guess since the iPhone has Siri Motorola might have felt the need to not make one for iOS devices.  But for folks like me who don't have the iPhone 4s, it would be nice to have that option.  But that's small cheese when you take this device as a whole.  All in all, I'm very happy with this device.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have gone through a lot of bluetooth headsets.  In fact recently during a trip I must have misplaced the one I was using which I had come to prefer.  So when this one arrived I was anxious to test it out.Well, it was a breeze to set it up.  Not a problem at all.  Took a very, very short time.The case is a bit bulkier than I like.  But that being said, the case is a reserve batter pack.  Every time you place the headset in the case it recharges it.  So you essentially get a lot of battery power with this unit.  The case uses a micro USB charger to charge and it has two little lights within that glow nicely to tell the charging state of the case and the headset.  It charges the headset first, then the case battery.The controls are real simple.  When you move the earpiece it turns the headset on and announces how much charge time you have.  When you turn it inwards it turns the headset off.If your call coming in has caller ID the headset announces the number.  You can answer the call by merely saying answer or ignore.  There is a mute control as well.The headset comes with a number of plastic rings to fit your ear.  It fits well and there is no protruding microphone that I always seem to have trouble with.All in all I highly recommend this headset and plan to use it as my preferred choice.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Had read many reviews from different people about different headsets.  Well I believe this is the best headset so far that I have used.  NO issues with noises around me and people can hear me clearly.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I had been using the Motorola H710 for the last couple of years, and while it was decent in its own right, I could not seem to squeeze out more than 4-5 hours without a re-charge, even when it was new.  I would get tons of echo and I could not travel far from my phone without losing functionality.  People complained all the time that they had a hard time hearing me.Not so with the Elite Silver!  Pairing to my iPhone 4 was a snap, I didn't even need to put in a code, just turned on the headset after charging it and it paired to the phone immediately.  I love the command functions.  I didn't think they would work well, as my experiences with voice commands always seem to be lukewarm.  I like just being able to say "answer" if I have my hands in something, like doing dishes or whatever, so I don't need to touch the headset at all.  You can also say "ignore" if you don't want to answer the call.  I have not figured out how to use it with call waiting other than pressing a button.  I guess the voice commands only work with the first call, which makes sense.  The headset also works great for listening to music/streaming audio etc., although some songs you need to have something in both ears to get the full effect from the song.You can pair this with two different devices, so my husband has it paired to his phone as well, although he did need to enter the code 0000.I have found that the battery does last almost 15 hours as the product claims.  I can't say anything for the standby time because I never leave it alone for long enough!  I like that the charger is also a carrying case as it makes it easier to find in my purse and keeps dust, dirt, and moisture from coming in contact with the headset when charging and not in use.  The H710 just charged with a regular charging cable and it was easily lost.Great headset!  Worth the upgrade if you are using an older Motorola headset!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a small, compact bluetooth with good sound quality when there is still a good charge. Having used this headset with my iPhone for the past 3 weeks i will have to say that I am quite satisfied. When the battery life exceeds 1 hour talk time the sound is great. Once you get below one hour - here comes the static. I've been able to squeeze up to 5.5 hours talk time on this device (shorter than the 8 that is claimed) and like I said the last hour is full of static. I appreciate that when you turn it on it indicates the status and talk time left. It fits in and over (behind your ear) so its not too noticeable - which is a plus. The drawbacks are the proprietary charger (or carrying case as Motorola puts it and the static filled final hour of talk time. Pluses are small unobtrusive form factor, voice status indications, sound quality.Pros:*Small and unobtrusive design*Voice status indicators*sound qualityCons:*Proprietary charger*Last hour of talk time is static-filledOverall 4/5 stars
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have been using this headset for almost two weeks now and that has given me some time to form some pretty firm opinions.First, I am using the headset with an IPhone 4.The unit is very well made, good build quality, with sturdy construction.  It fits very comfortably on either ear, you turn kit on by rotating the earpiece and the startup sequence is very pleasant.The headset comes in a case that also serves as a charger, the case has an internal battery that charges the headset even when the case is not plugged in.  This is a fantastic feature as it extends the life of the headset dramatically, even without charging in the case you can talk for almost 5 hours, and the case charge adds hours more.  The case is also very well built, and very easy to carry around.  I usually lose cases, but this one goes in my pocket whenever I know I will be on the road all day.The range is, as advertised, about 50 feet give or take, though it depends on building construction.  It can be linked to two devices, I linked to both my phone and laptop.  One problem, that seems inherent with all Bluetooth devices, is that it has had to be resynced twice.  I have no idea why and this is very annoying.  However the process is pretty painless.The sound in the earpiece is excellent, but the microphone has some trouble, even in quiet environments.  The sound is muddy, and loses clarity.  This is my chief complaint, and can get quite annoying.  When speaking to those with any hearing difficulties it becomes almost mpossible and you have to use the phone without the headset, but most people can hear it relatively clearly.This is by far the best headset I have used, but it is still somewhat limited.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is the only Bluetooth set that does everything what it does not say or in other words opposite to what it says... it does not block the noise nor it gives clear voice to the listener... yes may be if you are in your room it works fine but not good even if you are driving!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I miss my Jabra Stone. I used aJabra STONEbefore this Motorola Bluetooth. Even though that Jabra Stone is about 3 years older than this current Motorola Sliver, the Jabra Stone wins hands down. In this review I will compare both.PairingThis Bluetooth is super easy to pair and use. You can simply tap your phone and the Motorola Charger and you are done. I did the regular pairing with the code and it was simple as well.Design/FitThe fit and design of the Jabra Stone is excellent. It fits snuggly and has a slick design that was not cumbersome. In contrast, this Motorola Blue tooth is too big for my ears (average sized ears) and it cannot be adjusted. The design is clunky and heavy on your ear. Because of the weight and fit, the bluetooth has often fallen or slipped off my ear. Even during action as simple as taking off my coat.Talk FeaturesIt about the worst I have used. For several minutes I tried to "Call Mom" or "Text Mom" and other simple commands and the Bluetooth was not able to pick up a single one. Instead, it directed my phone to call people I had not spoken to in years. It was very embarrassing. Moreover, if you have even the slightest accent, this feature is even worse at picking up what you say.Charge/Talk TimeThis is the only good thing about this Bluetooth. It holds a 5 hour talk time charge and has a carrier that recharges your phone, even when not plugged in. The battery will last you forever.OverallI regret my decision to get rid of my Jabra Stone. I want it back. I will still use this Motorola Bluetooth but only until something better comes along.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I recieved this headset as a Vine offer, and I do not normall use or require a headset. But I have to say that I was very pleased with it. First off, the thing looks pretty cool. Its not as sleek as a lot of Jawbone or plantronics headsets, but I like this over the ear look. The earpiece definitely is noticable and you probably won't forget that you're wearing it, but it was comfortable for hours of wear and its over the ear design keeps in place when you move your head around. Another nice bonus: no "idiot light"! There is a blue LED that indicates certain activity, but it does not incessantly blink like other headsets. I never had any complaints on calls with it, and it does allow a certain amount of hands free manipulation (though I wasn't able to test this, since my phone setup is a little complicated):About the phone I used with it: Its a Samsung (Google) Nexus S. Running Android Cyanogenmod 7 (yeah, i'm one of those guys). I did try the NFC pairing feature, but the phone didn't know what to do with the NFC tag. It recognized it immediately, but it didn't launch anything. Fortunately the normal blue tooth pairing process is only slightly slower. The voice on the headset rather loudly proclaims "Phone 1 connected" and that's all there is to it. I could listen to music, speak voice commands, it all sounded and worked quite well.Battery life was quite good, though I never wore it long enough to drain it, and I don't use my phone for voice communication. But I was also able to pair the phone with my MacBook, where I do make calls. Again, the bluetooth setup process was fairly quick and painless and I was able to communicate with Google Voice and even tried recording it a few times to check the sound quality. Again, sound quality was pretty good, but when paired with the MacBook there were some fairly subtly pops- not quite static sounding and the sound was actually clearer than the onboard mic, but it could be a little distracting.The final great feature is the carrying case that also functions as a small recharge station (which Motorola touts as allowing up to 15 hours of "talk time"). When fully charged, the headset gives you 5 hours of talk time, so that probably means you can get about 3 full recharges just from putting it back in its case. When the case and headset are connected to AC Power, the headset charges first. Overall, I'm very satisfied with its performance (battery life and sound quality), though its only fairly comfortable to wear and at this price, the thing should feel good in the ear which I think Motorola could have done some more work on.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Ok, first let me start by saying this ear peice is truly 1 of a kind.  I have had at least 12 other headsets including  jawbone's, jarbra, bose, plantronics, etc..  The sound quality was clear as day and night.  NO that's right I said NO issues with clarity using it.  People immediately thought i was crazy because they could not see anyting in my ear. I went into a VERY LOUD basketball gym and tested the NOISE CANCELLATION with all options in the MOTOSPEAK application and they made no difference at all. title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I paired this headset to my iPhone right out of the box. It comes fully charged, which is easy to appreciate.First I'll speak to the quality. The headset fits very comfortably behind the ear and actually feels pretty good. I've used other Bluetooth earpieces and I've experienced discomfort, pain in the ear, low quality sound and poor signal quality. The Motorola Elite gave me none of those things. I called my wife's phone and spoke to her. She never even knew I was on a Bluetooth. I then walked way across the house, away from my phone and the signal never waivered. The sound quality I received was unexpectedly good; very clear, nice and loud, very good quality.It charges while resting in its case. It fits snugly in the case and easily fits into a pocket until it's ready for use. When turning the unit on, it announces the number of hours of talk time available, which is a nice high number when charged. Press the button on the bottom of the unity and speak the name of the person from your contact list and your phone dials the number. Say "hang up" and the phone hangs up. It's the one hands-free device that's truly hands-free (except for turning it on).All said, this is a high quality headset with advanced features and is user-friendly. Expect big things from this little item.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: THe bluetooth arrived on time, however the bluetooh does not work at the length given in the description. Porbably only works for 150 ft which is still good.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I love this bluetooth headset. The earpiece fits comfortably behind the ear. It can easily switch from the left ear to the right ear with just a twist of the ear piece. The sound quality is excellent for both making calls and listening to music on your phone. I have also used the headset to watch videos on my smartphone - occasionally there will be a slight delay between the image on the screen and the sound you hear, but since listening to movies/videos is not one of the advertised purposes of this headset, I don't deduct anything from its rating.My favorite thing about this headset is that the microphone portion of the headset is also located behind the ear, eliminating the need for what I call the "Britney Spears" mic - you know the kind that come across the cheek bone or in front of the ear. Those types of microphones are great for popstars, but I prefer a headset that is a little less noticeable. When i have my hair down, you can't even tell that I'm wearing it.I've used it to jam out to my favorite songs at the grocery store and talk on the phone when I've got my hands full. The bluetooth has an excellent range. I can leave my phone in the living room of my house and still be connected via my headset while I'm in the kitchen.The charging case is a fantastic accessory. Not only does it store your headset, but it has enough of a built-in charge that you can throw it in your pocket or bag when your battery is low and it quickly recharges it on the go. The case can plug into the wall as well for easy charging at home.This has been my favorite headset so far.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: When I opened the charger case that contained the headset I thought I was going to have to defend it from a friend who was standing at my side.  It is an elegantly designed bit of electronics and very attractive.I should probably confess that the last blue tooth telephone headset I owned was bought in 2006 in a foolish moment of optimism at an ATT phone store.  It looked like this one:Motorola H700 Bluetooth Headsetand I have still have it because I rarely used it.  It was uncomfortable and the features worked on an occasional basis.  It also ran out of battery power quickly and spent more time charging than being worn when I did try to use it.Ok, this one is as different as night and day.  Besides fitting my ear perfectly, it is easy to use.  I have an iPhone 3g with which it paired at once. The in-ear instructions were something I had not encountered before and they helped to make set up a snap.  The sound is clear and I use it to listen to audio books in confidence that if I get a call the music or book will pause and I will be given a choice to reject or accept the call vocally.Now for the problem.  Don't expect to get 300 ft from your phone and be able to hear it.  I took it to an empty parking lot and got about 100 ft.  In the house it was about 80 ft.  This didn't bother me a great deal because I'm usually carrying my phone.  I also think the 15 hour charge is a bit optimistic, but it was pretty close, about 13.5 hours.I would also suggest that you keep a close track on the case.  It's small and it is also the charger so losing it would be a nuisance or worse.Definitely recommended if you don't mind the distance thing.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I got this one for my girlfriend! She Loves it! I had to buy her another one because she broke her first one! I bought one that came in bulk packaging. I didn't like that one at all. I sent it back and I ordered another one (Retail Packaging! I love this one. The battery life is great and I get great sound too! You can charge the little case and when your battery gets low just put the Bluetooth in the case and t will charge without plugging the case in!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Product is good, lightweight you wont notice it after about 5 minutes. Only thing I would ask for is that the ear piece would fit better and it was a little louder
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: At first look I couldn't figure out how it could possibly have clear outgoing voice but it does.  I haave three different devices.  This is not my favorite but close.  It has a long use time both in talk and standby.  My favorite is the Jawbone for clarity of conversation but this one for staying on your ear.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have been using this headset for about 2 months now for chatting while playing online games on the Playstation 3.  I have both positive and negative things to say about it.My positive comments:This bluetooth headset is very comfortable and I like the design of it.  I love the fact that you can charge it in the case which keeps the headset nice and safe when not in use.People sound very clear to me and they say that I sound clear to them as well.My negative comments:I hear a constant popping sound in this headset.  It's almost like popcorn popping.  When the conversation is non-stop it's not very noticeable but when there is silence for a bit it can become quite annoying.My other issue is with the battery life.  When fully charged and it is turned on you have a voice tell you that there is "more that 5 hours of talk time".  This has not been the case with mine from the start.  It'll give me about 3 1/2 hours of talk time before the battery needs recharged.  Sure, you can charge it from your fully charged case and get another 3 1/2 hours or so but certainly not even close to the "up to 15 hours of talk time" that is advertised.Overall this is not a bad headset but if you need a headset that'll give you 4-6 hours of talk time like I do then you may want to look elsewhere.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: A part of me knows I probably shouldn't ding a product just because it arrives DOA.  I mean, stuff like that happens to all manufacturers and what matters most is how the company handles the problem, not necessarily that the problem happened.  But looking at the other negative reviews here I'm feeling less generous.  This particular unit appears to have multiple issues and it seems to me that the company could have done a better job preventing all these complaints.  In any case, can't comment on how this works because it pretty much failed after the 2nd or 3rd use (which was VERY brief).
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I bought this unit at the AT&T; Store.I experienced the really loud volume but, I took the unit home and contacted Motorola.**Problem 1: Volume problem best I can isolate:The volume increases to maximum when the attention signal is activated via the call button.  i was in the AT&T; store and people 10 feet away could here the headset. If you google the issue you'll find multiple examples of the same issue.Motorola's solution is to reset the unit. This is done by depressing the call button and turning the unit on/off simultaneously. This worked on my phone for two calls and then the volume spiked again.I'm still waiting for Motorola's response to the re-occurence of the problem. Until the problem is fixed I rate it one star as well.**2nd Problem: Iphone 4S Siri Interface.The Siri interface didn't work well either and the recommended solution was the same as for problem # 1.  When I reset the unit. the Siri interface started working. However, over time (5 activations of Siri) the response time went from normal to 30 seconds to 1 minute for command response and (you guessed it) the volume went to maximum when it did respond.I contacted Motorola and I'm waiting for a solution. I'll give it 5 stars once they fix it. But until then its useless unless you want hearing damage.Follow up: I went back to the AT&T; store and we tried a couple different Slivers all had the same problem connected to my iPhone 4S.I really like this headset, has anyone been successful using it with the iPhone 4S?
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola Elite Sliver is a high-end bluetooth headset. It supports a wide range of functions, including voice instructions and speech recognition, multiple device pairing, music playback, long-range reception, noise cancellation, and quick setup. It also has a case with an integrated battery that charges the headset while stored.Straight up, the headset itself is very light and easy to put on and take off. It's also comfortable when worn even for extended periods. It's easy to turn it off and on- simply twist the earpiece left or right. This also allows it to be worn in whichever ear you prefer.The battery charges quickly- about an hour and a half to full charge. If you count the battery in the case, you get at least 12 hours of talk time on one charge. Note that this isn't continuous, as it means you'll have to put it back in the case at least part of the time. The earpiece itself lasts about 5 hours at a time.Reception range is good, though I'd say the 300 foot range claimed is pretty ridiculous. Perhaps this is only the case with a high end Moto smartphone? At any rate, I don't have one- and with my LG Optimus it dropped out altogether at about 100 feet. Even at around 30 feet, signal strength begins to degrade pretty noticeably and past that it started to stutter pretty seriously. This is especially the case when listening to music.Pairing was very straightforward, and I had no problems doing so with both my Android handset and my Mac Pro. All functions worked straight up as advertised. Music playback picks up seamlessly and pauses on incoming calls. The speech recognition worked well for answering calls. If it doesn't, there's a button you can press, but I found it unnecessary. Unfortunately, the headset doesn't have any voice commands for initiating a call- to do so you have to hit one of the physical buttons. Doing this starts up the device's voice dialer, assuming it has one. Overall, both the microphone pickup and audio reception while making calls was good. Music quality is likewise decent, though I'll admit I'm one of those people that can't really stand listening to it in one ear. Noise cancellation is all right- not amazing but about what you'd expect from an earpiece that also has to be easy to put on.I did have some problems using Skype with this headset. It worked when I selected it as my primary I/O device, but for some reason after every call it threw a Bluetooth error and disconnected. The call quality was also mediocre; it stuttered continually and at times was barely understandable. I don't have the same problems with my laptop's built-in mic and audio and don't have any problems with other BT devices, so it probably was a compatibility issue with the headset (possibly on Skype's part since this one's pretty new).Design-wise, the earpiece is made of flexible rubberized plastic. It appears decently rugged and isn't huge or obnoxious in appearance like some other bluetooth headsets I've seen. Overall, I'd say this is definitely one of the better ones on the market, and is pretty solid all around for voice calls.Pros:Pairing is very easy, voice instructions walk you through it.Voice quality is clear, pickup is good.Comfortable and compact.Long battery life, fast charge.Charging case is a nice touch.Con:Not nearly as much range as Motorola claims.Doesn't seem to play well with Skype.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I must admit that I am partial to behind the ear type. The construction is a 10 /10. It is super fast in connecting. Sound is outstanding but I have become tolerant of BT defects. The sound is clear and full on both ends of the conversation. For years I have only had high end BT headsets so I have a good sense as to how to properly evaluate this one..  Styling is a 9. My guess that it would even be better on Android phone. As there is custom software for Android. It worked fine on my Iphone 4s and very well with SIRI. It's range was clearly greater in my complex environment rather than 6 feet from the rest of my high end headsets. It is very comfortable!!!!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The description is :What's in the BoxHD Station dock; HDMI cable; wall charger; additional adapter plate for compatible extra-capacity batteries, cases, and wireless charging doors; quick start guideHowever only the HD station dock, and quick start guide were included, and a wall charger that can't charge the phone directly..(not big deal as I have the charger that came with the phone).still, the station is a great, connection on my Droid Razr Maxx (without a case) fit perfectly. reviewText: I was pretty excited to get this for traveling.  The thought of having a portable entertainment system for hotels was intriguing.  Also I would no longer have to plug my devices in all over the room, with the included USB slots on the back I could charge my Ipad, keyboard and speaker from the back of the dock with one 110 Volt outlet!Alas I was bummed when it arrived and I could not get the phone to plug into it.  The hdmi and usb plugs just would not go in more than 1/3rd.  I didn't want to force it so back in the box it went:(I guess I will wait till the second batch comes in from China and try again.

reviewText: I really like this dock because it charges my phone faster than using a USB cable with my laptop.It has external power from an A/C adapter. It used to take hours upon hours to charge my phone using a standard micro USB cable from my laptop, now it charges from 0% in about 2. It also has an HDMI port to connect to HD screen or a laptop with an HDMI port so you can use your phone on a larger screen.
title: Motorola HD Station with HDMI Cable and Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: not for the razr hd maxx returned and got credit.  It looks great but will not work on my phone.

reviewText: Initial glitches:  When it arrived and I tried to use it, my Droid RAZR would not switch to the proper dock mode. I tried it both with the case on (without the adapter plate) and with the case off (with the adapter plate). I had even contacted the seller about exchanging it. However, I decided to try again this morning, and it worked. I am not sure why it didn't work when I first tried it but it is working now.I don't have a television or monitor with an HDMI connection, so I can't speak to that function. I actually bought this model instead of the HD Dock in view of future use. However, even though I will initially be using this with the clock mode only, it still is a good addition to my Droid RAZR. I docked it one star, only because of my initial problem.I have a dock from another vendor for my original Droid. That has worked well. This one looks like it will also provide excellent service. My one concern is the very thin power connector. I hope that it is sturdy and will hold up well as I intend to use this dock while travelling. I would have expected the power connector to be more substantial, but if it holds up, it will be okay.
title: Motorola HD Station with HDMI Cable and Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The HD station was shipped quickly and received on schedule. I bought this for my Razor Maxx, however the plastic adapter plate that fits the Razor Maxx was not in the box as stated in the in the description of "what's in the box". I called Motorola Warrenty and they sent the missing adapter plate, part number SJYN1024A to me at no charge. HD dock station works great with my Razor Maxx and very pleased with it's performance.
title: Motorola HD Station with HDMI Cable and Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I bought this dock for my Droid Razr because I thought "Hmm.  OEM accessory.  Ok, it should work fine."  In concept this thing is a great idea, and I would recommend it hands down if not for two major flaws.1) My unit worked fine for five months or so, but then it started shorting out the micro USB chargers I plugged into it (first the charger which came with it, and then two other chargers I had lying around).  I think it has a defective ground inside or something.  In any case I am lucky that the dock only ate up chargers and did not short my phone or something.2) If you keep a protective case on your phone, you have to take it off to use the dock.  Even though the Droid Razr is meant to take a great deal of abuse (which is why I bought it), I still try to keep my Otterbox case on it.  I find it annoying and unnecessary that I have to remove the case.  Seriously, couldn't Motorola just make a small adapter for the dock?  I mean you only need to have access to the HDMI and USB port on the phone, and you're golden.  I would be willing to pay an extra $5 or so for them to include an adapter in the package which would allow me to keep my phone in its protective case.Otherwise this is a solid little unit.  If those two flaws were addressed by Motorola, I would give this 5 stars with no hesitation.  Though as it stands I think I am going to go with a less sophisticated stand where I can just plug the charger into the phone directly (like theCellet Clear Phone Stand).
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: When I lined up on 11-11-11 to get the new razr I didn't realize I would be buying a 50 dollar dock as well, turns out I'm glad I did.When I read about the dock after I got it CNET said it had 2 USB ports on the back, a 3.5mm audio output and a micro HDMI output.  So theoretically with a TV and computer speakers you have a little home theater that fits in the palm of your hand! Unfortunately they got rid of the two USB ports before sending it to production.  These would have come in handy on the road!  Hotel rooms never seem to have enough 110 outlets, and I always have to bring to 110-USB adapters.  You could use the other USB for a keyboard and to charge an ipad, but c'est la vi.  This product would have gotten 5 stars from me had it come with USB ports on the back.I do plan on using this in hotels to watch movies and wake me up in the morning.  The alarm clock function is awesome and the music controls are spot on.  The dock connects to the two ports (HDMI & Micro USB) which makes the connection to the dock far more sturdy than my Droid 2 dock.  So much so that I used the dock in a rental car, rested it on the steering column and it was wonderful.  Since the dock uses a USB cable you can use the dock in the car or at home.All in all I am very happy with this dock, it really brings the phone to another level of convenience.  At 50 bucks it seems to be priced a little high, but if you consider the HDMI and 3.5mm output, and what you can do with those two outputs, the value shines through.
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: It does everything it is supposed to do!Great bedside accessory for your phone.Works even with a slim case on the phone.I am using it with the RAZR MAXX.

reviewText: I had bought this dock for my daughter for christmas, and she is getting good use from it. My daughter seems very happy with it and would recomend it.

reviewText: I got this for my new Razr Maxx.  What the description leaves out is there is plastic spacer on the dock so you can use it with the Droid Razr and when removed, you can use the dock with the Razr Maxx.  The only issue I had was once removed, the Razr Maxx failed to seat just right on the dock.  There was enough extra space that it was obvious Motorola left room for some type of phone case.  The same is true for the car dock.  I tried the Otter Box for the Razr Maxx and while I loved it, it didn't work with the dock and was nearly impossible to remove.  An alternative was a "gel case."  However, those things stretch and stick to your pocket, purse, and are a pain to keep on the phone once stretched from normal use.  However, I did find a case that workedLuxmo Hard Shield Shell Cover Snap On Case for Verizon Motorola Droid RAZR MAXX XT916 + Tool-Magenta Pink.The dock itself offers an easy way to charge your phone.  When plugged into the dock, the phone offers multiple docking setup options that fit many needs.  This is a wonderful accessory for your new Droid Razr or Razr Maxx!  Love, love, love it!!!
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have really mixed feelings about this product. I previously had a docking station for my Droid X and loved it so much I bought a second one so I had on for  my desk and bedside table.  So, when I upgraded to my Droid Razr, a docking station was the first accessory I wanted.I got this as a Christmas gift, along with my phone.  And I couldn't get the phone to connect to it.  With 2 connectors, which don't seem to be quite straight, getting them to go into the holes in the top of the phone was impossible, no matter how hard I tried!  Once in a while, with some fluke of angle, it would go in the holes and work just fine, doing what a docking station should have (though I preferred the software setup that came with my Droid X docking station).However, as soon as I took the phone out of the docking station (which is really hard to do without touching the screen and starting something you don't want to touch!), I was back to square one struggling to get it inserted.Because I thought maybe I had a defective one, and because it had been a gift, so I didn't have the necessary receipt to return it, I bought a second one, figuring I'd be able to return the first as defective (it was from the same seller) once the second one was delivered...only, guess what?
