Same problem with the second one!  No matter how carefully I tried to push it into the holes on top of the phone, it took 5 minutes every time!  Having to be so careful not to accidentally break the connectors off in the phone.  This time, though, I finally figured out what the perfect angle is to get it lined up to one of the connectors and then gently push down on it to force it to straighten a bit so the second connector would line up with the second hole. What a pain in the neck!I continue to use both docking stations and didn't return them because I really wanted them, and there were no alternatives.  However, I have to say, be prepared for frustration!
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I purchased a droid razr to replace the brain dead phone I was using. The Razr is a superb phone and the HD Dock adds tremendous versatility to the phone.  I am currently using a bluetooth keyboard with mouse connected to my 23 inch monitor.  It is more like a desktop computer.  The only issue is the instructions.  Unless connected to a monitor, most of the dock options do not show up.  The documentation does not tell you this.  The other limitation is customization.  There is a limited ability to change default options on the icons that appear when in the office setting.  I would like to be able to reset all of them.  It only allows one to reset 4 of 6 icons. Otherwise it is an outstanding product.
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Right now, I kind of have a love hate relationship with the HD Dock.  To put simply, it does exactly what it's supposed to, but it is bogged down in a clunky interface.THE GOOD:Like I said, the HD Dock does exactly as it is advertised.  Once you plug in your DROID RAZR, a screen prompts you to decide how you would like to treat your docking station.  Would you like it as a bedside clock?  Enabling this option grants a large time display coupled with a few music options.  Would you like it as an office call center?  Enabling this option creates a few icons to allow for quick and easy communication (phone, text, group meetings, etc...)  It looks really nice, and it charges the phone well.  If you sit at a desk during the day, this is a nice little accessory to own.THE BAD:Unfortunately, a few interface design choices offer clunky use with the HD Dock.  This dock forces your phone into the aforementioned modes, but if you want to use your phone as its normal interface, you may as well just disconnect it from its station.  If you need to access your calendar, or any other app, you will need to repeatedly press the Back button until you come to your original homescreen.  Using the touchscreen while in its docking station also proves to be a little annoying; it's much much easier to browse the internet on the phone via handheld methods as opposed to this.I'm puzzled as to why this is labeled "Rapid Wall Charger;" my phone seems to take much longer to charge using this station than it does by simply plugging it into the wall.  The lack of customization options also proves to be really annoying after using the device for a while; users have to operate by what Motorola think you do in your office (or whatever interface option you have chosen).THE HUH?:No USB connection options?  This limits consumers to only being able to use wall/AC Adapter plugins to provide power to this station.  While the options that the phone provides regarding interface are fine (Office, Bedside Clock, etc...), I would have liked to see some kind of customization with this feature.  For example, for music, you will need to rely on Motorola's music service -- you can't enable Google Music or Amazon MP3 for instance without exiting out of the dock options entirely.OVERALL:This device is fine.  At $25+, it's not exactly a bargain, but it's worth the money if you spend a lot of time at a desk.  There are a few strange manufacturing options, and these missteps only go to show how much potential an idea like this would have given a bit better execution.
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The product is well built,has nice features and I would love to keep it.However it does not accommodate a Razr with a Diztronic , flexible protective case. The case is incredibly thin and it would not take much engineering for Motorola to make it work, hope they get it figured out in the coming weeks . If they do I will re-order the docking /charger.In the meantime it is being returned.About three days after I posted this review I found that the docking station has a removable docking plate. Removed it and it works fine with my protective case. Sorry Motorola.
title: Motorola HD Dock with Rapid Wall Charger for DROID RAZR - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola Smart Controller is mainly useful if you often have your phone or tablet connected to  a TV for watching streaming video or playing audio through a sound system.  Unfortunately, due to a combination of jerky controls, and a slightly unpleasant rubbery surface on the touchpad, you would never want to use the device in a circumstance where you didn't really have to--which is the default for me.The touchpad supports multi-touch gestures, but the entire touchpad area is a single click button that is a bit too sensitive perhaps, and my motions are often misread.  On the plus side, the device can be used as a handset to make and receive telephone calls -the sound quality is extremely good, and much better than a standard Bluetooth earpiece.  It does not have a speakerphone function, however, so you will have to hold the device to your ear during the call....like a phone!  It is much lighter than a smartphone, but as with the touchpad, the main button to use the phone feature is so sensitive that it is possible to click it accidentally, hanging up.  Pairing the device was easy enough once I realized it was listed as two separate items -basically one for audio and one for the mouse.  It has the standard menu/home/back/search buttons you would expect from an Android device as well as volume and mute.All things considered, it is a lot of money for a device with pretty limited unique usefulness, unless the first thing you do when you get home each night is connect your phone to the charging station and the TV.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: It seems like technology is not plug and play yet especially with so many different level of phones that have so many features to them. My phone fortunately is one that has all of the features that will make this controller work with with it. Overall it works not fully but it isn't perfected yet I was happy when I got it to make a call through my TV and I was able to scroll thru my phone using my TV. I was prepared for worse because of all of the complaints about it so I was happy when I got it to answer the phone. They should really over stress what you need and what will not work with this since this is getting such bad reviews by people. The good thing is is that this is a start and should be more refined the longer it's out.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The description says that it works with any andriod device. It didn't work with my Samsung Galaxy or my husband's LG something or other. It would be great in theory if it actually paired with my phones, as mentioned in the description.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: As cool as this device can be, please be warned that it will not work with most Phones out there, even if your phones happens to be a Motorola phone, and you have even worse odds if your Smart phone is not made by Motorola.Here is the list of devices listed on Motorola's own website as compatible units for the Smart Controller:Droid 3Droid 4Droid RazrDroid Razr MaxxAtrix 2BionicElectrifyPhotonXYBOARD (Tablet)Ok, So I was one of the lucky ones who happens to own one of these devices (Razr Maxx)and although I did like the idea, I do not find much use for it in the long run, I mean, are you really going to use this to answer phone calls when you have the real phone right next to you? I think that this is more of a novelty item other than the next big thing when it comes to cell phone accessories. I will definitely use it to share photos with the family, maybe even watch some netflix, but having a Playstation 3 that is able to play Netflix movies and share my computer's hard drive where I store all my pictures, plugged in to my TV at all times, kinda makes this product obsolete.I guess it's a nice device to show off to your friends, but not something that I see myself using on a daily basis, that is just my honest opinion, other people might find more use for it that I did.Other than that, installation is a breeze, the device works like it should, controls take a little time to get used to but it's not uncomfortable to use.I hope that this review helps you make a better buying choice...
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Considering Motorola's reputation, this product needs to be withdrawn and repackaged. The product listing indicates that it's compatible with most Android devices supporting HID - not true. Motorola's own site shows it only works with a subset of Motorola smartphones (and another reviewer finds it works on his Samsung, which isn't listed in their compatibility list). It doesn't work with any of the HTC phones I tried. Even the QR code on the side of the packaging resolves to a 404 Error since nobody bothered to either build the page or check the code being published on a widely released retail product.The product and support information is among some of the worst I've seen for any non-beta electronic product. A 3"x4" manual comes with the product and provides the briefest overview of what the device can do. It doesn't even mention how to pair with a television. Searching the web, there's very little information and even Motorola's own site page (bizarrely not indexed in Google) only repeats the contents of the manual.It also doesn't ship with a wall charger, only a USB to micro-USB cable. This means that you must have a computer with a USB port if you want to charge it. For taking calls while your phone is charging, the average user would be better buying a Bluetooth headset since this is a bulkier way to take calls. I can't report on the actual Smart Controller functionality since it's not compatible with anything I own (I wouldn't have selected this product for review if the manufacturer had provided a compatibility list).
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I was able to get this smart controller paired with my Samsung Droid Charge, but after spending an hour messing with it, I couldn't get it to actually do anything useful. If you have a Motorola phone, this may be somewhat useful...maybe. But if you don't have a Motorola phone, you should check their website before buying it.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'm one of those "early adopter" types that have to have the latest gadget as soon as it hits the market. One of the good things about the Vine program is being among the first in line for the gizmos. As a rule I have seldom been dissapointed in the devices I've reviewed, but this time It's hard to find much good to say about the Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset.I could not get the device to talk to my Samsung Droid phone, period. I spent more than two hours messing with it and never had the slightest hint of success. From the sound of the other reviews it looks like that is a more than common occurrence. I found nothing in the instructions that was any help and had no strength left for wrestling with tech support in Mumbai of Singapore.It seems to me that at best this device is designed to add pretty limited functionality to smart phones and pads of various makes. The one thing it has to get right is connectivity between devices and it can't even manage that. As it is it provided zero utility to me.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I am reviewing this device when paired with a Verizon Samsung Galaxy Nexus Android phone. I assume it fully works with recent Motorola Android phones. No idea how well it works with other phones.Motorola is selling a bunch of Android accessory devices that enhance the functionality of their Android smartphones, especially for business users. The Android bluetooth keyboard has special Android-specific function buttons (like the ones you see on your phone). The Android multi-media docks power your phone and have HDMI outputs to connect to a big screen TV. The laptop docks convert your phone into a laptop computer. This "smart controller" is another device in this product line.The smart controller is a bluetooth touchpad and with a few smartphone-specific features. On the side, there is a volume control that works just like the volume control on your phone. On the back, there are the 4 standard Android buttons (menu, home, back, search) that work just like the buttons on your phone. Also on the back is a 2 inch square touch-pad that remotely controls your phone's touch screen, except a little differently. One finger drag gestures move a cursor around your screen to you can select specific objects in the Android GUI. Two finger multi-touch gestures move the screen around; scrolling the screen up-and-down or left-and-right. On the front is a telephone handset so you can make or receive voice calls. There is a single phone button to make or end calls.This device paired easily with the Bluetooth on my Galaxy Nexus. All of the advertised features work fine. One finger gestures on the touch pad work easily, though the cursor is blue and can be hard to see if your background is also blue. Two finger gestures take some getting used to, at least if you have fat fingers like me. Phone call quality is pretty good. You can make calls using the touch pad to access your phone's contact list or touch dialer. Or press on the phone button to redial the last number you called (or to pickup an incoming call or end the current call).Do you really need this device? If you have your phone hooked up to a HDTV to watch videos or slideshows or business presentations on a big screen, then this controller is very handy, though of course not everyone is going to do that. If you only do this kind of thing occasionally, the $100 price tag for this device is very expensive. If you already have a bluetooth mouse and bluetooth headset, those will probably give you most of the same functionality.The smart controller has a rechargeable battery that runs for more hours than my phone, so no complaints there.4 stars because this smart controller mostly achieves what it is designed for. Knocking off one star for the price and also because the two-finger gestures are a little tricky on the small touch pad.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Okay, so, yes, I COULD see that this DID pair with and control my HTC Rezound (which, incidentally, I LOVE!!! WHO needs an iPhone?!? Not me!!!), but, to what end??? I already have a touchscreen phone, so... I have the need to drag my finger over this little gizmo's touchpad for its few boons because... why?Just to ensure that I didn't sell this thing short without really giving it the ol' college try, I even picked up a Micro USB to HDMI adapter for it, in an effort to see if I could get anything from my phone to be broadcast to my TV via Motorolla's "Smart" controller.... No dice. And, really, since this thing already retails for around a hundred note, is there any particular reason Motorolla couldn't have just tossed the dagnabbed HDMI adapter IN with this thing to begin with?!? Why sell you something that requires one last little, cheapie-cheapie doodad that'll cost a big company mere pennies to add in what SHOULD be bigger functionality? I thought that was just cheap of Motorolla to omit that accessory and simply mention in the paperwork that it works with one, but not to INCLUDE one!The audio sound that comes from this thing when using it during calls is just more of the same low-quality audio that my phone blows out of the water in and of itself.Overall, this small-sized, high-priced (relative to valid functionality) gadget seems like a good idea on paper, but the execution is woefully lacking. Your fingers are free and, paired with your phone's existing functionality, offer a better variety of options than this dud by Motorola bothers to add.Total bust.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This did pair quickly with my Motorola phone but I found little value.  It's not a very good remote control and the phone doesn't put out a true hi-def signal.  I like new gadgets but when you can't describe what it does on the box, you've probably made something that doesn't need to exist.  Maybe I should have spent more time with this but: Sorry Motorola but this was a dud for me.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Like many reviewers have noted, you have to have a Motorola device in order for this item to work properly.  And when it does work, it doesn't work very well. Also, you have to figure out how to get your Android device hooked up to your tv. My android phone didn't come with an HDMI adapter, so I had to hunt one down before even attempting this review. When I did get the device working properly it did work ok, but I would suggest saving your money. This is a cool device on paper, but when you start to use it becomes more of a hassle than an assistance.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I tried this on my Samsung Tab 7 and my LG cellphone.  Pairing it with my cell phone yields very limited utility.  It can answer calls, sure, but the audio is pretty awful and I can't imagine why I'd want to use it to answer my cellphone remotely.  I already have a much better hands free bluetooth device for that.  Pairing it with my Samsung Tab does have some value.  If my tablet is hooked up to an external monitor, I can use this device as an Android bluetooth mouse/trackpad.  It would be useful in that mode if I had presentations on my tablet and I was a road warrior kind of salesman.  But when I give talks, there's always a laptop there.  I just give the host a thumb drive and I'm ready to go.The device is easy to charge though a USB cable (supplied).  Overall, it's pretty intuitive.  I found the controller kind of non-responsive as a mouse/trackpad, and while I could scroll with it, I couldn't manage to use the trackpad to rotate the screen.  In summary, yes I've gotten this thing to do just about all that they say it can do.  But it's kind of lame in its implementation, both as a bluetooth phone and mouse/trackpad.  I would not recommend this device unless you're truly committed to the idea of abandoning your laptop and getting by with a tablet when you make presentations.P.S.  I just thought of another use for this controller and my tablet.  If I were the kind of person who truly hated fingerprints on my screen, I could use this device and keep my screen superclean.  Kind of silly I know.  And I don't mind fingerprints.  Overall, I would describe this device as an item strictly for true blue gadget lovers.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This product is well styled, solid, works precisely as advertised, but I can't say much about its practicality.Yes, if you are using your smartphone to watch videos connected to a TV, this is a great gadget, but thats about it.But I think its unlikely you would own an HDMI-connected smartphone and an HDMI tv to go with it and not have a better VOD solution already installed.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This was easy to pair with my HTC Evo... however anything beyond that was just more work that I was willing to try.  It is not even a great speaker for the phone.I'm usually one of those people that get the latest and greatest techno-toy...  This just seems like a dud --I was hoping to maybe be able to use it as a remote control for the phone itself scroll through content play songs etc...  but never seemed to be able to do much more than use it as a speakermaybe I gave up too early and maybe it is the next best thing...  but if it is it is too much work to bother.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: In theory this must have come up as a good idea - it would be nice to have a remote for your phone or tablet if you use it for playing videos off of your TV. However, this Motorola "Smart" Controller is anything but.First, the description says that the controller is compatible with many Android powered phones? So you mean this will work on my N1? Nope - go to Motorola's support page and the only "compatible" ones are Motorola-branded devices. Well why not say that up front? So much for my dreams of using this with a Samsung tablet or phone.Even if you get it paired up with another "compatible" Android phone, you'll be disappointed. Sure, you can use this as a headset but the quality wasn't that great, even within 5 feet of the phone. I'd rather spend half the amount and get a proper, working BT headset. For tablets, this *might* come in handy. It would be nice to use this as a remote if you had it plugged into a TV but unless you're lazy (like me) or a gadget geek, you wouldn't pay nearly $100 for this.Good concept, poor execution.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Seems like more of a novelty than a real useful gadget.  It is also awkward and not very comfortable performing gestures on a curved surface.  Can be used as a mouse but I have a mouse that I am already comfortable with.  Can be used as an HDTV remote, but who doesn’t have a phone that can be loaded with a remote control app that is even easier to use.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewerName: P. Colin McGraw "AV, Computer & EnviroTech Nut"
reviewText: Once paired via Bluetooth, this thing is pretty freaking handy! It's like an uber-remote control complete with trackpad and even voice command support so you can browse websites by talking which is especially awesome when plugged into a TV! It worked flawlessly with a Motorola Xoom sporting Ice Cream Sandwich.Unfortunately, it doesn't work with every Android device. The most notable device this won't work with is the Kindle Fire, which doesn't have Bluetooth. However, I also had trouble pairing and using it with an HTC Thunderbolt (Verizon) running Gingerbread.My recommendation is to jump on this product if you're interested in some Android-supported browsing/app usage on your TV, but do a little research to make sure your device is supported.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I am writing this as a 2nd to comments made by another reviewer who appears to have had the exact same experience that I have had this afternoon... Having a Motorola Smart Android phone I never dreamed it would not work with my Droid.. Well count me one disappointed person.I ran into the same issue with the bar code on the side of the Box.. all I got was an error when scanned.. Then went to the Motorola website... No other option as the included instructions are so abbreviated to be almost useless.There I found my MOTOROLA SMART PHONE won't work with this devise..this lead me to approach a friend who had what I though was  a compatible phone so that I could intelligently review this product.. Well that lead to another discovery.. When trying to explain to him why I needed to use his phone .. He asked to explain exactly what the Blue tooth controller would do ?.. Well that prompted me to look carefully at the box and included literature..I am finding so ,many of these tech companies are produceing products that THEY understand.. but you have to wonder if they ever field test them with regular Joe's ?. No where could one get a clear indication, in my opinion. what the full fucntion of this unit was.... I can only imagine someone in a Brick and Mortar store looking at this on a shelf and passing it completely by... Even the packaging is generic .ALL IT SAYS .. IS  CONTROL PHONE CONTENT ON THE BIG SCREEN"... huh ???.. what exactly does that mean.. Do I need an adaptor ...what kind of PHONE can I use, how does it connect to the TV.. again packaging only says..  and in almost microscopic writing.. it says MUST SUPPORT BLUETOOTH HSP FEATURED AVAILABLE ON SELECT MOTOROLA DEVICES....................... BUT YOU NEED A MAGNIFYING GLASS TO READ IT !!!!!!So all in all this has proven to be a very frustrating and incomplete afternoon of trying to get this gizmo to work.. all to find out it doesn't work on their own Motorola HARDWARE....  Count me one disappointed person.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: It takes a bit to get used to and is nice to have when watching Netflix on your TV. I would not use it for every day for texting etc. Verizon does not seem to allow the phone function to work. I am still trying to get it to work.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Let me open with something handy to know; this controller will work on most recent Android devices that support the HID (keyboard/mouse) protocol.The basics are simple - this is a mouse, 4 button controller and Bluetooth handset all in one. The way you use this is equally simple - pair with your tablet or phone, connect your phone to your TV using its dock or Mini/Micro HDMI cable, then sit back on the sofa and use the Motorola Smart Controller as a remote. Use the mouse to pick a movie, and if a call happens to come in, you can pick it up on the handset. While this sounds absolutely brilliant, it means you get to pay $90 for the luxury of not having to get up and touch your screen or order a $20 headset.If you are into gadgets (and I am), you'll LOVE this thing. I used it last week in a hotel room with my Motorola Xoom - plugged the Xoom into the TV, and when a call came in (using Groove IP, a Google Voice client), I took the call on the controller. So, to me as a geek, this is definitely worth $90 - but to someone less geeky (and less lazy), it may be worthwhile to spend that money on something else...Build quality is good - the mouse responds nicely and the call quality is excellent. Motorola makes excellent headsets, so a good voice quality is to be expected. The Smart Controller charges over microUSB, and a charger is included. One other plus - it has a "real" on/off slider switch.Only downsides? It lacks a carrying case/pouch.One other upside? It works on your PC as well! I paired it with my Lenovo and could use it as a mouse and headset with Skype. The buttons did not work right, as they are assigned to Android keys.I tested it on my Xoom, Transformer Prime, Galaxy Nexus and Windows 7 machine. In all cases, it worked as it should. Some comments mentioned that the mute button didn't work on their Android device, but I'm pretty sure the mute button actually only controls the headset, and isn't transmitted as a mute command to your device.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewerName: Therabbitssing "on the rock that spews lava.."
reviewText: Let's see...right out of the box, it comes with a charging cable but no charger.  I guess Motorola assumes you have a plethora of chargers for everything USB nowadays (which isn't far off the mark). It paired to my Droid RAZR really quickly after charging it.  As for the device itself...it's kinda meh.  The whole touch pad is kind of too sensitive.  If you use it for calls, you hold it up to your ear like a phone, but I found it's pretty easy to accidentally hang up on the call too. The gestures for the touch pad seem to work okay (more on that later), and I noticed that it really attracts the attention of younger kids who want to try playing with the touch pad. Works well if you leave your phone attached to your TV through HDMI out.  I have the cable and have done it a few times with my phone, but I don't normally leave it attached there, nor do I use my phone as a hub for most things.  I suppose if I did, this would be of more use, though the sensitivity of the pad needs to be less. I noticed for some reason, using gestures when you first turn it on work well, but seem to misread more and more as you use it until you pair again. It's okay...needs some work before ready for prime time.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: ** On opening the box **- ships charged well enough to use right out of the box- comes with charging cable, but no charger (USB-USB, no USB-AC)** On HTC Nexus One with Gingerbread 2.3.7 **- Identifies, Pairs, and Connects quickly- All default buttons work except Menu and Mute (does not mute phone's system volume, did not test call volume)- Pinch-zooming and rotate don't work- Multi-touch scrolling works- Works as a remote phone, but it takes some finesse to get it to do so (see note below)** On Samsung Galaxy Nexus with ICS 4.0.4 **- Identifies, Pairs, and Connects quickly- All default buttons work except Mute (does not mute phone's system volume, did not test call volume)- (Swiftkey) Keyboard input is missing when paired, and so is phone unlock number pad- Pinch-zooming and rotate don't work- Multi-touch scrolling works- Works as a remote phone, but it takes some finesse to get it to do so (see note below)** On Motorola Xoom Pro with ICS 4.0.3 **- Identifies and Pairs, but doesn't connect first time- Finally connected after removing pair and re-pairing- Pinch-zooming and rotate don't work- Other multi-touch functions work like swiping and scrolling- Mute and Phone buttons don't work, all others do- Keyboards are disabled while paired** On Windows 7 Ultimate x64 computer **- Identifies the device, but took a while to pair.  When it does finally pair, it does so as Generic HID at first.  After several more minutes, Windows 7 does detect it as Hands-free Telephony and Headset and it pairs to it as such...  I just can't seem to figure out how to get it to use it that way once it's in the system devices list.- Works like a mouse. Tracks well, main button clicks and touches activate normal left-click- Right-click is performed with Search button, Start Menu is performed with Menu button, Back Button cancels clicks- Home key is the same as using the keyboard's Home key- Volume, Mute, and Phone keys don't seem to do anything- Speaker and Microphone are not functional out of the box as additional audio devices** On Macbook Air OS X Snow Leopard **- Detected as Headset device and a separate Mouse device- Pairing took several attempts, power cycling the RZ100 several times before it negotiated correctly for Mouse use- Headset pairing doesn't seem to work.  Error: "This device does not have the necessary services."  Would love to see this area enabled.  Skype and similar solutions would be great with it.- Mouse works.  Buttons have obvious functions.  Search button doesn't seem to do anything useful.- Volume controls the Mac's volume- Pinch features don't work, but multi-touch scrolling does** General Experience **The buttons are nice enough, but an integrated app on the Android device would have been nice so that custom buttons like those relating to media functions could exist.  The mouse cursor is small and slow on Android, which is a major inconvenience.  The speed of the tracking can be changed, but the overall experience is enough of an annoyance to just not use the device with Android.  It was weird having to depress the main button pad as a giant mouse button - I'm used to capacitive touch events.  On a normal computer, if the mouse speed is accelerated, it's pretty tolerable and a neat novelty that gets attention.The vibrator in it is really strong.  Stronger than my Nexus vibrator.  You definitely notice it in the pocket, though the ringer is a bit quiet.If giving a presentation, this works pretty well as a presenter's mouse on a real computer.  An actual ball on top like a trackball would make the use of the mouse a lot nicer, but then there's the tradeoff of the multi-touch.It can charge off the computer's USB power, so that's also a plus.Unfortunately, no Motorola phones or iPad/iPhone/Blackberry available to try, so this was a test of everything else.** Getting the phone functions to work with my Nexus phone **At first it appears that the headset feature is unavailable, but it IS available--it just takes a lot longer for the headset device to become visible.  On the phone, I had to search for devices at least 6 times before the headset device of the RZ100 showed up.  The key is to NOT pair the mouse first.  If it does, there's a good chance it'll stop trying to pair.  Pair the headset first, then search again for devices on the phone and then pair the mouse device.The Galaxy Nexus does not support a button-enabled voice command, but there may be an app that enables that.  So pressing the phone button doesn't do anything.One advantage of using this as a phone with your phone is that you can charge your phone and talk using this device.  This could be really handy if you are on a long conference call, for example.  If your phone batter gets too low, turn this device on and charge the phone.  When this device starts getting low, switch back to the phone and charge this device.  Note that the headset feature does NOT work with music.  Only phone calls.  That's pretty reasonable though.** And the verdict is... **I gave this product 3 stars because it has a nice cool-factor and I can see its benefit as a remote mouse for a computer.  I thought it was a little awkward for use with my Android devices and I'm not sure I would have ever found an every-day use for it.  At this price point, that is certainly something to consider.  Still, I think I WOULD HAVE liked this device overall, EXCEPT...I got one of these as a "free sample".  The unit I was given seems to have been abused in transit or something because the touch pad area had scuffs/scratches right out of the box and after only a few hours of use, the unit quit functioning completely.  Amazon has an excellent return policy and if I had purchased this, I know they would have sent a speedy replacement.  However, because it was free and because they don't have any more inventory of free samples to send, then I guess that's all the sample I'll be getting.  I did not take any stars off of this because I don't think it's fair to base an opinion of build quality off of a unit that appears to be a lemon out of the batch of (potentially) good units.
title: Motorola Bluetooth Smart Controller for Android - Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I received these headphones to test its capabilities as a replacement to my wired headsets.  My favorite wired inner-ear headsets are the Ultimate Ears TripleFi 10, followed closely by the Ultimate Ears 600vi set.I opened the retail packaging to find a quick-start guide sitting on top.  Underneath was the SF600 wireless sports headphone, a bag with 5 sizes of ear cushions, a wall charger (micro USB), and a convenient black travel pouch.  The package Motorola SF600 has ear cushions in five sizes to ensure a secure, comfortable fit no matter what your pace is.  You can use any other micro USB charger to charge the batteries.The selling-point of this headset is the breakthrough HD sound with wireless technology that the manufacturers referred to as headphones that "deliver crystal clear, pulse-pumping sound quality to keep you focused and motivated through every step of every workout."  What does that mean?  Well, the Motorola SF600 features advanced HD audio capabilities that include APT-X codec technology that Motorola boasts to match or even the outperform wired headset performance.  Overall, the sound is one of the best I've heard from a bluetooth headset.  However, there are areas that need work.I tested this with an iPhone 4S, iPad2, Blackberry Curve, and a MacBook Pro.If you have the Plantronics Voyager Pro BT headset for you phone, you will have a pretty good idea how these may fit in your ears.  The earbuds sit in the outer ear canal, and you really need to fine which inserts fit best for your size and shape.  Otherwise, the fit will either be too small or too large, and the result is an earbud that will always pop out of your ear.One of the first things I did was put the headphones through a week's worth of my personal burn-in regiment.  This included playing a variety of songs (classical, jazz, r&b;, pop, broadway musical, etc.) for at least 10 hours a day for about a week at medium volume.  This typically "breaks in" the headphones for maximal performance.  I put about 100 hours before listening to these headphones.Having had the Jawbone SPORT and the Plantronics Backbeat, and being somewhat underwhelmed by these bluetooth headphones, I was prepared to be disappointed.  I will say that these Motorola SF600 outperformed these other two sets.  It produced a more significant bass response (when the headphones were seated properly), and the highs were more crisp.  However, I will not go so far as to say the sound is EXCELLENT, but it is one of the best sounding bluetooth headphones I have used thus far.  The start-up and shut-down audio prompts give a very good example of the potential by these headsets, but the actual audio that comes through is probably somewhere around 50% of its potential (generally speaking, of course).  I tried to play various audio to simulate the enhanced bass response (R&B;, Hip-Hop, Rap, etc.) and I just cannot get the same bass as the start-up and shut-down.  If you've heard these audio prompts, you will know what I am talking about.  The mids and highs are acceptable, but also can be a lot better.  So somewhat underwhelmed by these, and is the major reason for the 4-star rating.One major advantage is the lack of the wires, which is a major source of noise or interference.  Runners know this all too well, when the sound of the wires transfer to the earbuds.  This is similar to how voice vibrations transfer from a paper/plastic cup along a string.  With the SF600, your favorite workout tracks are streamed from your mp3 player (such as the MOTOACTV) so that you can keep moving without getting tangled up in wires.Also, this set boasts to be "protected" from moisture and sweat.  The headset sports a hydrophobic mesh and lightweight durable materials, including Kevlar and silicone seals deliver strength and protection from moisture.The battery life is very good.  I can go a day and a half of normal usage before the battery drains on me, and this includes listening to about 3-4 hours of music, watching 2-3 hours of movies and videos, and talking on the phone 2-3 hours a day.  My iPhone monitors the battery level, and when the unit is turned on it gives an audio prompt telling the battery level is high, medium, or low.These Motorola SF600 headphones allow you to answer calls as well as text messages (using Siri) whether you're on the trail or on the treadmill.  In addition to working with MOTOACTV GPS Fitness tracker and music player, the wireless Motorola SF600 headphones are compatible with most mobile phones, music players and tablets from Motorola and all leading manufacturers.  It has a built-in mic and controls make it easy to manage your calls and music. The answer/end call button (to control the phone) doubles as the play/pause button for the mp3 player.  UPDATE:  Siri can "read" NEW text messages received through the headphones (but it cannot read old messages), and you can "reply" to the text message through Siri by speaking the text through the headphones.  When you receive a text message, press the control button to activate Siri and say "Read text message" and Siri will "read" to you.  After, you can either have Siri "read again" or "reply" back to sender.One thing to note is that if you are listening to music (or watching a video) and you receive a call, and you want to use the Motorola SF600 as a bluetooth headset to answer the call, make sure you press the button on the headset (the top button on right earbud) and not the "answer" button on your phone.  For example, when I receive a call on my iPhone 4S and I press the "answer" button on the iphone, the audio will route to the handset and not the headset.  Not too big of a deal, I just have to transfer the audio to the headset using the controls on the iPhone (it will take a few seconds).  This is the cause of confusion for many users.Overall, it is a very good set of wireless bluetooth headphones.  I like the convenience of the wireless feature.  I would give it a 4.5 star rating (out of 5) for a bluetooth headphone set, and an average 4 out of 5 for a headset.  I would rank it as one of the best wireless bluetooth headphones (the best ones in my collection).  In terms of sound quality and compared to all of my headphones, I would rank it somewhere in the "average" range, and for the price you pay for the convenience of wireless and the very good battery life.  It is not the best set of headphones, but it is one of the best wireless headphones at its pricepoint, currently about $129 at Amazon.comWould I buy these for $129?  If you are looking for convenience of wireless bluetooth, these SF600 are the way to go.  If you are looking for sound quality for the same price and don't mind the wires, I would recommend the Ultimate Ears 600vi.  Also recommended is the Klipsch S4/S4i which have better sound quality than the SF600 but at a lower price (sub $100).UPDATE:  The headphones give an audible tone (same tone as phone's sound) when a text message or email is received.  You can have Siri "read" your text message by pressing the control button to activate Siri and say "read text message."  You can then either "read again" or "reply" to the sender.  It's a really cool feature I am appreciating more and more.  Also, a text message can be sent through the SF600 with Siri (on the iPhone 4S).  Press the home button on the iPhone (or the control button on the headset) to wake Siri, say "Send text message to [NAME]" and then you will be prompted to say the message to be sent.  (I have not tested this feature on a Blackberry.)Below are the manufacturer's descriptions.Product Details* Hydrophobic Mesh to keep the beats rolling and the moisture out* Made with Kevlar fiber to hold up to your toughest workouts* Wired Quality Audio over Bluetooth enabled by apt-X Lossless Wireless Technology* HD Sound with enhanced bass* TrueComfort Fit* Multiple Ear Cushion Sizes* Music Controls* Voice PromptsLose the wires and gain breakthrough HD sound. The Motorola SF600 wireless headphones deliver crystal clear, pulse-pumping sound quality to keep you focused and motivated through every step of every workout.Motorola SF600 features advanced HD audio capabilities including APT-X codec technology, designed and tested to match even the best of wired headset performance. Your favorite workout tracks are streamed from your MOTOACTV so that you can keep moving without getting tangled up in wires.Sweat all you want - these headphones can take it. Hydrophobic mesh and lightweight durable materials including Kevlar and silicone seals deliver strength and protection from moisture. Motorola SF600 has ear cushions in five sizes to ensure a secure, comfortable fit no matter what your pace is.Stay connected to your workout and the rest of your life. Motorola SF600 headphones allow you to answer calls and texts whether you're on the trail or on the treadmill. A built-in mic and controls make it easy to manage your calls and music. In addition to working with MOTOACTV, the wireless Motorola SF600 headphones are compatible with most mobile phones, music players and tablets from Motorola and all leading manufacturers.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I purchased the Motorola SF600 from Verizon Wireless in December 2012.  By March 2013 (3 months later) the battery in the device would no longer accept a charge so I returned them to Verizon for a new pair.  The manager at Verizon looked under the battery cover and saw white residue and accused me of getting them wet.  I assured him the only moisture to get on this unit was copious amounts of sweat.  I only bought these to use while running.  Anyway, he exchanged them for a new pair.  Between March 2013 and July 2013, I went through three more pairs, essentially clearing out our local Verizon stores inventory.  All but one exchange was due to the device's inability to accept a charge to the battery and all three were because of sweat somehow seeping up into the usb port on the headset, corroding the contacts preventing charging.  THe fourth bad unit had a separate issue where it would not turn off, so it was always dead when I went to use it.  It also malfunctioned regularly in addition to not turning off.So now the Verizon store has nothing left for me to swap out to and they will not refund the $105 I paid for the unit.  So I'm stuck with a broken headset that I exchanged 4 times in 6 months.  These are garbage and makes me suspect all Motorola products going forward.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: ...and, add the one-piece Bluetooth receiver to that list.*** The Benefits of a wireless, stereo Bluetooth headset ***Devices like this, (wireless) stereo sport headsets, are rapidly adding all of the conveniences of wired earphones such as:* high-fidelity speakers with in a compact design.* the ability to plug into portable mp3, mp4 and smartphones* relatively inexpensive- various price points.Combined with the functions of the one-piece Bluetooth headset:* the ability to receive and respond to incoming calls* wireless/ radio-frequency connectivity* long battery life.The drawback has always been, you needed both kinds if you want to:* listen to music in stereo* hassle of wires* the expense of buying two devices.Motorola Sports Headphone is one of the better wireless headsets I own.  It's marketed as having HD speaker system.  It's difficult to prove that it's actually "High Definition" but the dynamic range is incredible.  Listening to streaming audio up to 256 kbps and mp3 at 320 was a pleasure.The power of this device is its drivers and its built in amplifier.  So, if the music source is of lower quality, there's no way that the device will produce a HD sound, it can receive and replicate what is transmitted.  The good news is Bluetooth paired devices like a laptop or a smartphone usually has a built-in equalizer.For Android phones, like the Evo 3D I own, there are several very good free equalizers that you can download from the Marketplace.  When engaged, the beauty of the headset is unmistakable.Tracks like:Hayley Westenra's, "You Are Water"The Royal Airforce Band (UK)/ Glenn Miller, "In The Mood"Alexander O'Neal, "If You Were Here Tonight" - Jazzy remix (on YouTube)Or watching the documentary, "The Flute Player"--it was almost like being in a theater.*** Battery Life ***The battery life was consistently between 5- 5.5 hours these past couple of weeks.  This was one of the things I most concerned with.*** Comfort ***They fit snugly.  That's the way I like it.  I have a Bose wireless and I'm always concerned when walking outside with them because there's nothing to keep them attached to the ear.  And, unlike the Jabra Sport, I didn't have to get used to them.*** Comparing Motorola to Jabra's Sport ***The Jabra "Sport" is the other stereo, Bluetooth headset that I have and it, too, is marketed for active users.---Fit & Design---*  Jabra- Slimmer design, slightly lighter, but arm-connector was a bit too long. Took a few days to get accustomed to the feel.  Yellow w/ black trim, sports theme.* Moto--Considerably larger, wrap-around ear makes for a snug, comfortable fit.  Black w/ chrome trim.  (Conservative design makes it suitable for many functions)---Button/ Accessibility---Jabra--Simple, large buttons.  Easy to navigate, easily accessible while wearing.Moto--Many buttons spread across both r/l speakers.  The on/off button very small and difficult to find.--- Sound/ Call Quality---Jabra--Very good.  Easily as good as moderate price, earphones.  Call reception very good.Moto--Exceptional.  Sound is between moderate and high-end headphones.  The combination of the built-in amplifier along with the source's equalizer settings makes sound reproduction explosive.---Battery Life/ Recharging---Jabra--4.5 hours/ 1:15 to fully rechargeMoto--5-5.5 hours/ 1:05 for 80%, 1:20 for 100%---Price---Jabra--between $70- 90 (Amazon's fluctuating price)Moto-- $130.*** Conclusion ***As I mentioned, these kinds of headsets will, within 3 years, start to fully replaced the wired headsets that have become the mainstay of people with portable music players and smartphones.  Gone will be the days when a snag wire means that you're shelling out $50- 75 for good quality, wired earphone.  These wireless, stereo Bluetooth does it all and considering the price of around $100, you're actually buying an upper midrange headset for the price but without the worries of a wired connection.If you're in the market for a single-ear Bluetooth receiver, I'd say consider buying one of these stereo Bluetooth receivers.  For the price of a decent single-ear, you have all of the features except a 5 hours battery life as oppose to about 8.5 hours with a single-ear piece.  But, these can also double as a theater headphone that you can use as far away as 30'.  Think about this when you're watch a long movie like The Lord Of The Rings trilogy.The real question is... is the more robust speaker system of the Motorola of such importance that you'd be willing to pay the $30 price difference instead of buying the Jabra Sport, which is nothing to sneeze at either?One last thing.  I am not an exercise junkie.  In fact, with the exception of basic yoga and pilates, my strenuous exercise regiment is far in my past.  My knees won't hold up under any kind of gym workout.  But, these are marketed to the fitness junkie.  So, my advice aside, you might want to consider the objective advice of the fitness writers who have some thought to add about how it works in a gym-setting if you plan you use these in a gym.For my purposes, Motorola Wireless Bluetooth Headset # SF600---- 5 stars.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have recently started using theMOTOACTV 8 GB GPS Fitness Tracker and Music Playeras a device to help motivate my exercise routine. While I wasn't overly impressed with that device at first I have become a little more enthused with it, almost (note: almost) to the point of bumping my rating for it from three stars to four. Having said that, the headset that came with the unit is a bit annoying. Great sound but it is frustrating to have that connected wire from the player to the headset while you're running. So when I had the opportunity to try a wireless set I jumped at it.The Motorola SF600 is an easy sell for me. Excellent sound, wireless, and a very easy setup up. Of course it connected immediately to the Fitness Tracker. Had to try a couple of times but it connected with my Blackberry Torch fairly easily as well. The headset comes with a number of different sizes of ear gels so you can pick the best size to keep the speakers snug. If I have one complaint it doesn't appear to have a battery life indicator when the battery is getting low. The little "MOTOROLA EXPERIENCE GUIDE" flyer that comes with the headset does say to charge fully before each use so I guess you're to plug it in between uses.Overall, I'm very impressed with the head set. Comfortable, great sound, and sets up quickly and easily. I was rocking with it with five minutes of opening the box. What more can you ask for?
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: These motorola wireless headphone has worked great for me.  I have used them with the Motoactive watch and my Samsung Galaxy S2.  They have worked great with both devices.  I was a little concerned about the comfort of them based on the picture but they have actually been very comfortable while jogging and working out.  The sound quality is great, much better than i expected.  I have been using them for awhile and have had no problems with durability or sweat causing issues.  The ear buds fit my ear perfectly too.  In the past I have had issues with ear buds suctioning into my ear when I sweat but I have not had any problems with these.  Overall I am very pleased with these sport headphones and would recommend them.  They are much better than using wired headphones while working out and have been great for me.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: QUALITY:Well first of all they lasted 2 weeks.  I workout almost every day and do sweat a lot occasionally.  Just a couple days ago the left ear quit working when I was sweating a little more than usual.SOUND:The sound quality is good overall.  If you are used to Bose, which has a lot of mid base for vocals, etc, then you may not like the sound. The highs are nice and clean and the bass is good, but only if you wear the ear buds without grooves.FIT:These things are quite comfortable and fit well... until I start lifting weights.  I guess from my jaw movement and straining the ear buds tend to push out of my ear.  This is fairly annoying since the sound changes.  THEY REALLY NEED EAR BUDS WITH THE WINGS LIKE BOSE USES!CONCLUSION:These are still about the best wireless headphones I've tried, especially for working out.  I will exchange this pair and hopefully the next pair will hold up to sweat better.  WITH THE RIGHT EAR BUDS these things could be really amazing!
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've been using this 600 for several months now and it is... in a word... awesome. I had the old 10 version of this for many years and used the heck out of and this one is just as good. I use the SF600 primarily when I am walking or at the gym, and I know that I could never go back to corded headphones again.If you have on of the older designs, it does take a bit of getting used to because gone is the bar and hardness of it, it's just two earpieces (large) and a wire. At first I wasn't too sure about it, but I really do prefer this design. The swivel earpieces make this easily adjustment and comfortable. If you are afraid of the weight, it is less than having a bluetooth headset in each ear. The cord around the back of your head is basically unnoticeable.The headphones comes in a nifty carrying bag, and with a charger. I love the different sized earpieces that come in the bag. Finding a comfortable fit was fast and easy.Being cord-free at the gym or walking is the only way to go. If you are active and love music, I really recommend these headphones.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: These headphones sound really great for being bluetooth. I used to have a favorite wired pair that sounded really great but the dog got to them. These sound just like them which is why I like them. It was super easy to pair to my iphone 4s. I was even able to pair with my macbook pro for audio reasons. Didn't try them for skype or google talk but I was able to listen to music and videos on youtube. The fit was really comfortable. They were a little tricky to get them on my ears but with practice I had no problems any longer. I have small ears so they felt like they would fall off but I was able to go run outside and go to the park with no problems of them falling. The button locations are placed right so I am able to answer/end a call and higher/lower the volume. I don't use the phone to talk much so these are pretty much used to listen to music or videos with no wires in the way.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Bought these to replace the S-9 and s-10 that I had owned, both broke within a year.The Motorola SF600 seemed like an excellent idea in theory.  The first one would not charge - sent it back. Second one charged and was static prone for about a week and then would not charge. Still have it as I have not gotten around to tossing it. Do not wish to take the time to send it back a second time. Good ideas but poor Motorola quality control.  So the search for a decent headset continues.....
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The SF600 are bluetooth headphones designed to fit in the MOTOACTV fitness product line, but of course you can use them with any bluetooth device capable of handling the A2DP profile; I used these with my MOTOACTV and also my iPhone.The box contains the headphones, a very small 110/240V charger, a soft carry pouch and an assortment of five sizes of eartips.The headphones are made of two identical ear pieces (somewhat similar to a mono bluetooth headset) connected by a short semi-rigid wire that goes behind your head when you wear them.The eartips are adjustable in direction only, not height; and the part that fits behind the ear is thin. After a few tries I was able to put them on without problems, and they stay in place perfectly while jogging.The left piece features the power on/off button; everything else is on the right piece: microUSB connector (behind a rubber cover,) action button, and volume +/- buttons. There is a small indicator light next to the connector that gives you the status of the headphones (charging, pairing, connected, etc...) but it's placed in such a way that you don't see it unless you're looking straight at it, so it doesn't make you look like a Borg.Motorola seems to have paid particular attention to the controls on this unit, gearing them towards the use by fitness enthusiasts. Most other bluetooth headsets have separate controls for previous/next track, play/pause, and phone action; this results in a headset that is difficult to use while jogging. The three buttons on the SF600 are much simpler to use and provide most of the functionality of the more cumbersome design via the clever use of the multi-function button (at the top of the right unit):- one press to play/pause, or pick up a call if the phone is ringing, or hang up if a call is in progress- two presses to skip to the next track- three presses to skip to the previous track- long press for the power song (MOTOACTV only)A great feature on this unit is the voice menus and feedback. When you first turn it on, a female voice instructs you to pair the headphones with your device, and gives you the battery level. You can change the settings (voice feedback, high quality audio, caller ID) by pressing the power button and the action button simultaneously. If you're listening to music and a call comes in, you will hear "call from 2125551212" and you can press the action button to pick up the call (or a long press to reject). This is a really neat feature.Another great feature is the battery status display on compatible devices like the iPhone.The audio quality is spectacular. I think these are some of the best bluetooth headphones I've ever heard.To test the battery life, I fully charged them and then proceeded to listen to them continuously at medium volume. After seven hours, the battery was down to 1/3rd capacity.Pretty much the only sore point with these headphones is the microphone. I tested them while jogging, and my caller couldn't hear me. I then stopped to see if things would improve; I was standing on the sidewalk on a suburban street late in the evening, light traffic, no wind, and my caller still had trouble hearing me. So, lots of room for improvement here.THE GOOD--------* AMAZING sound quality* Very long battery life* Standard microUSB charger* Simple, intuitive controls* Sports-compatible (won't get ruined by sweat or constantly fall off your ears)* Voice prompts, including caller IDTHE BAD-------* Inadequate microphone* Design may not fit all ears, heads and hairstylesCONCLUSION----------If calling is not a major feature for you, the SF600 is perfect. If you regularly take calls while jogging or in noisy environments, and calling is a critical feature, there are better choices -- unfortunately, none of them with the spectacular sound quality of the SF600.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: 8-15-2013: Edit:  Having momentary music drop outs while doing yard work. Disappointing, but this seems to be the norm with many of these Bluetooth products. Still good at the gym where unit is on holder on equipment.  when  it is in your pocket you can expect dropouts.  If I had this to do over I'd buy another brand just to roll the dice to see if another one was better.7-18-2013:  EDIT.  Used second day on treadmill. Can't reiterate enough how difficult it is to use the buttons. They are very stiff and don't have a clicky feeling that lets you know you pressed them. Further, the action is delay by a moment after a successful press so you don't know if you successfully pressed or need to try again.  Looking back I wish I had tried something different, but I have these now and the sound is good, and they have not broke (yet) so I'll keep them (for now).  Wish there was one clear winner in the bluetooth headphone wars.  At this point I'd gladly pay $100 for the perfect set that would be bullet proof and feature rich.  I'm already missing the simple to use phone features of the 903 and its positive click buttons.7-17-2013:  Recently had, and returned, the Plantronics 903+ headphones as the music would cut out while my phone was in my pocket.  Just used these once and they do not have the same issue.  Sound is better. 903's were difficult to get on and adjusted, but so are these. Maybe more difficult, but once on they have stayed in place during mild activity. Buttons do not respond easily to touch - it's hard to know if you are pressing them. You have to squeeze the unit by putting your finger on the button, then a finger on the other side of the unit and squeeze to get the button to work.  Will try them at the gym this week and see how that goes.After reading many reviews for many different bluetooth headphones, it seems the technology is not perfected, that many units have problems with recemption, fit, sound quality, and sweat.  So perhaps I'll put up with bad buttons to get sound that does not drop, and a unit that does not fail after a month of use.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Using this with a HTC DNA smartphone and Bluetooth range is excellent - 30 feet easy in the gym and even beyond. Audio breaks up at that point, but barely skips a beat once back in range. I keep my phone at least 10 feet away during half my workout. Brand new, so can't comment on battery too much. Used it for 2 hours at the gym, then another hour at home while working on my basement. Still ran strong. Sweat proof - I'll only know after a few months how it holds up, but a buddy of mine beats his up pretty badly and no problems.UPDATE - had to replace the first pair under warranty. Not sealed from moisture as expected and charging port began corroding and charging light would not come on. Audio distortion in left earpiece which ultimately made me return it. Replacement is OK, but occasionally won't power after a full charge, requiring reconnect to charger for a second, the. It's OK.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Pros:This set has better noise isolation than Jabra Sport. With several different ear gel sizes included, there should be one that fits your ears well enough. In a noisy environment, such as a gym, you won't have to blast up the volume as you would have to with the Sport. It won't shut out everything, but it's much better than the Jabra in this regard.Note, though, that the lowest volume when using it for phone calls with the iPhone 4 is still pretty loud. Not sure whose fault that is.Good sound across all ranges, with decent bass. Tried it with iPhone, iPad. Unfortunately with Garageband you can't do recording in real time, due to the Bluetooth lag, but playback is fine.Seems sufficiently workout-proof. The hydrophobic mesh seems to be holding out. We'll see ...Pairing is easy - it prompts for pairing each time it's powered on. Voice prompts for pairing, power on/off, etc.Mic for phone calls and voice control (if your phone has it); pretty good voice quality.Cons:The Power button is kind of a strange little nub. To press it, you'll have to get leverage against the other side of the battery thingy that goes behind your ear.The battery, etc. thingy that goes behind your ear is largish, and the connecting wire is kind of stiff and (when worn with eyeglasses, at least) seems to be a factor in making the earbuds less secure. I think it rubs on the neck or collar and slowly unseats the earbuds.The stem near where the eargels go into your ear are kind of big, so it's hard to get them into your ear further to block more sound.The case is a weird, flat thing with a strip of velcro in the middle, so it's kind of open on the sides.Misc:Battery life is 6 hours or more, depending on usage and volume.Uses multi-function button - one press for play/pause/answer call, two for next track, three for previous track, etc. Whether this is a pro or con depends on how much you want separate controls for these. Due to the size of these things, the multi-function button seems like a good tradeoff.UPDATE: After using these for a while, my chief complaint is the rather large earbuds, which cause my ear canal to ache after a bit. Another thing is the tendency of the cord to unseat the earbuds. I've changed the rating to 3 stars from 4.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have several of these bluetooth wire less headphones and I would rate this pair as average compare to my Jabra adn other Motorola.Bluetooth audio is great, with clear sound and good range. I tried to use it as a phone headset and this one suffers the same weakness as my others: you have to speak loud, almost yell for the person at the end to hear you. One even comment to me that it sounds like I speak in a barrel, with fair amount of echoing.The headphones fit ok on my ear. I can't imagine running with it, however. If you have small or large ears, you might have problem as there is no adjustment. But I guess for most of population, this headphone will fit ok.Get it for listening to music or watch movies. As a phone headset, it only perform marginally.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I love the Motorola SF600 Wireless bluetooth headphones! They are the most comfortable fit of any bluetooth headphones that I have tried. They come with multiple sizes of earbud inserts so that you can get a good fit. They stayed in place in my ears despite movement, very well, which is something that I have had trouble with some other brands and previous models of Motorola bluetooth headphones. The sound is very good and I had no reception problems no matter where on my body I placed my phone (many other bluetooth headphones don't do well if the signal has to cross your body). Battery life has been decent at about 4 hours of constant music or talking use.Now my disappointments:-People listening to me talk on these say that it sounds like I'm "very distant" or "in a box". It seems like all bluetooth stereo headphone makers don't focus much on the quality the microphone. I do not know of a better stereo headphone in this category, but am disappointed again.-The battery is weird. Perhaps this is a problem with just my unit, but one more than one occassion I will charge the unit and get an indicator showing that it is connected only to have it be dead in the morning. Or I charge it for a few hours and get just a few minutes of use out of it. Then other times I'll get hours of use out of it. For me, this has made my unit almost unusable for daily purposes because I never know what I'm going to find when I wake up in the morning and try to use. it. Hopefully it is just my unit; if you own one of these and can speak to this issue, please leave a comment so others can know if this is a systemic problem or just with my unit.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have tried numerous bluetooth headsets in the last year or so, and they all have their pros and cons. Some don't fit well, some have poor sound and some are poor quality. I have been desperately wanting a secure pair of sweat proof wireless earbuds that I can wear while cycling and during workouts and I think I may have found the perfect set for me.The fit of the SF600 on my smaller than average ears is perfect. I don't feel like they're going to fall off. I can jump and run, and short of headbanging to some Maiden (hey, I had to try!), these babies will not budge. They are very light and after a fairly short period of initial use, I neglect to even notice them. Part of this is thanks to the genius who said "Let's put a soft covering over the cord!" (Thank you, genius) because without this, other earbuds have a tendency to pull themselves out of my ears when the rubbery cord grips the back of my neck during a workout. Not a problem with the SF600. Yay! Another factor is the multiple sizes of ear gels. Make sure you try them all and find the one that fits you best. You don't want it popping itself out every 5 minutes because it's too big and you don't want it falling out constantly because it's too small. No one should have any issue finding the one of the 6 sets that fits them perfectly.Next is the battery. I used this headset for almost a week for about 2-3 hours per day before I finally had to recharge. This seems about standard for this type of wireless headset but is nice nonetheless.Sound is pretty good as well. It's not show stopping, but we're still fairly new into this era of wireless bluetooth earbuds and considering the competition, it performs just as well as I'd expect. Music is clear and full, audio from videos is crisp and clean. No complaints here. It's also very easy to access the volume rocker. Some earbuds like to cram a billion buttons into a small space on these earbuds so that your fingers are confused about which button does what, but the volume rocker is all on it's own on the back of the right ear piece and can't be confused with any other buttons.The multi function button rests on the top of the right ear piece, so it's impossible to push the wrong button. And speaking of the multi function button, a single touch answers an incoming call after the headset announces who is calling. Nice! This isn't a first, but it's not a feature in most headsets so it's welcome indeed. One less distraction while working out is a good thing in my book. The multi function button controls all aspects of audio playback - forward, back, pause, play. Also nice. I have an older Motorola bluetooth headset that was great for it's price range but was littered with buttons and I finally gave up on it after the 10th time I accidentally called someone when I was trying to pause my music. Less is more in this case. There's only one button on the left side, and that's the power button which you probably won't even need to mess with because you can turn it on before you put the earbuds on and vice versa when you take them off. The power button is kind of tricky to push when they're being worn, but it seems that's by design. If you want to turn them off, that likely means you're done using them.All in all, I'm very pleased and so far (after several months of use) they have held true to their claim of being sweat resistant. They are still performing well and I think they are a strong contender in the wireless earbud market.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I picked up a "new in box" pair the about a week ago here on Amazon for 29.99. Not sure if it was a Goldbox sale or what but I happened to click on them while searching for a good pair of bluetooth earbuds to use at the gym.Amazon sent me a pair that weren't in a retail box and were missing all the accessories except the charger and the buds that were attached to the headphones themselves, they could be refurb or returns... I'm really not sure what the deal was but they offered to send sending me a new pair and while I wait for the new ones to arrive I am taking these on a test run to see how I like it... and holy wow I'm really loving them so far. It's been about 5 days since I got them (I also picked up a pair of Jaybird Bluebud X headphones from Best Buy last weekend and right now I'm deciding between the two pairs) and they are currently favored over my Bluebud X's first in price. The Bluebuds cost me $164 (though I used $160 of Reward Zone credit I had saved up) and though the clarity on them is a tiny bit better I feel that the SF600's are a way better pair of headphones for me.I'll quit with the comparison and try to stick to a straight review from here on out.Sound: I've had many a headphones being quite the headphone junkie and a audiophile on the cheap. These are on par with a good pair of Sony earbuds about the 80 dollar range ones. The bass is solid for ear buds, a tiny bit muddy in the mids compared to some of my top headphones but those lack in bass and I feel it's an acceptable trade off especially in the case of going wire free with these! The treble is clean and and altogether it makes my music very pleasant. Also it's not really noted or pushed but these are Apt-X bluetooth headphones which means they have a higher quality sound than BT headphones of yore... and it shows! These might be the most fairly priced Apt-X BT headphones available as of this writing! To note you do need a device that uses Apt-X compression (I used my Mac Mini) but honestly the quality from my iPhone/iPod Touch sounded great too. It's not like the older compression format that leaves a jingly high-hat sound in the treble from BT devices pre 2009. Overall unless you've got super hearing (mine is just above average) you wouldn't listen to mp3/compressed music to begin with.Comfort and Fit: It took a few minutes to figure out how to put these on... at least for me. I first tried to wrap them around my ear before pushing the bud in my ear canal. It's not really necessary actually. You can just push them in and the rest of it kind of wraps around your ears by themselves. Once their in they are quite comfortable, well as comfortable as any silicone ear tips get. Which for me is only good for about 45 min. I've ordered the Comply TX500s to put on. I won't know how they fair until next week unfortunately. But based solely on my usage over time it'll feel MUCH better on my ears. That said the included ear tips are a bit thinner and softer than ones I have used so they insert a little more comfortably but still do become uncomfortable after a some time. they also tend to slip out a little when I sweat. (Quick comparison I like the feel of these buds over the Bluebuds the bigger more solid wrap around piece that goes over your ear gives it more of a secure feeling like it won't ever move. I'll reevaluate after I get the Comply tips. The are the same ones for both sets of headphones)Battery Life: On my iPhone/iPod Touch the battery life is indicated on the screen, I never knew that it could do that, pretty nice feature! I went about 3 days at roughly 2 hrs a day on and off using the SF600 before the battery died completely. Once the battery hits "low" the voice prompt informs you that the "battery is low" and then procedes to beep once every 30 seconds. A bit annoying, but once you hit "low" you only have about 20 minutes before your headphones die completely anyway, so you'd probably want to stop using them at that point. All in all I got around 6 hours over the 3 days I used it.Value: At 30 bucks it's a heck of a deal. It's back up to $50 now I think which is still quite cheap compared to the alternatives... BUT I've read more than a handful of reviews stating that the one ear goes out from getting too wet or the thing dies completely in well under a year (I think it's been an average of 3-4 months) and I won't be able to find this out until after my return window has closed. This makes me a littler nervous because I actually love these headphones, even with the silicone tips. But if they die in 3 months then they're a waste of everyone's time. But then again I also don't know the circumstance of these other people and this may never happen to me at all. If these last me 2-3 years then there is no doubt that it's money well spent.Overall: If you've ever used canal headphones and hate them these are obviously not for you. But I would be hard pressed find a $30-$50 pair of bluetooth headphones that hold this kind of quality, style and comfort. Sound quality is top notch and I did not ever make a call using these headphones because honestly I've never had a pair of BT headphones that sounded even "good" to the people I talked to. I did record a little clip in quicktime and I sounded far away and harder to understand than when someone is talking directly to me in the phone.I can't say these are perfect for everyone but I'm definitely loving these headphones over anything else I've tested on the market so long as they don't crap out on me in the next 6 months.EDIT: Got my Comply tips in and they make a world of difference. What I've noticed about these buds is if they are jammed really tight into your ears the left earbud seems "louder" or more or less muffled. With the Comply TS500 comfort tips I got a decent seal without jamming the earbud too deep into my ear. The bass level increases a bit so not having them jammed in as tight is actually quite nice for sound quality. It's still a bit muddy compared to my Bluebuds X headphones but again at over 1/5 the cost these are a much better value at the end of the day. So long of course they don't die on me.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black
