reviewText: I can't say much for the durability as of yet, but the comfort, sound, and functionality are all good. The nicely designed "ear-gels" arre an insignificant part of the product, but make a huge difference in comfort. The sound is great, though the bass is understandably minimal (these are ear buds after all), and the fit is great. Listen to music and never stay out of touch as calls send alerts and the buttons on the headset access the phone.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I was able to easily connect these to my Blackberry 9700, but I experienced a lot of crackling over the BT connection when I was jogging with my Blackberry on an armband.  I also found - when jogging - that the ear pieces were a bit clunky and bounced around a lot.  I have theJabra SPORT Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Black/Yellowwhich are much more comfortable and stay put when jogging.  They seem much lighter when jogging than the Motorolas do.Another reviewer complained about them not being sweatproof.  I had no problem and they got quite moist when i was running in a small drizzle.  I could see, however, that over time moisture might be an issue because the buttons are not really sealed very well.  I also found the buttons difficult to operate while jogging.  The Jabra did not have any of these issues.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: These are mediocre headphones. They keep falling off my not so perfectly shaped ears. Because of this, I cannot get a great sound. They also cut out when I am walking. Basically because they do not stay on when I am active, I cannot use them.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: First Review: January 23rd, 2012These puppies come with 5 sets of "ear gels".So, I pulled off the default gels from the headphones and the speaker separated from the housing.Please see the picture that I uploaded.I will contact Motorola to see if they will replace them.UPDATE: January 24th, 2012I called Motorola and they are going to send me a replacement pair and they said that they would include a postage page return label for me to send the defective pair back. 24 minutes of my life wasted ;-) and they needed my credit card number to process the warranty.Once I get the headphones, I will post an actual review of a functioning product.UPDATE: January 26th, 2012I got an e-mail from MotorolaFrom: MATTHEWSubject: Your defective headsetDate: January 26, 2012 1:19:28 PM MSTTo: MarkDear Mark,Thanks again for letting us swap your headset for this new one. Sorry for the problem - our guys will be glad to get yours back for investigation.We are shipping you a new headset today for overnight arrival. If you can use the attached PDF to print a shipping label to send back the bad one ASAP, we will appreciate it. You can track the incoming replacement headset with this link: FedEx:  [...]The replacement headset you set up with our call center has also been shipped. However, it probably won't arrive until Monday and we figured you didn't want to wait any more than we did. When the other arrives, please keep both as a gesture of good will on our part. (Also including a water bottle - since you work out I figure it will come in handy!)Please feel free to contact me at any time.Regards,- MattUPDATE: January 27th, 2012The head set arrived along with a SIGG type water bottle, made in China, that will go to Good Will as I need to trust what I put in my body.The head set was fully charged in about 1 hour, and it took about 30 seconds to pair it to my iPhone.  I tried a bunch of ear gels and got a pretty good fit.  The literature says that the gels with the slots cut out are if you want to hear more ambient noise.  I tested the speaker connections to make sure that the initial problem did not repeat and they were firmly connected.UPDATE: January 28th, 2012I used them for a lift routine and I was able to walk 20 feet away from my iPhone, while searching for the right barbell and there was no static, or connection problems.For 1 hour, I was surprised how little my battery drained. I was running the fitness builder iPhone app (interacting with the screen), listening to an audiobook (Lord of the Flies), and using the bluetooth.  My iPhone went from an 85% charge to a 79% charge (according to the Boost Magic iPhone app).Normally, I use Etymotics which really block out ambient noise.  With the Motorola's I could hear every breath of the guy next to me.  These Motorola headphones only minimally reduce external noise.There is a real benefit to being completely wireless.  I have also used the Jabra Clipper, that allows you to use your own headphones, but then you still need to deal with the wire.  The benefit of the Jabra Clipper is that you can run with headphones you know work for you.For me, the Motorola sport headphones do not work for running.  I even am a forefoot runner and I hardly go up and down at all, but even so, the bluetooth receiver is kinda heavy and it bounced causing the gel to squeak with each step.In Conclusion:1 Star for Quality Control (1 in 100 headsets are tested)5 Stars for Customer Service (a free water bottle and two replacement headsets!)4 Stars for the actual product (easy pairing, good battery, good range, easy buttons, but not usable for running)
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones are comprised of two headphone bodies connected by a stiff, thin cable which runs behind your head.  The headphones connect to your player using a Bluetooth connection so that you dont have a cord running from the headphones to your player.  The absence of the long cord to your player makes the headphones very convenient to use since you dont have a cable swinging around you as you run.The Motorola headphones have a rectangular body which sits behind your ears.  The earbuds extend from the rectangular body and the earbuds can be swiveled to ensure a good fit into your ear canal.  Five different ear cushions are included with the headphones to ensure a comfortable fit.I have been using the Motorola headphones for several weeks while running and have been very pleased with them.  The sound quality is excellent and they have an amazing range which means that I never drop the Bluetooth connection.  I have not had any problems with sweat causing damage to the headphone components.Pairing the headphones with my laptop, phone and iPod was straightforward and easy to perform.These are not my first pair of Bluetooth headphones.  I also have a pair ofJabra SPORT Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Black/Yellowand so I will be comparing them to the Motorola version.* At first glance, I was concerned by the large size of the headphones because I thought that they would be uncomfortable.  The Motorola has its boxy, thin body which sits in contact with your head behind your ears.  Although this turned out not to be  uncomfortable, I was definitively aware that the headphones were there at first.  But, now after wearing them for some time, I dont really notice them anymore.  Alternatively, the  Jabra headphones are thicker than the Motorola, but they sit behind your ear (think one of the older style hearing aids).  With the Jabra headphones in place, I barely notice them.  In my opinion, the Jabra have an advantage for comfort while wearing them.* The Jabra earbuds are positioned right outside of the ear canal whereas the Motorla earbuds are inserted into the ear canal.  I actually prefer the Jabra approach because I can clearly hear the traffic around me.  Although you can choose to use a slotted ear cushions with the Motrola earbuds which is supposed to let in more traffic noise, I found myself feeling less aware of my surroundings.  While this may be the point for some people who would rather just hear music, drivers where I live pay little attention to runners or pedestrians crossing the street and so it is extremely important that I can both hear and see the cars around me.  In my opinion, the fit of the Jabra has the advantage.* A very big advantage for the Motorola headphones is the short cord between the headphones.  When the headphones are in place, the rigid cord is suspended behind your head without making contact with your skin.  The Jabra headphones on the other hand, have a long, flat cord (think linguini shape) that lies on your neck.  When you sweat, the cord of the Jabra headphones sticks to your skin resulting in the cord tugging at your neck whenever you turn your head which is very annoying.  The Motorola headphones have a clear advantage over the Jabra headphones in this regard.* The Motorola headphones definitely sound better than the Jabra headphones.  The music with the Motorola headphones is deeper and richer.  The Motorola definitely has an advantage in sound quality.* I found that the Motorola headphones never dropped the bluetooth connection to my player while I ran.  This was regardless of whether the player was on my shoulder, held in my right hand or held in my left hand.  The Jabra headphones have connection problems and even when held in my right hand (the side closest to the bluetooth receiver in the headset), the signal is dropped intermittently.  If you wear your player on your shoulder, this wont be an issue but for people like me who prefer to hold your player in your hand, the dependable connection of the Motorola headphones is a clear advantage.* The Motorola cable and headphones are black in color whereas the Jabra headphones are yellow.  While there are reasons to have flashy headphones, if you wish to be more nondescript, the Motorola headphones have an advantage.* Both the Motorola and the Jabra headphones have excellent call quality when using them for making calls.In summary, in terms of comfort while wearing and the positioning of the headphones, the Jabra is the better headset.  However, in every other regard, the Motorola headphones are better and I would recommend them over the Jabra headphones.I found the instructions that came with the Motorola headphones to be ok.  The font that they used for the at a glance instructions is ridiculously small (possibly 4 point).  I have not tried initiating calls with the headphones so I cant review how easy that is, but overall, I have found the headphones easy to use.Overall, I highly recommend the Motorola headphones.  The excellent sound quality, the positioning of the cord behind your head, the strong Bluetooth connection and the ease of use all give the Motorola headphones a clear advantage over other Bluetooth headphone options.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I bought these and received them RIGHT AWAY!! I got them on September 21, 2013. Up to this point, the battery holds a good charge, the gels are perfect fit, the sounds is extremely nice and they are snug. I workout at the college and don't have problems with them coming out of my ears. The battery has held a good charge for the hours that I have used them. I sweat a lot so no problem there either. I saw bad reviews but I don't see any of those things happening to me with the bad comments. THEY ARE GREAT AND WORK WELL!!! If anything changes, I will update my posting but I don't think they will give me problems.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I received this unit yesterday and have done some preliminary tests and it works well. Pairing with my iPhone 4 was easy and was coordinated by an auditory cue - as another reviewer noted you will like that cue if you like a British accent (which I do.) As I looked at the device, I thought that there is no way that it would stay in the ear since it appears there is so much weight in the back I thought it would "torque" out of the ear - but it does not. I just left the default gels in (they worked well for me) but it is nice they supply 5 sizes to improve the chances of a good fit. I actually examine multiple ears daily in my work and everyone's ear canal is different - almost like a fingerprint - so for some there is no doubt these would not work but I suspect the vast majority of people will be able to use them. I have not had any issues with moisture penetration but that might be a more long term issue and these have seen limited use thus far. Sound quality was good and I even walked away from my iPhone and did not start to get drops until I was about 15 feet away - which was a surprise (in a good way!)Overall, I am very pleased with the product and I'll post update with any issues.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: These is my first pair of wireless headphones, and frankly, I love the concept. It's nice to have no cords to worry about. However, there are several issues with the SF600 headphones that make them troublesome to wholeheartedly recommend. Let's look at the good and bad:The good:- Pair easily with Bluetooth devices. I was able to pair these headphones with both their intendedMOTOACTV 8 GB GPS Fitness Tracker and Music Playerunit and with my phone very easily. It tells you audibly over the headphones when you turn them on to press "0000" if prompted to when pairing, but I did not have to do that for either device. When using them after initial setup,  just turn on the MOTOACTV or other unit, turn on the headphones, and then tell it to pair with the headphones, and that's it. I can pretty easily switch from streaming music from my MOTOACTV over the SF600's to turning off the MOTOACTV and switching right over to streaming from my phone without any trouble. (and in case you're wondering, yes, you can have both your phone and these headphones Bluetooth paired to your MOTOACTV simultaneously to listen to music and get all your phone notifications at the same time)- They are fairly small. These look much bigger in the product photo. They are actually reasonably small and are partially obscured by your ears (see my user photo). You don't have to look like as big of a dork as the product photo makes it seem.- Higher ranges are pretty good. I mean...they're wireless headphones, but the higher treble stuff sounds pretty good.- Streaming quality is good. I get the occasional microsecond hiccup, but other than that these stream from your device fine. The manual says to try to keep the unit above your waist to avoid having any signal problems, but I keep both my phone and my MOTOACTV at my waist and have had no problems.- They are stylish. The black and red looks good and matches the MOTOACTV's style.- They come with a carrying case. The case is nothing special, just a small velcro case, but it's black and red like the headphones and stylish. It would be nice if it had a lanyard or something to make sure it doesn't accidentally get dropped or fall out of a pocket, but it'll do as-is.- They come with spare earbud covers. In addition to the "solid" covers that are on the earbuds already, you get two additional sizes each of "solid" and "open" earbud covers.- The on-unit buttons are useful, with the exception of the power button. There are volume buttons and a multifunction button (MFB) on the right-ear unit. These are pretty easy to get to while using the headphones, and of course you can just adjust volume on your phone or MOTOACTV if it's easier for you than reaching up and fumbling to try to find them on your ear. Similar to the "music" button on the MOTOACTV, the MFB will play/pause with one press, skip forward with two, and go back with three presses.The bad:- These are really hard to put on. It takes me like 30 seconds to put these on every time. Because of their bulk in the back and because the actual earbud part of them twists back and forth for adjustment, they are very awkward to fit over and stick in your ear. Once they're on you're good, but I struggle with this every time.- They get uncomfortable after a while. Because they're hanging over your ears, they suffer from that syndrome that these over-the-ear earbuds tend to have, which is that after a while they start hurting.- They feel a little loose when running. They're fine if walking or doing something that doesn't involve a lot of bouncing around, but while running they seem to feel a little loose. I don't feel like I'm going to have to reach up and grab them, but they just feel insecure...but I guess that's kind of an issue with any pair of earbuds while running.- The power button is terrible. It is a hard little button that doesn't push in or anything, so you just press it until they turn on. It's not a good design. Kind of hard to describe unless you see it yourself.- There is basically no bass to speak of. If you like bass, you won't like these. If you don't care about much bass, you will probably like these. The bass is waaaaaay low.- It's hard to know how much battery you have left. When it first pairs it gives you a message about the battery level ("battery level is high," or something like that), but after that you kind of have to play a guessing game.Miscellaneous:- The manual doesn't tell you what to look for, so when you're charging these, flashing red and solid orange mean they're charging, while green means charging is finished. These also come with their own charger (one single charging unit, not a separate USB cable).- If you like the sound of a woman with a British accent speaking to you, you'll be very pleased ;-)Overall these are decent wireless headphones, and if you use the MOTOACTV you'll like that they are designed to match the look and minimalism of the unit. However, it's up to you if you want to pay $130 for some headphones. I've done my best to outline the pros and cons above, hopefully you can make an educated purchasing decision now! Thanks for reading!
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'm comparing these to the Jabra Sport which are way better in many ways in my opinion, which I'll explain. These are hard to get into and over your ears. The earbuds do twist but its difficult to do unless you use both hands to get then hooked over your ear while simultaneously twist the bud into your ear. The jabra'a are flexible and you can do it with one hand much easier.The SF600 have a smaller connecting wire which I like better than the Jabra. The reason is that when moving and twisting your neck the jabra's stick to your skin if your sweaty and the Motorola's do not. Pairing on both was super simple but the buttons on the SF600 don't feel like they click or depress at all. The power button is a small nub that I thought was a piece of plastic that wasn't filed down during manufacturing. Plus its on the left and the there buttons are on the right. I like that the Jabra has them all on one side.The sound quality is a bit crisper and louder on the SF's but there isn't much bass so they sound more tinny. The sound on the jabra's has better bass and I much prefer them. Battery life on the Jabra is about 2.5 hrs and the SF's is around 3 of continuous music. I do like that the recharge cord is long on the SF's whereas the Jabra its about 3 inches. I did notice that while the music is at one level, if a message comes in or an announcement from the internal female voice its double as loud and its not only startling but it hurts your ears. Jabra doesn't do that, it stays at the volume level you have. The SF's do go louder than the jabra though but that's not a good thing to have ear buds blasting.The SF's also come with a bunch of different rubber buds to customize your fit as well as let more ambient sound in or not. It also comes with a nice carrying pouch to keep things in.  In my opinion I'd rather have better sound so my preference is with the Jabra. I wish there was a way to have a few things from the SF and a few from the Jabra which would make them a near perfect set at least for me. The jabra's look more like Apple earbuds so there are no rubber buds to fit. Its also been my experience that the rubber buds that the SF have can get clogged up after time if you don't keep them clean.I overall feel that the Jabra's are easier to use and have a better bass sound and also are quick and easy to put on but battery life isn't great. I really wanted to love the SF's but for me, the design was more of a problem than the sound.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewerName: Sean P. Logue "If you can't win, change the r...
reviewText: The sound quality of these seems good, especially if you can get a good seal with the ear plugs. I was able to use the default ones just fine.  I also liked the fact that they include textured versions of the ear gels that deliberately create a less-perfect seal and let sounds in from outside. Trying to run with isolating ear plugs is dangerous, in my opinion, because you can't hear the semi about to occupy your space.The black with little hints of red are very stylish, though the "guts" of the unit seem a little larger than I expected. They fit behind the ears just fine, however.The battery is terrific - they just keep going and going, which is very nice.The best part I found was the range. I was able to get very far away from my iPhone before the sound started breaking up. Much farther than you would normally encounter in real-life situations.  I have another brand of headphones that warns that the player should be no further than your arm. Not so with these!Recommended!Sean P. Logue, 2012
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Motorola 89553N SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones is a very good wireless headset, both for phone/talk and music. It is comfortable to wear and provide very decent sound quality (HD quality). It is suitable for sports as it is sweat-proof. Multiple ear cushion sizes are included so you can find the perfect size for you.Pros:1. Very light and comfortable to wear2. Great sound quality (HD quality)3. Bass is strong and sound clarity is good4. Great battery life and AC charger included5. Multiple ear cushion sizes included6. Sweat-proof which means perfect for running or workout7. Compatible with most Bluetooth Phone and Music Players (iPod touch, iPhone, etc)8. Also compatible with the MOTOACTV Fitness Tracker and Music Player9. Good sound and mic quality when using it to talk on the phone10. Solid connectionCons:1. The build feels a bit flimsy (especially the cable/moving parts). I know that this is not Motorola SF600 specific. I also have the Jabra Sport and Plantronics BackBeat 906 and they are also somewhat flimsy (though Jabra Sport feels more solid/durable) and I'd recommend you to be more careful when using/wearing these type of stereo Bluetooth headset. Having said that, Motorola said that this SF600 headphone is made from very durable material (kevlar fiber) so maybe it is durable after all. Time will tell :)Sidarta Tanu
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The 89553N SF600 (who names these things?) headset is pretty good for a BT device but it's still not the magic set I've been looking for.Pros:Battery Life - Very decent. In an indoor environment I've used them for over 4 hours without draining the battery. Outside, I get around 3-4 hours. This has been consistent for over a month.Fit - I am very happy with the fit and have no problem wearing them for hours. The headset comes with a variety of earbuds and I found a nice match. Additionally, the buds can be "rotated" left and right for an even better fit.Earbuds - One thing that I really like is the buds that allow outside sounds to come in. I can even wear these while riding my bike. At a low volume I can hear sounds around me but still know my environment. The downside to these particular earbuds is that you will lose some bass. If safety isn't important to you then you can still use the traditional earbuds and get a nice amount of bass.Instructions - Well written. No complaints.Pairing - Same as any other modern BT device. Push and hold the power button and tell you phone to look for it. Simple.Sweat - These are designed for working out and so far I have had zero issues with sweat. I mostly use them when I'm commuting my bicycle so they have seen their share of sweat. I'm pleased.Calls - Very good. People sound great on my end and nobody has complained about the sound quality on the other end. I have a very nice Jawbone headset that I use for most voice calls and people sometimes complain about hearing an echo of there own voice. No such complaints from the Motorola.Cons:Outside Usage - As with every other stereo BT headset that I've tried these still cut out when worn outside. They work beautifully inside and I can walk all over my condo with little to know degradation in sounds quality. I do realize that this is a common theme with this style of headset but until the quality matches the manufacturers' advertising I'm going to continue to ding them on this issue. Having said that, they work better than most outside and I can even keep my phone in my pocket and hear my music consistently.Buttons - The buttons are difficult to use. They require a lot of pressure to push which causes the headset to sometimes dislodge from my ears. I can somewhat compensate for this by creatively pushing my thumb on the other side of my ear but it's awkward. I must add though that the button *arrangement* is straightforward and makes sense.In Conclusion:By far the best BT stereo headset that I've tried. MUCH better than the Jabra models. I still feel BT technology hasn't reached its promise but we're quickly getting there.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have tried pretty much every brand and model of this type of headphones and these are easily the best.  I use them for running, skiing (under a Giro helmet), and under shooting earmuffs for work with power tools.  They work really well in every use case that I've thrown at them.Sound - The sound on these is great.  I wish that they could go a little louder, but they are just as loud as the other competing products from Motorola and Jabra.Comfort - From the picture on the website, I was leery about how comfortable these would be.  They appeared like they would be heavy, bulky, and uncomfortable.  This is definitely not the case.  Nothing hanging on your ears is going to be un-noticeable, but these come pretty close, especially when compared to the others I've tried.  I am using the large size ear cushion, they come with 5 different sizes to choose from.Battery - The battery life on these is great.  I haven't run them down in a single use yet.  I don't know how long the battery in them is supposed to last for, but they kept working for a full day of skiing, so anything beyond that is gravy.Connection - These connect easily with my Motorola Triumph Android Phone and with my Motorola MotoActiv Sport GPS.  They stay connected, and I wasn't able to make the connection drop out at all during normal use, inside or out, even with a ski helmet on.Durability - The first one of these I got was broken/defective out of the box.  The sound would only come out of the right ear.  I called the Motorola number in the manual and they sent me a replacement headset right away.  The call took about ten minutes with lots of miscommunications with the foreign based customer service representative.  They sent me a replacement and a shipping label to return the defective unit with.  The replacement set has worked very well so far.  It seems to be highly sweat and rain proof, and based on my experience with other Motorola headsets, I have little doubt that these will continue to perform well.  I will update this review if it doesn't continue to work well.Buttons - The buttons are well placed and easy to use.Accessories - the charger, travel pouch, and ear cushions are all good quality.  The manuals are concise and well written.Calls - This headset is great at making and receiving calls.  Both on my end and on the other end the call quality is exceptional.  I am always amazed at the quality of the calls with this latest generation of headsets, because they manage to have good call quality even though the microphone is so far from your mouth.Customer Service - When my first headset arrived with a defective left ear, I used it as an opportunity to try out Motorola's warranty support and Customer Service.  The 800 number in the manual went to a foreign based call center that was very difficult to communicate with.  The call took three times as long as it would have with a US based CSR and I left the call very unsure if I was ever going to see my replacement headset.  Despite my lack of satisfaction with the phone call, they quickly got me a replacement headset and also provided free return shipping for my defective unit.I highly recommend these headphones.  Motorola should consider US based phone support and better quality control at their manufacturing facility, but otherwise these are a great product.  To date, these are by far the best Bluetooth headphone on the market.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'll keep this short and straight to the point.Good fit.Shoddy construction.Left Channel went out after 3x of use.charging port started corroding and made them useless.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've tried soooo many bluetooth headsets.  The sound quality has never been great, nor has the fit/comfort in my ear.  I've found 1 in the past that worked well just for phone calls, but was only 1 ear, and would never work well for the gym.  These motorola headphones have definitely delivered!  The fit and comfort in my ears is excellent, even with the default ear gels (comes with 4 alternate sizes in case you like those better).  I wear them during my entire gym workout, and never even noticed they were there, even when doing bench press, where my head and neck are pressed onto the bench.  I did have some intermittent trouble with song skipping, but I think this was my phone, not the headphones, as it has been going slow and in need of a reboot.
title: Motorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I was excited after receiving this headset as I read some good reviews.Unfortunately, it is a decent headset inside (no better), and terrible when there is any surrounding noise, wind, etc. I leave it at my work desk now and only use it indoors when my Plantronics Voyager Pro needs recharging.Other callers complain they cannot hear me, and say my voice sounds far away/in a well.  It is however, easy to hear other callers.Overall, I wouldn't recommend it and strongly suggest looking into a Plantronics Voyager instead:[...]
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have been told this Bluetooth headset sounds best among the ones I have (or ones I lost). Motorola claims this one has extra long range; perhaps in closer proximity this means stronger signal. Anyhow, I am happy on that front.Another thing that I love about this headset is how compact it folds when not in use. It is the smallest I have. When fully folded, it is off. The ear loop is also ambidextrous and easy to flip around for left or right ear, no need to snap it off first (like with other headsets I've had). It will fit in any tiny shirt or pant pocket or corner very unobtrusively.The headset is very easy to pair (although they are all getting much better these days). In addition, it tells you "8 hours of talk time remaining" and so on every time you turn it on. This is all good, but I noticed that without much talk it starts saying "7 hours" and then 6, so perhaps this battery indication is not the most reliable :)My only issue with this headset is that after prolonged use (just keeping it on my ear), my ear starts to itch. The strange thing is that it itches in the ear canal, and this headset has nothing that protrudes in there. Maybe it is just me, or maybe there is something to this headset that could irritate the skin. This is not a big deal for me because I normally fold the headset (off) when not expecting a call.Recommended.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I'm a daily commuter in a large metropolis. Bluetooth has become essential to my life due to recent laws in the city and I rely on these for work and personal reasons.With that being said, I found the H19txt to have both great perks and some noticeable flaws. As of right now, it is my primary device, but that is more out of convenience than anything.Pairing is no big deal - like with every Bluetooth device, my iPhone 4S was ready in under 20 seconds. The battery life is as advertised: 8+ hours of talk time on each charge can be expected. The charging is easy and fast. The buttons are similar to previous Bluetooth models and perform admirably, even when pressed against your face.Sound quality is always an issue for me and I found it to be just OK. Rarely would it static up / red line and just turn into a mush. I would stream some music in as well, which sounded about as good as one can expect from such a miniature speaker. The mic works well too, with nary an issue in terms of being heard on the other side. The flip-out mic, operating as an on/off switch as well, is exceptionally fragile. I would recommend not messing with it too much and simply unpairing the device.Comfort is hit or miss. Without the plastic joint the headset will fall off with too many sudden movements. With it on it will hold in an acceptable fashion. The joint can also can feel a bit rough around the edges, which also hinders the comfort level. Once again, the flip-out mic and its fragility works against how you wear or use this headset.In terms of the Motorola line of Bluetooth headsets, I have found this one to be the most reliable one yet.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This must be my 10th Motorola, not including other ear headset devices, and close but quite as advertised.Pros: battery level in talk hours upon turning on with boom, boom on/off, sleek but finally tactile functional primary command button, numerous ear attachment options, comes this charger, good volume control, My Moto text reading, sending and commands, battery life for size and weight (nearly double the H17t)Cons: range up to 300 feet...not on earth, divide by ten, 30 feet tops, retail packing on mine was clearly opened and poorly repackaged, making me wonder as to the actual newness of this device, very minor background hum on low volume settings when playing music.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I own quite a few different Bluetooth headsets.  Most of them are either Motorola, which are very good, Jabra, which are pretty good, Plantronics, also pretty good, and Blue Ant, which are terrible.Until the Motorola H19txt arrived, my favorite headset was the Motorola HX550, which is also very good and similar in appearance to the H19txt.But there's no question that the Motorola H19txt is my new favorite Bluetooth headset.  There are 3 reasons why I like this headset so much.  They are:1. Range.2. Battery life.3. Audio clarity.You might have noticed that the title of this review is "A review from the toilet seat".  What did I mean by that?  Let me explain.As much as we might not like to admit it, I think there are times where we might use the phone while on the John (no offense intended towards those named John).  I live in a pretty small place and my bathroom is the one and only room in the house where, up until now, conversations were so garbled as to be nearly inaudible.So as a test, I tried the Motorola H19txt in the bathroom.  Amazingly, it was the first headset I've used that was actually pretty clear even from the bathroom!  Was the signal perfect?  No, it wasn't, but it was pretty good and I'd say a 50%-70% improvement over all of my other Bluetooth headsets.  It's now my "go to" headset when I have to go or otherwise!I also mentioned battery life.  This unit features talk time of up to 9 hours.  When you turn it on, it says, "More than 8 hours of talk time remaining".  Battery life seems quite impressive.The audio quality is also very good and better than the Motorola HX550, although only marginally so.Pairing is very simple, so no complaints there.The form factor is very small and light.  It's also relatively comfortable to use with eyeglasses.  I've used a number of other headsets that were not comfortable when used with the ear loop and eyeglasses.I haven't used the text features.  Sounds pretty cool, but I'm not a big texter and besides, I don't believe my phone is compatible with the MotoSpeak application.  I'm sure others will address that feature.But hey, it's a really good Bluetooth headset. It delivers exactly what is promised.  Absolutely the best I've ever used and a definite range advantage over all of my other Bluetooth headsets.  5 stars all the way!
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I gave this 4 stars.  I like the Motorola H19txt  headset due to the many features as well as the clarity it produces. Motorola need to include more ear piece sizes.  It comes with three wear styles: On your ear, In-ear without a hook, and In-ear with a hook. I would like to use the in ear with hook but it's too big so I end up using the on your ear with hook but when i tilt my head the headset feels as if it's about to fall.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Disclaimer: I am reviewing a headset that I received for free through the Vine program.Nice Bluetooth earpiece/headset.I do  have another model (Motorola HX550, ASIN B005FPT380) that's not quite as nice as this one, so I'll be using this one instead of that other one from now on.Compared to the HX550, this one seems to have a bit longer battery life, is slightly larger so easier to handle (but not so large as to be clumsy or uncool), buttons are a bit easier to press, maybe slightly more comfortable (probably just psychological).
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I bought 2 of these bluetooth for me and my boyfriend.  We were having horrible sound quality with our phones prior to getting these.  Since we've been useing them we can hear each other clearly.  No annoying noice.  I love it and I love that I can listen to music through it.  It's also comfortable in the ear.  Thanks Motorola!
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The first thing I loved about this, was the packaging! It came in a small box that was easy to open (I wish more manufacturers would realize simple, easy, packaging is appreciated!). The directions were simple and straight forward.The headset didn't come charged, so I had to charge it first. After it charged, I paired it with my iPhone which was totally simple. All I did was go into my settings, opened "Blue Tooth" and (after turning on the headset), set it to discover the device - it did immediately and I didn't have to type in the security code (located in the instructions). It's crystal clear when speaking, and I have small ears, so often, things don't fit well in my ear, but this wasn't a problem. It does have a great range. I was wearing it all day and while in the garage (and my iPhone was in the upstairs bedroom) - I almost had a heart attack when my ear "rang" - it's quite comfortable and I forgot I was wearing it.The only criticism I have, is that the light that tells you if it's on or off/battery/status - is really tiny. I'd say people who can't see very well would have a very hard time with the light.All in all, it does a great job, very clear, (I even tried it while driving with the sun roof open and no complaints from the people on the other end of the headset) and it's been 3 days and I still haven't had to re-charge it.So far, 5 stars! As always, if I run into any problems, I'll edit my review.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Previously I had the Motorola H17 with a bluetooth range of 33 ft.  This H19txt model has almost 10x the range at 300 ft.  This is my favorite enhanced feature because it allows more freedom from the physical location of the cell phone.  For example sometimes I'll make a quick stop to drop off a box, or buy some gas, and I leave the cell phone in my car console.  With the H19txt I don't have to put the cell phone in my pocket, I can just leave it sitting on the console and continue the phone conversation, and it stays in range.  The H19txt makes the quick stops more convenient.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: If you're looking for a small, unnoticeable, high quality headset, this is the best.  The speaker is clear, connection is solid (even when my phone is in another room) and it's comfortable.The only complaint I have is that the microphone isn't perfect.  I've asked people on the phone, and they say my voice is more "tinny" when I'm using the headset.  Not so for my other headset, which outperforms the microphone on the phone itself: thePlantronics Voyager Legend Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - BlackHowever, that headset is large and very noticeable.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Ok, let's start of with the most important thing about any bluetooth headset, sound quality: It's great! Just great! Voices on the other end of the bluetooth are crispy clear, I asked friends how good the quality of the bluetooth was on the other end and for the most part they said they couldn't even notice that I was using a bluetooth device, that's how good it is.Now for the best thing about this bluetooth, besides sound quality, size! This thing is tiny! And trust me, when it comes to bluetooth headsets, tiny is good! Easy to carry around with you and easy on your ear, plus, it will save you some embarrassing comments about you looking like a cyborg from one of those Van Damme Movies!Battery power is great as well, it gives you about 8 hours of talk time per charge, and I don't think anyone talks 8 straight hours on their cell phone, this is the text generation baby!Overall, great bluetooth headset, great price too. Buy it, you won't regret it.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset is one of the best Bluetooth headsets that came out from this company. And I am saying this from the perspective of owning different brands of BT headset and comparing it to the Motorola H19txt.My impressions:Advanced features: The Motorola H19txt has a Rapid Connect feature where the mouth piece or boom of the BT headset can be folded to turn it off and unfold it to turn it on. This is great if you need to conserve your BT's power when not in use. With A2DP, you can stream music to your BT headset or listen to navigation commands from your GPS. Voice prompts lets you know when you are or are not connected to your phone. This headset also has the capability to connect to 2 devices at the same time. For iphone users, the Motorola H19txt also works with Siri. For Android users, the free app My Motospeak can be downloaded to give you a wide array of additional functions with the voice prompts.Shape Factor: The Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset is compact, smaller than most major brand bluetooth headsets currently out in the market. If you have hair that covers your ears, this BT headset practically disappears from sight.Wearing Flexibility: The Motorola H19txt offers three wear styles for the perfect TrueComfort fit: On your ear, In-ear without a hook, and In-ear with a hook. The flexible ways of wearing this BT headset also translate to wearing comfortability. This BT headset is worn according to your own personal level of comfort fit and thus can be worn for hours without ever knowing it is in your ear. I found this expecially true during a stop over at a hotel during a long drive. I didn't realize I was still wearing the headset were it not time to lay down in bed. It also can be worn comfortably even when you wear glasses or a hat. Some hook style BT headsets will not fit around the contours of your ear with your glasses on. Since the Motorola H19txt can also be worn in ear without a hook, this solves this minor predicament.Audio: The Motorola H19txt boasts of an HD Audio Plus for exceptional clarity and a dual microphone technology that cancels background noise. My audio test-run from a moving vehicle proves the call quality. The person I am speaking to heard me clearly and I am able to hear them clearly.Power/Battery Life: The Motorola H19txt has a standby time of 16 days and a talk time of 9 hours. So for those of you out there who are contantly on your cell phones, this outstanding talk/standby times pretty much covers you.The Motorola H19txt comes in a sleek, hard plastic packaging. The packaging contains the BT headset, an on-ear hook, an in-ear hook, 2 in-ear gels, charger and the user guide. I really enjoyed using this BT headset. It is compact and full of features you would normally expect from something double its size. Highly recommended!
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is an expensive Bluetooth device and it could be better. It is not loud and not extremely comfortable. I am used to the Motorola H700 series and these are quite comfortable, easy to get on the ear and loud. I do like that it is small and it streams well. I picked this Bluetooth because I wanted to stream my computer and it works great for that, even though it is not as loud as other Bluetooth devices. I also didn't notice a great deal of difference between this Bluetooth and my H730 as far as distance. There is no way this works 300 feet away.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The sound is very clear and distinct. I had no problems walking around the house or driving in the truck. Motorola includes 3 types of ear pieces for any type of wearing style. I prefer just the hook with no gel. I can't handle having something stuck into my ear.Pairing was super simple. I turned the headset on and then turned the bluetooth on. Within seconds I was paired. No special codes, no jumping through hoops. It worked, right out of the box. BTW, I have a Sony Experia Android phone.I don't know where they get the 300 foot distance thing. The most I got was 108 feet during my test. I used one of those rolling rulers the contractors use. I placed my phone on the ground just outside my garage door. Then walked down the street, in a clear line of sight, using the rolling ruler. I got to 108 feet when all sound died. Then on my return trip the sound didn't come back on until I was 47 feet away from the phone. I still think 108 feet is a great distance for a bluetooth device.This headset is light and stays put with just the hook. Talk time is about 8 hours which is fine for me. I can also listen to my music streaming from my phone. App games sound okay, but they can be a bit choppy.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The compactMotorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packagingarrived in an attractive hard plastic box which I'm using for storage of some little bits which made me happier than having another package to recycle.  The headset is compact and different than my other bluetooth headsets because the boom is foldable.  The most difficult part of getting this up and running was removing the little plastic from the headset, so I'd give it tom marks for accessibility and function.  Easy to charge, this headset hasn't burned the charge any faster than my other headsets, another plus.  Pairing with a Motorola Razr was simple and required nothing other than turning on both units, yay for ease!  I'll admit that I was startled because a voice spoke to me as soon as I opened the box, but I wasn't too surprised since the light was already on in the headset.  I've had no problems with the fit in my ear or the reception, but I dpn't usually travel too far from my phone, so it hasn't been tested to the max.  The design reminds me of a Volvo, boxy, if you know what I mean.  I'm very impressed with this Motorola headset, but must admit that I prefer my Plantronic bluetooth headset which is in this price range.  I am not complaining about this one, I just really prefer the other because I like it's design better.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I'm not that fond of bluetooth earpieces. The list of problems with them is legion: they fall out, they're uncomfortable to wear, adjusting the volume is a pain, you drop calls, etc.I have to admit, most of these things aren't issues with this Motorola headset. It paired nicely with my iPhone, so I wasn't spending all day trying to get them to link.One thing I particularly like is how the microphone flips open for on, and shuts off when you close it. No more fiddling around with the on/off button!The reception is good. No one is saying, "I can't hear you!" What I do like is on my end, I don't have to turn up the volume for people to hear ME, and meanwhile, they are so loud in my ear it makes my eyes water.If I had a quibble, and I do, it's that the earpiece isn't adjustable and not terribly comfortable. (I never use the in-ear thing; that never works and always falls out.)If you can bear a little discomfort, though, I'd highly recommend this. All the troubles I've had with bluetooth earpieces are pretty much solved in this unit.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Very Good Product everyone needs one of these. 300 feet is very good and not a problem!!!! And I will buy another just for keeps!!!
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Bluetooth headsets are seemingly simple items that are actually very easy to get wrong.  Many are uncomfortable, obtrusively large, have short battery life or bad sound quality.  The Motorola H19txt series is a great example of a bluetooth headset done right.  It's extremely small and lightweight making it easy to wear for extended periods.  The small size and lack of LEDs also makes the headset relatively discrete.  The H19txt comes with a wide variety of ear clips and in-ear silicone plugs ensuring that you'll be able to get a good fit.  The battery easily manages eight hours of talk time, much longer on standby.  The folding boom design makes it simple to activate and deactivate the headset as well as provides a clear visual indication of whether the headset is on or not.  Opening the boom while talking on a call using the handset instantly shifts the call to the headset, a very useful feature.  The phone has numerous voice prompts that communicate the headset's status.  The "txt" in the name indicates that using Motorola's "My Motospeak" app, you can dictate texts through the headset.  Lastly, and perhaps most importantly, this headset sounds great.  The noise cancelling is truly excellent and the microphone is very sensitive.  You no longer have to shout in a car at highway speed for the other person to hear you if you're using this headset.  You'll also be able to hear them better.  This is a slightly expensive headset but you're really getting what you're paying for.  I think it's the best headset currently on the market.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewerName: Lisa Shea "be the change you wish to see in t...
reviewText: My boyfriend uses his phone fairly non-stop, and it's critical to him that his headset works clearly and well. He's tried many options over the years. So he was curious how the Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset would hold up.First off, the small size is great. It fits right into your ear in multiple ways. There's an over-the-ear hook, which he finds too loose and it easily falls off when being active. Then there are in-ear rings. For him, one size is too small and easily falls out. The other size is a bit too big so it fits but the pressure hurts after a little while. So he'd like a middle size.The battery life is good - he gets a steady eight hours out of it. It's got a number of neat features. If you press the volume on and off at the same time during a call, it mutes, and tells you verbally that it's muted. Do it again and the mute turns off. If you do that when you're not on a call, it'll tell you talk time remaining. If you press and hold the call button while turning on the headset, you can change various options including the voice interface and caller ID.We highly recommend turning OFF the caller ID feature. With it on, you have to wait through an interminable computer voice reading out all ten digits of the phone call before you can answer it. You'll be lucky the person didn't hang up by the time you wait for that to finish.Compared with other phones we've tested, this one works much better at staying connected while calls come and go, and other activities like audio books stop and start again.He'd like it if it could let you listen with the little microphone piece tucked in. But that's a minor complaint.Well recommended.We received a review copy of this unit through the Amazon vine program.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: My last Motorola Bluetooth headset was the direct predecessor to this model, and while I loved that last one, this one makes several positive improvements. It's smaller, darker colored, and the controls are simplified and streamlined. The battery lasts nearly a third longer, the sound is somewhat clearer, and the charge slot is straight on the end, rather than a weird angle. Also great for streaming podcasts and other media from your cell phone that you don't mind listening to in mono. Subtle and light, it's the best Bluetooth I've used yet, and I can't recommend it enough!
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: This is a very small headset.  But it outperforms others that are bulky and heavy.Easy to set up.  Button that controls things is easy to find.  I use the over the ear loop to help keep it in place.  No complaints at all about the loop.The sound is great.  This is one of the headsets I use often.Very nice indeed.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Just got back from UPS whre I sent my recently purchased Motorola H19 TXT back . I decided to give it another try after it kept going in and out losing connection in mid conversation after about a month of use rendering the headset worthless! I like the 8 hur talk time and when positioned correctly the clarity and being able to hear whom I am speaking to. I upgraded to this unit after my Motorola HX550 Headset just quit on me after 2 1/2 months ! Fortunately Motorola sent me a new one out. Sooo I upgraded to the H19txt and this one went on the blink after less than a month of use! I will keep you updated! Also I use my blutooth heavily as I am a manager at a Honda store and I despise holding a phone up to my ear all the time . I will up date you guys on weather this unit is for COMMERCIAL USE! The talk-time of 8 hours is GREAT but can it hold up?????Very easy to power up a does not take long to charge!!! 8 Hours talk time . The only drawback is the distance in staying connected but its minor and can be worked with! Not bulky or tacky sharp sleek. Gets the job DONE.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: However, each time I use it. I am always having to pair the head set to my cell phone. That is so inconvenient.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have used a number of Bluetooth products by Motorola throughout the years as Bluetooth headsets have progressed.  This particular headset is a very good product in that same line.1.  What's in the box?  I received a smaller box with the headset unfurled so to speak with the boom mike out.  Inside the box, there were instructions, a extra set of earpieces, and a charger included.2. Aesthetic?  This is a small unit.  Imagine something placed on your fore-thumb and that is about the size of the unit.  It is an appealing gunmetal grey color, with a silver boom mike and a raised surface on the front (visible) side, with a button in the middle to place calls, and a volume button on the top.3.  Use?  The first measure of this unit was the set-up.  After charging for an hour or so, I simply pulled out the boom mike and you will hear a sound telling you that you have battery power (up to 9 hours?!) and whether a connection has been made.  Using an iphone, I did not have to "pair" the device, but the item was discovered and announced it was ready to go.  Phenomenally easy! No entering in passcodes or anything similar.  High marks for this.I really love the idea that turning off this item is as easy as just closing the mike.  Nice.  Also, it seems as though I have been able to talk for hours without having to recharge.  In earlier incarnations, the headset would need a charge after a few hours.  I have yet to run this thing down from talking.  The standby time seems impressive as well.  I have been able to use this item for days without any issue.Sound?  After removing the plastic cover on the microphone, the sound is quite good.  Other parties have stated that the sound is good, but a bit tinny. However, the sound is good according to other people listening to us on the phone.Pros:  Easy set-up.  Nice, attractive looks.  Long battery life.Neutral:  This is a nice-looking unit.  Although there is the lower-priced unit available that is white, silver and read that looks really neat, this is a still nice looking, however.Cons:  None really.  I am satisfied with this headset.  Keeping in mind that I received to review, it is an expensive headset, currently being about 100ish.  In all honesty, I might purchase a lower end model.  However, this is still a very nice unit.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I generally like this Bluetooth, with a few caveats.  The sound quality on MY end is very good.  Unlike my last Bluetooth, people I talk to don't tell me that I sound like I am in a tunnel, far away, or other indicators of poor sound transmission on their end.This unit has the convenient flip on-and-off tab that I MUST have in a Bluetooth -- no wondering if you left it on, you can see if it is on or off.  Also, it is really hard to "butt dial" anyone on this style...something that used to happen a lot with the style of Bluetooth that turns on just by holding a button down for a couple of seconds.This unit pairs with my phone VERY quickly...VERY.  That is a huge help -- it will connect before I even have to answer by the third ring.Another nice feature is that it tells you upon connection how much battery life is left on the Bluetooth (i.e., "over 7 hours left").  This is helpful if you aren't talking on an iPhone (which shows you the battery level onscreen).The only drawback (and this is a big one for me) is the hard, non-adjustable ear loop.  It tends to irritate my ear because of its inflexibility, and also tends to fall off, since it cannot really be adjusted to fit your ear at all.  It does come with additional in-ear clear rubber buds, so it can be worn without the loop, but I find that the unit seems to fall out easily, either due to the design or the weight distribution.  The unit is not heavy, but it still will easily pull the bud out of your ear.Anyway, so overall a very nice quality Bluetooth, but if you have sensitive ears, the hard, inflexible ear loop may bother you.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Great Bluetooth Headset.If your using it with an iPhone it will show the battery icon next to the BT icon. This is a pretty nice feature.I also use it with an android device and must say i am happy with the loudness of the speaker and the quality of the microphone.Another feature i personally like is the flip to power on and off. This is much more convenient for me then having a button to press and hold.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've owned several different Bluetooth headsets over the years, and this Motorola H19txt is easily the best. I couldn't believe how easy it was to pair with my Samsung Dart. I just turned them both on and that was it - they were paired. The range is great... I can walk throughout my whole two level townhouse and not lose it. If you do happen to wander out of range, just come back within range and it instantly reconnects. It comes with 4 different ear pieces (2 with hooks, 2 without) so you can choose what's most comfortable for you. I've never had an issue with it coming loose, and it feels extremely comfortable in my ear. Call quality seems top notch also, as I haven't had any complaints on my calls yet. Overall, I can very enthusiastically recommend the Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset based on my own great experience with it.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I have been using the this now for about a week and find it works very well. People who call say they hear me as well as when I'm on the phone. I downloaded the app to let me hands free hear and send text. While it takes a little longer it does work well and keeps me totally hands free. I can hear callers with not issues and it fits very nicely in my ear. I would only change one thing and that would be the flip mic flips inward and I find it would be easier if it flip outward-not a biggie though. It has great battery life.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Great little design and clear voice sending and receiving. The issue I had and I am not sure if it is with many or I just got  a lemon, but it randomly made a high pitch beep and then clicked over to the phone. It did not hang up it just like turned off or somehow sent the call over to the phone so I had to fumble around to either get it back in the headset or pick the phone up, It did this with random amount of chargedness, It really sucked when you are driving and your bluetooth decides it needs a break. Usually it only happened after talking for more than a few minutes but it happened on almost every one of those calls. I decided to go back to the Platronics Voyager series which I have always used, I was trying to go cheaper and smaller, it just didn't work out for me.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: The Motorola H19txt bluetooth headset offers so much potential to those of us who have tried headset after headset looking for THE ONE that finally works as advertised. Unfortunately, the Motorola H19txt falls a little short. That's expecially diappoointing given the premium price this model is going for. Where are the disconnects, so to speak? Mainly audio quality. Motorola says the H19txt has two features called HD Audio Plus and CrystalTalk that employ a dual-mic technology to increase call clarity and richer sound (whatever that means). In my testing, the sound quality was mostly average in comparison to other Bluetooth headsets I've used, and at times it was noticably worse. CrystalTalk is supposed to cancel out unwanted background noise, but on the model I tested noise gate had a nasty delay that caused an abrupt and unnatural-sounding clipped tone whenever somebody would speak. This undesirable "sound effect" started to get on my nerves, and no amount of fiddling with settings on their otherwise decent Android app helped very much. Otherwise, performance was about what you would expect from a bluetooth headset. The onboard controls are logical and easy to use, and the app does a nice job of freeing you from having to use any of those controls at all. Usable range was excellent, and the battery life is nothing short of amazing. Were it not for some troubling issues with the sound quality, I would have given Motorola H19txt a much higher rating.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I'm a pretty simple guy when it comes to Bluetooth headsets. I rate them on the following:(1) Ease of setup(2) Comfort on my ear(3) Length of charge(4) Ease of phone appI'll give you my impressions how this headset measures up, I used this on my HTC One X.SETUP:On my smartphone, I went to the Bluetooth menu, and it recognized the headset and paired right away. No code entry was required, but depending on your phone, you might need to enter a pairing code (which is provided in the instructions). I then downloaded the "My MotoSpeak" app, which was very easy.When you flip the mouthpiece down, a voice will announce: "Phone one connected. More than [x] hours of talk time."COMFORT ON MY EAR:This is a very, VERY comfortable headset. The headset can be adjusted to fit either the left or the right ear with easy adjustment, There is no need to remove and reattach the hook.I've uploaded a few pictures to "Customer Images" for you to look at.It can pivot up or down to your comfort level, and it didn't feel heavy on my ear.LENGTH OF CHARGE:A full charge gives you 8 hours of talk time. I typically this headset for about 45 minutes to and from work,  and I have over 6 hours of my charge left.EASE OF PHONE APP:This is the big selling point for this headset, My MotoSpeak (Current version is 3.0.57).The app allows you to do hands-free sending and receiving of text messages. If you don't have the headset in, you can still have your phone read messages aloud, but sending messages is harder without the earpiece, unless you speak loudly. You can add an optional signature line to your messages, but I disabled this.If you get a text while driving, there's a blip on the earpiece and you'll hear:"Text from [person's name], Listen now?"You can say "Yes" or "No".If you say yes, the message will be read by a female voice. Once it ends, the voice will say "Reply?" And you can say the following: "Yes", "No", or "Repeat" to repeat the message.After speaking your message, it will read your reply back and then say "Send the message?" and you can say "Yes" or "No". If everything's fine, I pick "Yes" and the message is sent. If it didn't recognize what I was saying, I'll pick "No". It will then say "Try Again?" and you can either choose "Yes" (which allows you to rerecord your reply) or "No" (which closes the message).When you press the button on the headset, it will say "Say a Command". If you say "Text [name]", the phone will repeat the name you spoke and then say "Opening Text message. Say your message". At this point, you're ready to go.No voice recognition software is perfect, but this one is very accurate for me. Heck, it recognized the word "gobbledygook" - and any headset which can do that is top notch in my book.ANY DRAWBACKS?Well, it's mainly the app I have issues with. If I get a call and someone text messages me, the message will not be read to me when the call is over. It would be nice if a future version of this app has a menu option to listen to the most recent message.I also found this is not compatible with Google Voice on my phone, so I have to turn off the headset if I want to do updates for Twitter or Facebook.FINAL VERDICT?Overall, this is a very comfortable Bluetooth headset. It is easy to set up, comfortable, and holds its charge. The app needs some work, but 3 out of 4 isn't bad.Definitely recommended.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: By far the smallest and lightest Bluetooth headset I've used.  I love that it folds to an even smaller size when I need to throw it in my bag or briefcase.It connects flawlessly.The sound is clear and I have had no complaints that my voice is coming through muffled.Highly recommended.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've tried many different Bluetooth models and so far am really enjoying this little Motorola H19txt. Here's what I like about it:- 9 hours of talk time and 16 days of standby time (to me, this is key since my BlueAnt usually dies so quick even on standby). The product info compares is to Plantronics Voyage Pro HD which gets 6 hours of talk time or Jawbone Icon HD which only gets 4.5 hours.- it's hard to find a model that fits well on the ear - the H19txt has 3 wear options: on your ear, in ear with a hook or in ear without a hook- 300 foot roam range from my phone - granted my house is small, so it's nice for me to be able to walk around- supports Siri (how useful Siri itself is still up for debate)- great sound quality, has worked excellent even with the wind blowing outside- RapidConnect feature that allows you to just flip open the Bluetooth to take calls. Flip it closed and you can save battery life- can pair with 2 phones at the same time- helpful voice prompts to let you know when you're connected, running low on battery, etc.Cons: I don't really have anything bad to say here - so far it's been a pleasure to use. One thing that I'm still struggling with is the free My MotoSpeak App that's supposed to let me hear incoming messages, speak texts, make and take calls, etc. I haven't been able to get it to work well, but it says it's optimized for Android phones and I have an iPhone, so that may be the problem.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I've used multiple Bluetooth Headsets throughout the years and I'm rating this on the upper levels.  It's not the best ever, but it's on the upper echelon.Opening it is straight forward.  One of those new hard plastic tops and you slide it out.  As with new headsets you can wear it just in the ear or just over the ear or both (which I do...both).  During the day you move around and with just one (ear or over ear) it can fall off easily.  With both I've never had it fall off.Pairing it is easy.  I have a Droid 4. Perhaps that's due to both being Motorola, but I had no problems.I can hear people great.  However I'm taking one star away due to people saying my sound quality is not crystal clear.  NOTE they can hear me, and I've tested it with another  and the best I can say it sounds like is like I was in the end of a tunnel.  Not that  "Heeelllloooooo" from deep in a tunnel.  But a slight "Hellloo."  Did that make sense?  :-)I feel that makes it better than most is the battery life.  It lasts a good seven hours of talk.  I've been going 3-4 days without charging.  Does not come charged. Included Micro USB and AC adapter charger.NOTE it's most likely you will need a extension cord.  Unless you have a setup of some sort as the cord is not long to charge it.Wearing it causes no problems.  No ear irritations.The commands for using it are the same as with other Bluetooth headsets.Again, other than the problems with other problems hearing me, this is a good headset.  That's why I take away one star.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Likes:- Voice guidance is a great feature that takes the guess work out of its status. It even reports battery level with estimated talk time remaining.- The flip-open mic seemed redundant at first, but it did work more reassuringly than a tiny physical switch. The "Rapid Connect(TM)" instant-on feature is great in that you just flip open the mic at the incoming call, and it's connected and working immediately from sleep. It saves battery without hassle of waiting for re-connection.- Long battery life: there must be more tricks than large battery size to save battery here. Standby time is over a week with average daily talk-time of an hour. It's pretty amazing given the small physical size.- Long range. Motorola claims 300ft range, which is probably at its best conditions. Yet in my own testing, it held connections easily for over 20 meters or 65ft unobstructed in an office space. I imagine that should be good enough for most needs.- Pairing with phones have been pain-free. No need for passwords. Have not been able to test NFC pairing.Dislikes:-Sound quality is average for a bluetooth handsfree. Interestingly, in testing it seemed to give out different audio quality from different phones, suggesting possible proprietary DSP support. To me it worked best with an Moto Atrix tested. With an iPhone 4s and an old LG Optimus T, both simply didn't sound as good, with LG's not as loud as the iPhone. I do not have conclusive evidence, but if you have a Motorola phone, your experience is likely to be better than others.Other notes:-Supports MicroUSB, so you can charge with most android phone charging cable and adapter, and vice-versa with the included charger+cable-supports on-ear and in-ear options with gel plugs. For me the in-ear is fairly secure even on movement, making a viable option especially if you wear glasses.
title: Motorola H19txt Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging

reviewText: I honestly don't really care that it didn't work since I was just looking for a way to charge my tablet anyway and the cord that came with it works fine, but I think you should be aware if you are buying this for what it actually says its supposed to do. reviewerName: Jeri Zerr "formerly a Road Warrior of the Nth...
reviewText: I was initially very leery of this docking station initially simply due to having thePURPLE Rubberized Plastic Hard Protector Case Cover For Motorola Droid 4 (Verizon)on myMotorola DROID 4 4G Android Phone (Verizon Wireless).I am happy to report not only does to docking station accept the DROID 4 with the protective cover (bought at a local Verizon corporate store), there is ample room on the docking station to allow a thicker cover.  This was NOT the case with Motorola docking stations for the original Droid. I am glad Motorola learned from prior experience!I was also concerned with the phone docking onto 2 connections, both the mini HDMI as well as the micro USB jacks, that act of docking may be difficult at best and cause the jacks to fail prematurely. Rather the connections feel solid, but not too solid, and have become easier after docking the cell several times. I no longer feel this will be an issue, but only the test of time will verify.As for the usefulness of the dock, it works GREAT for all intended purposes!  When initially docking the phone, the phone will pop up a menu allowing the user to select between a bedside / alarm mode or a desk / phone / business type mode (among others). This is a very useful feature I now wish the original Droid had offered the past couple of years.As expected the docking station works flawlessly with both my DROID 4 as well as my Xoom. If you own the Xoom or Xyboard tablets, the docking station is a must have if you frequently stream movies onto a larger display such as an HDTV.
title: Motorola HD Dock with Wall Charger for Motorola Smartphones and Tablets - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have 3 docks and all work great, but 1 design element could use improvement.  When it's time to pull the phone from the dock I'm always 'fumbling' with the best way to eject it.  I'm concerned that uneven stress may cause problems with the jacks (HDMI & USB) down-the-road.  I try to grab the phone by the sides with one hand, and hold the stand with the other, then lift as evenly as possible.An 'Eject' button would be a great improvement, and would make this a one-finger operation.On occasion I need to use the phone while in bed (record some notes, respond to a text message . . .).  Doing this while docked is not convenient, so I prefer to undock the phone first.  Well  . . . undocking the phone two-handed (or even on-handed) while lying in bed is near impossible, and an 'eject' mechanism would be nice.
