reviewText: I bought this from Radioshack about 2 years ago as my first smartphone. I was super psyched about being able to use apps and mobile data and what not.The best feature overall is the physical QWERTY keyboard. If I had the option, this would be on all of my smartphones. However, there's an issue with the design in this keyboard. The track on the keyboard that extends and retracts from the screen is fairly thin (there are two) and can become damaged. What happens is it forms a behavior on how it feels like closing after a while and requires you to push one end of the phone before the other end, otherwise one track will trigger while the other is stuck.One serious con about this phone is that it is outdated. The processor on this generation of Droid cannot meet the expectations of the apps that are in the market today. I would frequently use my phone for nothing but texts and calls, and apps would run in the background without my knowledge and slow the phone to a halt and thus be infuriating. The only way to restart the phone would be to remove the battery which, in the end, would cause software damage and data corruption.Don't get me wrong, the look and feel of the phone is wonderful. If you're not looking to use this phone for many, many apps, then by all means please buy this phone. But whatever you do, do not put a case on the phone as the case will misalign the track on the phone and cause future anguish. For me, I dropped my phone once and it was never the same.TL;DR (too lazy, didn't read) - I gave this a 3/5 simply because of the phone track on the keyboard being easily misaligned and the processor being too old to handle current generation apps. I would recommend you research into this phone further if you don't believe me.
title: Motorola Droid 3 Verizon Xt862 Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: Maybe you saw the original version of this review. If you did, forget everything you read, because in the few months between then and now, this phone has taken a disastrous nosedive.Here's the deal: Lots of electronics these days, they're made to break. I was hoping that this one was an exception, but after a few months of gentle use and great care, I have been entirely disappointed.I won't make a grocery list of glitches and crashes, it'd take far too long. Just know that if you go into this thinking "But I just want it for X feature", you'll probably be disappointed. My cell signal is weak compared to other phones with the same company. The battery life is painfully weak. Buttons to call your contacts just don't respond. Occasionally, text fields will ignore all input, making it impossible to type anything, anywhere, until you reboot - which takes a weirdly long time. The wallpaper doesn't even stay up. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. Don't even get me started on apps - native, purchased, downloaded, they crash all the same.This phone's strongest selling point is the Google Play Store, which is expansive, reasonably-priced, and very secure. However, that comes with any Droid, and if you are looking into the Droid OS, don't let this discourage you - I hear wonderful things about other Droid phones. But this isn't the one for you. And mind, this isn't just one buggy phone. Many reviewers agree with me, including my own sister, who got the phone at the same time I did and is struggling just as much.Bottom line: I'm surprised this thing ever reached shelves. A stain on Motorola and Android, both of which are generally far superior to this piece of work.
title: Motorola Droid 3 Verizon Xt862 Verizon Cell Phone

reviewText: I was looking to find a replacement for my droid X2. I found this one on Amazon for a really good deal. So i thoight i give it a shot. Honestly, functional it has no problems at all. Fast processer, easy user interface. Great camera's and does as it should. My only complaints come from the design aspect. The screen size is below average, if just feels so small. The other issue is it felt bulky in my hand. I didnt like that either.  Overall decent phone from Verizon.

reviewText: I use this to charge my phone while listening to music or watching videos. Be sure you order the correct one. This one is for last year's DROID RAZR MAXX, not the current MAXX HD. The headphones, USB and HDMI connections are on top (left as shown in the picture).

reviewText: Works great. I put my RAZR MAXX in an Otterbox Commuter case and it no longer fit inside of the dock, so I disassembled the dock and found that there is nothing behind the "hump" and nothing sensitive near the USB/HDMI connectors where they plug into the phone, so I took a Dremel sanding wheel to the plastic and carved out the "hump" and took a small amount of plastic off the bottom of the arm exactly where it attaches to the phone USB/HDMI ports. After that modification, the phone INSIDE of the Otterbox Commuter case, fit PERFECTLY. With a little bit of epoxy, sanding, and matte paint, it would look factory again, but I don't care enough since the unit is still sealed even after removing the hump (there is another flat layer of plastic that seals the unit, behind the hump). After modification, this dock will not work with an un-cased RAZR/RAZR MAXX.
title: Motorola HD Dock for DROID RAZR MAXX - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This was well worth the purchase price.  I enjoy using my phone as a clock and having it charge overnight while I sleep.  Excellent value.

reviewText: This product arrived early before schedule and was not damaged...PLUS. Plugged it in and hooked it up to my TV and it works perfectly...PLUS. title: Motorola HD Dock for DROID RAZR MAXX - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This accessory is especially made for the DROID RAZR MAXX: the phone has a more consistent thickness (as compared to the sloping back of the original RAZR).  Right now, I kind of have a love hate relationship with the HD Dock. To put simply, it does exactly what it's supposed to, but it is bogged down in a clunky interface.THE GOOD:Like I said, the HD Dock does exactly as it is advertised. Once you plug in your DROID RAZR, a screen prompts you to decide how you would like to treat your docking station. Would you like it as a bedside clock? Enabling this option grants a large time display coupled with a few music options. Would you like it as an office call center? Enabling this option creates a few icons to allow for quick and easy communication (phone, text, group meetings, etc...) It looks really nice, and it charges the phone well. If you sit at a desk during the day, this is a nice little accessory to own.THE BAD:Unfortunately, a few interface design choices offer clunky use with the HD Dock. This dock forces your phone into the aforementioned modes, but if you want to use your phone as its normal interface, you may as well just disconnect it from its station. If you need to access your calendar, or any other app, you will need to repeatedly press the Back button until you come to your original homescreen. Using the touchscreen while in its docking station also proves to be a little annoying; it's much much easier to browse the internet on the phone via handheld methods as opposed to this.I'm puzzled as to why this is labeled "Rapid Wall Charger;" my phone seems to take much longer to charge using this station than it does by simply plugging it into the wall. The lack of customization options also proves to be really annoying after using the device for a while; users have to operate by what Motorola think you do in your office (or whatever interface option you have chosen).THE HUH?:No USB connection options? This limits consumers to only being able to use wall/AC Adapter plugins to provide power to this station. While the options that the phone provides regarding interface are fine (Office, Bedside Clock, etc...), I would have liked to see some kind of customization with this feature. For example, for music, you will need to rely on Motorola's music service -- you can't enable Google Music or Amazon MP3 for instance without exiting out of the dock options entirely.OVERALL:This device is fine. At $25+, it's not exactly a bargain, but it's worth the money if you spend a lot of time at a desk. There are a few strange manufacturing options, and these missteps only go to show how much potential an idea like this would have given a bit better execution.
title: Motorola HD Dock for DROID RAZR MAXX - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: First shipment came with accessories and no dock.  Amazon sent another one next day but it would not properly mate.  Got one from Verizon on sale and no problems there.  Amazon accepted the returns with no hassle.
title: Motorola HD Dock for DROID RAZR MAXX - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This was actually a gift purchase. My friend cracked his screen on his phone for the third time so I decided instead of him getting a 3rd replacement for $100, I'd get him a much better phone for cheaper. The phone arrived in excellent condition and a clean ESN. I had to purchase a SIM adapter though, (my fault for not doing the proper research) but after getting one, the phone reads the SIM good and works well. I'm still waiting from my friend to return from vacation, so if there are any troubles, I'll update this review. But until then, I am extremely satisfied.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: I have had my droid for 2 years now. I have replaced the screen 3 times because of my carelessness. They are pretty cheap to replace if you are handy with the Youtube tutorial.Shortcoming number one- Battery life. Over the last two years I learned to have chargers everywhere I need to be. The good news here is all the different docks and chargers are high quality and dirt cheap. The real lifesaver is the Lapdock. The battery in that can save your butt when you are away from other power. A full charge when new lasted for about 10 hours without significant use but only half that if you use wifi or background intensive apps. I had to replace the factory battery last year but it was so cheap I didn't even mind.Shortcoming two- The Motorola version of android is kinda limited and there are frequent compatibility issues with apps. It was better with Jellybean because Motorola and Verizon really bloated it on the updates. So much of the bloat is rooted in and you can't uninstall it. Root is your friend. The risk isn't so high because the phone has been around awhile now.  I rooted the phone and rolled it back to the more enjoyable jellybean.Conclusion. I like the cameras, the external speaker is loud and there are lots of accessories for the phone. The phone rarely failed to do the things you have a smartphone to do. I paid way too much for it two years ago but for $100, this phone is easily worth it.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: I got the phone and I'm really like the speed and the interface. I bought a ballistic case which is highly protective and the first day I had it in my back pocket and the screen cracked on me. I couldn't believe it. I had a Droid X for a couple of years treating it the same way and nothing ever happened to it. The good thing is that the crack happened on the outside edge but just the thought of it happening on the first day is unnerving.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: Hey guys, im planning to buy this phone and have it flashed to cricket does anyone know if that is possible?
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: Updated review: previously I noted having a very poor battery life with this phone but have been told by Verizon a capacitor is bad so I have requested a replacement from the seller, Increased Mobility.  Will update when the replacement arrives.I bought this phone to replace one mid-contract with Verizon. Nice phone but the battery life is awful! I made sure the battery received with the phone was new and bought a new 'back up' battery as well. With the same apps running as my other Motorola phone this battery will go from 100% to 30% in about three hours.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: Coming from a Rezound the Bionic is inferior in almost every way. Earphone volume does not get loud enough. Speaker volume is off the hook loud. Battery life is horrible. Makes the Rezound look downright good in comparison. Pretty much the Bionic has to be plugged in all the time. Cheap feeling phone. One of the charger prongs fell out. I pushed it back in. Mini usb plug on the charger bent with no abuse. Probably because it was always plugged in. Had to occasionally pull the SIM card to reset the phone connection. A minor detail are the cartoon character icons. I can live with that if everything else works good. Far and away the best things about the phone are the screen and the texting program. Both were better than the Rezound. Can't wait to not own this phone.I've since found out that the "new" phone I had purchased had been used before. Looked new, shrink wrapped, packaging.. So with that information I'm upgrading to three stars.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: I bought this phone after my iPhone 4S died because all technical specs pointed at this phone being the closest product to what I had. It was Motorola's "rival" to the iPhone 4S.This phone is nowhere near the level of an iPhone 4S or even an iPhone 4 for that matter. If you are looking for a smartphone that can't really multitask and is only useful for small tasks like texting and calling, then this is the phone for you. But if you are a 21st century cellphone user and want to be able to browse multiple apps while listening to music, then this phone is not for you.I would frequently try to listen to music while running another app and this phone simply cannot handle that. The music would constantly freeze and stop playing (much like a lot of apps you use). The processor in this phone is VERY weak and makes me feel like I am using old technology.It is great this phone has 4G capabilities (with Verizon after you purchase a 4G simcard) but it's really not worth it, even for the price of this phone. Look elsewhere for a phone, like a Galaxy SIII if you are trying to spend reasonably.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: When I ordered this phone the seller stated in his description "Great condition" so when I received this product I was very disappointed when I found it was all scratched, the top right hand corner had a small crack, no charger, and in bad condition.  I immediately contacted the seller, no apology no nothing just a " as soon as I receive the phone you will get a refund."  That's it!!  So I shipped it back, had to pay my own shipping, and packaged it correctly, with bubble wrap to protect the already damaged phone!  Few days later I got my refund....and went phone shopping again :)  But it was very disappointing to go thru all that and find out they lied about the condition of the phone!
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: This droid bionic is one of the best smartphones that I've used, i know its a couple years old but it has great features, and plus it responds fast and well. I would give it 4.5 star if it would let me do 1/2 star. The phone was delivered faster than I expected.

reviewText: I've had several Android OS phones, and this one is somewhat above the norm, for what it is.The pros for this phone are:-simple interface-great processing speed-large screen-responsive and intuitive GUI-plenty of memory for tons of apps-Took a pretty hard beating over the past year & kept kicking, even with a shattered screen.The cons:-battery life is terrible, even by 4G phone standards-weak antenna. Even in the suburbs of a city of 3 million, I have tons of deadspots, including my house.-the latest O/S update crashed my device, will not even power up now-I noticed absolutely NO difference in internet speeds with the 4G capabilities of this phone as opposed to older 3G phonesAll things considered, this was a decent phone. Unfortunately, with the price tag as high as it is, I would not buy this phone again. Today's price posted is $400, which is entirely too much for this device. I wouldn't pay more than a third of that cost, and even then I'd be hesitant.
title: Motorola Droid Bionic 4G LTE WiFi Android Smartphone Verizon Wireless

reviewText: This is the best piece of equipment I have bought for my phone. It makes using the GPS easy and keeps the phone charged while traveling. I used to stick it to the windshield, but I recently bought the i.Trek HDFMB-2 V2 Open Front Heavy Duty Friction Mount Base for it and it's a much easier to reach on the dashboard now while driving.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: OK, so I bought this for traveling to use the navigation and it works well.  The only thing that doesn't really work for me is the charging.  It works to a degree, but not as I had hoped.  So to explain a little further, when I use the navigation, and the battery was charged down to say 40 or 50 %, I have it plugged into the lighter socket and the battery doesn't deplete, but it doesn't increase either.  I used to to drive about 2.5 hours and it stayed at 50% the whole trip.  On the way home, I used the navigation and radio app at the same time, and the battery actually drained as I used it.  I was hopeful that the charging would be better.  Still haven't decided if I want to keep it or no because of that.Please note that the audio on mine playing thru the provided jack and into the Aux in of my car works flawlessly.  The sound is awesome.  Maybe I got a bad charger part and other got a bad audio jack.The suction works perfectly for me.  Didn't fall off once.Also, sometime when I dock the phone and try to lock in the charger part, it doesn't go in easily.  I have to carefully press, release, press, etc, until it goes in.And, no, for those asking, you cannot use any case when using this.  You must remove it from the case.  I have a few easy ones to remove, so that isn't a problem for me.I know that using navigation, especially in junction with i heart radio or Pandora, will use more battery life, but I thought since it was plugged in to charge, and yes the charge icon is showing charging, I figured it would still charge somewhat.I will try to use the phone by itself without any apps or anything running, to see if this charger does work.  But I haven't traveled anywhere since that trip other than a short trip to work and back.  Last time I tried this, for about a half an hour, it went from 20% to 21% in 30 minutes.  My standalone charger was much quicker than that.  Just mentioning this so you know.I still recommend this, but if it isn't to your satisfaction, you can always return it.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: First of all, the good points:- Holds my phone securely - phone has never fallen out of the dock (I do not have any skins/cases/etc attached to the phone).- Stable charging interface - the micro USB receptacle on the phone is not subjected to twists or bends as with a standard cable.- Car dock functionality - automatically comes on when plugged into the dock (no need for additional software).  Provides one-touch interface for navigation, music, calls, or maps.  I can customize the car dock homescreen as desired to provide quick access to the apps that I use the most.  AND the phone is charging while using battery-hogging navigation or internet music.- Seamless integration with car stereo - Music and sound (including navigation voice directions) are played through my car speakers (via 3.5mm AUX jack on my stereo).- Supports music over USB - no need to attach a multitude of cables.  I insert the phone into the dock, push the charger plug into the micro USB receptacle, press a button, and music plays.- Two USB charging ports - one is for the dock, and the other is for your passenger's phone or other USB-powered accessories (great for me since I only have one cigarette lighter power receptacle in the car).Now the bad:- My charger plugs into a cigarette outlet, and there is considerable alternator whine introduced to the audio.  Would be better if a noise filter had been included with the dock.- Other noise introduction - even with the power plug disconnected from the cigarette lighter, miscellaneous noise is still audible.  While no alternator whine, buzzing, popping, and static can be heard, even when the phone is not inserted into the dock.  Not sure if the 3.5mm audio jack is acting as a giant antenna or if the noise is generated from the USB connection to the dock itself.- The sticky stuff isn't.  The suction cup on the dock either attaches to the windshield (which blocks my view) or a little plastic "plate" with double-sided tape for attachment to the dashboard.  The double-sided tape loses its stickyness, especially if the car gets hot.  This may not be a problem for you if your car interior doesn't get warm while sitting outside in the sun in August...  One bump and the whole dock fell from where it was mounted.  It also helps if the spot where you attach the disc is smooth and flat (in which case, you'd probably just use the suction cup itself).- Suction cup only.  It would have been appreciated if there were other mounting options such as A/C vent, but you have to use the suction cup, either alone or in conjunction with the plastic disc.In summary, it suits my needs: keeping my phone charged while providing navigation and music.  The alternator whine and static can be bothersome, but overall a pretty good product.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'm happy with this unit, but still in the first month so I cannot comment on the complaints of failure that others report.It's simple to use (one hand insertion) and combined with the Smart Actions app you can automate settings and launching of your dock app when inserted.The Razr Maxx does suffer from overheating when run on full brightness (my battery temperature goes from 85 degrees to 115 degrees), so I suggest you run it on 0-15% brightness to keep the temp down, prolong your battery life and improve the rate of charge while operating in the car. This is especially important if mounted in the sun. Leaving the phone in the hot car will shorten the battery life, even when powered off.The suction mount is excellent, as is the mechanism for securing the arm position/angle.Updated October 14, 2012:Developed the same cable connection issues that others have written about. Now it works fine most but not all of them time.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Great design.  The power cord plugs into the actual cradle and not directly into the phone so it can stay plugged in all the time.  You then insert the phone into the cradle and slide the latch containing the USB power source into phone to provide the phone power and keep it secure. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is that the windshield mount is 1 piece so the only adjustment is on the ball socket in where the cradle attaches to the arm.  I addressed that by using the old suction cup arm from my original Droid car mount as the ball socket is the same.  Also, for what you get its kind of pricey.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Before I bought this docking station I was placing my phone on my lap and looking at the map for navigation. After a few times that I stopped short because I had to take my eyes off the road I realized I need to change my setup. I bought this mount and it's simply awesome.Before it felt like I simply had my phone in the car when driving but now it feels like I have a communications center at my fingertips with this docking station. Looking at Google maps is a breeze because I mounted the unit on the dashboard in line with my vision. When I get a phone call I can talk easily and listen easily because the aux cable allows the call to be piped into my car speakers. I also listen to Pandora and that gets played through my car speakers as well. It seems like a lifetime ago I was listening to dull FM radio.I highly recommend this, it makes your phone turn into a lot more when driving.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Very happy with the Razr Navigation Dock. The unit worked as advertised. Plugging the Razr into the dock immediately starts the selection screen. From here you can go to the navigation screen, play music, or make a phone call. I had no issues with Google maps and found the smart phone with Google maps more accurate than a TomTom or Garmin Auto Navigation GPS.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: For the most part, I am comparing this to official Motorola car dock for my Droid 1.  This car dock for the MAXX is a GREAT improvement and shows Motorola can actually incorporate some good ideas.First, I made sure to research docks before getting one.  Which can be hard since this one didn't have a ton of user reviews right away.  Quickly I did learn that what Verizon was pushing in their stores was not the same as could be ordered from Motorola and elsewhere.  My biggest draw was the integrated audio.  This is a great idea and, in my opinion, worth the premium over the Verizon (which doesn't have the integrated audio cable).  My old Droid dock was just a holder for the phone.  I had to supply the charging cord and the aux cable (which went to the 3.5mm jack in the phone).  It got cluttered, but hey, that's the way is was 2 years ago.This dock for the MAXX has the connector that slides in to lock the phone in place, charge it, and place audio.  Only one cable that goes into the back of the dock.  Very clean.  2nd USB port is also a plus.  The "horn" that comes with this dock has the same size ball as my old Droid dock, as well as my old Garmin, so use which ever you like.  I like my old Garmin because it is more compact and uses a smaller disk.  I haven't had any issue with this dock losing suction, so I'm happy there.  Also, just pressing the phone into the dock without inserting the USB/audio connector is easy and seems to keep the phone in there pretty well.  It isn't to hard to pull it out, just watch for where the volume buttons are so you don't change them accidentally.I have one gripe.  I use a bluetooth device to [sometimes] talk when I'm driving.  This device is also capable of playing music from my phone.  With my old setup (Droid,dock), I would have BT broadcast enabled on the device, the music to BT option enabled, and a cable in the headphone jack going to my car stereo.  I'm listening to something from my phone and it plays on the car stereo.  When I get a call, it pauses the music on the phone, answers the call via BT device, I talk, hang up, music resumes over car stereo.  Perfect. With the MAXX and its dock, I no longer need to plug anything into the 3.5mm jack while I'm in the car.  The problem is when I have BT function enabled, music to BT option enable, and the integrated USB/audio connect inserted everything is pushed to the BT device.  If I turn off the BT device or disable the BT function on the phone, then music plays through the car stereo.  If I forego the dock and just use an aux cable going to the 3.5mm jack on the phone, then everything works great (as it did w/ the Droid).  This seems like a major oversight and I would think that it is just a software issue (but hey, I didn't design this thing).  Now, this is probably more a flaw of the phone than of the dock, but since Motorola makes both the phone and the dock and both of the items work exclusively with each other, I think people need to know about it. There is no reason the integrated USB/audio connector should affect the transfer of functions to the BT any differently than the 3.5mm jack.I'll gladly edit if I find out anything new on the BT issue or if an update fixes it.  Overal, great product at an acceptable price, with one oversight.==================================================================================================================Edit 6/8/12I've noticed that over the past month the audio crackles when going over bumps and rough roads.  It is the micro USB connection of the cable to the dock that is failing.  When I hold the connection rigid or switch to using the 3.5mm jack then there are no issues.  After looking at the micro USB side of the cable under magnification I can see that several of the metal prongs are flatter than others.Now, I first have to admit that I do not drive on the smoothest roads, and even for Wisconsin I think these are some of the worst roads around.  I would still expect better performance than lasting 3 months.  I have taken the review down from 4 stars to 2 because of this.  And to think that I was disappointed with getting only 1 year out of the bad retaining tab on the original Droid....  I expected better from Motorola.  I don't think that expecting this to last more than 3 months was too high.
title: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX Vehicle Navigation Dock with Rapid Vehicle Charger - Non-Retail Packaging - Black
