reviewText: I live in a state where hand-held calls while driving is now an invitation to have a conversation with Mr. State Trooper. Even if your normal driving environment is someplace where the law hasn't caught up with technology, a Bluetooth-enabled hands free solution is just a good way to keep your focus where it belongs...on the road.The Roadster 2 paired easily with two separateHTC Evo phones. Incoming call quality through the integrated speaker was satisfactory, and callers reported good quality via the Roadster 2.If you get tired of losing aux audio input cords (or drive a car without one), you can use the Roadster 2 to stream audio from your phone's apps through an integrated FM transmitter to your car's radio. This wasn't always a strong or steady signal (and I'm not sure if it's because of a crowded FM spectrum where I live or signal strength through the cars root to the antenna above my rear windshield). You can also stream music through the integrated speaker in the Roadster 2, but I'm not sure why you'd want to (what's fine for a phone call doesn't do justice to music you like...).This device recognizes when you enter or leave the car (perhaps by the noise of the car door closing??, and battery life is quite long. No AC adapter is included, but a 12v DC adapter for the car is). A very detailed user guide is included.We've been using theearlier versionof this model (the Roadster) for 16 months, and it has worked very well. Assuming the changes to the Roadster 2 are actual improvements, we expect to get long and useful service from it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: - Works with iPhone and BlackBerry- Good material- Excellent finish.- Speaker with good sound quality.- My itme, up to 2 weeks of standby time- Quickly rechargeable battery
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I ordered this device because I've always like the concept of a speakerphone hands free. I find this one to be very easy to setup and use, with good call quality when used with the FM radio, fairly useful Android Apps, and clear (if a bit sparse) instructions.The device is a nice looking silver. It clips onto the sun visor in the car. All the setup and connections are by voice prompts, making it unnecessary to remember a bunch of button combinations to use it. There are three buttons on the front (as it hangs from the visor) for mute, hang up, and dial. On the under side of the device, towards the windshield, there are buttons for music play/pause, volume / tuning +/-, and an "FM" button to change the speaker from internal to the FM radio. The FM radio connection works by having the handsfree device transmit at very low power to an unused channel.ProThe voice prompts make it extremely simple to use compared to many headsets. When first turned on, it provides instructions on how to pair to a phone. It also speaks the name of the device when connection is made.It can be paired with two phones simultaneously.The device has power saving features; it shuts down after 10 minutes, although the instructions also say that is will then subsequently re-pair. I don't see how this works without running the device constantly. The manual speaks of turning on when you open the car door. This was about the only part of the manual that didn't make a lot of sense. EDIT: After more use, I have discovered that the device apparently listens for the door opening, and powers itself back up. This is a nice feature.The manual is short, but informative. Obviously the designers decided to put the needed instructions in the device as voice prompts, and it works very well.When connected to the FM radio, the sound quality is outstanding. The device tells you the frequency being used when you push the "FM" button, and the "+" and "-" buttons will auto seek the next available frequency. Once I found a good frequency, everything was great. In this mode, the radio volume controls are used instead of any controls on the device. UPDATE: The FM tunes frequencies from 88.3 to 107.9.If you have an Android phone, you can go to the market and download the two apps that work with the phone. the first app is MOTOSPEAK, which is simply outstanding. It allows you to make and answer calls (which is run of the mill stuff), but it also allows you to READ and SEND text messages. This is really great.The second app is the Motorola Car Finder App (descriptive but not the catchiest name). It makes a note of your location when you are no longer connected to the device. You can then load the app and see a satellite picture of the car location. It works fine, but I don't generally run my GPS - and the program issues complaints about being unable to access the satellite unless location services with GPS is on. Since the program automatically launches when one is connected to the device, I ended up uninstalling it. But for people who visit large malls or parking lots, it may be useful.The device will stream music from your phone. The quality is good, but there are no controls other than play and pause (the same button does  both). The handsfree will answer and make calls while the music is engaged; it pauses the music while the other functions are working. Overall, a good job.Con:Not a super "con" for me (I use Android phones), but I'm surprised that there isn't an Iphone app. This limits the devices additional capability to Android phones. I list it here for those Iphone users who may be interested in the device.When not connected to the FM, the call quality was not very good at the distant end. Also, the speaker sounded a bit tinny. I plan to use the FM radio option.There is only one button to control the music playing, so it doesn't really provide much control of the music. I wish there were more controls; it would be nice to be able to skip a track, for example.The device makes a REALLY annoying loud "PING" sound when it is turned off. Maybe it is designed to be left on, but it is very intrusive, and unnecessarily loud.UPDATE 3 APR 12: When receiving a call, the device announces only the number, not the person (even if the caller is in the phone book). Other hands free devices I have owned have announced the person. I still like this one best!Summary:A good choice when used with the FM capabilities. The send / receive text message capability is particularly nice. Highly recommended.EDIT: After more time, I can report that this device is still my preferred hands free. However, there are two things to report. First, it has mysteriously disconnected from my phone once. Second, when it powers back up "automatically" (I presume by hearing the doors open), if it is in FM mode, it switches back to internal speaker mode. This would not be a problem except that when I start up the car, the FM radio is still on and makes static until I manually switch the Roadster 2 back to "FM" mode. Otherwise, this has been a stellar device.EDIT 2 Oct 12: It still has that habit of suddenly powering down at infrequent times, with that loud "BING" sound (well, at least one cannot miss it!). I simply slide the power switch off and on and it picks right back up. The great feature set keeps me liking it even with this problem.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I was excited to try this with my new iPhone 4S.  The size is perfect.  Not overly big and not too small.  Unlike other speakerphones I have used, the Motorola 89556N is much narrower and takes less space. I am using it in my restored 1984 Mustang.Paring was extremely simple.  Just power it up and listen to the voice prompts.  Most speakerphones now turn on or off automatically once it senses the vehicle's door has been opened or shut and your phone is in range.  It announces that the power is on.  It is quite amazing when you think about it.  The call buttons in front of the unit are contoured perfectly for easy identification and access.In regards to clarity and sound, so far so good.  I have not heard any complaints from callers and I have not had any problems understandings the person on the other end. As calls come in, the names are announce correctly for the most part and the unit recognizes my command to answer or ignore the calls.The one feature I really liked that my Jabra does not have is the FM scan feature.  It will scan the FM channels for a clear frequency and then tell you what it is.  That is much easier then searching by increments.Now for all the extras, if you don't have a Motorola smartphone...forget about them.  They are more specifically designed for Motorola brand phones and the apps are not available in iTunes for iPhone users.  The one good thing about the new iPhone 4S is Siri, I can always just use Siri to send out or read my text messages through the speakerphone instead of using the app.Overall, it is a nice unit but it is intended more towards Motorola Smartphones users.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: The Roadster is Motorola's 1-piece, Bluetooth, car speaker and GPS-enabled navigation system.  The system also has the ability to act as a receiver for streaming audio, FM-radio and as a voice-activated personal assistant via the Android app's "My Motospeak" and "Motorola Car Finder."With a measurement of 2.5" x 3.75" x 1.5", the device is noticeably broad.  And, that's not a negative criticism in anyway, but just an observation.The beautiful metallic silver front has a touchpad on the bottom that allows you to control the music-audio functions.  The top keypad row controls the phone functions.  The right side is where the micro usb charge port and power switch is located.******  *******My trip to the grocery store a mile away provided me with perfect opportunity to see how the device works out.I engaged the Motorola Car Finder app and it immediately asked me to take a snapshot.  This, I discovered was more for my benefit as a snapshot would help me to remember where I was parked from a street-level view.  But, I declined and went on to the next screen.  Just as I arrived at the mall, I received a phone call.  The speaker on this device is loud!Just before the conversation ended, I inquired about how well I sounded.  I was impressed that her answer was "fine" considering it was somewhat windy as I was coming into the parking lot.A few moments later, I turned on the My Motospeak and had the system "text Yvette!".  Within seconds, a voice blared out, "Which number?"  Afterwards, the system repeated the message I spoke to it.Pretty impressive.*****  *******After a couple of weeks of playing around with all of the features, there are some minor things that I'd like to see in a future version.1.  I wouldn't mind seeing a glass display instead of the metal mesh that covers the speaker.  So, that display can give you a visual of where you're at or who's calling.  Any speakers can be moved to the sides and to the bottom.2.  I'd like there to be included a micro usb to ac adapter.  The device comes with almost no charge and it took a couple of hours of it being plugged in before the battery indicator light turned green.This is important because the kit only comes with a car charger.  If you're parked in an area and will be there for a considerable amount of time, I wouldn't leave this $100 device lying around and especially not plugged in.  This means, on the other side, that you'll need to have an ac adaptor handy so the device can stay charged while indoors.3.  I'm not crazy about the $100 price tag.  If it had a glass display and extra cords, maybe.  But, by itself, I think a fair price would be in the $50-$60 range.So, there you have it.  Motorola Roadster 2-- 4 stars.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Directly after having my in-ear Bluetooth headset finally die, I received this new Motorola Roadster 2: a portable car speakerphone with universal Bluetooth capability.  Due to the strict regulations on using the phone while driving, I was hoping this would be a superior replacement to what I've had previously.  It definitely is.  To be clear about this review, I just want to point out that I will be using the Roadster 2 with an iPhone 4, so I can't guarantee equal results for all cell phones.To start out: The unpackaging.  In the box, we receive only 3 items: The speaker, a car charger, and the Quick Start Guide.  Personally, I don't consider a 25-page manual to be a "quick" start guide, but oh well.  Anyway, the manual starts by congratulating us on owning this fine piece of machinery.  I'm honoured, Motorola.  It also goes on to mention some of the different functions of the product, including:- Simultaneously connect with two phones.- Hear caller's name or number, and use your voice to answer or ignore calls.- Switch between your FM radio and car kit speaker.- Hear voice prompts to guide you on connections, battery level, and other functions.The first few steps are clear enough.  Plug it into your cigarette lighter to charge (it can be used while charging), hook it onto your visour, and switch it on.  One nice little power-saving feature is that the Roadster 2 will turn off if you take your phone away, then turn back on when you return.  Very helpful and convenient.  To start up, you have to pair your phone with the Roadster 2.  Every phone's different, so consult your manual if you're unsure.The most important feature is making/receiving calls.  To make a call, you can either dial from your phone directly and have it routed to the Roadster 2, or hit the voice command and tell the phone whom you want to call.  For iPhone users (at least), specify home, work, mobile, etc., after the name.  The dialing process is easy, though it does momentarily stop it from being "hands free."  Receiving calls is even easier.  When a call comes in, the voice prompts tell you who's calling and you simply respond "answer" or "ignore."  It even pauses your music for you.There is also a music feature with the Roadster 2.  You can actually play the music directly through your speaker, though the quality is about as good as you'd expect from a small speaker.  You can also run your sound through an FM transmitter, which is another nice & convenient feature.One issue I do have with the speaker is that one of the coolest features can't be used with my iPhone.  This feature, which is the ability to find your car with your Smartphone, is currently only good for Android users.  There is an app that can be downloaded that, unfortunately, can't be downloaded for the iPhone yet.  Hopefully they fix this soon.Overall, this is a very good hands-free speakerphone that is convenient & well made.  Well recommended.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: In an urban area Fm connections to radio is spoty. Gets annoying trying to find a FM channel that works. There is no way to program the channels you find that do work, you have only a + & - keys to move from channel to channel. If your best open channels are 101.9 and 107.9 it will take almost 15 min of key pushing to get to the channels.Device also connects and disconnects from phone over and over again.Sound quality is ok.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Before purchasing this product, I reviewed its instruction manual to find a sentence saying "You can use your car kit while unplugged or plugged into the charger." So, I purchased a smartphone-sized solar charger and and placed it on the windshield with velcro tape near the product, hoping that it would constantly be charging the product. I chose this way because I wanted to avoid running a USB charger cable all the way to the cigar lighter plug or periodically attach and detach a charger plug to the product.My plot failed. Once the product is fully charged, keeping a USB charger plugged to the product seems to disable the product; while a charger plug is attached, the green "CHARGE" LED remains on, but the "STATUS" LED never turns on and the product does not respond to any action such as pushing buttons or sliding the power switch back and force. The only way to restore the product to function is to remove the charger USB cable from the product. It is not satisfactory to disconnect the cable from the solar charger end, but the micro USB connector needs to be disconnected from the product. Disappointing...The product has a few good features like ability to register and use two phones, voice announcement of the caller ID, etc. For the iPhone, voice dialing actually activates iPhone's voice control so that I think I use any of iPhone's voice controlled features.One of the annoying features of the product is music playing. My daughter borrows my iPhone to watch YouTube on the rear seat. Unless she uses ear phones, the product automatically plays audio and there's no way to disable this.I have tried "Roadster," the predecessor product to this, too, and I believe this newer version is better in design quality.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: When you get into the truck it senses your butt and connects to your I Phone. Idiot proof. I no longer need to hold the phone in my hand now. Makes a chime sound and speaks to let you know the battery charge level.  EASY EASY EASY ! Great investment. Cheaper than a ticket for talking on the cell while driving. They still wrote me a ticket for no seatbelt :( & I thought the windshield was supposed to stop me .
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Detailed features the Motorola Roadster 2 in-car speakerphone kit offers can easily be seen in the Product Description above, so I will limit my review to just those aspects that I think are most important to know about in helping you decide if this product is for you....Its setup is very simple. Simply, plug in the car charger, clip the speakerphone onto your visor, switch it on and follw the easy, helpful voice command steps. In two minutes the speakerphone is ready to be used (even without being fully charged)....The device automatically turns itself on when you open the car door and turns itself off when your phone is about 33 feet away from where you leave the car; thus saving battery life....Very clear sound quality; with  dual microphone noise cancellation and echo control settings that work pretty well to  block out background noise....Dialing is as easy as tapping the "Call" button and following the easy voice prompts. Receiving a call is totally hands-free; in that the voice prompts will instruct you to say Answer or Ignore....Good battery life, allowing talk time up to 20 hours,and up to 3 weeks of standby time...Allows two phones to be connected simultaneously....You can listen to calls and, if you have a smartphone you can stream music, through either the device's 2-watt speakers OR using the FM transmitter so that you listen through your car speakers.Two other very cool features are available to Android users, but iPhone users and other non-android users (of which I am one) are likely to be annoyed by the fact that the apps that can be downloaded for free are not available to them. One of these features (available by downloading the MyMotospeak App) enables the user to listen to incoming text messages read aloud, then using voice commands to respond or initiate texts. The second feature, available by downloading the Car Finder app, automatically marks your car location using GPS technology, so that should you forget where you parked your car, you'll be easily led to your car's location.Overall, while the Motorola Roadster 2 is a very good, easy to use speakerphone, I don't know if it's worth its $99.99 price tag if you don't have a smartphone, and particularly an android-based phone.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: UPDATE: I recently started carrying a Lumina 521 and the original 710. The Roadster recognizes both when I enter my car. Since my contacts had already been paired with the Roadster, there was no need to re-do that step.My original speakerphone was a Jabra Journey which I purchased locally at a warehouse store.  I loved the fact that I could talk & text over this little machine.  The Jabra Journey synced quickly with my phone (windows Lumia 710) & it was easy to use.  However, it died within 8 months of my purchase.I researched & read reviews on other speakerphones before making the decision to purchase this Motorola Roadster 2. I almost went with the BlueAnt S4, but decided that the Roadster was a little newer & would pair better with my cell phone.Overall, I am happy with the Roaster 2.  Here is a breakdown of my impressions of both speakerphones:Roaster 2:1) Synced well with my Lumia 710, although I had to plug it into my computer first to download contacts;2) Takes a little longer to connect to my phone when I get into my car than the Jabra;3) Doesn't cut me off & try to use the bluetooth when I exit the car & go inside;4) Doesn't come with a wall charger (only car charger);5) Have yet to figure out how to do FM radio (not a deal killer for me);6) Phone callers can understand me even with road noise (in a heavier car that didn't produce as much road noise, but had the speakerphone further from my face, the Roadster 2 performed well & understood my commands);7) Roadster 2 seems to understand my voice commands slightly better than Jabra;8) Roadster 2 buttons are slightly harder to push than the Jabra;9) Battery life seems slightly shorter than the Jabra;10) Roadster has volume buttons, so volume adjustment is easyJabra Journey:1) Synced easily with my Lumia 710 - no need to hook up & download phone contacts;2) Fairly quick connection to my phone once I got into the car;3) Long bluetooth range, so the bluetooth would override my phone when I was outside of my car (in house and/or office);4) Comes with both a wall charger & a car charger;5) Phone callers sometimes had a hard time understanding me because of road noise - would have to put the device closer to my mouth (I did not use the Jabra in a vehicle that didn't produce much road noise, but assume that the call quality would be better);6) Jabra sometimes had a hard time understanding my commands (understood "Dial" better than "Call");7) Buttons are easy to push;8) Battery life is excellent.9) No volume buttons - have to adjust volume on your phoneOverall, I like the Roadster 2 slightly better than the Jabra Journey.  Even without considering the Jabra died on me & has better (responsive) buttons, the Roadster 2 seems to understand my commands a little better than the Jabra & that is what is important because I have a small car & encounter road noise.  In a heavier car or one without so much road noise, the Jabra would probably perform well too (then you need to take into consideration the fact that the Jabra may have a short life).  Once the Roadster 2 makes it for 8 months, I will update this review.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Works and then it doesn't.  Recognizes, my Motorola XPRT and then it doesn't.  Thinks my Nokia Lumia 900 is the XPRT.  Recognizes the Lumia and next time it doesn't.  Never recognized a friend's Samsung phone.  When it does work, people complain about excessive background noise and a whooshing sound.  Full disclosure:  I drive either an Aviator or a Volvo S60--ALWAYS with the windows rolled up in steamy SW Florida, and yes, I turn off the radio when I'm on the phone.  So, where is the background noise coming from? Speaker sounds like its cone is made of rice paper.  No bass at all.  Police scanners have superior fidelity.  Other than a nice look, soft touch buttons and cool packaging, this unit has nothing going for it.  I fooled around with it for THREE MONTHS, so I gave it a fair chance.  The Roadster 2 is going back. Nice work, Motorola.  What's next?  An Orange juice can on a string?
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Motorola has always made good products, and this is the same, a good item for legal hands free phone operation.  Good software as well for your smartphone.  The setup for the phone to stereo for music is a little difficult to setup, but that could just be my car stereo.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This speakerphone does the job although I'm not crazy about the FM tuner part of it.  The speakerphone part works well and the only comment I've gotten is "you sound a little muffled."  Not bad for my noisy car.Big plus is this allows me to play Pandora through my car radio (I have no direct input jack).  Yes, tuning the radio to find a clear channel is a hassle - but better than nothing at all.  Fidelity is nothing to brag about when playing through the FM, either.Only real down side of this gadget is I have had it go completely dead for reasons unknown to me (battery charge high).  To prevent this I now turn the power off to it before I get out of the car.  Problem solved that way, anyhow.So, I think this is worth the money if you don't mind having one more thing to do for your commute.  It's not perfect although I think I'm a safer driver now that I don't have a phone against my ear when I drive.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Bought this product to add Bluetooth hands free calling for a company car. The unit is a quality product. The call quality is very good and the voice cancellation is great. Caller on the other end report that the conversation is clear.I have not tried the FM section of the unit as I really do not need it since the volume is load and clear enough. The car finder App worked as advertised as it gives you directions back to where you parked your car.Speaking of Apps, could not get the My Motospeak app to work with my Samsung S3 running Jellybean, maybe a Samsung thing or that Motorola needs to update the app as Google voice is the default app when you press the voice button and there is no way to override this.The battery level is good considering the unit is never turned off, love the fact that the unit awakens when you get into the car.Would recommend this product
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I gave this item as a gift for Christmas to my son.  He left his original in a rental car while on company business.  He liked the original and uses this one all the time.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewerName: David L  Hall "David L  Hall "Get the Bes...
reviewText: I spent many hours trying to decide:  Should I buy cheap prices or decide what options are available and get what I really want?  Guess what?  I got exactly what I wanted!This Roadster is easy.  I still have not learned how to use it's features; but, some features jump out to be recognized.  First, I charged it for about 2 hours.  At first, when I turned it on it announced "Battery is Low".  Now it announces: "Battery is High" and it has been high for 3 days now, without additional charging.After charging, you have to link the device to your phone.  I went to my phone settings and checked "blue-tooth". Then I turned on the Roadster.  I do not know what happened next, it just announced "pairing successful?".  That was it.  I am using a Motorola DROID RAZR, that may or may not make a difference.  I do not know one way or the other.So I attached it to my visor and turned it on.  When I get in the car, it makes a sound to notify me that it is connected to my phone and what my battery level.  When I physically dial to make a call, audio is clear through the Roadster speaker.  I did not have to do anything.  Then a call came in and I did not know what to do.  Roadster made it easy, it identified the caller and asked me to accept or deny.  I did not touch the phone.  When the call was ended, it hung up for  me.  Now I know: I push a big button on Roadster and it asks me for a command.  I simply speak: "Call"  it responds with give a name or  something to that effect.  I then speak the name and it must automatically check my contact directory; because, it found the name and asked me if I wanted to call home, office line 1 or 2.  I simply answer the questions and it goes right through.  So far it has not made a mistake.Roadster also uses an app to locate your car?  Unbelievable.  I already had the app installed on my phone so I just opened it.  Amazing, I did not have to go through any set up that I remember.  Yet, there was a picture of my house and a car in my driveway.  I pushed the directions button and it informed me I was 21 feet from the car.  Sure enough, it was about 21 feet away.  It is all automatic.  As I move, it tells me if I am getting closer or further from the car.Next, it has the ability to link to my car radio?  I do not know if I am suppose to buy something special to make that happen.  I have a wonderful feeling that I do not need to buy anything.  I pushed a button labeled FM.  It made a scan and announced a frequency for my radio.  I have not tried it yet; but, I think it will broadcast directly to that frequency on my radio.  I will have to try it to know for sure.  I will report back later on this.Bottom line: I decided to buy the features that I wanted to own: Regardless of price. As I learn more about the product, (the manual does not tell me much at all), Roadster seems to be hassle free.  Volume is good enough to hear in the back seat. It looks nice and I think it is going to do everything I wanted in a Blue-tooth car kit.  At this time; I feel confident to recommend it with 4 stars.  If it had an operating manual, it would have all 5 stars.  I will use it for awhile and follow up later.P.S. I could have made this purchase anywhere on-line. I chose Amazon for free shipping and if I would have decided to return it after the first week, I would not have had a problem.  I trust Amazon.com.I have had a chance to use this a few days now and have great news: The charger recharges in as little as 15 minutes and I have only had to recharge once, so far.  I also decided to try the charger on my RAZR MAXX.  It was at 80% and I plugged it in thinking it could charge during my 45 minute drive home.  After 10 minutes it started signaling it was fully charged and to unplug it.  This is good news.I also learned how to link it to my car stereo.  There were no instructions, so for a test, I pushed the FM button. It then announced the FM 1 frequency. Each time I pushed the plus or minus sign, it repeated the next available frequency up or down.  I chose one and let it go.  Just for the heck of it, I turned on my stereo and set it to the channel of my Roadster and let it be.  The phone rang in and I answered the call through the stereo.  That was great.  I thought I would have to buy something to link it to my car.  Apparently it puts out a broadcast signal of it's own to be received by the stereo.Then, since my radio was not working while I had it set to the frequency for my calls, I started playing my music from my RAZR.  I was astonished when the music came out of my car speakers.  Now everything is cycled through my stereo and the music stops for incoming calls.Special note: Select a channel that is not in use, locally.  Otherwise you will have your broadcast mixed with the competing broadcast.  I know there is more to learn about this Roadster.  As I learn, I will share.One last thing to add: Download the free "My Motospeak" to send/receive and read all your text messages while driving.  This program has an excellent tutorial and additional command list for emoticons and punctuation.  You gotta love it all!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: We just had a baby, and I wanted my wife to use something hands-free in her RAV4. This was a good option, and it's worked out pretty well thus far.It's very simple to set up. It comes with a wall and car charger (micro USB). Just charge it up, turn it on and instantly it's in "pairing mode". Just search for bluetooth devices with your phone, find the Roadster, and pair it. Easy as pie.The unit automatically connects to your phone when it's in range (e.g. when you enter your car). Once you leave and are out of range, it goes into "sleep" mode. This way it saves power but makes it super convenient to connect and disconnect whenever you're in range. If you had to manually connect every time you entered your car, I would almost never use something like that. It announces that you've connected via bluetooth, and you're free to make/receive calls as you like.You can send the voice over your car speakers by setting the unit to transmit over a certain frequency. Overall, the sound quality is adequate. I can hear my wife speaking pretty well, but there are definitely times when it sounds like she's talking underwater. And if she moves the shade to block the sun, or moves her head away from the speaker, then forget it - you may as well not use it. The sensitivity on the microphone isn't nearly strong enough, especially when driving on noisy highways.Overall, the concept is good and this is a handy product. I'm still holding out for a unit that picks up sound better than this one. The search continues...
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is my fifth bluetooth speakerphone, and the word that sums this one up best is "cool".Like all the other speakerphones I've used, pairing this with my phone was easy.  In this case, a recorded voice guides you through the process.  This comes with more controls than most (good clicky feeling buttons, too), making music playback easy.The FM transmitter is better thought out than products I've used in the past.  The recorded voice tells you the station the device is using (which is typical), but if you hold a volume button down, the unit will automatically scan the FM spectrum until it finds an unused frequency, then announce the channel.  This is a cool feature that is a lot safer than trying to drive while adjusting both car radio and speakerphone ten times, looking for a clear radio frequency.  This feature alone is probably enough to justify choosing this unit.The sound clarity is noticeably better than the others speakerphones I've used.  I credit this to the noise cancellation claims on the box, but what matters is that calls go through clear.  The people I've called have remarked on it.Battery life is roughly equivalent to the Jabra it replaced and far superior to the other speakerphones I've used.  I was on the phone for 50% of a routine six hour trip and the fourth drive was nearly completed before the recorded voice reported "Low Battery" (It's a nice touch that a voice reports the battery level whenever the device turns on).  Most speakerphones need to be charged after two trips (the Jabra needs to be charged approximately as often as this Roadster).And this segues nicely:All the other speakerphones I use are designed to be charged via USB.  This too has a microUSB port, but instead of a USB cable the box comes with a DC car charger (and it's a swanky looking DC charger).  This is so much better thought out.  I don't always have time to remove my speakerphone and charge it.  I often need to charge it in the car.  I don't want to buy an extra cable or have redundant cables.  The charger has a coiled (think old telephone handset) cord and a nice clip and is intended for serious use.  I really like it.  If you have a car that shuts off the DC power when the car isn't on, you might consider just leaving this thing plugged in forever.This product also detects when you enter and leave the car, pairing automatically.  I have to admit I didn't really have a problem hitting the button on my Jabra to initiate the pairing, but this is one less step.  Pretty slick.The Android app is quite cool.  It relies on your phone's location service, but you can also save a snapshot of your car's location.  I actually often take a snapshot when I leave my car at the airport, but now that process is more automated and organized.  I'm a huge fan.The lighter grey color fits the interior of my car much better than black speakerphones, too.  It looks sharp.This product retails for $20 more than the one it replaced, but I think it's worth the additional cost.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I had a few bluetooth for my car and this one have been the best. People on the other end can understand me without a problem.I never have to turn it on cause as soon as my phone gets next to my car, it sense's it and turns on.  Likewise it turns off when I leave the car.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I bought Roadster for my wife and was about to purchase one for me when I saw the Roadster 2. It's far superior than the regular Roadster. If you undecided, go for this one, much better in sound, in connection, commands, battery, you name it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Super easy to set up with an iPhone. You're ready to use the speakerphone in less than a minute.I have another speakerphone I've been using and it has slightly more features, of which I never use! However, when it comes to clarity, this speakerphone is crisp and clear. I have a sun roof and with my old speakerphone, I would need to close it in order for the other person to hear me, this one, however, picks up my voice even with the sun roof open and windows down. That is worth the price alone, because for me, that's all that really matters.One other thing that I do love, is that it plays my itunes playlist from my iPhone over the speaker.It also has a car charger so you don't need to bring it in the house to charge it.One word of caution - the range reaches quite far! I've been in the supermarket wondering why I couldn't hear the person on the other end of my iPhone, only to realize, they were talking over my speakerphone - out in the parking lot!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Definitely not worth the $100 I paid for it (at a big blue box store) so I took it back. I had the predecessor to this, and that one had way better sound quality through the FM transmitter. This one made people on podcasts sound like they were inhaling helium, and music sound like it was all 96 kbps mp3s.Also, people on the other end of calls said I sounded like crap, but then again, they say that pretty much no matter what I'm talking on (phone, speaker, headset), so I haven't found a device that can make up for the crappy cell networks we have here in the states. That said, my guess is that this didn't do a particularly good job of canceling out noise from the car.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: After you pair this device with your phones, it will turn on and recognize your phone when you get in proximity to your speakerphone. As far as I can tell, it really does shut down when you are not using it so it will save power automatically, which makes your stand-by time longer between charges.The sound quality in both directions is very good. It is better if tvhe person on the other end is not also on a speakerphone at the same time. It has a neat feature that lets you answer your calls just be saying "answer" instead of pressing a button.This device will stream very high quality music from your Bluetooth-capable device through the car sound system using an available FM radio frequency. I have an LG Cosmos 2 and it worked fine for music and calls.This device comes with a Car Charger, which is ery helpful if you are like me and keep forgetting to bring your speakerphone into the house to charge it. It has a clip so you can attach it to a sun visor.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I paid close to $90 when this first came out and regret it. The problems that plagued the Roadster I, the Roadster II is no improvement. The BT connection still drops and the vibration detection works intermittently. I pretty much have to slam the sun visor to get this to turn on. Occasionally when driver, it would "bing" and the connection would just drop (again, I have to slam the visor). Battery life is terrible. When the battery gets to under 20%, it would just quit working without notice (not even a verbal "low battery" warning)..No more Roadsters...
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I previously orderd this for my mother and myself and really like it.  It is easy to use and the display is well lit. I purchased this one for my husband who is technology challenged.  He finds it easy to use as well.  Sometimes it is difficult finding a compatible radio station so the calls can be routed through the speakers.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: The Motorola 89556N Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone is a great little device to reinforce safety while you drive. It is common knowledge that we SHOULD NOT answer our cell phones while driving but it is inevitable that no matter what the situation is, we tend to answer our cell phones while driving. I guess this would be true for majority of us the reason why a lot of us now buy bluetooth headsets. Having a headset planted in our ears increases awareness and minimizes distraction compared to holding the phone by hand or pushing it against your shoulders.The Motorola 89556N Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-car Speakerphone reinforces the "safety measure" when you drive and talk on your cell phone. Set up for this bluetooth device was the typical plug & play. It did not take long for my phone to scan & pair with this device. It is ready to be used once it is paired. Placing it on the sun visor of you vehicle assures maximum performance since talking will come naturally and the projection of your voice will be frontal or facing the bluetooth device where the speaker is also located just below the control panel. The 2-watt speaker with noise and echo cancellation proved to be crisp and clear. The person I was talking to heard me precisely. No jitters or background noise of sorts. Everything I said was heard and comprehended by the other person on the phone. The controls are easy to reach, call function buttons and indicator lights are on the front of the device--volume control, mute button and the call answer/terminate button. No fumbling when you need to press a control button which is very convenient. The power button is on the side of the device allowing you to turn if off when not in use but with a stand by time of 3 weeks and a talk time of 20 hours, you may intentionally "forget" to turn it off. Comes with the ultra convenient car charger so you can charge and use it while on the go. With a little bit of manipulation on the controls, this device is also capable of voice prompts for basic functions like battery status, muting and unmuting the device and call status. This convenient speakerphone also comes with an FM transmitter so you can stream music from your device and can now be integrated with an android app that you can download to your phone to serve as a car finder. Very cool indeed!Overall, very impressed with this device. Highly recommend this to further enhance your safety when talking on your phone while driving although common sense dictates that if your attention span is short or you are easily distracted, better NOT answer the phone.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I purchased this item for my father's car. He took this to other countries and tried to use it, and it worked perfectly.The quality seems great and ver convinient to use it!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I occasionally use this, seems it messes with my reception so calls fade in & out while I'm driving and I end up having to disconnect it to talk on my cell phone directly....kinda defeats the purpose of "hands free". One thing I like about this is when I'm using gps or music from my cell phone, I'm able to make it come out of my speakers - LOVE that about this device!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Hands-free is the law in Oregon. The Motorola Roadster 2 handles calls beautifully and provides adequate sound for music and other features.PROS:Easy to set-up and use; my wife snapped it in place and connected her Android smartphone immediately. Voice commands provide step-by-step instruction.Battery life is excellent. The unit announces the battery charge level every time you get in the car. The kit comes with a microUSB port and a DC car charger, which accommodates charging on the go or an overnight charge.Sound quality is very good. The noise cancellation feature makes a difference. I've called my wife when she's on the road and while it isn't as crisp as a land line it is far superior to the other Bluetooth products we've used before.Music quality is good. We like that we can play our Amazon Cloud playlists via Bluetooth. On long drives, we slip the Motorola Roadster 2 onto the back of the seat and let our kids listen toBill Cosby's comedy albums.Motorola's Car Finder app is an added bonus. It saves a snapshot of your car's location and locks its position using GPS technology. Too bad the app is available for download from Amazon (hint, hint).Rating: Five stars.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I like this speakerphone, but ten days after I started using it the battery died and I couldn't recharge it, so had for turn it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I love that I can be hands free, including the connection as long as the device is powered on.  Just be careful, I left it on one evening, my phone rang, and apparently I was close enough to the car for it to connect.... Turning it off each night will solve that problem.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I had high expectations for this in-car speakerphone.  I have been using a Motorola Oasis ear bud for over a year and I love the ease of use and sound quality.  I was certain that the Roadser 2 would be every bit as good as the Oasis and more.  Ease of use is certainly an aspect of the Roadster 2, but the sound quality leaves something to be desired.  Once I had my iPhone paired with this device I called my mom who is my go to person for helping me test out these types of products.  She found it difficult to hear me and said I sounded far away.  On my end, I was surprised at how tinny the speaker sounded.  If the sound quality doesn't matter to you, this speakerphone might not bother you, but I wasn't impressed with it.The speakerphone comes with an in-car charger, but an ac adaptor was not included.  I suppose Motorola was unaware that many cars cut the power to the car's outlets when the motor is not running.  It took me several days of running errands to get the battery fully charged before it's initial use.  I could have used it sooner if it had an ac adaptor.Consumers with an Android phone can download a free app to tap into more features that this speakerphone offers, such as the ability to locate your car if you have forgotten where you parked.  Those of us who use an iPhone will just have to remember where we parked our car since Motorola chose not to develop an app for iPhone.Overall, this speakerphone is ok.  I simply didn't find it to be impressive.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I ordered the Motorola Roadster 2 after owning the original T325 Motorola hands free car speakerphone for several years. The T325 was the best hands free device that I have had after using several Plantronics and Samsung "in the ear" type of headsets. It's still working and I use it currently. With my iPhone it eliminates the need to upgrade my car to one that has integrated hands free calling and is much cheaper than getting a new car!Since I was a happy Motorola user, and when I noticed that my father was having problems with driving and using his phone, I promptly got him a new Motorola Roadster for his birthday. After playing with the Roadster I was so impressed that I decided to upgrade my own hand free device. When I went on Amazon, I realized there was updated Roadster 2 (silver case versus black) so I promptly ordered it. I figured with the update and paying $80 versus $50 I would get an improved product.I got the device yesterday and starting playing with it and yes, it is silver in color. However, as of this writing I have not noticed any noted improvement in performance over my dad's Roadster or my original T325. Also, the most troubling thing is that they tout the ability to hear and dictate text messages as a feature. This is one of the main reasons I got this unit.  However, what they forget to mention is that this feature is PHONE DEPENDENT. Meaning if you don't own an Android phone, this feature is not accessible. So if you have an iPhone or any other phone that does not use the Android OS, you just paid for a feature you can't use! Since I am a heavy text user, this was an appealing feature but now that I realized that I cannot use it, I'm bummed. Shame on you Motorola for not noting this in the product detail description!All in all, I'll probably keep the unit since I need another hands free device for my third car anyways but I seriously question the value of this Roadster 2 over the original Roadster. I'll also reconsider when it comes time to upgrade whether to buy another Motorola product.  I'll update my review later if I do realize after more time using the device, that it is in fact, better.Update: Since my last review I have have had to order another one of these as I had an issue with battery draining completely to zero after charging it overnight 2 days before. Its never consistent and there are times where I will partially charge the battery and it comes back to life and says that its fully charged. I never had this issue with the older unit that I had. I got a new one and again, it has happened with the newer one after the first charge. I have recharged it again and am going to see if it works. If not I am sending this unit back and requesting my money back. Due to this, I am going to lower my rating from 3 to 2 stars.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I can't find a bad thing to say about this!  It was super simple to connect, and it's very easy to use. It pretty much just connected itself to my phone and always pairs up without any problem.  It works great, just the way it is supposed to, and the design is small and inconspicuous so it doesn't stand out yelling "Break the window and steal me!"  I do think I'd have liked it better if it were black though - it's silver.  I had a black one and it was harder to see.  It's very easy to slip onto and off of the visor.It lets me play music over my stereo, which was great because my CD player died, and now I can use my iphone's music library so that in itself was a bit plus for me.  I love that it prompts me what frequency to tune too.  The reception is great - so much better than those adapters I tried.  It's a really neat feature to have built into a speaker phone.Some people complain about the prompt voice but I like it.  It sounds techy, and I like that, and also, there are little touches like the cool little blue light on the charger.  The controls are easy to use and intuitive too.I had a Kyrocera that wasn't a smart phone, and it worked great on that too, then I got an i-Phone 3GS.  I haven't had any problems with pairing or using the two of these together.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I installed this in a 2008 Audi A4, and paired it with two different iPhones (a 4 and a 4S).The first thing I noticed is that the unit is smaller than I had anticipated from the photos.  I posted pictures for you, with a Pilot G-2 pen for comparison.The pairing process was SUPER simple.  Just follow the directions and the prompts--no problem.  With the iPhone(s) there was no need for the 0000 code.The voice activation software works well for calls (80% of the time it gets the name right), but voice texting is sadly lacking.  My boyfriend has a deep voice, and he had a really hard time (he finally gave up).  The idea is a good one, though, but needs some work.The "Find My Car" app ONLY WORKS ON certain MOTOROLA phones.  There is NO app for the iPhone.  I was disappointed in this.  The initial read of the advertisement did not specify, and it wasn't until I received the unit itself and read the paperwork that I saw that it was only for certain models of Motorola phones.  I searched the 'net for more possibilities, but no luck either in the Apple App Store nor the Motorola website.  I guess I cant' blame them for wanting to promote their own products, but they should specify this in the ad.  (Upon writing this review, it's still not specific on that in the ad.)As far as call quality, it all seems to depend on many factors.  Signal quality certainly affects your call quality (more so than your regular bluetooth earpiece).If your conversation is being held with another person on another hand free unit, it seems to really get fuzzy.  In many of  my conversations, the person I was talking to complained of a periodic clicking sound (I could not hear it).  I have never had this with my earpiece(s).When I spoke to people on their landlines, NO one complained and everyone said the call was great.  As the receiver of the call, on the landline it sounded clear as a bell.  As the receiver (of a call placed with this speakerphone), while I was on a cell phone, the call was less than perfect (fuzzy, but not so bad that I could not understand).While making calls from the Motorola speakerphone, it ranged from crystal clear to so fuzzy I couldn't understand what was being said at all.  (This is all in the same relative area, but varied constantly.)  It seems VERY susceptible to call degradation due to background noise (the Audi has very little of this, so if your car has lots of wind noise, this would not work for you).The unit looks good, and the backlights make it easy to see.  The charger cord could be longer, but is fine in the Audi.  (It would have been too short in my Suburban.)The speakerphone had no issues with finding the phone(s) when we entered the car, and could handle calls coming in on both lines while we were both in the vehicle.  Battery life is great--it's been charged for days and is still reading with "good" battery life left.  Charging didn't take long at all (less than a couple of hours--I left it plugged into the outlet in the Audi while I was at dinner and it was fully charged when I returned).I believe that if you are in a downtown area, with plenty of well maintained top of the line cell service, this could be a good addition to your car.  However, if you live in a rural area (as I do), there are many variables that could degrade your call.  Always have your bluetooth earpiece handy, as those simply do not have the issues that this does.  (I use a Jabra Supreme http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005RUOUHW)I have posted pictures of the unit in the car for your viewing pleasure.  :)
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I got this bluetooth solely for the purpose of placing on my visor when I'm driving.  I find earpieces and headphones to be rather annoying while driving, so this product seemed to be the best alternative. I turned it on and it paired easily with my blackberry. Sound quality was good and I found that I didn't need to shout or talk differently while I was driving on the freeway so that the other person could hear me.  There is a feature on this model that it can pair with your radio and play music through the speaker.  I tested it out and it worked well, but I don't see the need for this feature when I'm already in the car and have the radio/speakers right there.  There is nothing too fancy about this bluetooth, it does exactly what it says and does it well.  It's a solid hands free device that keeps you safe and allows you to focus on driving while you're in the car.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is an almost perfect product except for the terrible sound quality of FM. If this same product had an option to connect it to my car's auxiliary input, it would easily trump all other bluetooth car kits.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Bluetooth streaming to my FM radio works great; it's the primary reason I selected this model.  My only complaint are the constant voice prompts when starting up.  Very distracting if you've got a passenger.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I really like it.  Works really well as a stand alone speaker phone.  Excellent noise reduction on the microphone - no one can tell that I'm not talking directly into my phone. Paired with my Droid 2 easily.  The new Motorola app for voice commands works well, and the vehicle finder seems to work well (played around with it, but haven't really had to use it to find my truck).  Battery life is excellent, and it charges really quickly.There is some static & a little bit of hiss when using it through my truck's radio via the FM function - that's the reason it got 4 stars instead of 5.  If there was a 4.5 available as a rating, It would have gotten that.Amazon shipped in their usual fast awesome manner.  Short of replacing my factory radio/CD/Cassette system (which I like) with a direct bluetooth unit like I had in my other truck (which while I liked it, I missed the cassette - books on tape), this is the best alternative.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I have been using this device for months now with my Iphone 5s....it's a great Bluetooth speaker. It works as advertised, the sound is good and the battery life is long.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Maybe it's because my car was new in 1998, but I couldn't get it synced to my car. Maybe cause my phone isn't smart enough, but  I haven't had luck with the "call" sync. I aswer the call, and the speaker is quiet loud. If I put it on my visor, I am too short for my voice to pick up in the microphone, so I end up clipping it to my shirt or jacket collar. Now I'm waiting for a car and phone that will sync!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: this product works great.  it connects well to the radio stations and is a breeze at connecting to the cell phones.  very loud speaker and it also annouces who is calling and asks you to indicate verbally to accept or ignore. thumbs up!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I own the older Motorola T305 Bluetooth speakerphone and bought this one because I wanted to upgrade to something better and with more features.  The older T305 has exceptional sound quality and has always performed very well.  I bought this model because the T305 is significantly bulkier and lacks some of the more advanced features that this unit has (i.e., the FM Radio, noise cancelling, etc.).On the Roadster 2's maiden voyage, I called my wife, who immediately reported that I sounded muffled and she was having trouble understanding me.  I also noticed that her voice quality was quite a bit muffled compared to the T305.  I hung up, switched over to the T305, and called her back.  I repeated this switch several times, and concluded that this unit has significantly worse sound quality (in both directions) than the T305.If the audio was only bad in one direction, I might suspect that I got a defective product, i.e. if my wife said that I was muffled, but she was not, then I might suspect that the microphone on the unit was defective.  But, since the muffled voice quality persisted in both directions, I am more inclined to suspect that there's just something in the design of this unit that is responsible.  The difference between the T305 and this unit was subtle enough that I suspect it is the noise cancelling software, or some other design feature, rather than a defect.  Despite the subtlety, the audio quality makes the unit unacceptable to me, and so I returned it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I bought Roadster 2 mainly becasue I have two older cars without aux for car stereo and to be able to BT stream through the FM radio.  I had read other reviews on the prior 505 model that noted that the older model was reviewed to have cleaner FM streaming without noise but that is out of production and you never know what you get used and new 505 from other obscure sites were more $$ than this R2.Took it on trip from CA foothils to Monterey through Bay area.  I find that the unit will work for me as FM streaming has pretty good sound free from backround static noise mainly ONLY IF the power charging cord is plugged in.  If the charger is not plugged in 1/2 of time you will get static sound drifting in backgorund even when finding the best unused frequency.  I wish this were not the case and find it surprising that according to other reviews Motorola actually went backwards to a weaker FM transmit than the old T505 - too bad as otherwise the unit is pretty good.  Since I like to run new battery units down 3 times from new full charge I'll probably use this as HF phone doing that and then keep plugged in streaming MP3 from Galaxy S3 after that.The Galaxy S3 S-voice seems to work fine through the R2. After reading poor reviews on the Motospeak app I decided to not install and will go with S3 S-voice.  Now if I could just find an app that would allow me to voice command dial number to use commands to navigate within my voicemail.  With S-voice I can program have it pause and dial codes to get in but not choose commands by "dial 2" or "dial 4"I would have rated this 4 or 5 stars if the FM noise was not present without the charger plugged in; or even some times with it plugged in.  The navigation worked fine through the FM from S3 cutting in on music as needed.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: this works great for hand free when your driving a standard tranny truck and can't hold a phone to your ear
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I was surprised by the clarity of the sound.When I’m driving with my windows down, the person on the other end can still hear me without me talking extra loud.I didn’t realize that two devices could be connected to the Roadster at the same time. This has been a great feature when kids are in the car with media devices.I am very pleased with the product.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I have been one of this units biggest fans of this unit for about two years.  I love the fact that it worked seamlessly with my Samsung S3 JB 4.1.1  It would initiate many phone apps, read incoming texts and I could dictate and send text messages, all at the touch of a button.  With the android OS upgrade to v4.3, the unit would read incoming text messages, but the button used to open applications and initiate text stopped functioning.  The app used to integrate this unit with the phone is Motorola My MotoSpeak.  It is apparently no longer being updated, as Motorola has it listed as a "Sunset" app on its website.  Without upgrading the app, this unit is basically useless to anyone using current software on android devices.  Bad move Motorola (owned by Google).  Why continue to sell this at a premium with no *warnings*?
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is a great car speakerphone. I charge it once a week and the verbal introduction when I get in my car lets me know how the battery is doing. It pairs right up when I get in the car (Droid Bionic) and it doesn't connect when I am in the house (A problem I have had with other speaker phones - wow is that annoying - pick up the phone and the speaker in your car is handling the call ... ).The sound is great and people on the other end have said I sound loud and clear.I have not used the android apps that work with this, but if you do a lot of parking or road warrior stuff, I can see those apps coming in very handy. Certainly a nice option to have while traveling. For me - I am kinda boring, park in the same place all the time ... so not much help for me ...Anyway - the size is perfect, the build quality is excellent, and the sound is clear. All A++ in my book.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I needed an option to connect my phone to my car stereo. I have an older car without an aux in plug nor does my car stereo have a bluetooth feature.This product was used with a Verizon Galaxy Nexus and a T-Mobile Galaxy Note 2.My review will primary be related to the FM feature as that is what I purchased the product for.  I purchased the Jabra Freeway Bluetooth Speakerphone at the same time to compare the two (spoiler alert - the Motorola Roadster 2 won hands down).I have used FM transmitters ever since the first one was released by Belkin for the original iPods.Review:The product paired to all my phones easily.  I have read the other reviews but for some reason my unit still continues to announce instructions on how to pair the device when not paired.  I can pair multiple phones at the same time and the unit will switch to the phone that is being used with one exception.  The first phone that pairs to the device is considered the primary phone and only the primary phone can be used as a multimedia device (music, etc).  The other phones are relegated to standard phone calls and text messages.If you download the Android Motorola app calls that come in while paired are announced verbally.  Assuming you have the app (again I have android phones so that is all I can speak to) the callers name is also displayed on the phone screen.  Most of the time callers can hear me although I have not found any system that eliminates all the outside noise from the call or is clear enough for me to hear completely all the time.When a text is received you are given the option to listen to it.  When you chose to send a text you can say it aloud.  The voice recognition is decent, about the same as Google.The FM transmitter is very strong.  I tune to a blank station and it comes in loud and clear.  I rarely have to adjust it even on trips and although not perfect it by far is the best FM transmitter I have ever used.Battery life is excellent.  I use this Monday - Friday for approximately 70 minutes a day.  The charge will last me anywhere from 2-4 weeks.It is not without its flaws though.The unit I have shuts off randomly.  It doesn't happen all the time but at least once a week.Changing the FM station is done via the volume buttons.  The station is announced each time you hit the corresponding button.  It makes it an awkward process to quickly go to another station that is far away from your current station.Without the unit being transmitted through my car speakers it is not loud enough to be heard clearly.  Keep in mind that I have hearing loss and as I get older it doesn't improve.Pros:-Strongest FM transmitter I have used-No issues pairing multiple phones-Announces calls and texts-Battery life is excellentCons:-Difficult changing channels rapidly using FM mode-Product shuts off occasionally-It is difficult for me to hear if I don't use the FM mode
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: good overall, but not quite as good sound to my callers as supertooth hd.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Iam very happy with this product, working fantastic and I recommend this for everyone that want to drive very saving.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: works great in the carclear soundeasy to set upWill be purchasing as gifts in the future for those that do not have bluetooth in their car.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: The Motorola Roadster 2 paired instantly with my iPhone 4S, and the sound quality on calls is superior to most all other Bluetooth devices I've used. It has a sleek look that blends nicely in our Caravan, and I love the fact that it includes DC car charging capabilities along with the standard microUSB charger. The Roadster 2 is easy to use even for the technologically-challenged, and we haven't experienced any issues with performance. If you're going make and receive phone calls while driving you need a device like this, not just for your safety but for the safety of those on the road around you as well. The Roadster 2 looks great and functions beautifully, and I can highly recommend it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: good battery time, connects great and broadcasts audio from my phone to my radio seamlessly.  This is my 2nd one, I gave the first one to my wife and she loves it also.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Haven't used this thing too much yet, but I like it a lot already. People seem to be able to hear me really well, the battery lasts a long time, and the built in FM tuner is really convenient for streaming music over the car speakers.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewerName: Raquel S. "Avid Amazon Fan and Kindle User"
reviewText: I was so looking forward to trying the Motorola Roadster 2. I've used Motorola in-car speaker phone kits with good results, and figured this will only be better. Out of the package, everything that the Motorola Roadster 2 was designed to do, it did it smoothly with ease. Using it it was so easy and everything worked so beautifully! The installation, charging, hooking it up via bluetooth to my Samsung cell phone, making voice calls, everything I needed to make calls with ease. I was rapidly falling in love....until I made a phone call.The very thing the Roadster 2 was built to do failed miserable. My phone calls were horrid.Those who spoke to me immediately recognized there was something wrong with my phone call. My voice sounded like I was in a fish bowl and made it so hard for them to understands what I was saying. It was passable when the car was off, but if the car was on, it was worse - nobody could understand me at all!I am so very disappointed with the Motorola Roadster 2. The design and functions worked beautifully, but the inability to have an clear voice call is tragic. This item is useless for me now, except for the cool-looking in-car micro usb charging cord. It works great to charge my Samsung cell phone and my Kindles. Very pleased with that!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is a slick looking Bluetooth speaker. The most appealing feature of this device for me is the auto-on when you get in your vehicle. However this is also its biggest fault. I have 2 of these; one for myself and one for my wife and both have the same 2 issues which Motorola has not been able to resolve. If you shut your door like a normal person (gently) the speaker will often not detect the sound/vibration and not turn on and sync. So solution #1 always slam your doors. The other problem, and this one has nearly resulted in me throwing it out the window, is that often when the previously mentioned issue occurs the device will be unresponsive. Pressing any button or even switching the device on/off it does NOTHING unless you plug it in for 5-10 minutes regardless of the battery charge of the device. When is does finally decide to function, you'll get a "(your phone name) connected, battery level is HIGH" despite the device functioning as if its never been charged. Perhaps these are just 2 lemons bought from different retailers at different times, or perhaps there are faults with the device that need to be addressed, but either way you as the buyer should be aware before spending the money on such a high cost device.When it functions it functions great so long as the other person isn't also on a speakerphone, then the other person sounds distorted and distant.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I bought this as a cheaper alternative to getting my car radio replaced or augmented with bluetooth or usb to listen to books in the car.  I'm so glad I did!  The setup requires loading the app, Motospeak, on my phone.  The app worked immediately and the setup was painless.  I clipped the Roadster on my visor, and it connected to my phone automatically. Every time I get in the car it plays a short musical tone, which lets me know it is working, and it also tells me the battery level.  By the way, the battery lasts a very long time, especially since I leave the Roadster on all the time.Once I choose my book or music, it plays immediately.  The speaker is very good for being so small.  I can also choose to use my car radio speakers.  I just push the FM button, it tells me what station to select, and when I do my book or music is transmitted through the speakers.  This usually works well, however, sometimes the radio sound becomes fuzzy or the station frequency changes.  This is a problem with the radio transmission, not the Roadster.  I have found that listening to books through the Roadster itself works fine, because the sound from its speaker is very clear.If I get a call, the music or book I'm listening to is placed on pause automatically and the Roadster announces either who is calling -  if the caller is in my Contacts - or the phone number of the incoming call.  I just say "Answer" and I'm connected.  The sound for the caller is excellent.  When the call ends, my book or music starts right back up.  I also like that I can push a button and my phone's voice dialer is activated, so I can make a call handsfree.  I can also use the Motospeak voice dialer, but I haven't done so yet.I can charge the unit in the car, or take it in the house to charge.I did not expect how happy I would be with the Motorola Roadster, but I am very glad I chose this instead of changing out my car radio.  I recommend this to anyone who doesn't have Bluetooth, a usb or phone jack connected on their car radio.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I ordered this for my husband to use in his work van.  He regularly travels up to 4-5 hours one way for work and he doesn't like the in the ear bluetooth headsets.  I thought this might be a better substitute for him.  It's also nice because you can pair 2 devices so he can use his personal (LG) and work (Blackberry) cell phones with it.  Today is the first day we tried it and we could both hear each other pretty well - especially for the noisey work van environment he is in.  It seems like the noise cancellation feature works pretty well.  I'm not sure if I have both phones paired correctly yet but at least one of them worked just fine.  He said he didn't have to do anything special - the unit picked up his LG phone as soon as he got in to leave for work.  We don't know if it paired automatically with his Blackberry yet or not, so we will have to see about that.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: why the reviews for this are so glowing i cannot figure. this is a "dumb" speakerphone that has near zero voice recognition - instead it relies on your smartphone dataplan and hardware to figure it out for you. I wanted a speakerphone that stored data on it, not merely a link between me and the phone.Oh, and it SCREAMS at you when turning it off and on, like LOUD speakerfeedback. this is not customizable. that is lame. there are hardly any customization options for the phone.This is dumb, Im  returning it. The $35 models do 10x more.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: It is limited by the ability of the cellphone's voice recognition and that was worthless on my Iphone 4S and is no better now I have a new Samsung Note2.  the ROADSTER does it's job but the phone doesn't speak the same language that I do it seems because it hears differently.  I'm a Brit so it may struggle with my accent, but my American wife has the same problem using her Samsung via the roadster.  Receiving calls and instructing THE PHONE TO answer works every time so that is brilliant, the problem is with telling the phone to make a call outbound
