reviewText: The best hands free car system
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I was happy to receive this product, since I needed one for my second vehicle.  I have used bluetooth headsets in the past, but the volume was never quite loud enough.  Because of this, I prefer using bluetooth speakers.  The volume level of the Motorola Roadster 2 speakerphone is loud and very clear.  I can hear my phone conversations easily.  The calling party on the other end never complains about the clarity either.  I have not used the FM transmitter, so my experience is solely through the speaker on the item.Pairing the device with my iPhone 4 was very simple.  I did not bother reading the directions, and was able to set it up easily.  The unit itself looks good, and looks good clipped to my sun visor.  The clip appears to be very strong, and I have not had any problems with it falling off.  The unit is quite a bit smaller than what I had anticipated.  The charging cord appears to be heavy duty, and has a nice curling cord similar to a corded telephone.There is also a feature that allows you to find your car in a parking lot, etc.  However, this does not work for the iPhone.  As I understand, it is only available for Android phones.  That is disappointing, and should be better clarified in the description.  Otherwise, I am very happy with this unit.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone is a very good quality bluetooth speakerphone. It is easy to pair up and operate. The button are back lighted and big enough for easy operation.  The sound quality is good for both speaker and the mic due to dual-microphone noise cancellation technology. The auto on and auto off feature is convenient and help the battery to last a long time. The sound is loud enough even when used in a car with decent cabin noise.  You can also find where you have parked your car with the new Motorola Car Finder app (using GPS technology).Features:1. Good speaker sound quality (mic quality is also good)2. Very easy to operate (easy to pair up, and buttons are back lighted with LED)3. Pair up with multiple devices4. Auto-off (and auto-on) when you exit (and enter) the car5. Solid build and compact6. FM frequency can be customized (vs just a few pre-set frequency)7. Read message pretty good (text to speech function)8. Great battery (up to 20 hours talk time)9. Find where you park your car (with the Motorola Car Finder app)Sidarta Tanu
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I owned a Motorola Speakerphone for a year, before the voice dial broke, and I could no longer use it to call people while on the phone. Now, I'm so happy that it did.The Motorola 89556N Roadster 2 is like a significant upgrade over my previous speakerphone (which I loved). Unlike my previous Motorola speakerphone, this one disconnects when I'm not not nearby the car. I don't have to worry about scrambling back to the car, to turn off the speakerphone if I'm inside a store or at the house. The speakerphone also plays music!!! This feature alone is fantastic. The speaker, sometimes, sounds a little staticky though.Motorola uses Android apps that help you locate your car in a parking garage or other facility when not nearby. It's almost like a GPS system. For people who sometimes forget where they park -- like I do -- it's a great app to have.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I know products like these can be subjective. For example i tried a Blueant S4, and it didn't work for me. This did. Connects fast, speaker works great. People can hear me clearly with no issues. It also works well with voice command. I have android. Price was right. It's inconspicous...at least in my car because i have grey interior. I only use it for phone connect, and it's awesome for that. No need for me to use the FM tuner. If you want a bluetooth device that will work great for phone conversation purposes...this is recommended. I can't comment on the other aspects.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I recently got a new car that has bluetooth and everything is hands free.  My other car is 12 years old with a tape deck.With the new laws about talking and driving, I needed a solution for my old car.  I've been using a bluetooth device in my ear, but it was picking up all of the car noise.  I also had the problem of getting the music from my ipod to my car.This device solves it all.  With my iphone, I can use Siri to text and make hands free calls.  I can stream my music via bluetooth and then to an fm station.  I've had fm transmitters in the past, but they never worked well.  This one is awesome!  It works so well!  Calls are easy to make from this unit and will either stream through fm or come through the speaker on the unit.  I've asked several people that I've talked to through the roadster and they've all commented on how good I sound.  There's no road noise and the voice is loud and clear.  My phone connects when I get in the car and the charge seems to last a while.I'm totally happy with the purchase.  It has given my old car new life!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is a great Bluetooth In-Car Speaker System.  Well made, easy to use and very handy.  I have no complaints about this device.  I highly recommend it to anyone in need of such a device.

reviewText: I have not had any other speakerphones so I have nothing to compare it to, but I can tell you this one has spoiled me.  This as super easy to set up and works great.Setting up the Bluetooth was as easy as it can get.  Jump in the car and it syncs!!  It works great.I now use this for my GPS navigation to speak through.  We don't use the system that goes through the car radio, so this really helps us hear the directions much clearer than simply off the iPhone.The voice commands is my favorite part.  I just ask it to call my wife and bam-baby!!  It does it!!!  Really really cool.  I also like that it gives me the option of answering or ignoring an incoming call.My only recommendation would be to add a charger you can use in a normal outlet.  This only comes with a car charger.  We did the initial charge using a portable battery that has car charger ports on it.All and all this thing really rocks!!!  I love it and highly recommend it!!!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: It took me a while to get around to trying out the Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone.  It was only once I got addicted to the built-in hands-free phone setup in our new car that I started to miss it in the other vehicle.  I started trying this out, and it's not bad.  It paired up quickly with my iPhone, and the battery life was good enough that I was able to forget recharging on a daily basis.  I ended up plugging it in weekly just to top it off.  Sound quality coming in for calls was excellent, and the people I talked to thought it wasn't bad from my end.  I like the fact that it's designed to clip onto the visor, as I can push the visor up when I get out, and there's no real indicator that I've got something there that a thief might want to break a window to get.  I wasn't able to test out the car finder feature, as I don't have an Android phone.  But if you do, that's a very nice feature.Probably the best way to get used to using this is to play around with it indoors to get the hang of the pairing, commands, etc.  Much better to do it there than while you're trying to drive.Disclosure:Obtained From: Amazon Vine Review ProgramPayment: Free
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Bought as Christmas gift. Totally loved by my son and I don't have to worry about him on phone while he is driving
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I am from Illinois where, like most states, a new state law requires cell phones and other electronic devices to be hands free when you are driving.  I have been taking my time searching for a reasonably priced device that would work for me.  After helping my son relocate from Arizona to Chicago, me driving a 16 foot Penske truck and him driving his Nissan I expedited my search.My son's car has a factory hands free device that came with the car. On the trip I communicated with him and my wife, at another location in Illinois, using an ear bud device that allowed me to drive hands free; however, I wear hearing aids that interfered with the ear buds.Today I went to the local Sprint Store about some issues I was having with my HTC telephone and for information about a hands free device.  Although, at $105 at their store, the customer service agent there recommended the Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone because its "Dual Microphone Noise Cancellation and Echo Control setting block out background noise in the car better than other speakerphones"--8.5 DB noise reduction as compared to Blueant S4's 5.0 DB and Jabra Cruiser2's 3.5 DB.A bit reluctant, I asked the sales representative if she would install it, let me test it and return it if I was not satisfied.  She did and I was so embarrassed that I had her install it.  The device provides very simple oral step-by-step instructions.  You simply pick turn on your cell phone blue tooth, place the device on your visor, plug in your Roadster into the cigarette lighter and follow the instructions.Before making a call, make sure your cell phone blue tooth in turned on and your Roadster is turned on. Then, all you have to do is push a conveniently located raised symbol that activates the device.  An oral prompt asks you who you want to call.  You say, "Call Home" or any other contact on your cell phone contact list and the system contacts you.To hang up or to receive a call, you push a conveniently located raise telephone symbol.I listen to my calls through my car speakers and make calls through the Roadster device; however, the device has a 2-watt speaker if you would prefer to listen to your calls or stream music through it.Additionally, the user can download the Application "My Motospeak"  for free.  This App allows the user to orally receive and send text messages through your device and cell phone and it provides "caller ID and important battery and call status voice alerts."Further, for Android powered devices, the user can download "Motorola Car Finder App" from Android Market that automatically saves and displays a map of your car's location when you turn your Roadster device off and guides you back to your car by GPS.I am so happy with the crystal clear incoming and outgoing calls that I have made with the Motorola Roadster 2 device that I bought another one for my wife's car and iphone 4S cell phone.The Sprint Store gave me twenty percent off because I purchased two of these devices; however, if I would have thought about it, I would have saved more money purchasing them through amazon.com.Enjoy!
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Works great with MOTO DROID RAZR MAXX HD.  I noticed when it was 100 degrees outside and much hotter inside the car it kind of freaked out a few times.  Otherwise very handy.  Long battery life, clear, android app reads texts, voice commands work well, auto off.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: My Motorola Roadster 2 synced instantly with my iphone. I have to admit I was (and am) a little put off by series of music notes it plays before a computerized voice announces it is "connected to trose's iphone 4."  I would prefer a simple beep when it connects because it gets annoying when Im running errands and getting in and out of car.OK minor gripe out of the way....On to the things I like:The easy connection.Automoatic sleeping when it's no longer connected via bluetooth.Easy to use buttons and controlsThe sound is clear (although tinny)The battery life is one of the best I've found.Im very pleased and would highly recommend this speakerphone.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: Firstly, this was procured from a Verizon retail store after having purchased another one (4 in fact) for adult off-spring with children. It wasn't until a year later when I bought one for myself they told me "it didn't work." But, then I raised so much voice with Verizon over it, with them insisting I could NOT have a refund (typical for that company), I was given this product to go with my Razr. It's a slight bit better, but not much. I end up talking to "it" and even raising my voice to "it" in front of the highways and fellow travelers at traffic lights like an idiot. Only when I have someone with me who's going through this as well do I have any comfort.In the 90s I had a speaker/mic system in my vehicles that was 100% better than this thing. All I can count on is that it's on my visor, sometimes works, sometimes doesn't. As for making a call, forget it. I've changed every name in my "People" list to a clear phonetic spelling; that didn't help. In fact, it's dialed people without my consent, or whatever one consents to.Would I purchase this product? Not on my life! It's time devises are R&D;'d for consumers, not for corporate profits and it's time Verizon started to refund money on faulty equipment.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: This is not the first visor bluetooth speakerphone, and I thought the Jabra I had was good, until I got this. Here are some impressions:Pro:- it's loud and clear, always a plus. Picks up voice extremely well. No problems on its basic functions, and worked very well.- it has a strange (amazing, really) ability to wake up on the proximity of a cell phone, even without the bluetooth turned on. No actions needed to wake it up from sleep, yet its sleep cycle is still quite frugal on battery consumption (last weeks on normal daily use).- it also has the best bluetooth pairing and response that I have ever seen on any bluetooth device. Used it with multiple phones, and reliability has been top notch and worry free. Always connected without problems, so unlike the fidgety bluetooth that I expected (and got used to).- it has voice prompt, which further eliminated any insecurities such as connections and status. e.g. It would connect and announce the device name, and its battery level, etc.- buttons are lit when actuated/waken. It's a minor touch but a much appreciated one.- enough buttons to cover my needs--as simplicity/sleekness are often traded with functionality. The buttons are well placed that they are easy to see and  actuate.- Comes with its own micro usb car charger (that you can also use to charge your phones, headsets, etc, provided they have micro usb charging ports).- It looks and feels of good quality, and I think it is a beautiful design.Cons:- Poor FM music streaming: the feature that I most anticipated is its ability to stream a2dp bluetooth sound to FM radio. The result was not acceptable: static filled. Even if I were able to manage removing the static, the sound comes out lean and tinny. I haven't figured out why, but it is simply a non-usable feature. Quite a disappointment.- The "car locator" software available for android or iphone wasn't terribly useful (or reliable) for me.For my money I would probably get the slightly downgraded model without the FM streaming, as that feature is simply not working for me (tried on multiple cars). It has demonstrated more than satisfactory performance in all other principle functions, and then some nice thoughtful touches. I have come to love this, because of all the nice thoughtful details. Besides the FM streaming miss, this really makes a very functional and (more importantly) worry free bluetooth speakerphone. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Universal Bluetooth In-Car Speakerphone - Retail Packaging - Silver

reviewText: I don't use this constantly, so every time I do I have to take stock of how to use it again . . .For some reason, the plug to put in your phone stumps me every time.  Apparently I have a hang up there.  It charges really well and actually holds a charge for a long time.  I just grabbed it to check since I might need it with our snow tomorrow, and it's still charged from when I charged it up about a month or so ago. reviewText: Last night my Droid Razr Maxx was down to 15% battery.  Just to test this product out, I pulled it out of my handbag and plugged it into the phone.  After a while (sorry, I can't remember exactly how long, maybe an hour or so? maybe more? I was working and lost track of time) the phone battery went to 40% and the indicator lights on the power pack were all off.  I was not using the phone, but it was still turned on.  I plugged the power pack in to recharge it, then re-connected to the phone (meanwhile, the phone went down to 30%)  After the second charge, the phone battery was at 60% and the power pack was drained.Since the Razr Maxx has such an amazing battery life, getting to even a 40% charge gives you plenty of usage.  This was a promo I got free with my phone, and I'm not sure I'd pay for one, but if you anticipate being without power for a few days, I guess it would be really nice to have this.
title: Motorola Droid Razr, Razr Maxx, Droid 4 1860mAh Portable Emergency Power Pack

reviewText: I bought this headset for its minimalist design, but the performance was disappointing at first. However I changed phones and tried it again, it works quite well now.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER HZ750 Bluetooth Headset - 89503N {bulk packaging}

reviewText: I buy one of these from time to time in order to replace the last one I had.  Why do I keep buying them, yet rate at only 2 stars?  Battery life and incoming sound quality.  I listen to podcasts nearly all day along so those two qualities trump everything else for me.  Do not get one of these units if you plan on using it for phone conversations.  The microphone is just abysmal.  Every single one of these that I've had exhibit the following annoyances:When you turn the ear piece inward it is suppose to shut off.  It does not and then you're going to hear the annoying voice telling you initiate pairing and enter 0000 if necessary.After about 9 months the very top of the unit, where the bend is, will begin to crack.  Crazy glue is a good temporary fix, but eventually that too will fail.If you lose the charge case, you can't charge it anymore.Neither of the two buttons will properly pause/play with Android.Overall, for the price and for my purposes, it gets the job done, but after nearly 15 years of waiting for the perfect Bluetooth headset, I'm beginning to think it'll never arrive.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER HZ750 Bluetooth Headset - 89503N {bulk packaging}

reviewText: I have had it for about a month now. I like it. the only problem i have with it is that the voice activated dialer does not work all the time. reviewText: I love this bluetooth headset.I bought the Plantronics Voyager Pro HD and the Motorola Elite (this product) at the same time, thinking that I could use this solely for listening to audio, and the Plantronics for talking etc.I was wrong, this sleek, light weight, loud, great sound quality bluetooth has quickly become my primary ear piece.Another nice touch is that when you turn the ear piece to the closed position it's in the off position, preserving battery life.When seated in the charger it charges all day.Great touch. I use it to listen to ~2 hours of audio books a day and have room to spare to talk for at least another hour.If i set it in the charger while not using it, it has more than enough battery to last a day.

reviewText: It deserves it 1 star rating. Here is why: Unless you buy it in the bulk option, this earpiece is much more expensive than the Oasis blue tooth, and it does nothing that the Oasis will do. I have an iPhone 4S, and the Sliver won't do much in terms of intelligent interaction: all it says is "x min. talk time remaining" and "incoming call from "number xxx". That is it. You won't be able to talk to your iPhone with this, the feature of the "Smart Button" won't do a thing. It is actually the dumbest button I've ever seen, my shirt buttons are smarter than this one! I just came back from a lengthy exchange with Motorola Customer Service, and the Rep admitted that this Sliver (not the Sliver II, of which I know nothing) will not interact with the iPhone, no matter what.Their publicity on this is totally misleading, as they state that the "Motospeak" app will work and accomplish all these great interactive services. They don't say that this is NOT available for iPhones. If you go to the app store for iPhone, you'll see there is nothing available to enhance the Motorola Sliver.So, if you have an iPhone, stay away from the Sliver. Mine is on its way back to Amazon as I am typing this.On a different note, the bulk version also did NOT include a set of extra soft buds for the in-ear piece. It says in the description that this should be included.OK, I am revising my review, to up it from 1 to 3 stars. I would have given it 4 or 5 if they had taken their own manual more serious and not misguided users as to what's what on this ear piece!I found a way to make it work with the iPhone 4S (and it will in all likelihood work with other generations, too):  While the "smart button" on the stem of the device is still as dumb as I said it was (it does strictly nothing), I found by chance that the bottom button (under the thick end of the earpiece) will do all of the communication demands, not just initiate and end a call. According to the Motorola User Manual, this button cannot do anything but initiate and end calls.So, when you want to communicate with Siri, just push the bottom button once, and Siri will ask for your wishes. Well, good thing I found this! I will keep the Sliver now!I will have to see if the short stem microphone (no boom) will work as well as the longer boom on the Oasis... more about that after I practice with this Sliver for a while!
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER HZ750 Bluetooth Headset - 89503N {bulk packaging}

reviewText: This is a fantastic headset.  I like that it's unobtrusive.It's not the greatest fit in the ear, but it more than makes up for that with everything else.  This version does not come with replacement ear gels as the retail version does.Call quality is great on both ends of the call.Combine this headset with the My Motospeak app to control phone calls and text messages with your voice.  This works quite well, but you have to speak punctuation with your text messages which is a bit annoying and not terribly accurate.I love that the headset is easily turned on/off by rotating the eartip.  It auto-connects quickly - so quickly that you can answer a phone call by pulling it out of the charging case, and placing it in your ear.And the charging case!  What a great idea!  It protects the headset and charges it.  The indicator lights on both the case and the headset keep you informed of charge levels.  The case makes this headset great for pockets.

reviewText: I am NOT a happy camper !!  If I could have given ZERO STARS, I would have. This product is sold by "PopUpDealz" and fulfilled by Amazon.  It is advertised as NEW when I believe it's actually REFURBISHED.  How do I suspect this ?1.  The earpiece itself is engraved (not stenciled, but actually engraved) with a code "RC0213", which I thought was very strange.  After finding out the unit is DEFECTIVE, I actually went to one of the corporate stores of one of the national cell providers and bought another one.  Guess what ?  The unit was NOT engraved in any way.2.  I called Motorola and the rep immediately told me that Motorola does not engrave items in any way.  They do PRINT the Mot part #'s on some of the items such as the charger unit.  She stated that I most likely had a REFURBISHED unit, which immediately made sense.  And if the code on the unit starts with an "R"... well, that makes even more sense.3.  Check out this link... [...]  It's very interesting that the Amazon link shown on this website leads directly to the product/vendor page that I ordered.When I did order, I didn't mind that it was bulk packaging because that was part of the cost savings, and many legitimately NEW items can be sold like that.  But finding out it's REFURBISHED really P***** me off, not to mention that it was defective.  I can't actually prove anything, but based on my explanation above, I think my suspicion is correct.UPDATE 7/14 - Yet another discovery... I found out the charger is generic.  Motorola chargers have their logo molded into the case, this one did not.  Again, even though this was bulk packaging, the product is advertised as NEW, so I fully expected everything to be OEM.  Who knows if the charger voltage and current are even compatible with the charging case.
title: Motorola ELITE SLIVER HZ750 Bluetooth Headset - 89503N {bulk packaging}

reviewText: This is a great item.  It is so simple and easy to use I purchased it for both my mother and my mother-in-law. Just open it to turn it on, and close it to turn it off.I have always had problems with Bluetooth headsets and because of that always insisted on having a corded set.  The sound quality, microphone quality and difficulty in knowing when it is on or off or when it is muted or when it is pairing... how many blinking lights, what color  - - look up in the manual what 3 blinking green lights with 1 solid yellow means... Argh it all was so frustrating, even more so when you couldn't hear the person well and they kept saying I sounded like I was underwater.This fixed all my problems.  I first bought it at costco, I loved it so much, I had my mom pick up one for herself.  She said she was having problems with the unit and couldn't tell how to keep the unit on.  In the end, the unit had a battery problem and had to be returned and replaced.  Now that it works, she loves the simplicity of it.  I then purchased one for my MIL from Amazon, which actually was cheaper than Costco. She loves hers as well.  Mine just stopped working and I replaced it through Costco and I can't say enough wonderful things about it.  (except that 2 out of the 3 had to be replaced)  BUT when it is working, it is great!You also don't need to use the little ear strap, it comes with ear inserts so you can just have a piece in your ear, not around your ear.

reviewText: I have had a couple of these headsets and they are outstanding!!! reviewText: I moved to this Elite Flip from the Motorola Finiti, which is a vastly superior device. This headset randomly disconnects from my Galaxy Note II, and will not reconnect without rebooting the phone. If the headset is powered off, then back on, it just goes into pairing mode. The phone has to be re-booted. Compared to the Finiti, the audio quality is substandard. The slightest movement of air near the headset causes audio to drop out completely. None of these BT headsets are great in a breeze, but this thing is absolutely useless if there is even the slightest disturbance of air in the vicinity, even a barley-detectable movement from an overhead room fan that is barely turning over.The controls are impossible to manipulate as they need to be when the headset is being worn. The flip part rests against your cheek when closed, and you have to pry it out away from your face to flip it open. Useless. I much prefer the simple slide switch on the Finiti. The ANSWER button...doesn't. Not sure what it does, but besides being difficult to press (hard pressure needed, which dislodges it from the ear), it never answers the call. Short beep in my ear, but no answer.Shorter: this thing is a POS.I have reverted to the Finiti, and will keep this Elite Flip for emergencies.This has biased me against Motorola BTs. Looking back to Plantronics, or some other make for my next.
title: Motorola HZ 720 - 89504n Elite Flip Bluetooth Headset, Bulk Packaging

reviewText: UPDATED MARCH 2013: Still all below is true, however, the flip began sticking - it would open about 85% of the way physically but not electronically connect unless I pushed the flip to full open position - very annoying. And of course out of Amazon's 30 day return policy. I contacted Motorola and they gave me a return authorization number with which I shipped this defective headset to Motorola (at my expense). Within a few days I got a receipt confirmation and with a few more days I got a replacement headset in retail packaging with ALL the ear gels, etc. Great customer service from Motorola!UPDATED JANUARY 2013: Everything I said below still applies. However, after using this for a while, I have to upgrade my rating to a 4. I've had Motorola "flip" headsets before and they're great. Performance on this one is also great and the "flip/turn-on" feature is super - (almost) instant power on - not like some of my other headsets I have that take quite a while to turn on and pair.ORIGINAL REVIEW: I just now got this - it pairs easily but haven't had time to fully test it. BUT, even though the pictures show ear gels (eliminating the need to use the over the ear hook), and the manual shows how to use ear gels, and the product description on the web site says it comes with ear gels, they don't come with this headset. From the product description on Amazon:"Multiple wearing styles--on-ear; in-ear without hook; and in-ear with earhook"The only thing you get is the over the ear hook - cumbersome at best. Fortunately, I have some ear gels from my H17 headset (that broke and this is replacing) that fit. More on performance after I've used it for a while.

reviewText: I have used several Bluetooth headsets over the past few years, and I believe that this is the best one I have ever owned!  It is extremely quick and easy to pair with both my original iPhone 3GS as well as my new iPhone 4S.The sound quality is crisp and clear, blocking out most background noise.  I was very impressed with the voice notification features included in this headset.  When there is an incoming call, a loud clear voice announces the number of the caller.  I found it particularly useful that the headset states whether or not a phone is connected as well as the status of the headset battery life when you first turn it on.On my new iPhone 4S, the Siri personal assistant is available with a single click of the main button on the headset and automatic redial of the last number called is available if you hold the button down.  The range with this device is phenomenal, allowing me to leave my phone in one room and go to any other part of the house.  I would highly recommend this headset!
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Got this as a gift for my boyfriend and he loves it! Uses it every day. Great sound. Very Clear. Charges fast and holds a good charge. Fast shipping!
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Motorola's Bluetooth headset HK 250 is a nice, no-frills, single-ear Bluetooth receiver.At around $30-35, depending on the fluctuating sale price, this is a good buy, if you want a headset that has a good call reception...of upto 30 feet.I have very small ears and I found the ear hook fit snugly and yet very comfortable.  It connected to my EVO 3D immediately and the voice attendant verified connectivity as well as battery strength.Although this comes with setup instructions, I couldn't find any mention of the app's you could use with your Android phone but the Android app, MotoSpeaks seems to work much better with this device than my preferred app, Skyvi.*** Talk for upto 300' ? ***"Clear Calls, Clear Music, Hands-Free...Up to 300 Ft Roaming Range" (front cover) / "Answer Calls From A Football Field Away...Stay Connected to Your Phone up to 300 feet away.  Allows you to roam freely without your phone throughout your office, home or yard.  Obstructions may limit range of use (back cover)"DON'T BELIEVE IT.I tested out this device for 10 days and you'll get a reception under the best conditions of 40', NOT even 50' and most certainly NOT 300 feet.I called Motorola's Libertyville, Illinois HQ this morning in order to get, perhaps, some clarification.After wading through the voice-prompt commands for 3:26, I was finally able to get a live person.  But, my frustrations didn't end there.After our cordial introduction, the next 14 minutes were spent listening to him read what was printed on the box and deducing that maybe I had an older phone and perhaps there was just too much interference where I'm at.My HTC Evo 3D is barely 10 months old.And, as far as the interference issue is concerned, I don't know of anyone who'd be talking from an unobstructed view from an unattended phone at 300 feet away.  Believe me, I wouldn't walk 300 feet away from a phone that I paid $499.99 (plus tax) because I felt that this phone was too heavy to carry.  If I did, I'd have a different problem when I got back.Anyway, all things being equal, ignorant customer service aside, if you measure the price against the basic, functioning features, it is a good value.Motorola HK 250-- 3.5 stars.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: [EDIT] July 27, 2012: Alright, this does it. I am officially downgrading my rating of this headset from four stars to two stars. It may look like I am just throwing a fit, but I am re-reviewing this in a calm and collected state. The last time I used this set was 2 days ago, so there's no "in the heat of the moment" thing involved here.Reasons:1) Connection Issues. I am one of those people who likes to keep their headset on their ears even when the said set is not in use. So, when the headset randomly disconnects (which is once every hour on average), the voice prompt saying "Phone 2 Disconnected, Headset not connected (1 second pause) Phone 2 Connected, Battery Level is High" is extremely aggravating.2) I still cannot, for the life of me, figure out how to make my primary phone "Phone_1" instead of "Phone_2."3) For reasons stated in number 1, this phone seriously needs a feature to shut off the voice prompts.4) When the automated voice prompt is currently saying something, and you shut off the set through the power flip button, the voice prompt continues speaking until it's done. She wants to get her point across one way or the other.**************************[Original Review]First things first, the sound quality on this thing is awesome. Even on the max volume setting, there is little to no unnecessary background noise. In a straight line, I would say the range of this headset is about 25 meters.Off to the extras, you can use this earpiece to listen to music on your phone. It also works as an audio transmitter for your video files. There is an option to turn this feature off, but you have to do it through your phone menu every time you wish to do so. Again, the sound quality is awesome up until about 85% of the max volume. It gets worse from then on. I am just happy that I do not have to use BTmono anymore.I did have a couple of gripes with the headset. First, whatever I do, it recognizes the "first phone" I pair up as "Phone_2." Now, where is Phone_1, you say? I do not know, and neither does the headset. Instead, the next device I pair up is recognized as Phone_1. Second, on a Samsung Galaxy S2, the headset sometimes disconnects, and then reconnects immediately after. Now, I wouldn't really have a problem with that, but when the headset is still in your ear, the automatic voice prompt "Phone 2 disconnected (2 second pause) Phone 2 connected. Battery Level is High" can be really annoying.Another thing is that the headset features a caller ID sort of thing that tells you the number of the caller. It would be nice to replace that with a custom name.Overall, it's a great headset, but it could have been better.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I got it so fast I was stunned.really glad I bought this because my husband took the first one I bought for work. And this one so nice!!! Love it!!!!

reviewText: I've never been big on Bluetooth headsets.  Each time I get one, I never use it.  The last one I had is stored away somewhere and probably wouldn't hold a charge by now if I did try to use it.  Ever since getting this one, I've found that I hate holding the phone to my ear and grab my headset when I'm going to make or receive a call.  I'm not about to wear the thing constantly, as I don't use the phone that often, but this is comfortable enough that I find after calls, I end up leaving it on for awhile, barely noticing I still have it on.  About my only complaint about the device is that the small flexible plastic piece that goes around your ear, twists and bends so easily, it can sometimes be difficult to slip it on with one hand, but I'm getting better at it.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a good low cost headset. It may not be the fanciest headset but it works very well. The sound quality is good and what I have come to expect of Motorola headsets. The battery life is fantastic and if you can deplete the battery in a single day then you are probably spending far too much time on the phone because it will last for at least 7-8 hours.  It sync's easily on my Samsung Gravity Touch phone and on my PlayStation 3. It comes with a simple wall charger and will charge pretty fast. If your headset battery dies then a 5 minute charge will get you a couple hours of talk time. The headset fits well in my ear and doesn't move or hurt my ear like some headsets do. I have owned five or six Motorola headsets and they have all worked well except for one so Motorola has a good track record for me.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: A decent headset. I paired it with my Motorola v9m cell phone. Flawless. Sound quality was great. I paired it with my Apple iMac computer. Again, flawless. The sound quality was scratchy, however I get this a lot with computers+bluetooth. I don't know which gadget deserves the blame for this. I paired this headset with my Apple iPod touch. That took two tries, but it does work. My iPod shows the battery level of the headset at the top of its screen. A nice touch. Sound quality was quite good. This would actually be a useful pairing, if you listen to podcasts or other one-eared audio content.I can confirm that the operating range is great. I left my phone two rooms away and I could still use the earpiece.The only real complaint I have is fit. A single rubbery ear cushion is supplied. A single earhook is supplied. If these two items don't fit your personal ear, you are out of luck. The earhook only swivels on one axis. This is common in the Bluetooth world, but it is not a good thing, in my opinion. Practically speaking, it means that it is not possible to twist the gadget so that it hugs the side of your face. You can only twist it so that it is aimed at your mouth (one axis of adjustment).If you have problems with fit, I suggest that you NOT attempt to manhandle the earhook into a shape you prefer. It will likely break.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Just to provide a point of reference I'm benchmarking my comments again my current earpiece.-Current ear piece: Motorola H17txtPhones used in the testing-Samsung Galaxy S2 Skyrocket running Android 2.3.6-iPhone 4S running iOS 5.1.1 (AT&T;)-iPhone 4S running iOS 5.1.1 (Sprint)Comfort-Current Ear Piece: Comfortable but if you break the fully adjustable ear hook and need to use the rigid one it's less comfortable.-HK250: Average comfortOn/Off-Current ear piece: Uses Motorola's flip mic to turn the device on/off. Absolutely my favorite feature Motorola offers.-HK250: Has a slide button which makes it easy to tell when the device is off but not as convenient as the flip mic.Connectivity-Current ear piece: Tells you when you are connected-HK250: Tells you when you are connectedRange-Current ear piece: Roughly about 200 feet. The earpiece will tell you when you are out of range and picks the call back up as soon as you get back into range.-HK250: The range about 300 feet however, if you exceed the ranged the unit will tell you that you are "loosing connectivity" and when you walk back it will tell you that you are "regaining connectivity."Setup-HK250: The setup went smoothly on the Android device however, I had to try pairing the earpiece with the two iPhone's a couple of times before it connected. Once the connection was made I never had a problemSound/Noise Cancelling-Current ear piece: Great sound and noise canceling qualities.-HX250: The sound quality is noticeably less crisp than my current earpiece. In some cases it sounds like you are talking to someone at a distance. Outdoors - no issues in moderate to heavy winds.Pro's-Bluetooth v3.0 + EDR-Talk time is great 7 hours-Standby time was not tested-ComfortableFeatures I wish the HX250 Had-Flip boom to turn on/off the earpiece. This is absolutely my favorite feature in my current earpiece. You never have to guess if the earpiece is off or not.-Motospeak. Motospeak allos you to dial via talking to the earpiece and respond to text messages. Great feature that is a must have.ConclusionHonestly, it would be a better investment to spend the additional money to get one of the following items from Motorola: H17txt, HX550, or Elite Flip. The difference in price is anywhere from $7 to $25 but you will get a much nicer earpiece. All three of the aforementioned items have Motospeak and the flip mic feature.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This ear piece has a long talk time and are also a quality made item. The sound quality is better than average and has the ability to play music.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a comfortable little unit, and it performs well.  No pairing issues at all with my Samsung Galaxy S phone, and noise reduction works very well.  Speech driving in a car with the A/C on full blast is clearly understandable to people I've talked to on this Motorola HK250.  It doesn't have the best sound quality of any unit I own, but its performance is definitely solid.One caveat -- some people have complained that they don't get anywhere near the 300 ft range as advertised.  This is probably because their phones are Class 2 devices, while this headset is a Class I device.  With my mobile phone (Class 2), I do notice a slightly extended performance range, allowing me to even change floors in my house if I don't wander too far, but, true, I can't wander 300ft away or expect transmission through 8 walls.  If you want to do that, buy yourself a Class 1 Bluetooth phone.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a solid entry level headset.  The sound quality for the speaker and recipient is very clear.  The headset is comfortable and easy to wear.  One of my biggest problems is retention when wearing these types of devices.  However this is not one of them.Pairing the devices is simple.  Operation for turning the device on and off, as well as volume control, is intuitive.  This simple design is even great for a total novice in gadgets.  Battery life is average for this price point.Overall, I'm very happy with the design.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Driving down the road the product doesn't fit very well in my ear, and i feel like might break it because the size. other than that it's an overall good product. but i recommend a little bigger one.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have an android phone that I use for personal calls and a basic Verizon phone I use for business. My Plantronics Bluetooth has absolutely no trouble connecting to both phones, so after using this Bluetooth off and on for the past couple of weeks I was surprised to find out that it's supposed to be able to connect to two devices at a time. The Bluetooth I received has never been able to connect to two phones. I have tried several times and it's one or the other, period. Yet my Plantronics Bluetooth has no trouble.I like the simple design of the Bluetooth and how easy it is to change the loop from the left ear to the right ear. It charges in no time and holds a charge for a couple of days. The on/off switch is easy to identify and use as well and the volume button. Overall, I've been very satisfied with the sound quality. I believe I got a dud regarding the ability to connect to two devices at a time. I've experimented with one phone being off while the other connects to Bluetooth, then turning the other phone on and vice versa. As well as disabling and re-enabling Bluetooth and other basic troubleshooting.I have had no complaints from people on the other end of the phone regarding sound quality.I love the Bluetooth and have always loved Motorola Bluetooth devices. I think I'll send this one in for warranty replacement and use my Plantronics in the meantime.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Great price, great sound, extended distance range, all make for a good bluetooth headset that doesn't break the bank and won't feel as bad if I lose it and can't seem to locate it with the headset locater/tracker apps...
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've owned several bluetooth headsets over the years, and I've always chosen Plantronics.  (The one time I picked a non-Plantronics product, I ended up bringing it back to the store.)  So I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of the Motorola 89561N HK250 Headset.  The sound quality and the range are excellent, and I didn't hear any complaints from the other end of my phone calls about background noise.  I also liked the voice prompt feature, which tells you how much talk time you have left.  I have a bad habit of forgetting to charge my Bluetooth headset, and it usually dies when it's the most inconvenient.  This feature spared me from having that happen.  The only drawback I found with this headset was the earpiece - I'm used to something a little more substantial - but it's not bad once you get used to it.  Recommended.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I also have the Motorola that flips open, which I love. But this one is half the price, literally. So for the money, I'm very satisfied.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset is a great phone supplement for convenience and safety. It is essentially a safety supplement in terms of using your phone while driving: it frees your hand from holding your phone and enables more focus on the road compared to holding your phone in your hand or placing it on your shoulder.Impressions:The Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset is a little smaller than other conventional bluetooth headset. It has an adjustable plastic hook that is suppose to mold to the contours of the rear of your ear but I found the hook to be a little loose fitting despite any kind of tightening that I do. Nevertheless, it is not much loose where it will fall off your ear. I was just probably used to my old headset where the adjustable plastic hook is a little thicker and more precise to the contours of my ear. Pairing it with my android phone is flawless and instantaneous, no hesitation on the part of the phone or the headset. It is enabled with voice prompts, a new feature for me, and you can place calls with voice prompts. User controls are accessible, no fumbling on where to find the volume or call/hang up button.The audio call quality is superb. While using it for the purpose of testing on both stationary and mobile platforms, I kept on constantly asking the person I was on the line with if I can be heard clearly and without static or background noise and the caller answered both in the affirmative. The call quality on my end was great too for the caller can hear me precisely and clearly.The indicated roaming range of 300 feet is a bit of an overstatement. I was first impressed when I was reading the distance specs of this headset but after on site testing, calls became staticky beyond 30 feet. Beyond 40 feet, the other party was already breaking in and out of the conversation. This testing was done in a parking lot where there was minimal trees or building. My phone was left inside the car and I kept walking away while talking to my wife. Distances were approximate but it will not take rocket science to conclude that maximum effective range to maintain legible conversation was under 30 feet. Remember, the acceptable "standard" range for any bluetooth device is a maximum of 33 feet. Beyond this distance, signal weakens and eventually drops.This is a bluetooth headset with stylish looks and a slight higher standard features combined with affordability. 4 stars is really pushing it.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have a Jabra bluetooth headset.  It works fine in my car but becomes excruciating to my outer ear after about a half hour of use.  No matter how I adjust it just plain hurts.  The Motorola functions better with clearer sound.  But most important to me was the added comfort of fit.  The Motorola is my new ear piece of choice.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Works well and connects easily with my nexus 7, ipad and samsung centura from Tracfone.  While i am generally tone deaf, it sound fine to me.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: just what i want recieved it before it delivery date works great fits rights easy to use price was right
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have had probably a dozen different Bluetooth headsets.  Some have been good, others not so much.  Those of late seem to be getting better and better though.  A few features make this one stand out.  First is the slide on/off switch.  Forget having to hold an on/off button for 5 seconds to turn on the headset while your call goes away.  Just slide the switch and the headset turns on instantly.  The headset plays a tone to tell you it is powering up and then tells you it is connected and to which phone (1 or 2).  You can pair the headset with two different phones or devices.  It also speaks the battery level when you power it on.  When the phone rings, the headset will read the caller ID of the caller.  Unfortunately, it won't match the caller ID to the name in your phonebook and read the name but at least the caller ID is progress.  This headset will also stream audio (music, Pandora, etc.) from the phone.  Audio is crisp and clear in both directions.  It is very comfortable in the ear.No the bad part:  This headset is it has a silicone cover over the earpiece that falls off easily.  It will likely get lost in short order and they don't give you a spare.  Hopefully, one is available as a spare part.  There is a charge LED next to the micro USB charging port.  It glows red when charging and blue when fully charged.  The problem is that it is so dim, you can only see it in subdued lighting.  I guess the good news is that it won't keep you awake at night.  Those are the only 2 flaws I can find.  All in all, I love this headset.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewerName: JSP "Part Time Soldier and Full Time Geek and...
reviewText: I bought this at Wal Mart but it costs about the same here. It's key feature for me is that I turn it on, it syncs up automatically, and it channels ALL audio from the iPhone not just the phone app.  I can listen to an audio podcast while I'm shopping or walking around the office. Also, it displays its battery status on the iPhone's home screen at the top, next to the iPhone battery!  Did I mention its cheap? And it works very well with both my iPhone 4S and my iPad3?  Simple, small, and battery lasts several days and its switch is easy to use too.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is probably a better headset for someone with smaller features. The size of the over-the-ear loop tends to pull the speaker out of my ear.  I can remove the clip, but I'd prefer my headset not be on the verge of falling to the ground.The on/off switch is small and rigid, but is easy enough to manipulate. The volume button is a single rocker type, but is small enough to be difficult to manipulate consistently.Sound from incoming voice is impressive and I have heard no complaints from the people I've called about the quality of the signal they receive. Though the HK250 is capable of streaming media audio, I'm not impressed by its music acoustic qualities; the feature ranks as mere gimmick on monaural devices, though I applaud the Bluetooth specification which enables it since, being a speaker it may as well play back media audio - it's convenient.My favorite thing about the HK250 is the spoken audible cues; connection status, battery level, the phone number of the incoming calls and a subtle "double-blip" which indicates when the call recipient picks up the line.The finish is unappealing. I thought there was a thin, transparent piece of protective plastic to peel off the surface, but there's not. The plastic face readily shows finger smudges.Overall, this is fine for smaller ears. It has exceptional voice quality for an earpiece at its price. It can pair up with multiple devices at the same time. The range is exceptional; the connection remains through several walls, from one side of the house to the backyard at the other end. I can use the charger from another brand of earpiece [the connector that looks like a mini HDMI plug] to charge the HK250 as well.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - BlackThis is the best Bluetooth I've owned.  I had the old one by Motorola for quite a few years, but I have other brands, too.  This one fits comfortably, and has a great range - you can be a couple rooms away and still hear clearly and no one ever complains about my not sounding clear. I think it's also being sold at a great price. I have the kind that are made like headsets, the similar kind with this same type of wire to wrap around the ear but for some reason this earpiece that holds it on your ear or maybe it's the Bluetooth body design- I'm not sure, is very comfortable no matter which way I'm wearing my hair or if I have glasses or sunglasses on, and it stays put.  It stays charged for a surprisingly long time too. I have models by other brands with similar "hooks" but they aren't as comfortable as this one. The others usually bother me when I have glasses or certain types of earrings on, as do the headset type.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I ordered it for a family member to replace their broken one. They love it due to the ease of use and the voice commands letting you know if your getting out of range. The number is announced so that gives you the flexibility  to know who's calling when your on another call.

reviewText: This is the third headset that I have used.  Out of the three I would rank this one second.  I found the plastic piece that cups your ear to be unflexible.  It should have more give to contour for smaller or larger ears.  I let my daughter use it but it would not stay on her ear properly (smaller ear).  Also, I would prefer the clippy part to be black instead of clear.The functionality of the ear piece was great though.  I love that fact that my phone (android) connected to it automatically and the music that I was playing went to it automatically.  The music was clear and even my daughter enjoyed it.  The call volume and clarity was good.It would have been nice if this unit came with a car charger.  Overall this is a good headset and I would recommend it.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: My gold standard for blue tooth headsets is the Motorola Oasis. I love it! I have to say, the HK250 is pretty darned good. First, let me say that it is a good, if not great, value. It is relatively comfortable (not as comfortable as the Oasis), especially for the design. I still have to re-adjust this, but not as often as some other brands, namely Samsung. I think if it came with different sized covers for the ear bud, it would be better, the ear bud is kind of large. Battery life is excellent and while I use it a lot, I don't have to recharge it for easily 4 days. Distance is about 12-15 feet from my phone and then it disconnects. The only thing that really keeps this from a 5 star rating is having to re-adjust it (a minor annoyance) and its maximum volume (a major annoyance). It is actually hard for me to hear people if they are not speaking loudly! If I could, I would give this 3.5 stars, but it really is better than 3 stars, so the HK250 gets the nod to 4 stars. I also like that it tells me the battery status when I turn it on. Pairing is easy (as it should be), and the charger works perfectly on my Samsung. The controls take a little getting used to but they work well and are fairly intuitive. You really don't need to read the instructions. Volume control, calling, picking up, etc., is easy....powering on and off takes some getting used (not much, but for me it's not where I would have expected it....it is on the bottom and I am not used to it there). I like the big power button! I just had to get used to it, and I did. For the price, I don't think you can find a better bluetooth headset than the HK250.....and even if you spend a bit more. This is number 2 to the Oasis. Come on Motorola, give us a better fit into the ear and let us make it a bit louder and it's a home run (even at a higher price).
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I gave 4 stars because the ear gel hurts after extended wear, but I'm extremely pleased that I can stream Pandora and other internet radios on it. I thought I would only be able to listen to music stored in my phone so I was pleasantly surprised when it streamed all media.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: If you need something cheap and fast, this is a good choice, but I do not feel it has the quality sound to be a permanent earpiece.It pairs extremely easily and within literally about 2 seconds. The charge lasts a decent amount of time, although I don't really think I got the full 7.5hrs out of it that it claims to have.The device itself seems fairly well built. It is lightweight, which is good obviously for something that is going to hang off of your ear, but I do find it uncomfortable and it does not come with different silicone earpieces to enable a good fit. The piece that sits in your ear is fairly large in comparison to some other bluetooth devices.The ear wrap piece is actually clear plastic, almost looks like lucite. I feel like it would snap and break if given the chance. Alot of times I would feel like it was not situated on my ear properly, and so when I would go to adjust it, or "stick" it in my ear better, I'd end up hanging up the call accidentally because the whole front of the device is basically a large push button which turns the device off/ends the call. You have to be very careful how you handle/touch it when in use.All of those issues I could have dealt with on a temporary basis but the sound quality is not very great at all, which is why I would not recommend this device.Almost every single call sounds muffled or slightly distorted somehow. I never had an actual crisp and clear call. It started to give me a headache during conversations lasting longer than 5 minutes. It is almost as if everyone was talking with a blanket over their mouth or something, or as if you needed to clean out your ear.I mean, if you are desperate for something cheap to use as a temporary replacement, or if you don't need a device for everyday use, this would be an ok choice if you don't mind the poor sound quality. If you want a device for everyday use, then I would look for a different device.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This headset was ready to go right out of the packaging. Upon flipping the power switch, the device immediately began to find a device to pair with and a friendly voice prompt told me to enter the bluetooth menu on my phone. The headset also uses voice prompts to let you know about battery condition, connection to devices, and if a call is currently muted. The mute feature works quickly by holding the volume button which is a very nice feature. The earpiece and ear hook are very comfortable and it is easy to forget you are wearing this tiny device. This would be a great headset for any bluetooth phone, however it does not quickly pair with a PS3 when it is powered off and then on again.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'm looking for a small, discrete Bluetooth earpiece with music in mind. Needs to be mono for work, so that I can be mildly entertained in one ear, and not oblivious to my coworkers and other sounds. I wasn't expecting the best experience being only mono, but this earpiece has no bass. I've never heard anything like it, and it sounds terrible. I'm wearing an earplug in the other ear so I can focus more on the other for testing purposes and I'm getting some of the worst sound in music that I thought wasn't possible with such a clear connection. Cannot detect subtle highs and lows and completely destroys my music experience.Despite music not being good as I want it to be, they're pretty lightweight, feel cheap, but get better range than my other headsets. Its no where near 300, its closer to 30 (I usually get 20 with my stereo headsets).I'd definitely send them back if returning online purchases wasn't such a pain.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've tried a number of the cheaper bluetooth headsets and I think this may be my favorite.  I'm using it paired with a Droid Thunderbolt running Android 2.3.4 and haven't had any of the issues other reviews are describing: connectivity is no problem, it hooks up to media as well as phone no problem and the voice dialing feature works fine for me.  I've had no complaints about trouble hearing me or me hearing other people.The only thing I might deduct half a star for, if I could, is that you MUST use the earhook.  My Plantronics sticks in the ear just fine and I don't think it even came with a hook.  Others came with hooks but seemed to sit just fine in my ear without them.  This is the first one I've had that will fall out of my ear unless I use the hook.  No big deal, really, though it does mean you have to pick one ear and stick with it, so your hook will be on right-side-up.Battery life has been great too.  Probably the best of any bluetooth headset I've ever had, particularly when idling.All said I think this is a solid choice at a good price.  Unless you really dislike earhooks.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Bluetooth is a good way to connect, and this Motorola HK250 hands-free headset delivers good performance. It's easy to use, and came with a regular charger (I'd suggest buying a car charger too, because for me, that's an easier place/time to charge), but I'd recommend this hands-free headset!

reviewText: I have 5 bluetooth units and this one is the quickest to charge and also the loudest. It comes with a thick little booklet and has other options-- like programing voice controls-- but I'm just interested in a simple and loud (I'm a bit hard of hearing) earpiece. I haven't listened to music or anything other than phone calls on it. I think it was probably fully charged in 30 minutes! reviewText: I bought this due to good reviews on Amazon and the good reputation of Motorola. I've tried many, many BT headsets. I wasn't expecting the world from this. I paired this with an iPhone 5. I used this for several phone calls, all in different environments. I tried this standing on my deck behind my house, in 2 different rooms in my house, and in my car. title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewerName: The Taminator "There's no going back. You've ...
reviewText: A couple of days after I received this from Amazon, myPlantronics Voyager PRO+ Bluetooth Headsetfell off my ear and into a sink full of water. I'd had problems with that one slipping before, so I wanted to try this headset anyway. It's now my full time headset. It took no time to pair it with myHTC EVO 3D 4G Android Phone, and the sound is crystal clear on both ends. People who normally complain that I don't sound clear on a headset told me they couldn't tell I was using one when I tested this.The fit is snug and I don't feel like it will slide off like my Plantronics did. I think I have average size ears, and I'm sure that factors into the fit. The small, flexible loop that snaps into shape around my ear also helps. It has long battery life and short charge time, and its compact size doesn't look silly or call too much attention to itself while I'm wearing it.I only use this to answer calls, and to make outgoing calls when I dial by hand on my phone. I don't use voice commands, so I don't know how well that works. I think the range is either smaller than what the company claims, or walls interfere with the reception. I've lost my connection 2 or 3 rooms away from the handset. I usually keep my handset with me, though, so this isn't really a big deal. I don't know what would necessitate having your handset 300 feet away from you while talking to someone anyway.For some reason, mine didn't come with set up instructions. However, it was easy to pull up product instructions on the company's website to get connected and running. It's compact, comfortable, simple, and stays on my ear. I think it's an excellent value, and in fact is an upgrade from my Plantronics headset. I like it very much, and I think most others will as well.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Includes:Power Plug with Micro USB plug.Headset.Instructions.Size, design, layout & comfort:At about 1 3/4 inch in length, the headset is light and comfortable in the ear. This is a sleek, stylish unit. It's a matt black plastic with gloss plastic top for the call/hangup button. Side slider button to turn the unit on/off, and on the top portion of the unit there's a micro USB jack for charging.Pairing, menu & voice commands:Using this unit was easy with user friendly voice prompts guiding every step of the way. You can pair this unit with up to two devices. You know which device you are operating based on the status light flashing blue or purple. When you first turn the unit on it instructs you on how to pair your unit.  Pairing the unit to the iPhone 4 was as simple as turning the blue tooth feature on in settings and selecting the Motorola Headset.  If you want to pair a second device just turn off the first one and turn the headset on repeat the same steps.To place a call, click the call button & wait till you get the voice command prompt from my phone. You can redial the last number by holding the call button until you hear a tone. Mute a call by holding the volume button until you hear "mute on" or "mute off". Hangup by pressing the Call/Hangup button.Volume Control & Sound Quality:Volume control is a single button on the side of the unit. It cycles through 4 levels of sound, cycling the volume up to the highest level before it will volume down, and vice verse, and using the iPhone I have 8 levels of volume.  The overall audio quality of the unit to person on the other end is similar to me using my iPhone on Speaker, from a foot or so away, though bit more tinny & cold, but not by too much, it sounds like a definite cell phone being used. It seems the sound choice was to go old fashion tinny w/no base to avoid muffled voices which is better then muffled. The iPhone normal by comparison is much warmer & natural.  The audio through the headset is clear & crisp & the volume can be made even louder then the max on the iPhone itself.Bluetooth Range:Overall the range is very good, with the unit on the main floor of my house I was able to walk anywhere in my home, from the basement to the attic without loosing reception, though it would start to sound underwater at extreme distances. The main floor to the attic is roughly the equivalent of over 20 feet & through two floors.Comfort & fit:The unit uses a single clear adjustable hook clip that goes over/around your ear holding the unit in. It's light & comfortable though the clip could be designed slightly better to hold the unit more firmly closer to the ear.Final impressions:Pros:Easy to use voice promptsOverall good call quality, tinny/cold, but clearPretty good bluetooth rangeSimple designStandard micro usb to chargeCons:Hook over ear design is a little loose, but not horribleOnly one button for sound volume so you have to cycle through them each time
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Bluetooth works well and connects easily. Shipping was fast came sooner than expected. Haven't had a chance to use it a ton to see if it works as far as it says which is why I gave 4 stars not 5.

reviewText: Simple headset but it works, no problems with my Galaxy S4 paring with it, calls are clear both ways.I like it.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Works fine with iPhone 4SI can hear music clearly, Siri works well.If you are buying this for use while driving then bad idea. Not loud enough to hear while driving.Worst problem (reason for 1 star)Everyone i have talked to using the BT has complained of poor sound which is the most important thing..I dont recommend at all.POOR
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I'm using this on my Motorola Droid 4.  It worked right out of the box.  Paired up with no problems.Fits in my ear with no problems.  You can wear it with just the ear bud or the behind the ear clasp.  However I prefer both just to have it on "double" and prevent an accident.Battery life, I've gotten four days.  Honestly I cannot say how much I talk per day, perhaps an hour all together.  Wearing it standby I have it on around six hours a day total.Voice comes through well.  And people hear me well.  Talking in wind, rain or crowds is not the best.  But then again I've yet to find one that does a great job at this, even when advertised.One warning, is if you perspire a lot, the headset will slip around. And if you are jogging it could slip off. Wiping around your ear helps or just remove the headset.The range does not come into play with me as I keep my phone with me and operate everything from my phone.I don't have any complaints on this headset.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: As you have heard from others the fit of this headset is not at all flexible.  I have had H700s, H715s, H720s and the HX1.  All had a set of different sized earpieces and several over the ear hooks.  This one does not.  It has one very hard and very large piece that fits inside the ear and one very small loop (hook) for over the ear.  So it's fit is not nearly as good as their other products.How about the 250 foot range....cough!  Maybe 30 feet at most.  Now that is about double my previous Motorola models listed above which maxed out at 10-15 feet.  This one will allow you to walk to a nearby room so long as the door remains open.  Move farther than one room away and it loses its connection to the phone.I apparently am very hard on the headsets as I can't get one to last much more than a month or 3 but I suppose this works as well as any of them.  It just doesn't fit as well.
title: Motorola HK250 Universal Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I could go on and on!  This is by far the best phone I have ever used including many Samsungs, iphone, droid x, droid, htc, etc.  Very thin and light for the size but still one of the most durable phones made by any manufacturer.  Gorilla glass holds up great, kevlar backing is super strong and it's water "proof" as well.  I don't even use a case with this phone it's so tough.  Samsung(body) and Apple (screen) products generally fall apart with any abuse.  Good camera, fast, big bright HD screen and good battery life make this a winner!

reviewText: In the past, I had the Droid 2 Global and Droid 2 and I loved both of them. This phone is the younger brother of those 2 phones. Amazing keyboard, big screen, apps play wonderfully on it. Besides being very heavy, this would be a 4 or 5 star phone. However...The battery life on the Droid 4 is so terrible that I have to carry around an external battery to keep this phone charged throughout the day. Even right out of the box, the battery functioned like a phone that I had been using a year. I have only had this phone 2 months or less.I have owned the Droid X, Droid X2, Droid 2 and Droid 2 Global...so I am familiar with how terrible smartphone batteries are. The battery on this phone is the worst by far. Are you kidding me, Motorola???I was doubtful purchasing any phone with a battery that cannot be replaced. All my other smartphones, I have purchased as extended battery which increased size and weight but was worth it for better battery life. With my other phones, I didn't have to buy an extended battery until 6 months or a year of heavy use.I'm telling you, within the first week I had to look for something to keep this phone charged which is when I bought a portable battery bank that adds so much bulk that I feel like I'm using one of the Zak Morris cellphones from Saved by the Bell. Not only am I using the portable battery pack but also a task killer to kill apps not currently in use.No, I do not recommend this phone. Trust me, 1 star is totally warranted and if you don't heed my advice and stay away from this phone, you will regret it. I am hearing great things about the Droid Razr Maxxx and their amazing battery life. I would urge you to try that phone.
title: Motorola Droid 4 XT894 4G LTE Black - Verizon Wireless

OEM and other fitting cords wouldn't work; I did have some luck for a little while using a USB charging pad, but that eventually stopped working as well. I also tried to charge it in the car using a USB adapter for the cigarette lighter, which also, wouldn't charge the phone.  I really only purchased this item, admittedly from another website, because it was a 2 pack and one can't have enough adapters.  Out of desperation, I began attempting to charge trying the variety of adapters I currently have, which, none worked, but, this is the only adapter that can used to charge my phone!  I keep one at home and one at work.  I'm thrilled that I can finally charge my phone; hopefully, it won't ever let me down while I own this god awful phone...

reviewText: Curious that the product description does not tell you the power output specification for this charger. The reason is that the printing on the device says 750mA, presumably split between the 2 USB ports. Compare that to a modern smartphone charger that is at least 1000mA for only one port. This Motorola charger will charge your phone eventually, but really really slowly. That maybe OK if you can let it charge all night (at least 8 hours). Don't bother if you need a fast charge at an airport or coffee shop. And don't even think of using this with a tablet. Tablet chargers are usually 2000mA or more and those still take a while to charge up.

reviewText: The charger's output is 750mah. This is horrible because if you want to use both ports at once, that amounts to 375mah per port. That isn't even as much as what you can get from a computer USB port (500mah per USB port on a computer). So it works if you have your devices off and you are charging them overnight. I purchased a few of these for work and regret it now. Just spend extra and get something from Anker that outputs 2-5amps.

Most USB chargers have a cable connection on the side and often than renders the neighboring outlet useless as it takes up some of its space.Devices this unit will charge:Ipods, iPhones, Android phones & some tablets, Ipads, Bluetooth ear piece, Small portable speakers like the Kinvo, Zune music player, Pocket PC/Windows Mobile Phone, and nearly any device that draws power from USB.

reviewText: The charger does exactly what it is supposed to do, charging two USB items at the same time.  I have found however that one of the ports isn't sufficient to charge an Iphone 5 - get a message that says not compatible.  Changing to the other port does not produce an error.  Not sure why, but past experience is that the power coming out of the ports is probably different different per port - in other words, 1 port might be 1000ma and the other port might be 2000ma.  For non-iphone 5, it will charge both items without an error on the device.  Ports are not labelled (or my mature eyes cannot see any indication of which port does what).  For the money, even if only 1 port worked, it would be worth it.  Since it is a Motorola part, it is REALLY worth it.

reviewText: My home remote, and one of my cellphones will not charge properly using this adapter. Only one of my phones can maintain a charge from it, which is a nokia with a 14 day standby battery life.Update: Having tried to pull this charger apart so I could solder the correct pins together to get a full charge on all devices, the charger is now worthless. Once you pry the gray top off, which will probably damage it, there are two black clips on either side of the circuit-board. If, and I mean IF, you can manage to get both of those clips undone at the same time so you can pull it out, you have about half an inch of wire to work with. I got frustrated after I ended up breaking one of the wires, and threw this pos out. I'll buy a new charger from another company.
