reviewText: First of all, the Droid 4 has built in battery. It is not meant to be taken out. That being said, batteries do die. I actually bought this one because someone tried to remove theirs and ended up tearing the ribbon cable. It was easy to put in and worked perfectly. Again, this is a repair part. If there is no malfunction, do not attempt to remove the battery in the Motorola Droid 4.
title: Original Verizon Droid 4 Battery with Flex Cable EB41, Genuine Motorola Droid 4 XT894 Replacement Internal Battery with Flexible Ribbon Cable SNN5905A SNN5905B 3.8V Lithium Ion Polymer 1735 mAh

reviewText: The new battery worked great and was easy to install with the right screwdrivers. Check iFixit for instructions on removal and replacement .

reviewText: I broke my original battery trying to remove it, since when do batteries get screwed in? Plus the screws were hidden under rubber like they really needed protection.  Give me a break Motorola WTF!  Anyhow, this replacement worked great.  Freakin' $50 though, I've gotten replacement batteries for all of my older phones for like $4, pretty ridiculous increase. However I do like my Droid 4. Stupid battery tho IMO, and it doesn't seem to have any real advantages.
title: Original Verizon Droid 4 Battery with Flex Cable EB41, Genuine Motorola Droid 4 XT894 Replacement Internal Battery with Flexible Ribbon Cable SNN5905A SNN5905B 3.8V Lithium Ion Polymer 1735 mAh

reviewText: I gave this 4 stars because upon instillation the battery wasn't charged so i plugged my phone it to see a 5% battery. After about a minute on the charger the percent went straight to 100% but my phone still wouldn't turn on. I figured it was a bad battery so i tried it in my girlfriends phone and it worked perfect. I was curious so upon inspection i noticed something covering one of the terminals and removed it then the battery worked perfect. So user error! be careful installing! Battery is good quality will update after weeks of use!
title: Original Verizon Droid 4 Battery with Flex Cable EB41, Genuine Motorola Droid 4 XT894 Replacement Internal Battery with Flexible Ribbon Cable SNN5905A SNN5905B 3.8V Lithium Ion Polymer 1735 mAh

reviewText: Motorola places some minor obstacles, but replacing the battery in a Droid 4 can be done in less than five minutes IF you have the right tool.  Amazon sellsT5 T6 Philips Slotted Screwdriver Opening Tool Set for Cell Phonefor a reasonable price, if you don't already have a T5 Torx screwdriver.  To release the back cover of the phone, so it'll slide off, you'll need to stick the end of a paper clip into the tiny hole in the upper right-corner of the phone's back while sliding the back cover downward.  Set the cover aside.Once you remove the phone's back cover, carefully peel the sticker off of the back of the battery and set it aside.  Holding the phone upright you'll find a small, soft, black rectangular insulator at the bottom right end of the battery.  Carefully lift and remove the insulator with your fingernail, which will expose two tiny screws.  That's where your T5 Torx screwdriver is needed.  Remove the two tiny screws and set them aside.In many Droid 4 phones the battery has been stuck in place with an elastic adhesive.  If your battery is stuck, carefully slide a thin plastic spudger between the battery and the phone, being very careful NOT to bend the battery.  Once you've broken the adhesive, the battery should easily lift out.  This new battery will fit into the exact same spot from which the old battery came.  Then use the tiny screws to connect the new battery through its flex cable to the phone's terminals, replace the black rectangular insulator and carefully re-apply the sticker.  Reattaching the phone's back completes the job.  Your phone should be ready to return to service with a fresh, new battery.  This battery gave my wife's Droid 4 new life.
title: Original Verizon Droid 4 Battery with Flex Cable EB41, Genuine Motorola Droid 4 XT894 Replacement Internal Battery with Flexible Ribbon Cable SNN5905A SNN5905B 3.8V Lithium Ion Polymer 1735 mAh

reviewText: I use one of the power outlets in our kitchen to charge my phone. The benefits are that the kids cannot reach my phone, I can hear the phone ringing throughout the house and it is in my line of sight when making breakfast so I don't forget it.I thought my phone or charger was broken after a few mornings where I woke up and my phone was at 20% charge. A new S4 and it is not holding charge? Then i realized that it was unplugged! Juvenile Alzheimers? NO!!! It was my wife unplugging my phone at night and plugging her own in!!! "I like that spot in the kitchen."Ok, so I needed a twin charger or to divorce my wife, hmm. Divorce was ahead at the start but the $4.99 for the charger just seemed like the better bargain.No problems with this charger, doesn't block a second plug from using the same outlet, charges just as fast as a single and saves thousands on divorce lawyers. Thoguh this may change next month when I take the charger on a business trip!

reviewText: It took me quite some time to obtain the tools required to replace this battery so it sat on a shelf for several weeks. Nevertheless, once I had the tools in hand, the battery installed easily (an exact fit) and still had 50% charge. This was handy as it allowed me to test my work without having to charge the replacement battery for several hours first. I was able to reuse the adhesive sheets that fit on both sides but it would be useful to have replacements included with the battery (even if at additional charge).
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: Bought this battery as a mod to my Atrix HD - a great phone with a lot of features, but a mediocre battery. Fortunately, the EB40 fits in the Atrix HD with a little bit of modification (and a slight bulge). The phone works perfectly with the replacement. With this battery loaded up, the phone now EASY lasts a day of heavy use and two days or moderate use. It is very freeing to know your phone is going to make it no matter how much you use it. Need to navigate to the store and don't have a charger? Don't worry about it. Want to watch some Netflix? Not a problem. Definitely better than the constant hunt for a charger. Only downside is longer charge time (for obvious reasons) and potentially (probably) voiding your warranty.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: For Atrix HD - battery is larger so a little hard to fit in the same space, but overall not a difficult install. Well worth it for the longer batt life, can go all day now and still have almost 50% remaining.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: My battery just arrive and it looks in excellent conditions, like "brand new", today I'll do the exchange and see how it performs. package from factor was a nice bubbleshock envelope, battery in a plastic bag, great price for a great product(so far), I'll recommend this seller.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: My Razr Maxx was on its last legs. I'm a serious power user, and after a year the stock battery was having trouble keeping a charge. I'd charge my phone to full, use it for a few minutes, and suddenly get a "50%" warning. Time to do a replacement.And replacement isn't easy anymore. In the race to make absurdly thin devices, manufacturers have resorted to making phones designed not to be opened. I got my Razr for the awesome battery, and frankly I find it too thin for comfort, but that's another review. Long story short- pry off the back cover, use T3 and T5 bits to get all the screws out, pry off the front cover, and you can change the battery on the Maxx. Mild to medium hardware experience preferred, but not required.The battery itself is excellent, and seems to have my phone back to stock. Performance of my apps also seems radically increased now that the phone isn't going crazy trying to figure out whether it has power. The battery I got even seems a tiny bit thinner than stock- I wonder if there was a revision at some point. It seems lighter too, likely thanks to the lack of all the glue the stock battery has to try and stop you from removing it.So I got a better-than-stock replacement for the Droid Razr Maxx. Battery is also compatible with the original Razr (instant upgrade to Maxx), and apparently the Atrix as well.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: Honestly this was like the best decision I made. Juice would run out after 10hrs of barely any use - just checking emails etc. If I actually used the phone it would die in 6-8hrs. Shipping was fast. Battery was pristine. Watch the YouTube videos, keywords "EB40 Atrix HD" and there is a video with sound that walks you through it. Do not attempt without a T5 Screwdriver, $5.00 on Amazon. There are a lot of screws. Once everything hooked up, just position the battery as low as possible so that it doesn't interfere with the Speaker, as it is part of the inner assembly. Because the battery is double the size, if the battery is too far up the speaker won't work. But get everything situation and voila, a new phone that lasts 40 hrs if very light use. Awesome! It does make the case bulk out a little but very little, and also make the phone heavier but small price to pay for such convenience of not needing to charge it so often.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: I ordered this, and it was defective (it was all the way dis-charged, which makes it not work again).The return was quick, and I ordered the same battery from another seller, (it was also $15 less!)The battery fit perfect (both times, since it's the same battery).My old battery was damaged when the idiot owner (me) decided that the phone freezing up and not turning off or anything was unacceptable, and severed the battery ribbon cable when taking it apart.The new battery functions flawlessly, and works just like it should.The phone itself, may have had one of three possible reasons for the freezing/failure:1.  It was on a windshield mount, which allows the phone to get very hot in the sun.2.  The microSD card became defective (at some point), and if inserted in anything, causes the adapter/whatever to get hot.  This could have damaged the phone, but it appears fine now.3.  The phone was rooted and had lots of applications on it, and was used for well over a year, without any "wipe" or resets... like a computer gets slow over time, so do smartphones.All in all, since it's OEM, this was a winner.
title: Motorola Droid Razr Maxx Battery with Flex Cable Genuine Motorola EB40 3.8V Lithium Polymer 3200 mAh

reviewText: This dock works great with my Atrix HD and of course is a premium dock because it's made by Motorola. To my suprise it even came with a usb cable to plug into a charger. The reason I'm giving this review 4 stars is because the description misled me into believing that the there was a headphone jack on the dock, in which I could plug a 3.5mm Aux cable into. There is no port on the dock so if I want to listen to music or take calls through my car stereo, I have to plug in the Aux cable to my Atrix HD manually after I plug the phone into the dock. It's just one extra step I have to take.

reviewText: This is a very well made mount.  Though I purchased mine as a used item, It is a great addition to have.  I can put the phone in the mount and it snaps firmly in place.  Even without lowering the USB piece, it stays in firmly.  The mount hasn't budged since the first day I placed it.  Even without power, the phone goes into "Car Mode" and has a larger icon'ed Home screen.  You can add some of your own apps, when in this mode, which i found useful.I love having the phone in front of me, even if I'm not using the maps.  Just being able to see who calls at a glance, or check a text message at a stop is helpful.I'd buy it again, and am sorry I waited a few months to look into the item.  Recommended.Do notice, it doesn't include a power cable.  Search for the Motorola Micro-USB cable that is about $5, here on Amazon.com for a good power supply.

reviewText: This is an ok stand, but for the price, I am definitely unimpressed.  Although I understand why Motorola is moving away from phone-specific docks, I am still disappointed with their choice.  This stand, while well made, is very overpriced for what it is.  The stand is just that; a simple plain plastic stand.  It comes with a micro-USB smart charger which is actually pretty cool if you have a Moto phone, but if they offered that separately, I would never bother purchasing this stand.  It's not all that great looking.  When using it using it as a bedside stand as I do, it stands a little higher and is angled a little more upward than I'd like.  There is no place to hold the cable, so when your phone is unplugged, you have to lay it somewhere beside the stand.  Nothing about this set up is sleek or streamlined.  I miss my old proprietary dock that I used with my Droid Bionic.  Having to find the cable, plug it in, then balance the phone on this stand seems like one step too many to do when you think about the price you're paying for it.  I would love to be able to buy this smart cable separately at a cheaper price; I have better universal stands that I can use.  As is, I'm not sure if I'd recommend this.  The cable is pretty cool and I like how the charging tip is at a 90 degree angle, but is it worth the price and this extra cumbersome stand?  I'm not sure.
title: Motorola Flip Stand with Smart Desktop Charger - Retail Packaging

reviewText: Purchased this to maintain a charge towards the end of the day on my Motorola Droid 4. reviewText: As others mention, this battery pack doesn't charge in a matter of seconds. However, in my case, it only took thinking ahead a bit. On a recent trip to NY after making calls, pulling up maps, checking Yelp reviews, etc my phone went dead in record time (and of course in the middle of a call). Having charged my Motorola battery pack the previous night, I was quickly able to connect again to the world. The built in cord connected phone and battery pack in just seconds. The phone was a little more cumbersome to use with the pack attached, but it was certainly preferable to no phone at all. Interestingly, the pack proved to increase the amount of time available by a multiple of 3 compared to my phone's stock battery. Back at the hotel I left the 2 devices connected and plugged in only the battery pack to the wall outlet. I was able to charge both devices at once even while periodically using the phone. Besides the phone, I've since used the pack to power / charge my Kindle Fire when it went dead while out and about. For me, the key has been getting in the habit of charging up the pack daily as I do my phone. With a not supplied mini USB to regular USB connection cord, I can also charge the pack from my laptop. Since this was cheaper than a 2nd phone battery, lasts longer than my regular phone battery  and can be used for more than just phone battery backup, buying the pack made more sense.
title: Motorola P893 Universal Portable Battery Pack 1860mAh Bulk Packaging

reviewText: Going into this purchase, I suspected the weakest link would be the FM transmission between the Roadster 2 and my car's stereo system.  Since Motorola pioneered radio and two-way communication, my hopes were very high.  I only invested a day determining the usability of the Roadster 2.On the plus side, pairing two android devices to the Roadster 2 was very easy.  The speaker on the Roadster 2 is very good considering the small size.  The Roadster 2 recognizes the names of the contacts then calls the correct phone number when selecting address entries by voice command.  The buttons are large and easily identified - consider it user friendly.  The best way to use this product is with the built in speaker.  It functions very better on it's own.On the negative side, FM transmission to the car's radio fluctuates, it is sometimes very good and other times very bad.  An FM channel that is clear initially may have static a few blocks down the road as you approach a stronger competing FM radio signal.  When streaming music to the FM radio the audio quality will not approach that of a factory installed integrated hands-free system.  The only flaw in this product is the use of the FM frequency for transmitting to the car stereo.  The Roadster 2 scans for strongest available channels which is exactly what it should not do - duh.  It should look for unused channels!  The best way to use this product is with the built in speaker which is clearer.Heck, I can get better sound quality by connecting the phone via standard audio cable which by the way works great for speaking on the phone too.  But, taking the audio cable approach, I still have to fumble with the cellphone buttons and that is dangerous while driving.If you do a lot of talking while driving, the Roadster 2 is safer than using the cellphone alone.  The Roadster 2's built in speaker is very clear and the buttons are easy to find.  The Roadster 2 provides easy to access buttons and vocal commands.  It is a useable product when not going through the FM car radio.  This product can not be compared to the integrated hands-free bluetooth radio systems that come installed on vehicles, today.  But, for the price it is as good or better than other FM frequency products.  I have paid a lot more for Bluetooth earpieces that do not have anywhere near functionality of this speakerphone.Bottom line:  If you are looking for a dedicated car speakerphone that supports voice commands, has a user friendly interface, and you are not concerned about a high quality stereo connection the Roadster 2 is a good choice.  I have come to the conclusion the FM frequency is always the weakest link.  The commercial FM radio broad cast signals are too strong.  The Roadster 2 seems to look for the channels used by the commercial stations.  Yea, I returned it.
title: Motorola Roadster 2 Tz710 Bluetooth In-car Speakerphone -Bulk Packaging

reviewText: The bluetooth part is wonderful.  The bluetooth call sound is great and clear, however, I am a bit disappointed in the sound quality for streaming music- doesn't compare with just plugging in the phone to stream music.

reviewText: Becasue I'm a road warrior, I'm always renting cars and this is the problem. I have forgot the other two in rental cars and people never return it to me. Works flawlessly, much better than Roadster I and yet I can use it as speaker for my songs when in the hotel room. I do recommend.

reviewText: Bought the Jabra Cruiser about a year ago.  This does the same thing but better.The other reviews capture all the great features, this shines over the Jabra because:1. It actually shuts off when you leave the car, doesn't re-connect when your car is in the garage and you're trying to talk in the house on the handset.  Turns back on when you get into the car.2. It has a hands-free answer feature.  The Samsung has a hands free mode, but when it's not switched on this allows you to answer a call (after declaring who's calling) by saying "answer."3.  It's smaller and less obtrusive, especially if you have a garage door opener, glasses holder...4. The Microphone seems better.  I get far less complaints talking on this than the Jabra.Wish I found this a year ago, hope it helps someone choosing between the two.

reviewText: 10-2-2013.  Rev A.  Used with XT926 (Droid Razr MAXX HD).Worse than the other OEM Motorola docks, that I had before this one (each phone generation is working more poorly, less integrated the docks.  Even worse with this phone, that it's supposed to work with)...Summery:-- Almost not worth the cost.  This is the worst yet from Motorola...-- Nice that it comes with two spacers, to allow some cases to be used with the dock!-- Sound out speaker jack or via extra combo cable is distorted, volume goes to max, with each call.  Brakes built-in music player is stuck at 150% normal volume.Bottom line:Dock dont work?1.  Volume goes to full blast, volume is not sticky.  Volume does not work with built-in music player Google Play (PowerAmp works good).2.  Does not come with the combo cable  (SKN6394A, ebay ~$8) that makes the audio connections automatically (comes with a audio cable you have to connect each time you connect to the dock.  For more info see below).  The Razr MAXX (non-HD), came with this combo USB and audio cable, that charged the phone and connected the audio, all at the same time, a real neat option (see below).3.  When used in landscape-mode, the sign-in password screen is reduced to 1/3 of the screen size, and nothing else takes the rest of the screen?  This makes it very-hard to input the password!!!  Overall harder to use this way.4.  Suction cup arm too short, for most cars (long dash/ windows).5.  Does not come with power cord (luckily no ugly blinding-blue Big-M, charger).6.  Seems to get stuck in car-dock-only-mode (cant use normal home screen, or apps)? If I used back arrow, it return to the normal home screen sometimes. But then, I'm stuck using back arrow in order to get to the main home screen, that you would normally use when it out of the dock).  The Razr' Software is unfinished for dock use...7.  Dock latch/lock interferes with the volume adjustment (too close).8.  My windshield is too far away for a suction mount, unless, I place it somewhere not legal in most states.  So I use the dock attached to a home made flat surface mount-in my car, that has worked with the two prior generations of Droid phones, as well as my P8767 flip phone (best phone ever - sound-wise).  I'm going to have to buy an aftermarket mount, to make it work correctly (I glued the supplied permanent mount, to the suction mount and then cut the sides off, to make a more square-ish mount, to fit my application).Notes:-- If the phone dont fit, try one of the 2 different adapters, that are included (assuming you have the Razr MAXX HD, and the correct dock)...#  My car stereo audio input connector, is less than one foot away from the phone.  I use this for both my music player audio (sound) and phone call sound.  Works well using the 2.5mm headphone jack.  Not so well with the SKN part (% See below for more info).  BT is over kill for this use.  I made a cord that brakes out the extra external mic that's part of the 2.5mm head phone jack.  And this works the best.  But I dont think the SKN-- cord supports this (TBD).Bottom line:--  Its broken...

reviewText: When I bought my RAZR MAXX HD in April 2013 I knew I wanted this dock for my car.  Using the shell combo w/holster and kickstand Xt926, the phone fit easily onto the dock.  A big improvement over my Droid X when I always had to pop the case off and was continually stressing the case to crack in the process.  The suction cup holds better however the whole mount shakes a little much for my taste driving on highways. When in use it allows me the hands-free use of texting and making phone calls.  Pulling off the road to dictate text may be easier but I like that it will read me any text received and I can safely continue driving as if I was listening to the radio.  I find it easier to insert the charger, easy to assemble/disassemble when I want to pack it for air travel and ready to use in the rental car.  Using this dock also allows me to set the phone up as a dash cam which is great during the day but at night if the windows aren't clean, the vid becomes blurry because it's focusing on the windshield.  I don't expect to find a charger included with this.  I bought mine at the Verizon store at a cheaper price with a discount but I've been told that they no longer sell these except as part of a package.

reviewText: Motorola is clearly listening to feedback. My previous vehicle dock had too many adjustable angles that made setup more frustrating than it needed to be. This has a simple ball and socket design that permits plenty of angles for any setup.  It is also nice that the charging cord plugs into the dock itself instead of directly into the phone. Now you don't have to fiddle with the cord each and every time you place or remove the phone.As per previous versions, the phone detects the dock on insert - along with the SMART Actions app, you have a wide range of control over what happens then (volume adjustments, gps on, wifi off, screen up, auto-reply texts, etc, etc). Nice accessory that adds a good amount of functionality specific to driving - a little expensive on its own, but a great deal when you look at the price of stand alone 5 inch GPS units.Does not come with a charger (nice, since I already have several) but does come with a head-phone to head-phone cable so you can plug into some car stereos directly. Also has setup for both windshield and dashboard mounting.Comes with custom fit pieces that allow for snug fit on both the RAZR HD and RAZR MAXX HD including with or without a protective case. That's right, you can have a protective case on the larger MAXX and it will still fit in this dock.Update 12/3/12: I finally received the Otterbox Commuter after a terrible experience with Otterbox - I'll save that for a different review. The case DOES NOT quite fit in the dock as intended. However, the phone does slide in nicely with only the inner soft skin from the Otterbox case. This would indicate that less robust cases and skins would actually work. If anyone has tried other protective cases I propose we list them in the comments section. Sorry for the delayed update here.Update 11/26/12:  I noticed one of the other reviews describes a problem with using the phone as a dashcam. I've taken a couple videos from the dock and none of the frame is blocked for me (I have it mounted to the windshield in this case). It's actually a cool little setup to record scenery or even the clever custom license plate. You can also switch to the front cam and record yourself driving if that suits you.

reviewText: Comes with a suction cup for the window, and a sticky plate for dash/other mounting. Product basically does what you would expect. Has 2 inserts so if you have a droid razr hd it's supposed to fit. I have the razr maxx hd, and it will fit without a case if you use attachment "B". Using the product with no attachment should fit the razr maxx hd with a slim case on it. I have a bodyglove case and it doesn't fit. Obviously this means if you have an otterbox case, that won't fit either. The only reason I'm removing a star is because there was no documentation on what cases fit and what cases don't. This is the case I have that doesn't fit in the dock: http://www.amazon.com/Body-Glove-9314201-DropSuit-Motorola/dp/B00AFJSR6A/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid;=1367523083&sr;=8-1&keywords;=razr+maxx+hd+bodygloveTo sum up:Dock with no insert will fit a droid razr maxx hd with no caseDock with insert "A" should fit a droid razr hd (not maxx). Not sure if it's made to fit with/without a case. I don't have one to testDock with insert "B" will fit a droid razr maxx hd with a slim case(I'll double check all that later tonight and update if it's inaccurate)Otherwise it clips in very nicely, keeps the device nice and secure, and you can tilt/adjust it a decent amount for better view-ability.

reviewText: I really like this headset.  I am constantly looking for headsets that fit my listening needs.  This one seems to fit the requirements. reviewText: About a month ago, Jaybird released what I thought to be the best new sports Bluetooth headset this season: Jaybird Freedom Spirit.***  ***Jabra ("Sport"), at this point, was perhaps on the cutting edge with their wireless, sport-bluetooth headsets coupled with Endomondo's sports tracker app, a better than average microphone and a reasonable price was difficult to overlook.Motorola ("SF600") had a better speaker system and a more secure fit than the Jabra Sport, but trailed very slightly with battery life.Other companies, like Sony, with their "XBA-BT75" offered a marginally better sound, but sacrificed fit, microphone and a decent battery life for a premium price.Jaybird's Freedom Spirit gave you two ways to fit the headphones.  Both are extremely comfortable.  The microphone and speaker are above average, but whose battery life and re-charge time and annoying button arrangement really took away from a headset that had solved many of the issues of previous season models.***  ***The two areas where Jaybird is deficient in--battery and design--is NOT an issue with this new Motorola "S11."It seems as if Motorola heard the legitimate criticisms about the headphones released across the board last year and made some very noticeable improvements over their "SF600" model.First, the earphones are just as snug but the earpiece is a little more flexible.  I especially liked how they wrapped around the head.  (When you first take them out, you notice a bit of a weight to them.  But you'll soon forget that when you put them on.)The battery life is a shade under 6 hours.  6 hours of any of the following: talking, listening to music, watching a movie on a Bluetooth-enabled device.  And, the headphone will chime and tell you how much battery life is left--something that the $300 Sony's don't do.The microphone issue is clear.  There is NO sports Bluetooth headset with as loud of a microphone system as these S11.  Period.  They blare when a call comes in.  I was told, during a 2-mile walk back home that I was walking next to a noisy crowd and yet the nearest people (a couple and their child were putting grocery in their trunk) were about 15-20 feet away.  When I got home, I gave the lady my phone and headset and I grabbed my business phone and had her to call me on it as we walked outside of the house in different directions.  I had to hold the phone away from my ears--and it wasn't on speakerphone.  It's unreal.The battery recharged in less than 60 minutes after being completely drained.Streaming music and music sitting on my microSD card in my Android phone sounded crisp, very little distortion.*** Comparing the new Motorola to Amazon's best-selling wireless, sports headsets ****** Sound fidelity/ Call reception ***Motorola "S11" (Nov. 2012)-- ExcellentJaybird "Freedom Sprint" (Nov. 2012)--ExcellentSony "XBA-BT75"--ExcellentMotorola "SF600"--Very GoodJabra "Sport" -Good*** Comfort ***Motorola "S11" - very comfortableMotorola "SF600"--very comfortableJaybird--Very comfortableJabra--ComfortableSony--uncomfortable*** Cost ***Jabra-- $75Motorola "SF600"-- $90Jaybird-- $130Motorola-- $130Sony-- $298*** Battery life ***Jaybird--3 hoursJabra--3.75 hoursMotorola "SF600"--4 hoursSony--4 hoursMotorola "S11"--5.75 hours*** Conclusion ***Now has never been a better time to buy a wireless, Bluetooth headset.  The sound reproduction has improved dramatically over the past 2 years and the cost has dropped significantly.  For the cost of replacing a couple of moderate-priced good, wired headsets, you could have a decent wireless Bluetooth headset.At this point, the best overall is the Motorola "S11" followed by the Jaybird.  The Jabra's, although about a year old, is still a very good buy.  I love the snug feeling and the great speaker system in the "SF600" but for a few dollars more, I'd recommend the "S11" over them.  I wouldn't recommend the Sony's under any circumstance.If the battery life and recharging cycle and the button design on the Jaybird were different, it would be very difficult to recommend the Jaybird over the "S11" or vice versa.Motorola "S11"--4.5 stars.
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: Back in January 2012 I started using theMotorola SF600 Wireless Sports Headphones - Retail Packaging - Blackfor my daily workouts and casual "walking-the-dog" jaunts. At the time I found it to be a product that provided great sound and convenience without the pesky wires hanging down and getting in the way. Over the year I became slightly less enamored as the ear piece had a propensity to slip a bit out of the ear. It never fell out completely but enough to be annoying. So with that in mind I decided to try the new Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset since it claimed to eliminate that.First off, yes the earpiece stays firmly in place. In fact, very firmly in place. It does not budge at all. This is due to the connecting part being a firm yet kind of flexible piece of plastic instead of a loose wire like the SF600 has. The sound is awesome and in my opinion even better than the SF600. And like the SF600 it is extremely easy to set up. It takes about five seconds after charging and you are off and running.However the fix Motorola used to keep the earpiece in place is itself a bit annoying. The plastic piece fits around the back of your head and is extremely snug. In my case it actually pushes the earpiece into your ears making it a bit uncomfortable. Plus there is no way to adjust where that plastic band rests on your head. If I had my preference I would have it a bit higher so that it rests across the bottom of my baseball cap I wear when working out but that pushes the earpiece out of the ears, defeating the purpose. If Motorola came out with a version that allowed a bit of flexibility in that aspect I would be all over it.Overall I would recommend this as a good and convenient wireless headset. I did try and go back to the SF600 but found I was too spoiled with the S11 sound. I guess can live with the minor issue of the flex-band.
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: What I liked:- The sound is rich and full.  You can even adjust the quality a bit using the built-in equalize to select among presets to emphasize bass, treble, voice, everything (not sure what that means), or nothing.- The fit is secure and comfortable.  You get four different sizes and the way this headset is designed, the selection isn't to keep the eargels stuck in your ears, that's taken care of by a slight and unnoticeable pressure provided by the rest of the headset.  The only thing the eargels have to do is seal against the sides of your ears to seal out noise.  Even picking the "wrong" size works well and you'll find one size that is particularly effective at sealing out most noises.- Controls are straight forward and easy to use.  There is one button to turn the headset on and off, a pair of buttons for volume up and down, and a fourth button for everything else.  The "everything else" button is the only one that needs explanation, though not a lot.  Press and release to pause the current song (and answer a call).  Press twice to skip forward.  Three times and you skip backward.  Hold it while a song is playing to stop through the equalizer settings.  Each setting is described with voice prompts.- I can send voice commands to my iPhone using the undocumented SECRET BUTTON SEQUENCE: Tap the everything button, as if to pause a song, and then hold it for two seconds to activate voice recognition on your device.  At least that's that happens with my iPhone.- I can see the headset battery level on my iPhone.  The headset also tells me, in English, how many hours of charge are left in the battery.  Speaking of iPhones, you also get an indication on the phone display of headphone battery level.- The signal reception is outstanding.  I've recently tried earbuds where it mattered which pocket I had my phone.  With these the phone can be in a different room... a different floor for that matter.- Calls made with this headset are at least as good any any of the dozen other headsets I've tried.What I didn't like:- I can't thing of a single thing.

reviewText: I Have to say I read a few reviews and had a few doubts , but let me tell you this.... These Flex's are the real deal! I have fought cords @ the gym for years & this is the greatest solution out there! The HD Flex are sleek, comfortable, stylish and sound is Awesome!!! The range of Bluetooth is Great as well. I have had these for 2 weeks with NO issues, they fit better than any earbud I have EVER tried and they are adjustable to fit you melon.  Laying down on a bench, running, lifting is hassle free with no interference. I bought the 3 year warranty in case I have an issue and bought the Otter Box protective case to protect headset. Setup is quick and simple for Bluetooth connection. The quick charge is Great also. I have had no issues what so ever with controls as I see some cry about buttons. If you want the best Bluetooth set available you HAVE TO grab a FLEX!****Note***** Had issue with ear pieces about a week in, contacted Motorola , woman was good and said they would get ear piece cushion/pad out...a month went by, nothing. contacted them again, on back order, they have no clue when  part will be back in stock? Contacted again 2 months later, still no idea-I would think this would be a common in stock part ( it's the stock ear piece rubber that goes in ear!) I know there cell phones are garbage  and even though this headset has been great for working out, I will think twice about ever buying a Motorola product again,  bad customer service!Took star away for customer service....should take 2, but I'll play nice

reviewText: I had 3 pair of SF600 headphones before these.  The first 2 quit working or started crackling.  The 3rd pair was better but the fit was never good.  They wouldn't stay in my ear properly.The S-11Flex is a huge improvement in fit.  They stay in place no matter how I move and are pretty comfortable.  Sound output is as good as the SF600, which was very good, but since these stay in place the overall sound is much better.  The only problem is when laying down such as when doing bench press.  The back piece gets in the way.  It's a minor problem considering all the benefits of this design.Pros:-Great Sound-Secure and comfortable fit-Very fast charging-Microphones cancel out noise pretty well for this type of headsetCons:-Neck Band gets in the way occasionally-Ear buds make a faint click from the rubber when moving certain ways, such as on a treadmill-The confirmation beeps when you press the volume button are VERY loud-Volume in call is too loud even on minimum

reviewText: I've owned more than my fair share of Bluetooth headphones.  I've owned the Motorola SD-9's.  I've tried multiple pairs of headsets from Sony.  I've tried a Jabra set.  All in an effort to make working out at the gym easier.  And to date, I've returned them ALL.  Either I am the Godzilla of sweat or no product can withstand the torrential downpour of sweat off of my head.  I'm not sure which but regardless, I've killed my fair share of electronics.Which brings me to the S-11. So far, I've been very impressed.  These paired with my iPhone 4 in seconds.  I've used them almost two weeks and they've been great.  When you power them on, the headset tells you how much battery life you have left in hours.  And after using them almost two weeks, I've charged them twice.  I'm amazed at the battery life.  The fit is fine.  The earbud pieces telescope out a bit so you can cram them in your ear holes.  I do find that the ear pieces do tend to jiggle a bit in my ears unless I push them in more.  Otherwise, I do hear some jiggling sounds as I jog away.  The sound volume is also solid. I have not had an issue where the sound is not loud enough.  Initially, the sound was down on the head phones so once I increased it to the hear-loss level, I was fine.Like I say above, I'm still waiting for the shoe to drop on this pair.  I'm trying to take extra special care of the headphones to be safe.  Should they breakdown, I will update this review.***** Update.  Still working after a month of solid use.  I really enjoy the 4 to 5 hours of usage I get from these.  I switched from an iPhone to an iPod shuffle during this and they're still chugging along.  I'll update again should these break. ************ Update.  Killed 'em dead.  I think the sweat tsunami finally got through them somehow.  Best pair I've ever owned but they're dead, dead, dead.  Won't power on.  Maybe it's the switch.  Who knows.  They're great when they work...

reviewText: These are really nice. They work great and sound is also great. Takes a little getting used to with the buttons but they're great. reviewText: I give these headsets 4 stars because I bought a BT device in the past that had more features on it than this one.for half the price. It also happened to be a Motorola product, ahem! Never the less these are excellent for my workouts but it would have been nice to have buttons that forward or reverse your music. The available buttons are power, music off and on and volume controls.Others have mentioned that the back piece of this product broke on them, I invested in the "Otterbox Motorola S11 Flex HD Headphone Case - Black" and never worry about my product breaking due to an accident that probably could have been avoided had this been available. If you leave this in your workout bag with a bunch of stuff packed in there like a sardine, what do you suspect may happen? Breakage, hmm, what a concept. Don't blame Motorola for your incompetence if that is what it is in fact.Overall, I am pleased with my purchase I just believe at this price point additional features should be available.

reviewText: Bought new in Dec. 2012, Product started out great, fit felt weird but not overly obtrusive, slightly heavier than accustomed to. Because of the various loose adjustments around the ear, I heard a lot of popping sound that was distracting from the music as I ran. The jarring that takes place while running transferred up to the headset and thats when the noises would occur. Walking or riding this noise is not noticeable.Now that the warmer days are starting, sweating during runs are more prominent so the test of "sweat" proof is now in question as the set will not accept a charge (unknown reason). Basicly I have an expensive piece of crap setting on my desk. Getting in touch with Motorola to see if they will replace.

The battery life does last a long time though, usually longer than 5 hours on one charge.

reviewText: This is a fantastic set of headphones. Out of the box they feel well-made and are definitely durably built. The sound quality is remarkable. Pairing them with my iPhone was simple, and made even smoother by the fact that when you press the pair button a woman speaks into the headset telling you the exact steps you need to take to get going.I am a runner and this is the main way I plan on using the set. I did my first run with them this morning and while I continue to be impressed with the best-in-class sound quality, I felt like the fit was less than perfect. As I ran, the headphones bounced around a bit on my head and it was a tad distracting as this bouncing (which sounded a lot like a heartbeat in my ears) took away from the aforementioned sound quality. In their defense, they are highly adjustable and do fit snugly. All in all, I'm still not entirely sold on wearing ear buds (vs. headphones) as I run. Tomorrow I plan on using the different sized earpieces (included) to see if I can eliminate or minimize the bouncing sound.If you plan on using these for activities with less movement, or on a plane, I'd definitely give them 5 stars. For running, I'm going to deduct one. If different earpieces make it better, I will report back.12/5/12 UPDATE: (changed rating to 5*)Today for my run I added the adjustment bar to the headphones (which I should have done before but somehow missed it). I have a huge head and typically on my baseball hats I have to use one of the last (biggest) settings on the adjustment strips in the back. On the adjustment for this headphone, I used the first (smallest) strap and once I did this it killed the aforementioned "heartbeat" sound but then I heard a new ticking sound as I ran. The sound wasn't in the headphones themselves, but rather a bumping of something (not sure what) as I ran.So, during my run, I made it my goal to get these things to fit perfectly, which lead to a very choppy start/stop run. The good news is that I perfected the fit and no longer hear any sounds as I run. The main thing I learned is that you don't need to have those ear-buds pushed into your ear-holes. Perhaps this is common knowledge, but I've always worn them this way in the past. Because these headphones have enough adjustments on them that they are able to stay put on your head, you can just press them towards your ear-hole without shoving it in. It took me several miles and adjustments to finally get to this conclusion, but once I did there was no noise/bounce/ticks, etc. at all and the rest of my run was fantastic and I was able to enjoy the clear sound and great Bluetooth connection.So, after this "adjustment period" I've got a different understanding about how to wear this device and I am 100% thrilled to be running with this set and have moved my rating from 4 stars to 5.If you found this review useful or have any questions, just let me know! I'd be happy to help!

reviewText: I really was excited to get these headphones for the gym.  I put them on right away after I charged up the unit, and found the sound not very loud, a little tinny, and low bass.  So I figured I would try the different size ear buds and other adjustments that can be made on the headphones, which are plenty by the way.  After trying various settings and adjustments, I was not impressed with the sound.  First it felt awkward on me, with the back of the headset resting on my neck, made it hard to move around.  Next, the sound was just not very good, not loud as my other headphones, not good bass, and could not get them to sit well at all overall.  I returned them.  I really wanted them to work out but just did not work for me.  On the plus side, for all the time I had it paired to my Galaxy S III it always was connected and never cut out, which was good on that level.

reviewText: The Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset puts a different take on what you should expect on a BT headset. It has so far exceeded my expectations as far as audio, fit, range and ruggedness I so desperately wished for in a BT headset. I've had similarly designed BT headsets before, an Altec Lansing Backbeat 906 and an LG Tone HBS-700, to which I will be making my head to head comparison. The Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset surpasses both the Altec Lansing and LG in just about all the categories I could think of in a BT headset.My impressions:Fit: the Motorola S11-Flex HD, as with the other 2 brands I am comparing it with, is an in-ear headset but like the Altec Lansing Backbeat, it has a wrap around bar that goes over behind your neck for stability. Unlike the Backbeat, the S11-Flex's wrap around bar is adjustable. It can be adjusted to the contours of your head assuring of a fit that stays and will not fall off, even when you are engaged in a full motion workout or you are running. It simply stays put allowing you to enjoy whatever you are listening to without the constant motion of adjusting it or putting it back on when it goes out of place. It comes with 4 different sized ear buds so you can get the best fit in your ear regardless of the size of the holes of your ear. I must also mention that the fit is very comfortable. I used it for workout lasting a couple of hours and I had no issues with comfort at all.Audio: the audio of the the Motorola S11-Flex HD was surprisingly very good, way lot better than the Altec Lansing or LG headphones that I am comparing this with. For one, the S11-Flex HD outputs audio evenly spread on the sound spectrum. Listening to music provides a balanced bass and treble, no overly broken highs or lows even if you desire to have the volume a little higher than usual. The LG Tone fails miserable in this department, once you turn the volume up, distortion is the name of the game as far as your music listening pleasure is concerned. This is the first BT headset that I had the chance to own with an Equalizer functionality. You can set your headset to an equalizer setting that best suits the music you are playing. The phone call aspect of the S-11 Flex is great too. I am able to listen to my call and my callers heard me clearly without any kind of background interference. This proved especially true using it when the car windows were rolled down, the noise-cancelling was great and we were able to maintain a clear conversation despite the wind noise.Connectivity: I had no problems connecting the S11-Flex with my android phone and my ipod touch. I have 2 android phones, one with a 4.0 Ice cream Sandwich OS and the other a 2.3 Gingerbread OS and the S11-Flex connected without any issues. I was also able to connect this with a 2nd Generation ipod touch without any problems at all.Range: the S-11 Flex boasts a range of 150 feet from your connected device. This is quite an overkill as far as the specified range is concerned. I tried this out on the parking lot of a local grocery store, left my phone in the car and started to walk away. Things started to have some distortion from 40 feet out. At approximately 70 feet, the audio was quitting in and out. So I'd say the stated 150 feet range is an overkill. I had no problems roaming around the house with it. Depending on the size/area of your home, you rarely venture to more than 50 feet in any part of your house. If you do, would be wise to have your device with you and use the BT headset at the same time.Ruggedness: the ability of the S11-Flex to withstand moisture and sweat is an added plus especially when using it while exercising. Sweat is acidic and anything that comes into contact with sweat, degrades over time.Overall, the Motorola S11-Flex HD Bluetooth Headset is a great performing headset to have. The functionality and ruggedness of the S11 surpasses other headsets in the same category. Very highly recommended!

reviewText: The HD sound is fine. The Bluetooth connection works well enough. The headphones are somewhat adaptable to provide a good fit that stays in play while running. If that's all you are looking for, then these headphones might work for you. On the other hand, if comfort and ease of use are issues, then you'd be better off stringing together two paper cups.Let's start with comfort. The earpieces for the Motorola S11-Flex headphones fit inside the ears. While I appreciated that Motorola provide various-sized earpiece shells for the user to try, I was unable to find a comfortable selection. In fact, these are the least comfortable earpieces that I have ever tried.Ease of use is not much better. The low-profile controls (e.g. power, volume) are built into the outer shell of the headphones, making it very difficult to find these buttons with my fingers while wearing the headset...even when knowing their locations. The buttons are small and their profiles are simply too small to easily operate. Even with the headset off, it is somewhat difficult to find the buttons.These limitations are simply not acceptable.Rating: One star.DISCLOSURE: This review is courtesy of the Amazon Vine program, which provides products at no cost in exchange for my independent and unbiased feedback. My objective is to provide you with helpful information that improves your shopping experience.

reviewText: I tried a number of Bluetooth headphones for working out to pair with my Motoactv watch. All of them had their quirks and some had great audio but would constantly cut out. I'm a distance runner so there's a few things that need to be met in order for me to call headphones a success: must have long battery life, must feel comfortable being worn, must be sweat resistent, and need to have good enough sound that I can hear my music. These headphones meet all of those requirements. These are the perfect headphones for distance runners. If you want solid Bluetooth headphones for light workouts with better audio, go with the Moto S305's. But, if you're a serious runner then don't bother. Spend the extra few bucks on these. You won't be disappointed in the least.

reviewText: I kept hoping and praying that I would eventually find a comfortable wireless headset that I could wear indoors and outdoors and experience great reception.  Thanks to the generosity of the Amazon Vine Program, I finally found one in the Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset.  It arrived neatly packaged in a box that can be reused for storing the headset, including its instruction booklet.  The instructions are easy to follow but difficult to read without a magnifying glass.Pairing the wireless headset with my Apple iPhone 4 was extremely easy.  I didn't have to type in a code or password.  An electronic voice told me when it was paired.  Now, whenever I power on my headset, my iPhone automatically connects to it.  The headset is extremely comfortable to wear.  No longer do I have an elastic strap that becomes stuck to my neck when I walk and causes the earbuds to be pulled out of my ears when I suddenly turn my head to the right or left.  I can dance as hard as I want (gyrating, twisting and thrashing my body) and don't have to worry about the earbuds becoming dislodged.  The reception, most importantly, is awesome, both indoors and outdoors.I can speed walk, jog or run and the music is always clear and sharp, unlike my other wireless headsets/headphones where the music played as though it came from a broken record:  stalling, sputtering, hiccupping, etc.  The headset's controls (i.e., power on, power off, volume increase, volume decrease, etc.) were easy to operate.  However, it was difficult to return to a previous song track.  One has to push the MFB (multifunction button) three times.  It seldom worked.  However, this is fine.  It seldom worked for any of my other wired/wireless headsets/headphones.  Charging the Motorola headset was also easy.  It charges in only a few hours.  I greatly appreciate Motorola providing an AC power adapter.  I can charge it with an ordinary electrical outlet in the wall.  I don't have to use a micro USB cable and plug it into my PC or my Philips SPS6038A/17 Home Charging Station (Philips SPS6038A/17 Home Charging Station).  I wish all of my wireless headsets/headphones came with AC power adapters.Not only is the reception great for the Motorola headset but it remains paired with my iPhone for great distances.  In my apartment, I can set my iPhone in the stairwell and walk to the farthermost corner, which is over sixty feet away, and still hear the music clearly.  This is awesome.  I have worn my headset to work, church, the mall, the grocery store and to the club house at my apartment complex.  I love wearing it when I'm using the elliptical machine, which has a docking station for my iPhone.  I am able to watch movies (that I have downloaded to my iPhone) on a screen and hear them with my headset.  Thanks to my iPhone and my Motorola headset, working out is more fun!  This headset is highly recommended for physically active individuals who love listening to music.I have enjoyed using my Motorola headset so much that I recently acquired the Otterbox Motorola S11 Flex HD Headphone Case (Otterbox Motorola S11 Flex HD Headphone Case - Black) for protecting it against breakage.  Many reviewers have complained that the flexible headband broke after the passage of time.  Keeping this in mind, I will carefully handle my headset, trying to prevent it from dropping long distances onto hard surfaces, and will keep it stored in my Otterbox.  Another problem I foresee in the future is the loss or tearing of the silicone earbuds.  However, replacement earbuds (Bluecell 10 Pairs Medium Silicone Replacement Ear Buds Tips  - Black) can be ordered from Amazon.  The Bluecell earbuds work great.  They are just like the ones you receive with many electronic devices.Joseph B. Hoyos

reviewText: I got these with the hopes that they would be more comfortable than the S10's I have.  I found that the S10's, if I left them on for more than 30 minutes, would hurt my ears alot.  The new S11-Flex does not hurt my ears at all, even after 1.5 hours of use.  I do think my S10's have a slightly better sound, but that could be due to how tight they fit my ears.  They also seem slightly lighter than the S10 headphones but that could also be me being more comfortable.  Battery seems to last awhile.  I do not like the button placement though, I find I push the wrong button all the time when I am trying to run and change a song, I end up making a call instead.  I'm sure its just me needing to practice, but it would be nice to only answer calls with my phone and change music with the headphones.  Overall, I like these alot better than others I have tried.  They are not perfec, but for working out or running, they are darn good.

reviewText: UPDATED -- 9 months laterSo I've been using these for nearly 9 months off and on. Typically when mowing the yard or kayaking on the lake. After about 9 months the rubber head band on the back broke, and shortly after the actual headband itself cracked in half. It still works, but it really isn't healthy. Did I get $100+ use out of it? I would say no, I really liked using them on the kayak and wished they help up, but after 9 months it broke, I kayak about once a week so I used it 36 times, plus add some lawn mowing so probably 50 times in 9 months before they broke, that's about a $2 per use cost. Not bad, but not worth me buying another set. I'd recommend you pass on these until they are able to make the bands stronger. Changing my star rating from 4 to 3.---------BELOW IS MY ORIGINAL REVIEW----------I like products where you use them and they fit every need you have right away. This comes close.First when I opened the package of this I was happy with the construction. These feel strong, not cheap.I liked when I turned them on it told me the estimated time remaining for the battery level, NICE!I liked that it paired really easily to my android phone.I liked the sound quality when making phone callsI liked the volume level of music even while hiking.What I didn't like...I started with this saying an estimate of 6 hours battery life. I spent 2 hours hiking listening to music. I hit the power button or so I thought. The next day I was going to use these again while cleaning up my garage and getting ready to move. I didn't want a stereo blasting as I was moving room to room... I put these on, hit the power button and nothing, apparently I either didn't turn it off even though it chimed like I thought it did or the battery died even though there was no longer a device connected... Seems like this should have an auto off if no device is connected after X amount of time... I don't understand how or why the battery died so quickly between uses.Other then that little issue, these fit good, they stay on and don't get in your way. I do like them. I just wish I could understand this battery issue better.Side note for Motorola, it would be slick (might not be practical) if these had a strip of solar panel around the band so that as you wore them they would keep charging in the sun. :)

reviewerName: Joel Avrunin "Electrical Engineer who loves S...
reviewText: I've become a common evaluator of headphones for Amazon, having evaluated quite a few high quality over the ear headphones, in-the-ear bud-style products, and also lots of single-ear bluetooth earpieces.  This is my first bluetooth wrap-around style headphone review.  Overall I am impressed, but I have a few reservations.COMFORTMost important for this class of headphones is comfort and fit.  These are behind the head style headphones that are designed to stay in even during strenuous activity.  They come with 4 different ear bud silicone inserts, but I found the ones already installed worked just fine (there are 2 smaller options a 1 bigger one over the ones installed).  The headphones form a nice seal inside the ears that doesn't feel too tight and stayed put.  Behind the head, the headphones were a little large, but there is an additional adjustable band you can install that reduces the size quite well.  Even on my larger head the headphones stayed put.  The individual buds also pivoted to adjust to exact head shape.How well did they stay put?  I decided to do a Beach Body P90X Cardio workout including Yoga and they stayed put the entire time.  Of course, they started to get a bit uncomfortable as I sweated, but it's to be expected.  The point is that they did not move despite doing floor exercises and jumping jacks.SOUNDJust as I would expect, they sound great and well balanced.  Not too hard on the bass, not too hard on the treble.  Hard rock for workouts, classical for relaxing - it all sounded great to me.  Immersive sound while outside noises were completely blocked.  I'd say my Audio Technica's or my Monster headphones with large pads are likely better sounding and fuller, but those are wired headphones with thick pads that are certainly not designed for workouts.INTERFACEThe headphones arrived partially charged (a soothing voice told me they have 4 hours of charge).  They were incredibly simple to use.  I turned them on and had them paired with my iPhone in no time.  The right ear features the power switch and volume control while the left ear has the multi-function button.  The right ear also has the LED status light and a rubber-grommeted micro-USB port for charging.  Thanks Motorola for using a standard charging port!  The package includes a wall-wart micro-USB charger as well.The place the interface suffers is in the multi-plexed switch.  Push once to pause, twice to skip forward, three times to skip back.  The instruction manual has a dozen phone features that can be activated, but you will need the manual to figure it out.  It worked, but with so much space, couldn't we get more intuitive controls and a few more buttons?BLUETOOTH RANGEUnbelievably long.  I use a Plantronics Legend with my phone and it will lose signal after a short distance.  But with the S11-Flex HD, I can put my iPhone 4 in one corner of my house and walk to the other corner of the other floor and still get great sound.  Truly impressive bluetooth range.TELEPHONE CALLSNo problem here - I made a call and the microphone picked up my voice quite well.  I was enjoying my music during a run and was able to easily take a call without missing a beat.  Noise cancellation isn't great like a dedicated headset, but for switching to a phone call without removing the headset, it works very well.BLUETOOTH FUNCTIONALITYSadly, here is where the headphones lose a star.  First, I noticed that the volume switch on the headphones doesn't send a signal to the phone to change the volume (as my Plantronics devices do), but rather changes the volume of the headset.  So if the phone volume is set low it can be impossible to get it turned up high enough using just the headset controls.  Other bluetooth headphones I have owned send the signal to the phone to change the volume.I was also disappointed that multipoint didn't work.  My Plantronics Legend is paired to both my iPhone 4 and iPad 3, both running iOS 6.0.1.  I routinely switch back and forth between them, so I know how it should work.  The Motorola paired successfully to the iPhone 4, but when I tried to pair it to the iPad, the screen said pairing was "unsuccessful", but then it showed as connected in Settings.  I had never seen that before.  Sure enough, the audio prompts in the headset said it was connected to 2 devices, but the iPad never recognized it.Switching the order, I deleted it from both devices, paired it to the iPad first and then the iPhone.  The iPad then worked fine, but when I paired to the iPhone, I got the same "unsuccessful" message.Sadly, I must report that at least for the iPhone/iPad, I could not get it to switch back and forth, even though the headset thinks it is paired to both.CONCLUSIONMotorola has done a nice job with the form factor and audio quality here.  The range is truly impressive, and the ability to keep up with the activity of P90X was truly impressive.  These would be 5 star headphones, but the clunky multiplexed interface combined with the malfunctioning multipoint force me to detract a star.  If you don't absolutely need multipoint, I recommend these headphones.UPDATE September 2013:When I wrote this review, I wasn't into running yet.  I got into running about 8 months ago, and found this headset to be amazing for my runs.  It stays put on my head and doesn't slip around.  I love having it bluetooth-paired to my iPod Nano so I can listen to music while running.  I do wish there was another switch to switch tracks though.  The multifunction switch requires you to "double click" to skip a song, which isn't always easy while running.  I also run with my iPhone and if someone calls, I am able to take the call with this headset, another nice feature.I did want to note one thing.  The bendy white plastic back of the headset started to develop cracks last month.  I could still get it on my head, but it did not hold tight.  A few other reviewers had the same issue.  I called Motorola to complain, and they replaced the headset when I explained which part broke.  It appears that this is a known issue with early models of the headset.  The new one they sent looks a bit different - both control buttons are orange (on the old one, one was orange the other was black).  I have had no issue with cracking since I got the new one.A good accessory to consider as well isOtterbox Motorola S11 Flex HD Headphone Case - Blackto protect these headphones in a gym bag.

reviewText: I've tried a few different wireless bluetooth headsets before this one, including theJaybird Sportsband Stereo Bluetooth Headphone - Bulk Packaging - Runners Redand theLG Tone Wireless Bluetooth Stereo Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Orange.  Overall, I think this is my favorite one, especially for when working out.  However, it isn't perfect.SOUND QUALITY:  Excellent.  Excellent when properly positioned, I should say.  Full sound - very loud.  I can hear it easily while running on a loud treadmill.  Unfortunately, after I've been sweating a lot, I have to make some adjustments to get the earbuds to get seated right.  I end up losing some of the bass unless they are seated just right.WEAR AND FIT: The process of putting these on does take some getting used to.  Don't give up, though.  Try it with the adjustable band, try all the different ear bud sizes.  I did and was eventually able to get it just right .  It sort of takes two hands and I had to push the top of my earlobe through the loop until I really got used to it.  Keep in mind, the band goes behind your head, not over your head.  However, I was able to lay my head back on a weight bench and it didn't get jostled or moved around at all.  Depending on your frames, if you wear glasses, it may be uncomfortable to wear these with glasses.  The area behind the ear can get crowded with your glasses and the back of the device there.  However, I am typically wearing contacts when working out, which is when I'm typically wearing these.PAIRING: I paired mine with two devices at once very easily and simply, a Droid Razr and an iPad.  It was much easier than other bluetooth phone headsets that I've used that pairs with two devices.  Here's the thing - it does depend on what you are using and which gets paired first.  I paired with the iPad first and then the Razr.  The iPad's sound/media was coming through the headset.  The Razr was able to handle the phone calls, but I was not able to play music off my phone.  When I paired with the phone first and the iPad second, I got the phone audio and the media from the Razr, but I got nothing from the iPad.  This really isn't a big deal to me.  I like that you can pair with two devices, but you have to be aware, that sometimes, you may be in a situation where just because both devices are paired, you may still need to disconnect one.PHONE CALL QUALITY:  This is much better than the Jaybird Sportband I mentioned above and about the same as the LG Tone, but still not the same as just talking on the phone.  It will get the job done, but you probably don't want to wear this headset all day or in the car while you are taking long phone calls.  Use a bluetooth device designed for phone calls.  This is more of a headphone headset, not a phone calling headset.PAIRING: I paired mine with two devices at once very easily and simply, a Droid Razr and an iPad.  It was much easier than other bluetooth phone headsets that I've used that pairs with two devices.  Here's the thing - it does depend on what you are using and which gets paired first.  I paired with the iPad first and then the Razr.  The iPad's sound/media was coming through the headset.  The Razr was able to handle the phone calls, but I was not able to play music off my phone.  When I paired with the phone first and the iPad second, I got the phone audio and the media from the Razr, but I got nothing from the iPad.  This really isn't a big deal to me.  I like that you can pair with two devices, but you have to be aware, that sometimes, you may be in a situation where just because both devices are paired, you may still need to disconnect one.OTHER:  One "neato" feature they have, for you late night or early morning runners out there, is a reflective strip so traffic coming from behind you will be able to see where you are.  It also takes the same mini-USB connector to charge as most other devices do these days.  Those Jaybird ones I tried had a special one that only works with that.  The fewer single use cords I have around the house the better.  Another thing is that I would prefer a track forward and track backward button.  Instead, it uses one button - press once for pause, twice for forward, three times for backward.PROS:GREAT sound and decent  bassDoesn't short out even with lots of sweatQuick pairingQuick ChargingVoice tells how many hours remaining on batteryPairs with multiple devicesCONS:Putting them on takes some getting used toCan be difficult to wear while wearing glassesCan easily slip out of place when sweating, requiring adjustmentsNo separate forward/backward track buttonsPairs with one device for calls and one for media, depending on the order

reviewText: Motorola people were truthful when they said "SOUND QUALITY: BEST-IN-CLASS HD AUDIO: Crystal clear highs, dynamic mid-range and body-thumping bass outperform even the best wired headphones"^^^ that is true!These headphones produce very good sound quality - it is indistinguishable from wired headset and I'm comparing them to Shure SE215-K that sound amazing.The included equalizer is very easy to change and is very useful and it does make positive difference - just press and hold the yellow multifunction button to change its settings.The charging is super fast on these - less than half an hour of charging produces over 5 hours of use - excellent!I cant comment on phone function as I never used it as I bought this only for my sporting activities.So, that being said, I have almost returned these headset because ... I couldn't find the right position for my ears/head. You see, these headphones are very - VERY - adjustable and this flexibility made it very difficult for me (they extend, rotate, headstrap extends)The left ear would, mostly, be ok, while the right one just would not properly seal the cushion making right side sound flat. I've tried all different combinations of cushions small, medium, large but still could not get the right side to seal.What did it for me is that once the earbud is in - rotate it forward - kind of making the sound driver to look toward the back of the eyes.Once I found the proper way to wear these headset for my physic - running, jumping, pull ups, push ups, bench press - nothing moves them out and they are very comfortable to wear.

reviewText: I bought them because I thought they would be an improvement over my M SD10s, which I love, but wanted to see how good these were. Nice and comfortable at first, I found I loved a couple of things. Sound seemed better than SD 10's (which is not bad at all). Also there is a voice that tells you how much battery you have left in terms of hours of use left. The other plus is the ability of these headphones to pair simultaneously with my phone and my tablet (I absolutely love this)Problem: As reported by many other reviewers, a month and a half of use (and proper care) and my beautiful headphones where torn in half. They still work but wearing them is not as comfortable as it was when they were whole. Too bad, all the nice features ruined by the lack of testing in real life use. Too bad. I am going back to the SD 10s.

reviewText: I am using these primarily for running. I have been using these for approximately two weeks now. They are comfortable and stay in place. I have always had trouble with the in ear style of headphones using the ear-buds. My ears must be an unusual shape as I have not had luck with any in-ear products. These have several ways of adjusting but I was still having a poor fit. I looked all over the internet to see if there were different types or sizes for this than the 4 sizes included. I came across a web site that had instructions for using a rubbery product sold on Amazon called Sugru. You simply fold back the end of the buds roll a small piece of this play dough type of product around the bud. Place it in your ear to set the mold. Let it sit overnight and then use. It takes the shape of your ear and stays in that shape while remaining rubbery and flexible. Now I have perfect custom designed ear buds. You can easily search the net and you tube for the step by step instructions.When the unit powers on a voice tells you the expected battery life which is a nice feature. A full charge is over 5 hours of use. I wish they could go a little louder but I expect they are plenty loud for most users. I made some tone changes on my iphone which helped.Comfort and looks I give it 5 starts.Sound and loudness it gets 4 stars.

reviewText: The Motorola S11 Wireless headset does not disappoint. The set up with very easy with my iPhone so I may listen to my playlist as I head out to my run. The band in the rear is adjustable for great comfort and more importantly for the head set to stay in place as I jog along. I have only used the blue tooth solely for my iPhone since I do not have an iPod. The headset comes with 5 adjustment points such as the band in the back, earphones and adjustments to the lengthen and rotate ear phones in each ear. The battery charge is phenomenal which takes a mere one hour. I have run in various conditions and did not find fault to any movement due to sweating or rain. The sound is very crisp and clean. I loved that the headset offered a tab to equalize the sound on the band to increase the bass if you like. There is also a vocalizer which can be set for you to take your calls. I actually took a call while on a walk and it came through with no static nor interruptions. I would highly recommend the headsets and they are an item that are know included with my running gear. I would not run without them

reviewText: As a headset enthusiast I have to say that these are well worth the price. I haven't had a ton of experience with Motorola products (aside from one pair of sport headphones I used last year) but my friend (an avid jogger) kept hassling me about trying these bad boys out for my 4 mile runs. I normally go back and forth between using my trusty Sennheiser P90X, my Sony  XBA-BT75 Armature bluetooth headset, Jaybird Freedom Set Bluetooth set and my Jabra Sport set. I love them all. I am normally not too picky between any of them since they all work great for what I need them for.The biggest perk to these would be the wireless factor. Wires become really annoying if you are a runner or jogger and the fact that these are cord-free is WONDERFUL!Second to that, the sound quality is stunning. Every song I have listened to is crisp, clear and pitch-perfect. This is a huge incentive for me and a rarity for wireless technology. I have found that wired headsets normally have a more pristine sound quality but these are outstanding. I have loved using these on my jogs and they seem to really cancel all other noises that could otherwise interfere from my experience.The battery on these suckers is fantastic as well. I have gotten around 4.5 or so hours of continual use without having to recharge them. That's a big perk. My phone doesn't even seem to last that long on continuous use!!! Amazing!!Phone call quality with these could be better but I am blaming that on my location. I have pretty bad service where I live and especially where I usually use these and hardly ever have problem-free calls. That said, these are great in areas where my sprint service has more towers and less interference. The incoming calls sound good. Not great...but good. I love that the headset informs you of incoming calls, messages and texts via a female voice.Navigation to switch over from music to calls is easy via convenient placement of function buttons on the headset. It only took me a few minutes to familiarize myself with the buttons and once that was done it was smooth sailing for me.Finally, the fit. I love the fit of these. They actually fit me great straight out of the box. I barely had to adjust them! If you need to do that though they slide  and move for more space. Very convenient and consumer friendly!Overall, I am in LOVE with these. Great wire-free headset with bluetooth! A+++++
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset is an excellent wireless headset with great sound quality and comfortable to wear. This headset is easy to use and pair with your device and the sound quality is also comparable with others. A big plus for this headset is very rapid charging time and the battery last quite a long time (6-7 hours) which is enough for most people to complete even long distance race like a marathon race.The sound volume and quality is comparable with most other wireless headset, and obviously it won't be as loud and powerful as the wired headset like Beats or Bose.I also have the Motorola SF600 wireless headset as well and I prefer the Motorolla SF11-Flex mainly because of the stiffer band. I use this for running and the more solid build than the SF600 helps and this one wear more comfotably too.Some people mentioned that their SF11 headset broke/snapped. I try to be more careful with mine after learning that and hope mine doesn't break since I like wearing this headset during my training.Overall, this is a decent headset for sport and normal day-to-day use.Sidarta Tanu

reviewText: I have owned and used extensively Motorola's S-9's, S-10HD's, and several different Jabra wireless workout headphones. They are the first Bluetooth headphones that I've felt were just as comfortable as regular sport headphones.The sound is really good, as is the Bluetooth connection.Battery life is adequate, and then some.I highly recommend these headphones.  They are comfortable, easy to use, and sound great.  You won't be disappointed.
