reviewText: This is a very nice headset for great sound quality.  The mics also works well for making phone calls.  There are 2 mics so that may be why it works so well.The battery life on these is great.  These are my go to headphones when I am doing something active like walking or working outside.That brings me to the only ding I have on these, and that is I can't wear glasses with them.  When I am at my computer, which is a lot since I am a software developer, I wear glasses.Also, on sunny days I like to wear sunglasses.  I have had to go to another set of buds at my computers and have often left these behind on sunny days.  They are great for the indoor gym and treadmill.Overall I think these are a great purchase for the sound and the call quality they deliver.
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: This is the third Bluetooth stereo headset I've owned, and it is by far the best in terms of performance and durability. The sound quality is exceptional - plenty of bass, if you can image that - and the fit and build quality is spot on. I wear this headset on the treadmill and while biking, and so far the Motorola S11-Flex headset has been impervious to sweat and movement. I even stepped on it once after taking it off and it survived the encounter without any issues. Yes, this headset is a little pricey compared to the bargain models (bargain being a relative term), but I think the overall return on investment will be excellent given the long-term survival chances of the S11-Flex.

reviewText: Ordered this from amazon to replace an older set of S10's. A lot of people complain that moisture leaks in and parts go bad after a workout.I have had a pair of these for 2 weeks now and don't have any issues to report.No love volume issues, no tears on the back of the headset. You have to make sure you find the right fit and don't force fit things that don't feel right. I don't have a small head either as I always have to buy XL hats and these feel great. I run and hour and day and also lift weights and have never had any issues with charging, bobbing, or discomfort.Before you knock them, make sure you try all the ear tips and also make adjustments as needed before your workout. Your head, ears, and neck will thank you!Bass is good, but not over powering. They do have several built in EQ settings that help. I also usually set my EQ to Electronic in my iPhone 5 to help with a little more boost with treble and bass and am very satisfied with these.

reviewText: Originally tried the LG HBS-730 Bluetooth Headset (Was HORRIBLE. Bluetooth cut out constantly even right next to the device. I tried two and they were both horrible.)Ordered this as an alternative, and OMG the Motorola S11-Flex HD is AMAZING!!!-Connection: Headset picks up a clear signal 50 feet away as long as there are no walls in between. (Far more than what's needed. A better bluetooth connection means less battery life. So I think they chose wisely.)-Sound: Quality is excellent.-Design is excellent: (I've got a rather large brain box) But note, this thing comes with different sized earbud cushions AND its setup for a very large range of adjustment. (It also fits my wife perfectly and she's got a very small noggin.)-Electronics/Software is outstanding: If its not paired it will alert you of that fact and walk you through doing so. (Not that I needed it but was still very impressive.) Once a connection is established it tells you how much play time is remaining. (Again freaking AWESOME!)-Price was VERY reasonable. (Probably going to purchase a second pair to keep at work and maybe if the wife is nice enough, another set for her.) :)-Added features: This headset can connect to TWO devices at once. Seriously understated feature. Connect to a phone and desktop computer, etc. (I have the Panasonic KX-TGA660M which allows bluetooth headsets. So now I can answer my cell phone or house phone using the same headset.)I'm ready to implant this thing. :PDon't bother with anything else. Get these now!
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: Update 01/10/2013: So my headphones have also suffered the cracking at the center of the behind-the-neck arch. Would it have killed the designers to include some metal reinforcement there? I was not using the product in any rough manner, certainly not on any marathons. Any product intended to be flexed, repeatedly, should be designed for that. This product is designed for tiny-necked people who will never stress that part of the product.Five stars for sound quality and BT reception, 1 star for horrible product design.Original review:Prior to purchasing these I was using LG's HBS-730 Tone+ headphones. I liked the sound and feel, but reception was terrible. As I'm writing this review, I am sitting in my basement about 50 feet away from my phone and getting perfect reception.I wear glasses, so the behind-ear pads are mildly disruptive and I suspect the bend in my ears may become uncomfortable if I use them all day, but I'm typically putting on and off my headphones over the course of the day, so I'm not too concerned.Play/Pause, Next Track, Last Track, and volume control are all very easy to use.I am not a huge fan of over-processing, so do not use the built-in presets, but they do work and are easy to access.The voice updates on changing/accessing features seems a bit loud, but otherwise helpful.Definitely charge to full. On a full charge (charging light solid green), the headphones state "more than 5 hours" of battery time.The LED light is completely unobtrusive, so will not interfere with daily use.They seem just the right tightness; should have no issues if using in high-movement activities.Will update review if the need arises, but as of right now, very satisfied with these.
title: Motorola S11-Flex HD Wireless Stereo Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/White

reviewText: While not perfect, this has quickly become my favorite headset for sports and other non-ideal conditions. However, for audiobooks, with everyday conditions, the Motorola S305's are still my favorite. Yes, despite the multiple Jabra headsets I own, the three Motorola sets I own are my favorite (HX550 headset being the third)Pros:Adjustable, for a great fit, for just about anyone. Seriously, the ways you can adjust this were very well thought out.Sturdy! Given my last point, adjustable, you would think that would add points of failure, but this is one solid feeling headset.Water resistant. What good would a sports headset be if it wasn't water resistant? No, I wouldn't go swimming with it, but it keeps on rockin' in a light rain.Best reception ever! Seriously, I forgot I had put my phone down, walked up a flight, across my house, and noticed it started to fade. Beats all my other sets.Noise isolating (not cancelling). The adjustability does a great job of letting those buds block out a great deal of outside noise. A great feature for any workout environment (except maybe running/biking on the road)Comfortable. A lot of headsets just aren't comfortable on me, and I don't care what else is right with a headset, if they are not comfortable, you just won't wear them.Cons:Because of the way it goes around the back of the head, it gets in the way when doing any exercises that require you to lie on your backLack of controls. The Motorola S305's are the king of controls. I have yet to see anything come close. This pair has a volume up/down, and play. Yes, you can use the play button for... well, everything else, with multiple presses. But it's hardly convenient.Sound quality is ok, nothing great.

reviewText: I was at first a little put-off by the somewhat bulky design of this headset (it goes around the back of your head), but they stay on like no other! reviewText: I listen to all types of music and these headphones perform very well. They fit better than my old motorola s-10s and the sound is better. There are plenty of good review here about the sound and quality so I just want to point out a couple minor problems I've experienced.I'm well experienced with different gadgets so when something really new comes along I'm certainly taking a look at the instructions, here the first problem. The instructions are not well written. Namely the use of the multi-function button (MFB) and how to wear them. This is really laughable, the picture on how to wear them in the instruction book is actually less than 1/2 inch square. Ok, so I figured that out without too much of a problem but then there's the MFB...Here, the instructions say hold in the MFB until you hear the voice options to make adjustments. I had to look this up because the bass was way too bass(y). Ok, I hear the voice but that's it. Nowhere does it say HOW or WHAT to do when you hear the selections. I looked online with no luck so eventually I called customer support and I was pleasantly surprised to get a representative in just a couple of minutes. That's where it ended! No matter how I explained it, the rep didn't understand what I wanted to do and the actual functioning of the the now (as I call it) the MF Button. After about 10 minutes I got disconnected from that rep and I did call back and quickly got another rep who was equally clueless as the the functioning of the settings. Eventually and incorrectly I might add, she told me that the button was supposed to bring up a menu on the phone to make those adjustments. With that piece of information I ended the call and started to consider returning the set. A week later I thought I would give CS one more chance and again, I quickly got a rep and just as before, the rep was clueless but this rep elevated the problem to tier 2 support for which I was supplied with an 800 number and told to give them a call, which I did.Unfortunately, the 800 number was worthless. No matter what buttons I pushed I could never reach a person of any any kind, much less any tier 2 support. (thanks to motorola for wasting 20 minutes of my time here). The good news was that after tinkering with the set during all of this I figured out how to work the MF button:To start the menu you press and hold and a voice will start going through the menu and when you hear eq setting you want, release the button. Yeah, it's that simple. I expect that for 100+ dollars that one sentence could have been put in the instructions. The differences are very subtle but that is how it works. So when you get yours I hope you find this helpful!

reviewText: I've had S9's, S10's, and now these. The sound is very clear, the battery charges in 15-20 mins, it uses the same charger as my phone (Galaxy S3), the controls are VERY intuitive, and the range is a decent improvement over the S10's. It took me a little while to find the right ear pieces to fit my ears and they take a second to adjust to my head but other than that I have no complaints. I cut grass with these on, on a commercial lawn mower, and they're definitely loud enough. I bought the Otterbox case for mine, which fits the charger and headphones nicely.

reviewText: Initially I wasn't happy with the purchase: didn't think fit was good, controls are limited, so-so mic. I still think they could've put extra buttons for next/play/previous (now you have to double click for next and triple for previous) but good sound quality beats it. I have $120 wired earbuds and sound is comparable, my ears burned into motorola I guess. Anyway, my biggest concern was slight buzzing sound in the right ear on the background of treble. I requested replacement and the other one had the same issue. Seems that it goes away after some time (~20hr of listening), probably burn in. At least I couldn't hear lately, keeping my fingers crossed. I like that they have micro usb charging port, same as my phone, convenient. Advice: don't fall into cheap $40ish BT headphones unless you hate the music you listen to. -1 star for only 5hr battery, lack of controls and so-so mic.

reviewText: This works very well for charging a single cell phone back to full power. It is very light, thin, and easily transported. I do really love the form factor which is minimal. However the primary issues I have are similar to others - firstly this thing runs out of juice fairly quickly. I have another portable charger and on that one I really can charge multiple devices. The cons to it are that it is big and bulky so not handy for everyday carrying around. Secondly, for me, it did not do so well at charging two things at once. I have a LG cell Phone and my daughter has an older Gravity T phone and it seemed to take a long time and didn't charge both fully. Thirdly is that cord issue - you basically have to carry a cord with you as there is no built in plug in it. That's not very convenient and some of that nice thin form I love gets lost if I have to toss in a cord as well.Overall it charges a cell phone back to power well but that's it. No more. It doesn't work for the new IPOD due to the cable requirement - meaning I now have to carry two cables if I want to recharge an IPOD and my cell. It does take a while itself as a unit to fully charge up. As a one shot deal in an emergency it does what it says it does which makes it o.k. I'm just used to additional functionality and this doesn't have it.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This portable power pack is extremely useful for travelling or other times when you might need an extra charge.  It's very small, compact, and light, which makes it easy to bring along on trips or while commuting.  Its power cord is built in, which is handy because it means it's not necessary to pack additional cords.  Recharging my phone takes only 20 minutes or so, and less of course if I only need a small charge.  It also works with both regular USB and micro USB devices, which means it will charge just about any device you own.  If you are someone who periodically finds yourself with a dead phone or tablet, this will definitely make your life easier.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: So, I am having trouble figuring out how people are getting this to work with the newer Apple products. I know for sure that this portable charger is not compatible with the new Ipad Mini because1)It uses the Lightning port, and2)I tried doing it myself.This brings me to another point. Iphone 5 uses the same lightning interface for charging purposes. I am assuming that to achieve this, you have to buy some sort of Lightning to Micro USB adapter?However, this power pack works well with other products that uses the Micro USB port. It can bring an almost dead Samsung Galaxy to about 85% charge within an hour. It also fits nicely in your pocket, so I suggest you give it a go.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Overall, the power pack is a decent product, but for the money, not so much. There's an organization called WakaWaka that is in process of making a solar-powered unit to charge your phones and whatnot. No wall adapters necessary! All solar! Right now their only product on Amazon is theWakaWaka Solar Lamp, but be on the lookout for the solar charger around May 2013.Pros:- Quality-made products. I really like Motorola and have other Motorola accessories.- Lightweight and not at all bulky. I can toss this into a bag or glove box in the car and it's accessible.- Charges mySamsung Galaxy S IIIin a matter of an hour or two.Cons:- Doesn't seem to have much battery life.- You'll need an adapter to charge this, and while on the go it becomes a pain when the battery runs out of juice. This is a letdown.Not sure:- Since I haven't yet tried, I don't know if this would be able to charge a tablet or lap top very well.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've owned several of these portable chargers and this is really one of the best, size wise. It's small enough to fit into your pocket, which is really nice. A lot are kind of big. Great if you carry around a large purse or briefcase, but not so great if you don't.It has the little "universal" port built-in. Awesome for your standard Android phone or Kindle. It charges the phone really fast too! If nearly everything you own has the universal port, then you're in good shape here. All of my stuff does, so this is perfect for me. The problem becomes if you have an iPhone or something that uses a different port. You then have to use the USB cord. Not a huge problem except now you have to carry around this great little charger AND a cord. It kind of defeats the purpose, I think.So, this is a trade off. For me, it's perfect. It's small and has the charger connector built in that I need. I can charge two things at once by using a cord. The phone charges super fast, but my tablet took a little longer.It really depends on what you need. For me, I'd totally slip this into my pocket/bag for an evening out when I wanted to pack light. For a multi-day conference, I'd likely bring a larger one with a little more power and multiple ports (more than one iPhone friend has borrowed some power from me!)
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: .USB battery packs keep your power-crazed smartphone satisfied while on the go.Many brands to choose from. Prices are bouncy and coming down.This Motorola P4000 (4000 mAh) is about perfect if the price drops below $30. Until then, best to check out thePowerGen 6000mAh, or theAnker 4500mAh.I'll update this review if the price gets friendly. (I've set a price alert at camelcamelcamel. Google it and set your own email alerts for any amazon product.)The imbedded Micro-USB cable is a big plus. Save space. No tangle, mess, or leaving behind. I use it with my iPhone, thanks to aLenmar Micro-USB-to-Apple-30-pin Converter Tip.PROs:* Thin and light (4.25 oz, 0.40" thick)* Imbedded cable eliminates multiple hassles- Fit and finish: Good. Looks and feels like quality.- Power-in: Standard Micro-USB connector - 42" cable includedOKs:- 4000 mAh capacity is good for about 1-1/2 iPhone charges (see Note 1)- The imbedded cable is heavy duty. Requires some effort to press into its notch.- 1.5-amp output: Charges some tablets faster than competing models- Textured surfaces are neither glossy nor rubberizedCONs:* Poor value when priced over $30- Listing copy is misleading in places (see Note 2)- - - Notes - - -Note 1: Motorola claims two 90% charges of a "1450 mAh average smartphone battery." That's 1.8 full charges, but my test gave only 1.53 full charges of my iPhone 4S battery (1432 mAh). It charged from 13.8% --> 100% + 29.3% --> 96.0%.Note 2: "Charges the average smartphone battery up to 2 times and powerful enough to charge your tablet" actually means (according to the footnote on the box) it will provide two 91% charges of a typical (1432 mAh) iPhone battery. Most current Android phones have larger batteries. It will charge a Samsung Galaxy S3 (2100 mAh battery) less than 1-1/4 times. It will boost an iPad 3 battery about 25% of one full charge.~~~ Comments & questions welcome ~~~
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I bought this because my phone and tablet kept going dead.  This works great.  It will charge them both twice before having to recharge this battery pack.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This device is a battery designed to recharge any portable electronic device that you charge via a USB cable. I got it for charging my iPhone and iPad when I'm on the road. You make sure the power pack has a good charge in it, then you plug in your device (don't forget to bring a USB cable) and you're good to go. (It also includes a built-in micro USB cable, which I did not use.)I had an older model of the same device, and it's worked well, but the battery charge was pretty limited. This new device is a definite improvement over that, with additional battery time. It'll charge up a smart phone approximately twice, which is very handy. It'll even power up a tablet, although you won't get nearly as much battery life.The power pack is surprisingly small -- about the size of a smartphone itself. The size hasn't increased appreciably from the earlier models, even though it holds a lot more charge.A great thing to have around!
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is the second portable device charger I have tried the first being theInnergie 2.1 Amp 3,000 mAh Pocket Cell Portable Rechargeable Battery Pack and Charger with included Magic Cable 3-in-1 with Micro USB, Mini USB and 30-pin iPod / iPhone Connectors, a product that I personnaly prefer to this one. I will compare the two devices as I review this charger.Size: an important consideration as you may be carrying both in your pocket with your phone is charging, the Innergie is smallet and connects on the end so the cable allows it to bend and fit side by side in you pocket. The Motorola has a built in cable that may work well for Android phone, but is useless for my iPhone 3Gs (I know, I'm upgrading soon and then the Innergie cable will be useless as I get stuck with Apple's proprietary cable connectors, sigh). The Motorola USB connection is on the side of the device so carrying it while charging is much less convenient, as it will not line up with my phone, making for a bulky combination in my pocketCharge: the Innergie required 3-4 hours to get a full charge and offered about 1.5 full charges to my iPhone, the Motorola takes 5-6 hours to charge and offers about 2 full charges to my iPhone, neither is capable of fully charging my iPad retina.Plugs, Connecters, Lights: the innergie comes with a cord with multiple connecter types, the Motorola has the built in micro USB connecter but no USB cord for charging. Both chargers are equipped with USB in and out connections and both offer status lights to display remaining charge on the chargerOverall, I find the Innergie more suitable for use with my iPhone and the Motorola seems more usable with an Android style smart phone.P-)
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: So in addition to this portable power pack we also have themyCharge Peak 6000 Rechargeable Power Bank.  It's hard not to compare the two.  This is definitely a good portable power pack.  It's very small, fitting easily into a purse or even a pocket (we recently took ours to Disneyland because our phones drain really quickly when using the pedometer and phone both so this keeps it charged - it was kept in my husband's pocket).Unlike the myCharge it doesn't come with a way to charge it in a wall outlet - USB only.It doesn't let you know that it is actually charging the devices (you'll have to rely on any battery displays on the devices themselves) where as the myCharge actually announces via a voice that it is now charging x device.This comes with a micro-USB cable and two USB ports where as the myCharge has a micro-usb cable, usb cable, and an apple cable.Size wise this definitely has an advantage and is a good battery.  If we somehow lost both of these power packs we'd be bummed and would go with the myCharge Peak as a replacement before this one, though we'd not be disappointed if we were really in a bind and this one was all we could find.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I have a Droid Razr M. It fully charges my phone, but I don't think it would charge my phone twice completely. When it fully charges my phone, there is probably 30-40% charge left on charger. It is the first motorola charger that I own that completely charges my phone, though. It is a little large, but it's as expected to be able to hold a large enough charge. Would recomend if you are looking for a portable charger to fit in your pocket. Is around the same size of my phone.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a decent charger and good for travel.  I liked how thin it is and thought it would work great for bike rides to keep my iPhone charged and it does.  However, it's almost a little too wide to fit nicely in the underseat pack I have on my bike.  With the iPhone USB charger plugged in, the device becomes even wider as there is only one USB outlet and it's on the long side.  Would have been nice to have it on the thinner end or an optional second one there.With the USB cable from my iPhone 5 plugged into the side I have to set the battery in the underseat pack at an angle.  I wasn't too keen on this thinking that it would bend my iphone charging cable and damage it so I tried to remove the cable and alas, it is permanently stuck into the thing!  I've tried just about everything short of taking the unit apart or using pliers to grip it out.  So now I have a permanent lightning charger in this and can't use the USB port for any of my other USB devices - unless, of course, they charge with the lightning adapter or use microUSB.  ** SEE MY UPDATE BELOW**As far as charging goes, this works well.  After charging the phone completely to 100% the battery pack will shut down as it's apparently no longer charging so goes into auto-shut-down mode to conserve its power.  So if you've left your device plugged into it, it will also stop charging and begin to rundown its battery if you have it turned on.I also have theNew Trent iTorch IMP52D 5200mAh External Battery Chargerand frankly I would recommend it over the Motorola P4000.  Both work fine for the intended purpose, but the New Trent seems to last longer on a single charge (it has 5200mAh while the Motorola is 4000mAh) and the charging outlets are on the end, it's narrower than the Motorola and, best of all, my cable does not get stuck so I can use it for several different devices that connect to power via USB.So I'd give this a higher star rating if my cable wasn't now permanently attached to it and if it had a USB port/outlet on the smaller end.**UPDATE 12/23/2012**I have raised this to a 3 star review because, thanks to a comment from "Gadget Grant"  I was able to remove the cable!  I have added photos so you can refer to those if your USB cable gets stuck.  I also tried other cables in this device and so far the only ones that get stuck are the Apple Lightning cables (used to charge my iPhone 5 and my boyfriend's new iPad mini.  so apparently this issue is not Motorola's, but Apples. Although, I must say that so far this is the only usb outlet I"ve had trouble with the cable getting stuck, and I've had it plugged into other USB hubs, my Macbook Pro, my Mac Pro, a USB wall charger (non-apple), and the NewTrent battery mentioned above - all with no problem getting it back out of the device.So, if your cable gets stuck, see the photos on how to remove it using a thin piece of plastic.  I used a Solo cup which worked like a champ - tried an old credit card but that was too thick.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack is very handy to have when you are desperate to charge your phone, and there is no power available.  As the owner of a smartphone with a very short battery life, I know the value of having an extra way to charge my phone. Now, I can just carry the portable power pack in my purse, and always know that I have extra power on hand if needed.The power pack comes equipped with a handy mini USB cable that is attached to the body of the device, which fits smoothly inside a groove for easy, out of the way storage.  I really like this feature, since I'm notorious for forgetting to bring along an extra cable.The power pack itself does not come with an adapter. Instead, it comes with a separate USB cable that will plug into your current Droid or iPhone/iPad/iPod charging adapter.  The pack charges up relatively quickly itself.When charging my phone, it does not charge as fast as plugging in to an outlet, but it gets the job done in a relatively short amount of time.The power pack has an additional USB port, allowing the possibility of charging your phone and an additional phone or other device at the same time.  However, I attempted to charge my iPad 3 and smartphone at the same time, and the iPad would not charge.  After unplugging the phone, the iPad would then receive a charge.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This charger is so slim - great for travel.  Also - the cord that comes out of it makes having to carry a phone's charger unneccessary. (YAY!)  I can see when this unit is fully charged and the BEST part is that it turns itself off when whatever device it is charging is full.  I will have to see how long the P4000's charge lasts - but after charging a phone and a bluetooth headset - I still show a full battery - so I am hopeful that this will be exactly what I need while traveling.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a really nice power pack, the best one that I have ever used. As with most Motorola products, build quality is excellent. The device is extremely slim so it can fit in your skinny jeans next to your phone, but it still packs a huge 4000mAh of battery power. Modern high powered smartphones usually have 1500 to 2000mAh batteries, so this power pack should recharge those twice. The 8W power output is high enough to charge tablets, unlike most lesser devices.The size is especially surprising. This thing is only 0.3 inch thick. 4000mAh power packs from other brands that I have seen are twice the size and won't easily fit in to your pants pocket like this one. The built-in micro-USB cable is a big feature; you never loose the cable and it does not add any bulk. With most power packs, you have to carry an extra and bulky cable with you, which is likely not going to fit in your pants pocket along with your phone and the charger. I also own a 10000mAh Anker power pack (for multi-day trips) and that is a much larger unit; 3 or 4 times the size of this Motorola when you include the cable.Some nice features of this device are automatic on/off so the battery won't run down when nothing is attached (as many cheap power packs will). The power test button is recessed into the side of the device so you can't accidentally activate it. A micro-USB cable is conveniently built in to the charger so you can never lose it. If you're charging an oddball device that doesn't use micro-USB, there is also a full-sized USB port so you can plug in your own cable.Yes, the price is more than what a generic 4000mAh power pack would cost, but I think the you get what you pay for with the quality level and super-thin size. If your smartphone or tablet burns a lot of power (like most 4G devices do these days) and you're going to be away from a wall socket all day and your device doesn't accept spare batteries (an unfortunate trend), then this is a great device to carry with you. You can even charge 2 devices at the same time, which is great way to meet people at the airport :)
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Some important specs :4000 mAH capacity1.6 mA maximum charging current (will charge devices that can handle higher currents faster)Can charge 2 devices at the same time (not mentioned, but I assume combined current is 1.6 mAH)Can charge other devices while itself is being rechargedLong description :This charger at first glance looks like a phone, and even weighs about as much as one. I've had a few people glance at me when I'm holding it, asking me what phone is that. It's shape makes it easy to hold together with the phone, or fit into your pocket if you're not wearing tight jeans, while connected to your phone and charging it. Among the 3 chargers I have, this is the only charger that can do that easily.The size is also its drawback. Battery technology means that you can only fit so much capacity into that size. The unit is rated at 4000 mAH. In reality, due to loss from multiple conversions and inefficiencies in charging batteries, you will not be able to get the full capacity. For example, my cell phone has a 1750 mAH battery. One would assume this means I can recharge my phone from empty to full more than twice from a fully charged power pack. In reality, I could only recharge it slightly less than 1.5 times. This is not a flaw, it is typical with all external battery packs.The 1.6 amp current output (8W) will recharge some devices faster than typical chargers this size, which are usually capable of only supplying 1 amp. For example, the Kindle Fire HD (which can take up to 2 amps for faster recharging) will charge about 60% faster with this compared with a 1 amp charger. Note that the capacity of this cannot fully recharge a Kindle Fire HD, but will provide you with an additional couple of hours of use. The extra current will not damage devices that cannot make use of it - devices will only draw what they need.The micro USB plug is nice to have, and means you may not have to bring a cable with you. The flat cable is held securely along the side of the unit by friction, and is about 6 inches long when pulled out all the way. On the side is one USB type A port for charging a second device (use your own cable), a micro USB port for charging the power pack from any USB power source, and a button. Press the button and the white LEDs on the unit (4 of them, on the front flat side, near the switch) will light up indicating the state of charge. A micro USB cable is provided, and you can use it either to charge a second device (that uses micro USB, obviously) or to use it for charging the power pack.The finish on the unit is a nice minimalist matte black. There's a very fine texture on the surface, and it feels smooth. The surface appears to mar easily (I had it in a bag with some other devices, and now there's some faint white marks I can't get rid of.Using it is extremely simple. Plug a device (phone, tablet, etc.) to it and it will start charging the device. Unplug and it stops. Plug a USB power source to its micro USB port, it will start recharging itself. There's circuitry built in for it to stop charging external devices when its charge gets too low (to prevent damage to its battery from over discharging). You can recharge the P4000 while you're charging another device from it - this is not true for all portable power packs. For example, the Anker Astro 5600 will not supply power to the charging port while it is being recharged. This is convenient because you don't need to switch cables - just plug everything in, let it recharge, and come back to check a couple of hours later.Without considering the price, I would have rated this 5 stars for an attractive appearance, good design, convenient shape, and extremely easy to use. However I feel that at $80 it is rather expensive, hence the 4 star rating.Additional notes for DIYers (not factored into rating) :I got a Raspberry Pi, and I wondered if this can function as a UPS for the Pi (spoiler : no). Basically, I want something that will pass through power to the Pi, but if the power supply is interrupted, I want it to seamlessly switch over to battery, and when power is restored, go back to the power supply (while recharging the battery).The P4000 is NOT SUITABLE for this purpose. While it looks good on paper, the problem is that when I connect or disconnect the cable from the USB wall charger to the P4000, the P4000 will briefly interrupt the power to the Pi for 1 to 2 seconds. This is not a problem for charging devices, but it is long enough to cause the Pi to reboot.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I really REALLY love this device!  I'm all about making my life easier and this sure comes in handy for charging devices on the go.  I use this all of the time and it provides reliable service.We have family that live out-of-state and we try to visit whenever possible and long drives with small boys contained in a car is not much fun without plenty of distractions.  These distractions usually start running out of juice the last 1-2 hours of the trip and this device saves the day.  I love how it provides the extra charge needed for an iPad, iTouch or iPhone.  It also takes Samsung and Creative devices.  Recently, I was without power for 12 days (Sandy) and when I charged my devices directly to an alecetrical outlet, I also charged this devise which would provide extra power.  This was key in keeping my family happy.Powering this up to a full charge takes as much time as other chargers and it holds a charge for 3 weeks and counting without any use.  I consider this a plus since my last one would slowly leak power if not used.  The slim design and small size makes it convenient and easy to store.I recommend this charger as it accepts quite a few different devices and holds a solid charge for later use but a price drop would make it perfect.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This portable charger is lightweight and truly portable. It charges my kindle and any other micro USB device without an additional wire since it has that in-built. It has a USB slot and to charge this device, you can use any micro USB cable and attach it to a wall plug (not included with this.) Addtionally, you can put your iphone usb cable in that slot to charge it as well. It does charge two devices at the same time. The battery has an indicator with 4 being the maximum and once I charged my iPhone, it only went down one level in terms of battery. This all worked out well and would have been a 5 star product had my iphone cable not gotten stuck in it. I called Motorola and they have said they have never heard of this problem and so they cannot help me!! I'm now stuck with a charger which does work but my iphone cable is now stuck in it forever and the usb slot is now unusable too! This problem told me volumes about the kind of company this is. For me, it's a lesson for life- Beware of Motorola!
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This backup battery does a great job charging my portable devices because it is powerful. It is appropriately sized for having so much charging capability (not so tiny as something you'd put in a shirt pocket, but not cumbersome at all).I am a power traveler which means I am on the road at least two nights per week usually in different cities which means lots of planes, rental cars, and hotels. I already used a similar device that I purchased several years ago but it is much weaker than this device. For example, my old device could only charge one thing before needing to be recharged. The device I am reviewing can charge two or three gizmos before needing recharging (Android phone, bluetooth headset,... no iPad though).It works by plugging into your phone's (or other device) charging port and transferring power to it just like you had your phone plugged into a normal wall or car charger. You disconnect the charger once it is done and stash it back in your travel bag until another gizmo needs juice. I typically recharge this product overnight so it is ready the next day. I recommend it if you are always dealing with low battery power - it's been very helpful to me.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've tried a couple different types of battery backups for my iPhone and this one is far and away the best I've seen. I also had a New Trent, but it would shut itself off periodically and not charge my phone completely. This one charged my phone very quickly and was able to recharge it again a couple days later. It also charged my iPad pretty quickly. It's thin and easy to pack away... Not only can it charge tow devices at the same time, but it can also recharge itself while still plugged into the existing  device. there is no excuse for ever running out of phone charge when you have a device like this handy. the Motorola is better in every way.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Pretty much a run-of-the-mill iPhone/iPad/cell phone charger, this.  But it works, it's small and light, and I can't complain.  There is a certain weird irony that it's made by Motorola, former king of the cell phone industry, with the RAZR.  We are using cheap Motorola hardware to charge expensive iPhones.  But that's the creative destruction of technology innovation.The unique aspect of this battery is the second micro-usb plug which allows you to charge two devices at once.  As many devices as I have, I can't recall many instances where I wanted to charge two at once (although I certainly have been caught using two at once).But you know what? This thing works, it's thin and light, and saves the day when your iPad or iPhone runs out of juice.  Until they come up with fuel cells that last for 6 months in the iPhone 15, this is the next best thing.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is my 4th portable power pack (long story) and I think it's my new favorite.The big thing is the integrated power cord.  Every other power pack has required me to carry a separate cable which, even if it's a retractable, is still one more thing to have stuffed in my pocket.  The size is perfect, being about the same dimensions as a smartphone.  It's only 4000 mAh, putting it a little on the medium-small side of power packs but that's still enough to charge most phones 3+ times.  It's also light weight (attn: bikers, hikers, joggers).I do worry about what happens if that cable wears out.  I've found quite a lot of USB cables start to separate after just a few months.  This one looks better constructed with the cable head being fully enclosed, so hopefully it won't pull apart like the others but only time will tell (if this review is more than a few months old then apparently it's still doing okay because otherwise I'd come back to update this review!)  It does have a second power output slot, though, which takes a regular USB cable (included in box) so if the main cable does go bad, you've still got that secondary slot.  You can also charge two things at once (if you carry that additional cable around with you).You'll still need a cable to recharge it but that's fine -- at least I don't have to carry around with me all day.I like my old Energizer power pack too, but it's short and fat -- a bit too bulgy for a jeans pocket -- and while the magnetically attached cable on it was cool, it's not as cool or convenient as the integrated cable in this Motorola pack.Solid win here.  (Edit: Also works well with my Kindle Fire.  Went to do some reading at lunch today and realized I'd let my Fire run down to 6% power.  Plugged this charger into it and went on my merry way, reading while it charged.)
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: The Motorola P4000 is a great portable charging device!  With a mirco USB cable connection, I plug my HTC Evo Shift right into it, and charge away: it works like a charm!  I recently traded in my Android for a new smartphone, otherwise that would have been a great other device to charge on this: this also works with my hands free head set, and I LOVE having a portable device for when I can't use a car charger or wall plug: what a gret device!  I would highly recommend this Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power pack!
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Pros:- It's so small you won't even notice it in your bag.- In a cellphone emergency this will get you out of a pinch.Cons:- It doesn't seem to have much juice; it can charge my Samsung Galaxy S3 from near death (around 5% charge) to about 75% in a couple hours, then the power pack dies. I haven't even bothered trying to charge a laptop with it; it would just be too slow and wouldn't be able to charge much at all, not to mention I'd need a USB adapter. If I had an iPhone instead, I'd also need to buy a separate adapter. Inconvenient.- The design is odd and not too user friendly: there are no markings on the outside of it. E.g., which ports are for charging the bank itself, and which for charging other devices? This isn't a trivial question because Motorola placed one of each kind right next to each other with no indication of which is which.- My biggest gripe is that when I'm out and about and end up needing the power pack to charge up my phone, the power pack dies and I have no way to charge it on the go. I can't plug it in at Starbucks without having to carry an adapter or two (which defeats the point of this device being small and convenient to carry). If I were going to be away from home for a few days, I'd definitely want something else that's more flexible.In the end I feel that there are better options available, as the small size of this one doesn't offset the inconvenience of needing to buy and carry separate adapters to charge anything other than my phone.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: We needed this powerpack because we use our iPads and iPhone a lot for work, and I often find myself out of juice by the end of the day. Other powerpacks have been just okay, but this one is great.For one thing, it's very small and light - like the size of an iPhone but way lighter and wafer thin. It can easily fit into a pocket. It has a micro USB cable attached to its side which perfectly fit my husband's Nokia cell phone. The device itself also has a USB port and that's what you would use to attach the cable from your iPad or iPhone.It powered up our devices in record time and it still had plenty of power left in it. (You can tell by the number of lights lit on it - 4 is full strength.) It also powered itself up fast, and it turns off automatically when not in use to preserve energy.I am very VERY happy with this it's so light and small that we keep it with us all the time.Highly recommended.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've tried several portable chargers and this one is by far the best.  It's lightweight, convenient to keep with me, and it works.  I like the built in plug -- the portable chargers with a bagful of adapters are so inconvenient.  I was put off some by the price tag but it does the job that it's intended to do and that makes it worth it.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I've got quite a collection of rechargeable power products, from the ill-fated Zagg Sparq 2 to a noname 3800maH pack that works reasonably well, to a teensy 800maH "Eveready" brand charger that is pretty wimpy.  The Motorola P4000 Portable Power Pack is better in many ways than all of these. First of all, it is slim - about the size of an iPhone 5 or of many Android phones. Sleek in appearance, an integrated cord with MicroUSB plug wraps around two sides of the device and fits in flush to the edges.  On the long edge are a standard USB "B" jack, a MicroUSB jack (used to charge the internal battery) and an on-off button, all recessed slightly. A short USB "B" to MicroUSB cord is included.To charge the Power Pack, connect the cord to a USB power source and plug in the MicroUSB end to the recessed jack. While it is charging, you can use either or both of the USB B jack and the integrated MicroUSB cord to power one or two devices.  The Power Pack automatically stops charging itself once full.Of course, the real purpose of such a product is to charge your portable device away from AC power. While Motorola doesn't say explicitly, the reference to 4000 in the model number leads me to believe that the battery capacity is 4000maH.  The size of the battery is about right for that, but I could be completely off. Motorola talks about an 8W charging rate, or 1600ma current. This will charge most tablets, and smaller devices will charge faster than from a standard 500ma USB2 jack.I like how sleek the power pack is - it easily slips into a pocket or briefcase. You do need an external power source to charge it, but you probably already have several of those.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: This is a great little product.  Its is size just right.  It is very thin, fits in a shirt pocket easily if needed.  It is lightweight and easy to carry.  I use it to charge my iPhone.  One charge on this device can fully charge my iphone and still have some juice left.  It is perfect for those days when you are running from meeting to meeting and can't find an outlet and don't have your laptop to charge your phone from.  It holds a charge for a while to as sometimes it sits in my bag for a couple weeks between uses.  It has a great capacity for its thickness and weight (like I said a full iphone charge plus).  It has a USB port to you can charge just about any phone with it including iPhones and Androids, as well as flip phones if they can be charged with a cable that fits a standard USB port.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Pros - I like the power button that shows whether it has a charge and how much charge is left.  I like the versatility that we can use it with different products (we have so many in our three-person family!).  I like that it holds a good amount of power and will charge my iPad.Cons:  For the price, I would have expected this item to come with a wall plug for the micro-usb power input.  I was able to use my iphone's wall outlet with a standard usb-usb cord, but it just seems to me if you have a dedicated micro-usb input, that you could include a wall adapter for that micro-usb input when there's an $80 price tag.The unit arrived with only one battery light still lit, which makes me think the power off button doesn't really prevent the battery from draining - even though the literature says it's not supposed to drain when off.  Time will tell how long this holds a charge, and I will update this review in a few weeks.Update:  It does hold a charge well and it does charge my devices.  It's nice and lightweight, comparatively.  I have a small pouch I keep it in which doesn't take up much room in my purse.One thing that's annoying is it has taken one of my iPhone lightning cords hostage.  It simply won't let go.  I'm afraid if I pull any harder it will ruin the cord and the battery pack.  So it's now only suitable to charging newer Apple devices.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power PackThe P4000 is very similar to the P793.  They both fit the following criteria below.  I could not get the mAh out of Motorola chat to know specifically why the P4000 is considered more "beefy" than the P793.  It is larger, the same size as my DroidX as opposed to the P793 which fits on the screen of the Droid.  The "chat" person said it has greater charging capacity.  Motorola claims you can even charge your tablet with the P4000.  It does NOT come with an AC charger.  You can use your AC phone charger to charge it or the included USB cable.  It will charge your phone much quicker than the P793.  I guess I can't give it a raving review because I can't accurately determine how much better it is than the P793.  If it is more than twice as quick or will charge more devices, it may be worth the double and some price tag of $79.99 at Amazon.  Frankly I haven't seen a huge difference between the two units.  If you need more juice, go with the P4000, otherwise the P793 seems more than adequate.The rest of this is applicable to both the P793 and the P4000 but if you read my review on the P793, you can stop here.Like many of us, I have found myself increasingly dependent on my phone.  I get positively paranoid if I forget my phone on my desk.  My palms get sweaty when I find my self evaluating the time left on my phone battery.  I feel the remaining time in excruciating detail as I wait for my life to go black!  Reading his over, I am increasingly despondent on how fixated I have become on cellular reception.  It isn't just to chit chat, Oh No!, nothing as simple as chit chat.I want to find the best price on gasoline with GasBuddy.  I want to check on Roethlisberger's condition.  Arrghh! I want to check the stock market or ball game score and I can't do any with a DEAD battery.There is hope and it isn't expensive.  This is the perfect item when you find yourself charger-less.  Those of you who have never, ever left your charger someplace you wish you hadn't may cast the first stone. Otherwise, button up and be aware there is a simple solution.  This little fellow is smaller and thinner than my DroidX and will recharge it while I am using it.  It seems to have double the strength of the battery on the Droid.  For $27.69 at Amazon, you can slip this in your briefcase, jean's pocket or duct tape it to the back of your phone and have TWICE as long to stay connected.  Motorola P793Universal and portable, the P793 is a power pack that can simultaneously charge multiple devices, including mobile devices like the iPhone, Bluetooth headsets, and MP3 players. With 1420 mAh capacity, the P793 can provide up to an additional five hours of talk time.It has a single micro USB connector that will fit many items besides your phone and a standard USB if you have your charging cable.  It charged to full charge in less than two hours.  This would make a great stocking stuffer.  Four star only because I really can determine if it is worth more than 2x the price of the P793.  BTW it took over 4 hours to charge this for the first time.
title: Motorola P4000 Universal Portable Power Pack - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I owned this phone for a week, it has a nice size but I had to return it because it randomly rebooted itself.  And that is just not acceptable if you are in the middle of a conversation.  It does not have much memory and a lot of apps cannot be placed on the 4gig sdcard that comes with it so I just could not use it.  I do not know if that is a problem with this particular phone the rebooting but it was a major problem with the one I had.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: I purchased this phone for my brother at Walmart.  He has T-Mobile service and I knew this phone would work, even though the Walmart folks said it would not.  The phone cost $100 and it runs Android. It does not have a ton of memory but it is responsive.  A 2 gig card was included and many of the apps can be moved on to the card.He checks email, uses only a few apps and texts like crazy.It is difficult to find a smartphone for $100 or less so it is certainly a good value.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: The biggest issue that I've encountered has irritated me to no end. Despite having an SD card slot for more data memory it is USELESS. I encountered a storage problem a couple days into using the phone. I kept receiving error message " insufficient memory" on several apps.  I did not even have that many applications (I had 7 to be exact, that I had downloaded).  I decided I just need to get a bigger SD card ( I had a 4 GB) so I bought in a 16 SD so i don't have to worry about storage for a while when it turns out that it doesn't matter if you have a bigger SD card all the app data was going into the internal memory....with no way to redirect it to the SD card.  Not all apps can be redirected to the SD card.  Will return phone to Amazon.  I am still trying to find a good prepaid phone for T-mobile.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: Its a great phone if you want just Meat and Potatoes with a little on the side. Its nothing for people that want tons of apps on it. I use mine for hotspot, call,text and internet. Plus out of 4 other phones ive tried the Tmobile Concord is the only phone ive had service where I live... Great Buy for a Great Phone !
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: Not bad for the price. Good as a low-end smart phone. However, there's no way to upgrade the Android OS, and this one freezes every once in a while. The only way to reboot it is to remove the battery. Other than that, it works pretty well. Battery lasts about 2 days (on and off usage), so about right for a low-end phone.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: Good for a simple smart phone.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: Searched for a while to find open phone. now all the newer ones will come supposedly open per provider. Brought it as a gift, still working.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: I give 5 stars not because of its capabilities as a smart phone, but lack there of. In the smart phone world this is plain. But I got it for My Mom as Her first smart phone and in that category it is perfect. It has basic smart phone features and easy to use. Great starter phone for people just learning, not so much for people that are experienced users because it lacks features of more advanced smart phones. Great price and easy entry level phone, but make sure to get an SD card because you need it. Really no storage space, but once You pop Your card in, Your good to go.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: Edited on 3/10/2014I've had this phone in my possession for a few months now.  I should've edited my review sooner, but better late than never, right?  Here goes:  This phone works okay if you need a replacement smartphone or if you don't plan on doing much, you may as well get a feature phone.  This phone runs out of memory a lot.  All I had to do was install iHeartRadio, Facebook & Dropbox and my phone is already telling me that the internal memory is low.  That's my biggest complaint with the phone.Old ReviewI bought this phone a few days ago because my old phone provider, Virgin Mobile, wasn't good in terms of coverage.  Sure, their pricing was okay, but I could hardly use my internet because I only got 1 bar at home, 3 to 5 in town if I'm lucky.  I was hardly able to use 3G in most places.  There was 3 areas where I could go to use 4G.  In either case of 3G or 4G, internet speeds were subpar at best and ping was a bit high as well.I decided to make the switch to T-Mobile.  I  had them once before, but with an iPhone 3G (at the time, I wasn't able to get 3G yet).  This phone is cheaper and certainly more features than the iPhone 3G.When I bought this phone, I went through the Walmart Family Plan deal.  For those of you wanting to do the same thing, be warned: T-Mobile/Wal-Mart does NOT provide you with a sim card.  You have to pay $25 ON TOP OF the service plan.  I didn't know this before buying the phone.  Even though I can get a discount through my work, I'd rather not pay that much just for a sim card if that's all it is and no credit towards the first month.  However, seeing as this is a T-Mobile phone (Wal-Mart Family Plan is covered by T-Mobile), I was able to get a hold of a temporary T-Mobile sim card and it worked.  I'm glad Wal-Mart decided not to block you from using a regular T-Mobile sim card to get you to use theirs.  I did see T-Mobile sim cards for $10 and that they still have a $30 unlimited text & data (first 5gb's of 4G) with 100 minutes for new activations.Internet:This phone does have 3G (1700/2100 band).  Living in a rural city, I get about 2 or 3mbps download speeds.  I tested this phone in two other cities.  One suburban area gave me about 4 mbps and the other area gave me an average of 5 to 6mbps.  I saw the Ping around 100 to 150MS with a decent signal.  I'm impressed by that for 3g.  I saw upload speeds around 1mbps to 2mbps.  If 3G is that fast, I can only imagine what 4G will be like when I go to upgrade to a 4G phone.  The one thing I did not know is that this phone also has a Mobile HotSpot feature.  That's a cool feature I wasn't expecting.  Last time I remember, it does cost $15 extra per month to use it.  Up to 8 devices can connect to this phone at one time for internet service.If you need to save your battery until you get a hold of a charger, there is an option to enable 2G only.  My speed tests shows I get about 100 to 300 kbps download & upload speeds in 2G mode.  However, 2G doesn't seem to work in some areas.  I went to a supermarket and 2G didn't show up inside or outside the building, leaving me with no internet.  Turning on 3G did the trick, but will burn through data faster if you're not already throttled (aka going over your data limit).Camera:T-Mobile/ZTE advertises that this phone contains a 2MP camera.  That is false information.  After looking in the camera settings, this phone takes 3MP pictures.  The photos come out okay, but I've used worse cameras for pictures.  The shutter is a bit slow, so make sure your target isn't moving until after the picture preview shows, or your subject will come out blurry.  The camera does not include Macro, which means it can't take photos up close (less than 70cm away).  The phone doesn't have flash either.The camera can record videos as well.  Like pictures, it's not the worst quality I've seen.  This phone records at a video resolution of 640x480 at up to 15 frames per second from what I've seen in my tests.  According to the quality setting mode, I can record 30 minutes at high quality or 10 minutes for YouTube.  At high quality, I believe it records at 1.5mbps.Memory:The one thing I highly dislike about this phone is that it has very low internal memory.  About 128mb's I believe.  At least a 4gb memory card was included.  I already ran out of memory once while trying to install an 8mb file, even after moving all the apps I could over to the SD card.  Turns out some apps were taking a lot of memory.I will update more later when I try the other features, such as the mobile hot spot.
title: ZTE Concord V768 T-Mobile Android Phone (A)

reviewText: I've had the S9HD, the S10HD, and now I own the S11.  The S9 had great sound but wasn't sweatproof, so after using for a year it shorted out.  The S10HD was sweatproof, but not as great of sound. Still good though.  It lasted over 3 years of heavy use and even running in the rain.  Unfortunetly it died too.  I have been using the S11 for 3 months now.  It's lighter, the weight is behind your ears instead of behind your neck which took a bit for my ears to get used to but it's ok now.  I'm training for a marathon and the long runs took a toll on my ears at first but not i'm used to it.  Sound is good, not perfect.  The flexible points tend to sqeek in my ears.  The time to charge and batterly life is outstanding.  The buttons don't appear as sealed as the S10, but so far sweat hasn't been a problem.  I wonder how they would do in rain.  Seems like the rain and sweat could get down in the buttons possibly.  So far so good... I recommend.
title: Motorola S11 HD Wireless Stereo Headphones - Retail Packaging - Black

reviewText: I like the S11 better but S11HD is nice and does what you need. Music with out wires and at stereo volume keep improving Motorola I can't wait to see what is next!

reviewText: Like every other Android phone I've ever had, the phone was wonderful in the beginning but slowly (but surely) began to malfunction after the first three months. I really loved everything about this phone, from the design to the large screen to the speed. Then, it started to suck more and more. Instead of finishing this review, I'll just compose a list of everything that has malfunctioned since purchasing the phone in November 2013:1.) Rear-Facing Camera: The rear-facing camera suddenly stopped working and nothing I do could fix it. Tried clearing cache and force stopping the app. Did not work. Tried uninstalling all updates. Did not work. Soft reset on phone and then hard reset on phone. Did not work.2.) Speaker: When I am on the phone with someone, I have to put it on speakerphone just to be able to hear the person I'm talking to. Mind you, this phone has never been near water or was not physically damaged in any way, shape, or form.3.) Battery life: Was great. Now it's declining tremendously. I used to get about 12 hours out of the phone and now I get about 5. I don't have many apps installed/running and I have the device on power saver. How does this happen? Plus, it takes about 6 hours to achieve a full charge. My iPhone literally takes about a half hour to reach 100% from 0%.4.) Glitches: Phone will force stop applications on its own and will randomly turn off and reboot.  It freezes often, also.With all said, I think I am done buying Android operated phones until they could create a OS that is more substantial and functional. Since every Android-based phone I have had, regardless of brand/model, has taken a crap on me, I'm assuming that it's because of the OS. I really wanted to love this phone, and did for a while, but it's not worth my time.
title: Motorola Moto X - 16GB, Unlocked Phone - US Warranty - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories'], ['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: The Moto X seems to do all the things I need a smartphone to do and it does them well.  I use mine with Republic Wireless which costs me about $10.00 a month as of the date of this review.  It's not the fastest phone and doesn't have the biggest screen, but it's fast enough and the screen is big enough and I'm fairly picky about my gadgets.  I've never found myself waiting on the phone's software to do something I asked and I can read text on the screen and watch videos that look great.  It doesn't have the most memory but it has more than enough for my daily business and nightly personal and entertainment use.  The battery lasts long enough for regular phone, email, text with a moderate amount of entertainment use each day and lasts longer than any other phone I've owned.  I charge it overnight on the nightstand.  However, if you plan to stream videos or music four hours a day in addition to several hours of telephone calls and other use, you might be disappointed in the battery life.  Reading some of these other reviews,  I think teenagers and college students (the ultimate power users) will never have enough battery power.  Keep in mind I use this for phone calls, email and texting mostly and the entertainment apps are an added benefit for when I don't have a tablet available.When the phone arrived, it was much thinner and lighter than I had expected.  The form factor is rests easily in my hand and doesn't make a large bulge in my front pants pocket.  The weight isn't enough to pull down on my pants or get in the way.  It weighs much less than the iphone or a Nokia 920.  The case material isn't too "grabby" or too slippery.  Easy to get in and out of my pocket.  The buttons are in the right place. I've used it for three months now & dropped it several times and it has no scratches on the screen or the back of the phone.  The black phone has an elegant and professional look that is fine for the formality of a more traditional business office.  To me, the Blackberry makes a "corporate drone" statement.  The new iPhone says "I'm a teenage girl or perhaps a tech fashionista who really likes to text, tweet and play video games.  This phone (in simple black at least) says something completely different and in between those two extremes.  The more colorful customization's available allows the flexibility to broadcast whatever image you want.Most importantly, the phone is open to many software modifications and much customization.  If you like to tinker and adjust your gadgets this is the phone for you.  If you have trouble working a VCR, care mostly about texting and listening to music & watching videos on a cell phone, then the iPhone is probably the best product for you.  The Windows 8 phones aren't good for either group.  They're best for employees of Microsoft to use when they're at the office and the boss is watching.With the Android software on the Moto X I can tell the battery how best to spend it's energy during different times of the day or during particular uses.  I was able to program it to do away with the lock screen when I'm in range of my home WiFi so I'm not constantly having to enter an access code to use the phone when I'm home.  When I leave my house the lock screen turns back on to protect the phone.  The phone takes excellent pictures & video when needed.  Most anything I can do on a PC or a tablet can be done on this phone.  Not that I would want to, but sometimes you're just not around a PC and I don't like carrying a tablet everywhere with me. I've been able to program to phone to let different alerts and notices through the lock screen depending upon my geographic location,  time of day and the kind of notice.  For example, emergency weather alerts can get through any time, but regular weather reports cannot.  Email from certain individuals sounds a chime, but  I can tell it to be quiet for most other email.  When the alarm goes off in the morning it calls my name in a pleasant voice and tells me the current weather conditions.  If I don't touch the phone for ten minutes after that, it tells me in a polite voice to get out of bed and get to work."  These are just a few examples of the world of customization that's opened up using Moto X running Android.For reference, I've owned and used a Nokia 920, an iPhone 3Gs, an iPad 2, an iPad 4 and a Microsoft Surface RT.  I also went through a faze where I tried to get away from smartphones and use dumb-phones such as "John's Phone" and "Snapphone" which are both sold through Amazon.  My very first computer was an Apple Macintosh (yes I know. . .  dating myself).  I ended up bailing on Apple computes when Steve Jobs left the company, quality control went bad and there was little usable business software that was available for their machines.  I haven't bought a Motorola cellphone product since the original RAZR.  The Moto X is also my first Android product.The later model iPhone's work well but are extraordinarily expensive and limiting in terms of the software that is available.  When I first used the iPhone, the Apple "sandbox" seemed big enough but I quickly out grew the sandbox when I encountered a great deal of trouble finding programs that would help me get things done.  The same thing happened in the late 80's when I found that Apple computers lacked enough business and work related software to be an effective tool for projects (This would change once Steve Jobs came back to Apple).  For Apple, most apps are games that I will never use or enjoy.  In my mind, an iPhone has become an elaborate expensive toy for teenage girls or tech fashionistas (not that there's anything wrong with that).  When someone says "iPhone" to me now, a picture of a very young woman with glitter nail polish wildly tapping out a text message with her thumbs comes to mind.  Not that there's anything wrong with games, teenagers or fashionistas.  .  . it's just that I'm not in that particular user group.  I tried using the Nokia 920 and Surface RT with Windows Phone 8 software for seven months.  Unfortunately, the apps are so far behind both Apple and Android that the Surface RT and Nokia 920 aren't really in the same league.  I tried hard to use them. I spent a lot of money on them and I wanted them to work.  The screens on both devices are large and beautiful.  However, the list of things you can't do using Windows 8 for the Surface RT and Windows Phone 8 is much larger than the list of things you can do.  The absence of software might very well kill them off.  The ability  of the Nokia 920 and Surface RT to work better with Microsoft PC software such as Outlook, doesn't begin to make up for all the other shortcomings.Hope this review helps some of you make up your mind on which products are best for you.  For those who disagree, please know that I am not an Android fan-boy and I have no financial interest in helping or hurting any people or businesses that make or use cell phones and the software the work with.
title: Motorola Moto X - 16GB, Unlocked Phone - US Warranty - Black
categories: [['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Accessories'], ['Cell Phones & Accessories', 'Cell Phones', 'Unlocked Cell Phones']]

reviewText: I purchased the Moto X from Sprint about a week ago, taking advantage of their new One Up program (phone cost me .42).  A little background to my Smartphone usage.  My first Smartphone was the HTC Incredible, so I have an extremely high standard for what a good Smartphone is.  I loved the Incredible.  I followed that up with the Samsung Galaxy S2, to extreme disappointment.  What a hunk of crap that phone was.  So, when the opportunity arose to dump the crap box ahead of my contract renewal, I jumped on it.I debated between going back to HTC with the One or going with the new Motorola Moto X.  I was hesitant at first about the X, but figured, it's made by Google, why wouldn't it be great?  I was correct.  The key to making the most out of this phone is to not gimp it out.  Use Google, leave the GPS and WiFi on.  The battery life is outstanding and lasts well into a day and a half even with all the features turned on.  The bonus to letting the phone do what it does is it makes life better.  This morning I had an up to the minute traffic update on my phone 10 minutes to my normal leaving time.  It knows my house and my work.  The voice commands are simple (despite what others are saying) and work amazing well if you take the time to really learn them.  It connects to my Jabra Bluetooth speaker amazingly fast and uses all the Bluetooth controls with no setup (there is no need to use the activation phrase with Bluetooth, it just knows).  In short, this is what a Smartphone should be.  Smart.  Don't be lazy in the first week or so of owning the phone and the phone will learn.  Then, by all means, be lazy.  Once trained, the phone knows what you want, it's a little freaky but totally worth it.
title: Motorola Moto X - 16GB, Unlocked Phone - US Warranty - Black

reviewText: There's no replacement for displacement.  That adage applies to phones as well.  I got the Moto X based on the battery hype and it disappoints.  All the little tricks they put into the X are great but at the end of the day 2200 mAh paired with a 4.7 inch screen (doesn't matter what kind) isn't going to result in great battery life.  To me it feels like 1 minute of screen time is equaling 1% of battery.  Unacceptable.  To be completely forthcoming I'm a heavy user with often between 1 and 2 hours of screen time per day.  If you're like me, a heavy user and on T-Mobile your current best option for great battery life is the LG G2.  I should also note, I purchased the phone from Motorola directly.Update 3/20/2014 - I've been getting a lot of wakelocks lately.  Nothing is worth then picking up a hot phone with no battery life left.Update 4/6/2014 - More wakelocks.  I'm downgrading accordingly.
